column10: Sick game

[h1] Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel [/h1] 
Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel offers a delightful return to the beloved Borderlands universe, with its signature blend of humor, loot-driven gameplay, and over-the-top action. Set on Pandora's moon, this installment introduces fresh mechanics like low-gravity combat and oxygen management, adding new layers of fun and strategy to the experience. The game's memorable characters, diverse arsenal of weapons, and cooperative multiplayer make for an unforgettable journey through the Borderlands universe. Whether you're exploring the moon's surface, battling hordes of enemies, or embarking on hilarious quests, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel delivers a thoroughly enjoyable adventure that will leave fans craving for more.

[h1] Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel [/h1]

[h3] Pros: [/h3] [b]ğŸš€ Unique Lunar Setting[/b] Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel offers a refreshing change of scenery with its lunar setting, providing players with low-gravity environments and new gameplay mechanics such as oxygen management and jetpack traversal. ğŸŒ•ğŸ”«

[b]ğŸ¤– Diverse Playable Characters[/b] The game features a diverse cast of playable characters, each with their own unique abilities and skill trees. From the high-flying Athena to the explosive Wilhelm, players can choose a character that suits their preferred playstyle and strategy. ğŸ¦¾ğŸ§ 

[h3] Cons: [/h3] [b]ğŸ›‘ Lack of Innovation[/b] While Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel introduces some new mechanics and features, it may feel more like an expansion or spin-off than a true sequel. Some players may find the gameplay formula to be too familiar, lacking significant innovation or evolution. ğŸ”„ğŸ®

[b]ğŸŒŒ Limited Variety in Environments[/b] Despite the unique lunar setting, the game's environments may feel repetitive or uninspired over time. Players may encounter a lack of diversity in landscapes and locations compared to previous entries in the series, leading to a sense of monotony. ğŸœï¸ğŸŒ‘

[h3] Other Drawbacks: [/h3] [b]ğŸ® Missed Storytelling Opportunities[/b] While the game delves into the backstory of certain characters and events from the Borderlands universe, it may fail to capitalize on its narrative potential. Some players may find the storyline and character development to be lacking depth or impact. ğŸ“–ğŸ¤”

[b]ğŸ‘¾ Limited Enemy Variety[/b] Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel may suffer from a lack of enemy variety, with players facing similar types of foes throughout the game. This can lead to repetitive combat encounters and a diminished sense of challenge or excitement. ğŸ¯ğŸ¤–

[b]Good Points[/b]
[list]
[*]Unique lunar setting with low-gravity mechanics.
[*]Diverse cast of playable characters with unique abilities.
[*]Maintains the signature Borderlands humor and style.
[/list]
[b]Bad Points[/b]
[list]
[*]Lack of significant innovation compared to previous entries.
[*]Repetitive environments and limited variety in landscapes.
[*]Missed storytelling opportunities and limited enemy variety.
[/list]

While it maintains the series' trademark humor and style, it may feel like more of the same for seasoned Borderlands players.

I've heard that this game was awful for so long, but I thought I'd play the game to give it a fair chance.  After completing it, the game had me scratching my head as to why this game decided to stray so far from what BL1 and BL2 did.  Would never touch this game again.

TL;DR - A very enjoyable Looter Shooter about working for a guy I'd best describe as "a tragic Lovecraftian horror protagonist."

Mind you - that DOES include the parts about "turning into a monster," forbidden knowledge, and a whole bunch of other scary shit you'd not expect to find in a "ha-ha, funny!" game series like Borderlands.

If you've not played this game, but HAVE played Borderlands 2? Do it. Imo, it adds so much to the story when you consider everyone involved...

Especially once you realize that Jack truly DID want to do the right thing and be a hero - but fumbled the ball...

...after all - this ain't no place for a hero, right?

So, good news and bad news. The bad news is that Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel plays pretty much like a big expansion pack for Borderlands 2. The good news on the other hand is that Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel plays pretty much like a big expansion pack for Borderlands 2.

In other words, if you liked Borderlands 2 and you want some more of that (with some fun new additions like laser weapons, new elemental effects, low-gravity fun and all-new environments) this should be a no-brainer.

As someone who speedran the game in 7 hours, and someone who's always been a very avid fan of the series. (But for reference I have played this game much more in depth on console on its release) I cannot for life of me understand why this game is as hated as it is.

Its a great game with fantastic storytelling. And objectively *nearly* identical mechanics to BL2, which to say is the crown jewel of the series. The villains were still interesting, Col.Z and the ??????. Showing the backstory of one of the most deranged and insane characters in all of video game history was a incredible experience. You can see a man with already a few screws loose, go completely insane over the course of the game. You see the progression, your there hand in hand watching him slowly slip down this slope of power. 

While the oxygen mechanic was kind of meh. I never was in a point where I actually had to worry about it. It practically replenishes on its own if you shoot enemies. And there's a spot to get oxygen practically every 5 feet. So really if you had that much of a problem with it, the only response I have is: Skill issue I guess? 

And moving onto the VH's you can play as. They are just awesome. Like the gladiator? Hell yes. F**IN WILHELM? YES SIR.

CLAP TRAP? Eh why not its funny.

And don't even get me started on the Doppelganger. Single best character I have ever had the pleasure of playing as. The voice actor for HJ, is the same guy as the Doppelganger, (as it should be.) And I like the Doppelganger more. Thats saying something to how incredibly the DG was written. 

That being said. Also expanding on Moxxi was a neat touch.

Overall: 

9.5/10 not enough Jack.

Glitchy, buggy POS. First game was great, second mediocre, this one was by far the worst. Not only not as good, but while they were all a bit buggy, it seemed to get worse with each game. With this one, it's so bad I bugged out on the final boss and got stuck outside the fight while my friend had to finish it, and then they had to exit the level because I was stuck and unable to move. And, of course, when I went to play on my own afterward, I found that since I bugged out on the fight, it didn't complete it for me. So of course I tried to do it myself, but the fight is so absurdly ridiculous that it's next to impossible. I went into it with full ammo and the boss takes so many hits, refilling its shield and health after you kill it so many times, that I'd just run out of ammo before I could kill it. And then I'd die, and it would restart the fight while, of course, leaving me with next to no ammo, because of course when I couldn't kill it with full ammo, it makes sense I'd be able to with no ammo for some guns and partial ammo for others. Gearbox clearly got lazy after the first game, hardly doing anything to improve the games or fix the issues, and in fact making some things worse, while just riding off of the name. Between that and the BS they pulled removing content that was PAID FOR and putting into DLCs, requiring people to buy it AGAIN, I recommend skipping this game and anything else these has-beens put out.

But what awaits him... So short unhappy life.

IT'S A GAME

[h1]TLDR: 8/10 The game that could and SHOULD have been better that Borderlands 2, but fell flat when 2K Australia shut down.[/h1]

[h3] Actual Review (No Spoilers) [/h3]
This game makes me sad. It had all the potential to outdo BL2: A quality story, more refined gameplay, better balance, better movement, and better designed vault hunters. The pieces were placed and then....2K Australia shut down. And thus TPS stopped development before a full set of campaign DLCs and whatever additional things they had planned could be developed and released.

[h3] Story [/h3]
Let's cover story first. Right off the bat, Borderlands has never been about story and the primary focus of the games are the gameplay/grind. The further into the franchise you get the stories do become more centered (which in some cases actually detract from the enjoyment of the game imo) but nevertheless, most stories the mainline games have are good to average. Thankfully, TPS falls on the good side of the spectrum as this game is Handsome Jack's origin story and rise to power. A lot of other stuff is explained here as well such as Claptrap's story, and it's overall a nice lore dump of a game for the series.

[h3] Gameplay: Combat, Grind, Content [/h3]
But the meat of the game is the gameplay. There's been a lot of changes, and most make for a unique spin on the Borderlands formula. This game is on Pandora's moon, so there's things like low gravity, an oxygen system, and air boosting/slamming. Cryo is also the new element that replaces slag and it's pretty good. Most bosses are also more unique and more creatively designed across the board compared to BL2 (and certainly compared to BL1). Endgame balance (which doesn't really matter until UVHM) is MUCH better than BL2's endgame balance. Partly because there's more viable weapons, but also better overall enemy and combat mechanics so that everything just isn't a tank like with BL2 UVHM and OP levels. The designs of the vault hunters are also improved. I can't say they are objectively better made than BL2's characters, but for the most part, skill trees are more complex and are much more synergistic, as well as rarely having any bad or weirdly scaled skills. For these reasons I have a theory that these characters were designed from the start with UVHM in mind, also because the insane builds you can run make even max level UVHM kind of easy. I will always wonder if 2K/Gearbox had planned to add OP levels or some equivalent to this game, I'm pretty sure these characters would have a way easier time there than BL2's characters.

Now in terms of the game itself: the engine, mission structure, and underlying framework. This game isn't as tight and polished as BL2. There's a variety of bugs and quirks and it's easier to glitch out or softlock stuff. But for the vast majority of the game, the only bugs you'll find don't interfere with your progression at all and are more just funny moments to laugh at. Characters walking through stuff, enemies randomly sinking into the ground or ragdolling across the map, NPCs breaking their neck to look at you, stuff like that. Borderlands being a more "wacky" game with how the humor and stories are constructed, these bugs almost feel like they fit right into the game.

The only major gripe that I and most people have with this game is the severely lacking endgame. There are no true raid bosses even in the DLC. You have a single campaign DLC and a Moxxi's Underdome-style arena DLC. the arena DLC is fine since it adds new gear and isn't completely obnoxious like Moxxi's Underdome. But thankfully the campaign DLC is one of the best campaign DLCs in the entire franchise with pretty much no downsides. It introduces a ton of new content, gear, and a new rarity type. The ONLY other big issue I have with this game is it feels like Gearbox/2K took a step back in terms of streamlining the game. A few examples would be like how there aren't many dedicated drop sources (which I understand because they want you to use the grinder, but it's not as fun) and there are also a handful of maps that have NO fast travel in them, so you can't travel to and from them easily. No idea why this is a thing.

[h3] Play With Mods!! [/h3]
Lastly I should mention that like BL2, there are tons of mods that you can run that improve the game tremendously as well as add new content like gear and enemies. If you're a first time player, I would HEAVILY suggest playing with the Unofficial Community Patch or the Exodus Overhaul mod as they are literally just TPS but better. (They also don't interfere with achievements and you'll be able to unlock everything normally)

[h3] Conclusion [/h3]
This game is definitely worth playing still and is an important part of the Borderlands series and story. It's got a great sandbox of new features and mechanics that offer a cool twist to the Borderlands formula. 8/10

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a good game on its own for its story-telling aspect - All about Jack. I have played just about 100 hours of B:TPS and, I am truly sorry here, but it's the worst game out of the lot. I will explain my reasoning below, so, let's get to it.

 [h1][b] The issues/cons/Why it's the worst Borderlands game [/b][/h1] 
âš«So, my first main issue is one of the main reasons why it is the WORST borderlands game to date. NPC's get stuck on EVERYTHING. The very start of the game, when you are told to follow Jack and he goes to walk onto the elevator, he gets stuck running into the dead body of the loader you had to melee. This forced me to restart my game 3 times before it fixed itself. This happened on countless missions. 
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3148204468 
âš«Enemies get stuck in walls, floors, roofs, objects e.t.c. This also forced me to restart my game over and over again or it forced a "FAILED" quest on me.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3150001492 
âš«Killing a boss or doing a quest that has an item or a bunch of items that drop is painfully bad. All of the dropped items get sent to space (LITERALLY) and you are unable to pick up quest items or the loot from the boss you just killed because of this.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3148205375 
âš«The maps were so boring to run around on. It felt like purposeless wandering with nothing to kill. A few audio logs to collect and like 2-3 cult symbols to collect and that's it. 
âš«The waypoint system in B:TPS is so inadequate it will have you scratching your head, going in circles trying to find out where your going... it will not "DIRECT" you or show you a path to your waypoint.
âš«Every single door you open you need to slog back through the area you just came from to flip a switch, pull a lever or activate a jump pad to open the door then drag your butt all the way back to the door. 
âš«Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel lacks TRUE engame content. Borderlands 2 had INSANE memorable content, bosses, guns, OP levels and so much more. B:TPS has NONE of this. No gun is memorable. No boss is memorable. No OP levels. No AMAZING DLC. Nothing. Just True Vault Hunter and Ultimate Vault Hunter mode. If you want, you can farm the guns from boss's but why... why do it on this game  when you can play the BEST borderlands game.... Borderlands 2. 

[h1][b] Pros/The only things that made Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel good [/b][/h1] 
âš«Jack. The story of how jack goes from HERO to Maniac is one of the biggest reasons to play this game from start to finish. Meaning you will spend about 20-or-so-hours trekking across Pandoraâ€™s moon, Elpis. Jack is more sympathetic in this game and it does not make him into the clichÃ©d misunderstood villain. He is excellently written.
âš«The new "VAULT HUNTERS". The new VHs are really well designed. First you have Wilhelm, accompanied by his flying drone duo, Wolf and Saint. These two really stand out. One does automated bombing runs while the other hangs back to heal him. Then you have Nisha who is a gunslinging killing machine with AIMBOT. Then you have Athena that throws shield's like Captain America. Then you have Claptrap who is by far the craziest, granting him different abilities depending on the situation at hand. 
âš«The DLC. I'm not going to say much about this but all I am going to say is this - You go inside of Claptrap. Yes. For. Real.

[h1][b] My Verdict [/b][/h1] 
Spending 10-15 hours jumping through hoops before you get to the good stuff makes this Borderlands game a boring snore fest. The lack of endgame content and the bugs/issues I encountered really had me pushing through the game so I could finish it and never touch it again. If you want a "GOOD" Borderlands experience, just replay Borderlands 2 over and over again. It has amazing DLC's. Amazing combat. Amazing weapons and so much more. Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel feels like a rushed standalone adventure in the Borderlands universe.

[h1][b] 4/10. It's a good game if you're interested in seeing Jack become the Villain apart from that, Borderlands 2 outshines this by a mile [/b][/h1]

2/5

The Borderlands franchise is one of my favorite looter shooters out there. The first was was all about the vibe and atmosphere. Taking the FPS genre in a new direction. The second one took what the first game was, and did a complete 180. The story was fantastic. the game play  was amazing, and the characters are some of the best if not the best to ever grace all of video games. Gearbox and 2K took this formula, and somehow failed to match the original. Not only is there way less content (half of every map is empty, and I managed to finish the story twice and am more than half way through my third play-through of my first character in a little less than 120 hours, compared to my 200+ hours of Borderlands 2 and I just started my 3rd story play-through) but its been really frustrating. i went back and fourth on my 2nd story modes twice on both games, and discovered that The Pre-Sequel is in fact way worse in terms of game play. guns are not nearly as powerful yet enemies get stacked to a point where you can empty mag after mag into them and they have the ability to one hit you and you get knocked down repeatedly. The combat in Borderlands 2 is very well balanced overall and I had a lot of fun playing even when I raged. The Pre-Sequel was just downright frustrating. The Claptastic Voyage DLC takes this and made everything so much worse. if you haven't payed for that DLC, don't. The final boss will make you wish you never bought this game. In addition all of the loot is really weak and honestly not worth it. The only thing that saved this game for was story. It wasn't perfect, not even close, but I kept playing it for that reason and because I'm trying to 100% it and be done. Side note but the optimization is really bad. lots of frame issues and the default settings are garbage. If you want this game, but it on sale or else you will likely regret it

I am a 45 -year -old father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father raising my son, who is now 14 years old. My son won this game from his uncle, so we installed him on his computer and he started playing. Until the end of the week he had 24 hours in this game. This was horrible for me, because it was hard to find ways to spend time with my son, because he is always with friends or just watching Youtube. So I decided to do a Steam account and get this game to see if I could play beside him. I bought the game, chose my skin and world and started playing, but I was stuck in what you should do. I asked my son for help and he organized a game for me to participate. I loved it, because it was the best time I spent with my son since my wife died. Since then, this game has approached me and my son again and now we spend time together away from home as well. This game reminded me that there is fun in everything, and I brought many happy memories to me and my son.

I'm not sure why this Borderlands is so hated compared to the other ones because this is my favorite of them all and is also probably the best one that came out. The special type of weapons for this game which are laser guns are really fun to play with and feel good to use and I wish they were in other games, the classes you get to play are also extremely fun and unique and honestly they are one of the best playable classes in the whole series. The humor is not as annoying as the other ones either and the low gravity makes it fun to run around and traverse. Genuinely this is one of the better Borderlands out of the whole franchise but for some reason, people tend to disagree and pretend it doesn't exist.

Goods:
-There's a new environment that is 6/10 interesting (wouldn't call it amazing)
-There's a new equipment type that is 6/10 fun (wouldn't call it amazing)
-There's the weapon grinding together system which is 7/10 kind of amazing (but see the drawbacks below)

Bads:
-Things like Roland and Lylyth's relationship were bad to even have to hear in the second Borderlands right?!?!?! Well, get ready cause it seems like everyone and their dog (hide your stuffed animals and legs) are super ready to be in a relationship with anything that moves... and it's just as akward as Roland and Lylyth, but much much much more prolific and randomly tossed in. Literally, 0/10. If you are going to do something relating to romantic or physical relationships, make it funny, or make it make sense. No wonder there won't be anymore borderland games.
-Falling into instant death is not fun, but is now a staple (though it may add some mild irritating thrill). 2/10
-Why do I never have any money ever? Maybe we had a little too much and not enough to buy in the other Borderlands, but in this one there are a couple more interesting things for sale... and you can't ever afford any of them. The grind and purchase mechanics aren't two options, they aren't competeing options, they are directly opposed options. And keeping money is even harder cause you fall to your death every 6.5 minutes. 2/10

So averaging out my scores I'd confirm my feeling that this game gets a total of 3.83/10. By the way get used to averages, cause when you grind items together they will average the level of each item together. You think damage per second is fun to calculate? Me too. And this average thing isn't fun to calculate. Oh yeah.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is an incredible accomplishment that not only lives up to the high standards set by its predecessors but also introduces new and interesting components. This installment elevates the iconic Borderlands experience, both literally and figuratively.

The moon-based environment is brilliant, introducing low-gravity gameplay that completely changes the way we approach combat. Vault Hunters can now soar into the skies, performing jaw-dropping aerial stunts and annihilating opponents. The sheer excitement of navigating this low-gravity world adds a thrilling layer to the Borderlands formula, which is already addicting.

The story, which takes place between the first and second games, adds to the lore of the Borderlands universe. The new ensemble of characters, which includes Athena, Wilhelm, Nisha, and the iconic Claptrap, adds a new perspective while retaining the series' distinctive wit. The plot takes surprising twists and turns, keeping players interested and committed in the fate of Pandora and its moon.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel's cel-shaded graphic design continues to amaze. Character design, environment design, and weapon variety are all exquisitely detailed. Each locale is a brilliant, colorful work of art that immerses players in Pandora's chaotic yet delightful world.

The Borderlands series' trademark randomized loot system is in full effect here. Because of the enormous diversity of weapons and gear, each playthrough feels distinct, stimulating research and experimentation. The game accommodates to your playstyle with an unmatched level of customisation, whether you want a rocket launcher that shoots lasers or a shotgun that sets foes on flames.

To sum up, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel surpasses all expectations and is a fantastic intergalactic masterpiece. It solidifies its status as a must-play for both die-hard series fans and newcomers with its inventive gameplay, gripping story, and gorgeous visuals. You won't want to miss this adventure, so get ready, Vault Hunters!

This game saved my life...

In a world that often feels overwhelming and unforgiving, there exists a game that transcends its digital confines to become a lifeline, a source of solace that saved me when I needed it most. This is not just a game; it's an emotional masterpiece that wove its narrative threads into the fabric of my existence, rescuing me from the depths of despair.

As I embarked on this virtual journey, little did I know that it would serve as the anchor to my sanity during one of the darkest periods of my life. The beautifully crafted tale unfolded before me, a symphony of emotions that resonated with the echoes of my own struggles. The characters, mere pixels on the screen, became companions in my solitude, offering solace and understanding when the real world seemed devoid of both.

The game's narrative prowess lies not in its complexity but in its ability to mirror the intricacies of the human experience. It became a mirror reflecting my own journey, the highs and lows, the triumphs and defeats. As I navigated through the virtual landscapes, I found echoes of my own resilience mirrored in the protagonist's struggles, a comforting reminder that I, too, could overcome the seemingly insurmountable obstacles in my life.

There were moments of profound beauty, delicate and poignant, that left an indelible mark on my soul. The soundtrack, a haunting melody of hope and melancholy, served as a companion during my loneliest nights, weaving a tapestry of emotions that guided me through the tumultuous seas of my own existence.

This game, with its enigmatic charm, became more than a mere escape; it became a lifeline. During nights when the weight of the world threatened to crush me, I could retreat into its digital embrace, finding solace in its narrative that transcended the pixels on the screen.

It's challenging to put into words the profound impact this nameless game had on my life. Suffice it to say that when the shadows seemed insurmountable, it provided a glimmer of light, a reason to hold on, and a reminder that beauty can emerge from even the darkest corners.

To the creators of this masterpiece, thank you for crafting an experience that goes beyond entertainment, transcending into the realm of salvation. This game, with its tears and triumphs, became the unexpected savior I never knew I needed.

Recommended, but with a giant caveat: This is NOT BL2. At all. Buy it when it is on discount.

Lower your expectations for both quality (BL2 ripoff) and quantity (DLC size, if that) and enjoy.

New characters, new weapon type (laser), new effects (cryo, lowgrav & vacuum). Some of the new characters are both over the top and flat as a pancakes, and become old after a while. The laser has a lot of variety and a huge ammo pool, but not all player characters can benefit equally well. Some 'new' weapons are very like BL2 originals, this sometimes feels a little copycatlike but also can be great. With the new cryo effect you can now freeze your enemies and punch them in the face at your leasure! There is a nice variety in environments. Due to the lowgrav effect some of the maps are hard (impossible?) to navigate, but google is your friend yet again. 
Added to this a sizable set of quests and an illuminating storyline on Jack to make for a decidedly above average gameplay. Added joy: Many familiar old characters return and the BL story is expanded nicely.

While according to the Steam player data replayability is not nearly in the range of BL2 there is still lots to enjoy.

This game is often considered the worst of the franchise, however I gotta disagree. In my opinion this game has some of the best skill trees and the cryo mechanic (though a bit op) is very fun to play with. There is the downsides of severely lacking in end game content, but in terms of playthroughs I find it quite fun. It also has arguably one of the best Dlc to come out. The Claptrap DLC has a interesting story, lots of side quests, good legendaries, and includes a brand new item rarity that can have some really fun interactions with certain characters.

When considering engagement with the Borderlands game series, the recommended entry point would undoubtedly be this particular installment, primarily attributed to notable advancements in visual aesthetics and enhanced playable character abilities. The game offers a perspective into the iconic "Handsome Jack" character, adding a layer of novelty for seasoned players.

However, amidst these commendable aspects, certain drawbacks merit consideration. The inclusion of millennial writing elements, while reflective of contemporary trends, does not resonate universally and often alienates a segment of the gaming audience. Additionally, the characterizations within the narrative fails to leave a lasting impression, rendering many of the personas somewhat forgettable.

A further point of contention arises from the perceived lack of substantial rewards accompanying the completion of side quests. This omission diminishes the incentive for players to invest time and effort in these additional missions, detracting from the overall gaming experience.

[h1]Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel - A Cosmic Heist on the Moon's Edge[/h1]

[quote=author]Step into the anti-gravitational chaos of Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, a space-faring adventure set on the moon of Pandora. Developed by 2K Australia in conjunction with Gearbox Software, this installment in the Borderlands series offers a unique perspective, exploring the rise of the iconic villain, Handsome Jack. Get ready for a cosmic heist, low-gravity combat, and a whole new side of Pandora![/quote]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Introduction[/h2]
Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel takes the action to the moon, providing a fresh perspective on the events that led to the rise of the series' infamous antagonist, Handsome Jack. With its low-gravity environments, new playable characters, and a narrative that bridges the gap between the first and second games, The Pre-Sequel adds a cosmic twist to the beloved looter-shooter formula.

[hr][/hr]

[spoiler] [h2]Low-Gravity Gameplay[/h2]
The moon's low-gravity environment is a game-changer, introducing a new dimension to combat and traversal. Jump higher, slam down on enemies, and navigate the moon's surface with a sense of weightlessness. The low-gravity mechanics add a layer of strategy and unpredictability to the familiar Borderlands gunfights.[/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Play as Handsome Jack's Henchmen[/h2]
In a unique twist, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel allows players to step into the boots of characters who would later become key members of Handsome Jack's villainous crew. Playable characters include Athena the Gladiator, Wilhelm the Enforcer, Nisha the Lawbringer, and Claptrap the Fragtrap. Experience the rise of these characters as they navigate the treacherous lunar landscape.

[hr][/hr]

[spoiler] [h2]Cryo Element and Oxygen Management[/h2]
The introduction of the Cryo element adds a chilling effect to the arsenal, freezing enemies in their tracks. Additionally, the moon's atmosphere lacks oxygen, requiring players to manage their oxygen supply. Oxygen can be replenished with oxygen generators or by shattering frozen enemies. These elements add an extra layer of strategy to the gameplay.[/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Dynamic Storytelling[/h2]
Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel delves into the backstory of Handsome Jack, providing insights into his motivations and descent into villainy. The narrative unfolds through the perspective of Athena, who recounts the events to the mysterious character known as the Watcher. The storytelling approach adds depth to the Borderlands lore and offers a fresh narrative structure.

[hr][/hr]

[spoiler] [h2]Moon's Edge Environments[/h2]
Explore the lunar landscapes of Pandora's moon, complete with futuristic settlements, cavernous craters, and low-gravity environments. The moon's edge setting introduces a distinct visual style, combining the familiar Borderlands aesthetics with a sci-fi twist. The environments are not only visually engaging but also contribute to the overall gameplay experience.[/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Loot and Weapons Galore[/h2]
As expected from the Borderlands series, The Pre-Sequel continues the tradition of a vast array of weapons and loot. From laser guns to new grenade mods and shields, the moon's arsenal is brimming with high-tech gear. Experiment with different weapon combinations and gear up for the challenges that await in the cosmic frontier.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Cooperative Multiplayer Madness[/h2]
Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel retains the cooperative multiplayer mayhem that defines the series. Team up with friends or other players online to form a squad of lunar Vault Hunters. Cooperative play introduces synergies between characters, creating chaotic battles that are even more unpredictable in the low-gravity environment.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Expansive DLC Adventures[/h2]
Extend your lunar adventure with downloadable content (DLC) expansions that introduce new campaigns, characters, and challenges. The DLC content adds even more depth to the story and provides fresh opportunities for loot and mayhem. The moon's edge continues to be a canvas for ever-expanding adventures in the Borderlands universe.

[hr][/hr]

[h2]Conclusion[/h2]
Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel propels players into a cosmic caper, blending the series' signature humor, looter-shooter mechanics, and a unique low-gravity twist. With its memorable characters, dynamic storytelling, and the lunar landscape as a backdrop, The Pre-Sequel adds a stellar chapter to the Borderlands saga.

[quote=author]Embark on a cosmic heist, defy gravity, and witness the rise of Handsome Jack in Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel - where the moon's edge is your playground for loot-fueled mayhem![/quote]

[h1]BUYER BEWARE: 2k Spamming Ads In Its Games[/h1]

As much as I have long enjoyed several Borderlands titles over the years It is absolutely enraging to have Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, a product I paid for - WITHOUT ads - force an ad down my throat every time I load the game. 

Not only is there a banner ad in the middle of the screen on the main menu, there is also a text menu bar ad on the left hand side of the screen. This addition has reconfigured the menu in such a way as 2k hopes the player will accidentally click on the link to the game being advertised instead of allowing you to easily quit the game. 

2k's Steam moderators have censored criticism of 2k's in-game ads in the forums on numerous occasions.

I will keep this review a thumbs down and without any direct mention to the qualities of the game itself (graphics, music, game-play, fun etc) as long as 2K insists on prioritizing their ads at the expense of the product I bought and my experience with it. Hopefully a class action lawsuit is brought against 2k for compromising the quality of the product.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel : By Triple F

"Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel", a thrilling installment in the beloved Borderlands franchise, takes players on a cosmic roller-coaster ride through the untold story that bridges the gap between the first and second main titles. Developed by 2K Australia in collaboration with Gearbox Software, this game delivers a unique experience that expands upon the iconic loot-shooter formula while introducing new mechanics and a fresh perspective.

Set on Pandora's moon, Elpis, The Pre-Sequel showcases the rise of the charismatic yet morally ambiguous villain, Handsome Jack. Players find themselves aligning with a motley crew of characters, including fan-favorite NPCs like Claptrap and Athena. The narrative unfolds as a flashback, narrated by Athena, adding depth and context to events previously hinted at in the series. This new perspective injects fresh energy into the well-established universe.

The standout feature of The Pre-Sequel is its low-gravity environment, which drastically alters game-play dynamics. Jumping several times higher and gliding across lunar landscapes feels liberating and adds verticality to the gunfights. Oxygen management adds an intriguing layer, forcing players to keep an eye on their remaining air supply. While this can occasionally feel like an unnecessary distraction, it generally spices up exploration and combat, demanding more strategic decision-making in battles and navigation.

The character skill trees return, accompanied by the brand-new "Oz" kits that provide both oxygen management improvements and unique character buffs. This system allows for more personalized play-styles, and experimenting with different combinations is half the fun. The four playable characters each bring their own set of skills and abilities, ensuring diverse experiences in subsequent playthroughs.

Graphically, The Pre-Sequel retains the franchise's distinctive cel-shaded art style, delivering colorful, comic-book-inspired visuals. Elpis' low-gravity setting grants the environments a refreshing twist, showcasing a blend of lunar desolation and twisted futuristic architecture. However, some textures and character models do show their age, especially when compared to contemporary titles.

Gun variety, a staple of the series, receives a cosmic expansion with the introduction of "Cryo" weapons, which freeze enemies in ice. Watching foes shatter into pieces brings a gratifying sense of satisfaction. The arsenal's sheer diversity remains a cornerstone, though a few more innovations could have elevated the experience further.

Multiplayer is where The Pre-Sequel shines brightest. Co-op game-play amplifies the chaotic fun, making it an ideal game for playing with friends. However, solo players might find certain encounters more challenging due to the game's balance being somewhat skewed towards cooperative play.

In terms of storytelling, The Pre-Sequel serves as a supplementary narrative to the main series. While it offers valuable insight into Handsome Jack's transformation into a villain, the plot lacks the same level of emotional resonance as seen in Borderlands 2. The humor and quirkiness synonymous with the series persist, but some jokes miss the mark or feel overused.

In conclusion, "Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel" successfully takes a calculated leap into the unknown by introducing new mechanics and a fresh perspective on the beloved universe. With its low-gravity game-play, varied characters, and unique story angle, it's a must-play for Borderlands fans and an engaging entry point for newcomers. While it falls slightly short of the narrative brilliance of its predecessor, it's still a cosmic joyride well worth embarking upon.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel sucks just as much as Borderlands 2, if not worse.

1. Story and pacing. 

After beating the game and starting UVHM it's clear as day that the writing ran out of juice by the end of production cycle of this game. While at the very beginning you can see clear paths and motivations for characters, that all goes away by the final chapter. Additionally, some characters are completely gone and pop up to say "Hi" before you go to the Vault (Pickle and Janey, for instance).

2. Gameplay and gameplay loop. 

Just like in Borderlands 2, guns are an additional enemy you have to fight in this game. Not only do you struggle with challenging enemies on UVHM, but also struggle with your shitty gun. 

Another issue I have with this game is the grinder. While cool on paper, it feels much like a chore. Also, the game doesn't feature recipe book in-game and it is undercooked. Let's say I want to create a specific type of gun: a Maliwan SMG with shock damage. It would be nice to know that I can grind only Maliwan SMGs with Shock damage to upgrade them to blue/purple/orange. But I'm not too sure such a thing is even in the game, to me it was all random and I can't be bothered testing it out. 

3. Difficulty spike towards the end. 

The game was a breeze up until the last chapter, which ramps up the difficulty quite steeply and feels rushed. 
Just not a pleasant memory about this game is all. 

4. Challenges

Challenges were introduce to replace gun specialization from BL1 and they still suck. By having Baddass rank 2249 I have a salad of added stats to my character, but all those stats individually do not exceed 5%! 

What is a 4,8% added to grenade damage my grenade mod gives me 450 damage per grenade. That would make it around 26 damage! Isn't that all fun and exciting? 

You get the gist of it: it sucks and should have never been added to the game.

5. Classes and characters

Those that I've played are cool. Athena is a famous character from BL1 DLC and Wilhelm comes from BL2 and they are really nice to play. I didn't have any issues with it and it is worth praise. 

Story characters though sucked: Lilith was a bitch, as well as Moxxy, Janey was absent from 60% of the game, Pickle was alright, but still the same issue as Janey. Jack's descent into madness was fun to observe. It's a mixed bag. 

All in all, I would not recommend this game, just go get a copy of Borderlands 1 instead, a much better experience.

The game is as good as I remember it.

The game runs smoothly, the graphics are pretty and the mechanics are good.
One thing I have noticed is some latency issues if you join another persons' game, no matter how good your (or their) connection is. I don't know if this is a connection issue or something to do with the servers, but at any rate it's not bad enough to spoil the game entirely... maybe screw up a sniper now and then.

Some of the NPC's might act a little buggy here and there, their pathing may be off but this is -usually- caused by a player or NPC walking into their path and delaying or forcing them to walk around you. Don't be surprised if Jack is on an elevator clipping half-way into the door, that's just his thing... let him do his thing. He's okay.

Overall, aside from the NPC bugs (keeping in mind this wasn't technically an official Borderlands game) i'd say it's worth it for the banter. These characters do come out with some really weird things here and there, so definitely give it a play!

To be honest about this one, it leans very close to a "do not recommend", mainly because the game is considerably shorter, the DLCs are not good enough (with ONE Exception) to pad the game and the game has a level scaling that makes the first game seem a LOT easier. But why is it I recommend? A few reasons:
1. Cast of characters. Specially Athena, Handsome Jack's Double and Claptrap. Playing as any of these three is really fun.
2. An Ice day to kill. Freezing enemies and blasting them into flakes of blood and bones?! HECK YEAH! And Lady Aurelia Hammerlock has that in spades!
3. Lasers. They eat up its own ammo reserves like crazy but let's talk be real: you always wanted to melt someone's face off with a constant beam.
4. Handsome Jack's descent into madness. We all know the nice guy we meet in this game is going to be a massive jerk in 2... But why?! Figure out and have fun doing so...
5. Remember I mentioned ONE exception? That exception is Claptastic Voyage. It is better than General Knoxx from 1, but does not compare to Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep. It's still really cool.

TLDR: Play Borderlands 2 first.

Making this recommendation off the fact that you can get this and the DLC for a few dollars or less during a sale. Pre-Sequel doesn't have as much content as Borderlands 3 or even close to the vast depth of content as Borderlands 2, but if you're looking for more Borderlands content it's worth at least a run-through on normal mode. If you're looking for a new end-game grind here you're not going to find it. The end-game is essentially non-existent, and you'd be better off grinding OP levels in Borderlands 2, or Mayhem 11 in Borderlands 3.

The story here is the 2nd strongest in the franchise (which isn't saying too much to be fair) and the dialogue isn't nearly as painful as Borderlands 3. The Vault Hunter choices are interesting with the favorite being the Doppelganger (Jack is the default name). Lazer weapons are unique to Pre-Sequel so if you want to try them out this is the only place to. Pre-Sequel also introduced Cryo, slams and removed Slag after Borderlands 2 (thank god). Legendaries that are farmable don't have too bad of farms in my experience, HOWEVER there are legendaries that are locked behind the grinder, so if you want something specific you may have to grind Moonstones first (which drop far more often than Eridium in Borderlands 2).

Out of all the Borderlands games, I'd say the Pre-Sequel is the most underrated one. Obviously it's not on par with the greatness of BL2, but it does provide you with some interesting mechanics and fun characters to play with in addition to providing you with more lore about the characters/events from BL2/TFTB. People have complained about things such as Oz kits and zero gravity but personally I found them to be enjoyable cause they made traversing the world a lot faster.

I wouldn't buy the Pre-Sequel at full price. However, it has had discounts of 75% (in some cases even 90%) in the past, so I'd definitely recommend getting it on sale if you enjoyed BL2/TFTB. And, worst case scenario, it still won't be as big of a slog to sit through as Borderlands 3's story lol.

This is pretty much just a carbon copy of borderlands 2, exact same engine, programming and so on. So much so that it suffers from the same stutter and bad optimization for modern systems that borderlands 2 did. It's in a way like a huge, huge DLC for borderlands 2.

They added some minor new things like laser weapons, cold elemental effect, Oz oxygen function, low gravity and slamming, some new vehicles. but generally just the same game so if you first played borderlands 2, you'll likely get a bit fed up with the mechanics and feeling after a while. I didn't even bother to play the dlcs or all optional quests because I got sick of it in the end. But it's still a good time waster and while I played solo, this game would be far, far funnier and better if you have a good friend to play it with.

What I loved the most was that claptrap/fragtrap is playable in this game. I really enjoyed his dialogue, just felt like there could've been a bit more. He's easily my favorite character so being able to play him was great. This game probably had some of the funniest dialogue yet in the series with plenty of moronic characters doing stupid crap all around.

But there were some glaring issues. There were way too many "jumping" puzzles and insane traveling for side quests. I absolutely hated the time I had to spend trying to do the side quests, I thought borderlands 2 was bad with this but this really took it a step further. Really annoying how much time was wasted just trying to rush through the same maps with just a tiny quest and goal in mind, wasting 30+ minutes just walking for a quest sometimes through a place you already visited before and don't care about anymore. Jumping around everywhere due to the "fancy" new low gravity and and air jump sucked, so much time wasted trying to solve stupid puzzles that had no clear solution at times, like where to jump from when there are 50 possible points that might work so you just have to walk around, start jumping and hope to find the right place.

It's the first game in the series where I got so fed up in the end that I didn't bother with the dlcs, I instead watched a walkthrough without talking and skipped to the dialogue parts to quickly absorb the story. I also couldn't care enough to finish the last few maps of side quests, it just bored me half to death at that point and I wanted to quit and try out borderlands 3 instead. This is probably in big part thanks to playing alone and having played borderlands and borderlands 2 with all dlcs and quests done right before over the last few weeks. This game is just too similar in all ways to borderlands 2 that I got sick of it and the looting hasn't really changed at all over these 3 games.

I will now try borderlands 3 and hope that it's actually going to change things enough that it's fun to play again. Will probably skip all side quests that strike me as uninteresting or bothersome too. Bet that will make it much more fun. If I had played this game with NO side quests, I would be singing far more praises than I'm doing now I think, but then I likely wouldn't even have been able to finish the last boss without cheating unless it scales.

Oh, and I played probably closer to 30 hours at least for this game, probably because I played in offline mode and then just quit steam without letting it sync properly, it isn't showing the proper playtime.

Unique Setting and Gameplay:
The Pre-Sequel's setting on Elpis presents a unique and visually striking environment. The low-gravity mechanics introduce a new layer of verticality and freedom to the gameplay. Players can jump higher, perform ground-slams, and even use oxygen as a resource for both survival and enhanced abilities. The altered physics add a fresh twist to combat and exploration, making every encounter feel distinct and exciting.

Compelling Storyline and Characters:
The Pre-Sequel delves deeper into the lore of the Borderlands universe, revealing the rise of the charismatic antagonist, Handsome Jack. As players align with Jack and work for the Hyperion Corporation, they witness his transformation into the iconic villain. The game introduces new playable characters, each with their own unique skills and background stories, offering fresh perspectives and expanding the lore.

Improved Mission Structure and Side Quests:
The mission structure in The Pre-Sequel is refined, providing a more streamlined experience while still offering plenty of room for exploration and side quests. The side quests are engaging and varied, featuring memorable characters and rewarding players with interesting loot and storylines. The game strikes a good balance between main story progression and optional content, ensuring a fulfilling and enjoyable gameplay experience.

New Weapons and Skill Trees:
Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel introduces a range of unique weapons and gear that take advantage of the low-gravity environment. Players can wield laser guns, cryo weapons that freeze enemies, and new grenade types that have different effects. The skill trees for each character offer a fresh set of abilities and playstyles, allowing for diverse character customization and strategic choices.

Humor and Character Dynamics:
The Pre-Sequel maintains the signature humor and irreverent charm that the Borderlands series is known for. The witty dialogue, pop culture references, and absurd situations provide plenty of laughs throughout the game. The interactions between characters, particularly the banter among the playable Vault Hunters, contribute to the game's lighthearted and entertaining atmosphere.

Cooperative Multiplayer:
As with previous Borderlands titles, The Pre-Sequel offers cooperative multiplayer, allowing up to four players to team up and tackle missions together. The cooperative mode enhances the gameplay experience, fostering teamwork and coordination as players combine their unique character abilities to overcome challenges. The drop-in, drop-out functionality ensures a seamless multiplayer experience.

Conclusion:
Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel successfully expands the Borderlands universe, offering a fresh perspective, engaging storyline, and unique gameplay mechanics. The low-gravity setting, new weapons, and skill trees provide a refreshing twist to the familiar formula, while the compelling storyline and memorable characters keep players invested in the game's narrative. Whether played solo or with friends in cooperative multiplayer, The Pre-Sequel delivers an entertaining and immersive experience that will satisfy both fans of the franchise and newcomers alike. Prepare for another wild ride in the Borderlands universe, filled with humor, mayhem, and unforgettable moments.
not as good as the previous game, but its a good game

I think it's the worst of the borderlands series. It has all of the flaws and very little of the strengths from the other titles.

The low gravity makes everything so much more tedious. I was constantly floating helplessly waiting to touch the ground again while enemies can jerk around and defy the physics however they please. None of their motion is natural making it extremely difficult to aim. Oh there's a small lip in the ground I can't walk over. Guess I'll jump way up here and slowly float to the ground to get over it.

The vehicle makes no sense. If there's no gravity when I'm not in the vehicle why is the vehicle stuck so hard to the ground? It doesn't take much to make it flip out. I tried to drive down a seemingly smooth hill only to have the slightest bump send the vehicle out of control and facing the opposite direction.

The quests sent me back to the same areas over and over respawning all of the enemies there and none of the ammo. The lack of fast travel forced me to run through hordes of enemies just trying to get from point A to point B. 

The level design is terrible. I  was exploring a ship doing the main quest and right near the end I saw a chest so I jumped down and opened it only to find that I was now stuck. Unable to jump high enough to escape and unable to kill myself with my measly 3 grenades I had to save and exit. When I came back I had to clear the entire level again just to get back to where I was. Two parts of the main quest had me using a vehicle to jump a gap that took multiple tries and cost me dearly. You need to build speed to make the jump but they didn't give me enough room to build it up or some random bump took it all away. I often found ledges I was sure I could reach but ended up hitting some invisible barrier that suddenly stopped my upward momentum. That rocky slope sure looks like I could use it to climb up that cliff. Nope I just slid smoothly down and got stuck in a hole instead.

Take two steps forward, fight a horde of enemies. Take another two steps forward to investigate the loot and fight another horde of enemies. Try again and yet another horde. The low gravity left the loot scattered everywhere and often in places I couldn't reach. Because of this it seemed like nothing every dropped.

I finally make it to the boss and somehow my shield is instantly gone and I'm burning alive. Try again and again until I am out of cash. Luckily my progress taking down his shield thingies carried between attempts and I was able to unload enough bullets into him while "fighting for my life".

It seemed to me the entire time I played I was fighting for my life or reloading or switching weapons. Reloading and switching weapons is painfully slow. Any weapon that reload fast enough isn't doing enough damage anyways. The game is needlessly difficult. They told me to find cover when my shield breaks but the reality is that my shield is almost always broken and there is no cover because I am surrounded.

The game did a poor job of showing me whether things were above or below me on the minimap.

I couldn't break the rocks with my rocket launcher or the missiles from my vehicle. Instead I had to go to the other side of the map, reclear everything in between, and get a few sticks of dynamite to do the job.

Borderlands the Pre-Sequel Review

Apparently certain masochists who played the main campaign in this game complained that the final boss battle was too easy. I hope those deviants were pleasured voraciously by the DLC boss battle because I found it impossible to beat. So while the pre-sequel was a great game there was a sour taste at the end as I could not finish the claptrap DLC. 

The game had another DLC called Shock Drop Slaughter Pit but I never even encountered it in the game. No great loss as I have no interest in challenge gauntlets. I bought the game because I like Borderlands. I played B1, B2 and now this; next would be the point and click game. 

The lower gravity traversal was fun for me. I found enough moonstone to vastly increase my backpack space as this is essential for looting and selling. The new laser like weapons that shoot a constant stream of lightning or fire were also a cool addition. As I played the full version of the game I played as the Doppelganger which is incredibly thematic and hilarious. The Be Inspired skill is a blast to play with. These games have good progression and levelling up and such was the case in this game as well. I appreciated the plentiful golden chest key codes. I unlocked so many keys but I didnâ€™t even use a fraction of them. Standard Borderlands cell shaded style stands the test of time always. Interesting prequel story and well done humour as expected.

However, despite all these good qualities it's important to remember that the studio that made this was shut down not long after the release of this game. Almost all of the gameâ€™s characters had the Australian accent, which is not bad but some more variety would have been appreciated. The Kraggons turned out to be the most annoying borderlands species of all time. I saw some reviews and internet comments saying this game showed a misunderstood side of Handsome Jack. Uh no, that's not the case because he remains the same egotistical psychotic maniac he always was. Nothing to sympathize with here. The air supply management was annoying but later loot negated this annoyance, mostly. Backtracking to turn in missions was annoying as usual as there are limited means of transport. Constantly re-spawning enemies are a hindrance as usual. The grinder mechanism did not provide good results for me and I did not use it afterwards.

Overall Score 7/10

[h1] BLTPS > BL2 [/h1]
Everybody has their own taste and IMO Borderlands the Pre-Sequal is better than Borderlands 2.
What I prefer in the Pre-Sequal is both the guns, as there is more variety given with the laser guns and the glitch rarity, and the story/characters. Now, I find the vault hunters we play as a lot more interesting in the Pre-Sequal compared to 2 and, more importantly, they feel more balanced. For instance; I like CL4P-TP/FR4G-TP for his dialog and his action skill and I also like Athena for her aspis, which is a strong throwable shield but also not TOO strong like Salvador's ability to hold two guns and once. The story I find more interesting, as it gives much insight as to why and how Jack became the villain that we know him as from 2. Still, both games are great if you're into Looter-Shooter and I think you should definately give them both a try. 8.75/10

[h1]While Borderlands 2 was the masterpiece, this one, unfortunately, is a piece of [strike]sh...[/strike] completely different kind.[/h1]

Below are my thoughts after beating it with all achievements right after a 100% replays of Borderlands 1 & Borderlands 2. Also I used unofficial community patch for the whole playthrough.

[h3]Good:[/h3][list]
[*]main story showing Handsome Jack's rise to power and change from hero to psychopath
[*]gameplay cloned from Borderlands 2 with few nice tweaks like no oxygen atmosphere, lasers and jetpack boosts
[*]playable characters have plenty of voicelines, dialogues and interactions that are funny, well written and fantastically acted, but only during main story[/list]

[h3]Bad:[/h3][list]
[*]SIDEQUESTS - while these were one of the strongest features of BL2, here they're absolutely terrible - offering no interesting story at all, almost zero funny dialogues/comments, and no change in gameplay - to the point that there're at least 5 sidequests that are done in 10 seconds (literally you pick up a sidequest, monologue is being played at the scene, quests ends) - soooo lazy!
[*]NPCs - newly introduced NPCs are mostly cringe and terribly voiced with weird accents that make you want to mute the sound while they speak - no surprise that literally not even one of them returns in BL3
[*]DLCs - two of the dlcs are just arenas (at least one of them has like 3 minutes of story voiceover from BL2 characters... quality content much), while the only story DLC, Claptastic Voyage, was I guess supposed to be funny, but ended up sooooooo boring - I still wonder how can you take one of the most beloved character in the franchise (Claptrap), make dlc with him, supposedly, in the center - and end up with this kind of dull, humorless, weird garbage
[*]basically 2K Australia took all that was amazing in BL2, butchered it leaving only good main story, and weaseled out of doing the rest properly

[b]Ultimately it's better to just watch a recap of main story on youtube with all the dialogues, than waste time actually playing this game. You'll save few dozen hours with absolutely no loss of quality content.[/b]

Greetings fellow gamers! Today, I'm here to share my thoughts on "Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel," a game that, in my honest opinion, falls a bit short compared to its predecessor (Borderlands 2). Now, before we dive in, let me assure you that my quirky style and love for the franchise will remain intact throughout this review!

Gameplay-wise, I couldn't shake the feeling that "The Pre-Sequel" resembled more of an expansion pack to "Borderlands 2" rather than a standalone installment. It brought back familiar gameplay mechanics and graphics, which aren't a bad thing, mind you. It's like how "Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood" complemented "Assassin's Creed 2" but with laser guns and a fresh set of characters. There were some additional features like lower gravity.

Now, let's talk about performance. Things were running smoothly for me until I switched to an AMD 5600 XT graphics card, which should have been a solid choice for the game. However, Borderlands decided to give me a "poopy" experience (yes, I said it) and started acting up. If you encounter performance issues, I strongly suggest addressing them immediately, and if all else fails, don't hesitate to request a refund. It's a bit of a lottery with this title, unfortunately. At the moment, there are two fixes one can try, both on [url=https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Borderlands:_The_Pre-Sequel]PCGamingWiki[/url]. You can try fully disabling PhysX or fully disabling Texture Streaming. After switching to a Ryzen 5 5600X + RX 6700 XT OC combo, what 100% fixed my performance issues was fully disabling PhysX using the PCGamingWiki instructions. Disabling Texture Streaming was causing me memory-related crashes for some reason.

One of the shining stars of "The Pre-Sequel" was Handsome Jack - his character was exceptionally well-portrayed, and the jokes delivered some hearty chuckles. The storyline managed to keep me interested. I must say, Athena and Claptrap were the real showstoppers, adding that extra flair to the overall experience. And let's not forget the epic last boss battle! It hands down earned its spot as the best boss in the series so far.

All in all, "Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel" comes across as a great prologue-like expansion to "Borderlands 2." If lady luck smiles upon you and it cooperates seamlessly with your PC, you might find some big enjoyment here. However, being the dedicated fan that I am, I couldn't help but have a bit higher expectations for this game.

For achievement hunters: the game has 63 achievements. As with all Borderlands titles, hunting for all the achievements is a huge, grinding, and time-consuming challenge. NOT for the faint-hearted.

In conclusion, while "The Pre-Sequel" may not reach the soaring heights of Borderlands 2, it still has its big moments of fun and charm. So, if you're a die-hard Borderlands enthusiast like me, you'll probably want to give it a shot. Just remember to cross your fingers for a smooth performance and enjoy the quirky adventure!

Happy vault hunting, fellow gamers!

IT'S BORDERLANDS ON THE FREAKIN MOON! lot's of little bugs, texture hangups, annoying vehicle handling, but damn if I don't love it to death anyhow. great characters, cool guns and scenery.

[h1]Verdict:
B- Tier,
6.5/10,
3.25 stars,
[/h1]

[b]Worth a Buy?[/b]
Yes, if you want to play with others, but ideally you should only get this during a sale along with the collection of the other games. Additionally, this game is essentially a Borderlands 2's expansion that has been made into a standalone title. This game and Borderlands 2 share a lot of similarities. So if you will like this if you like the other.

[b]Disclaimer[/b]
- This review is based on a single-player experience, not the multiplayer co-op experience, so it does not accurately represent that.

[b]The Good:[/b]
- In comparison to Borderlands 2, protagonists now have dialogue to respond to in-game situations, as well as a personality.
- The new laser weapon type is a nice addition.
- Gravity movement mechanics such as double jumping and ground slamming can be entertaining.
- Blood and gore.
- Doesn't contain much DlC compared to the other Borderlands games.
- 10GB install size.
- The art is incredibly distinctive and iconic. It has the feeling of an interactive comic book.
- The game's visuals and aesthetic make it ageless.
- The UI design blends in effectively with the art style.
- When a character makes their initial appearance, a cool intro is played.
- Characters are enjoyable and memorable in a positive way.
- Great voice acting.
- Co-Op for 4 players.
- Solo gaming is still a viable alternative.
- Extremely replayable.
- The skill tree that can be respecced for a fee.
- Contains numerous secrets and easter eggs.
- There are two new game plus+ modes: "True Vault Hunter Mode" and "Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode."
- The game serves as a nice explanation and prelude to Borderlands 2's events. It also clearly expresses Jack's perspective.
- The story writing is fair; it's surely much better than Borderlands 2.

[b]The Bad:[/b]
- Given that the majority of the game is set on a space station and a moon. When compared to Borderlands 2, the environments can feel quite similar.
- The post game is lacking compared to the other Borderlands games.
- The story pacing can feel slow at times.
- Unskippable cutscenes makes replaying very tedious.
- On current PCs, performance can be inconsistent necessitating the use of DXVK.
- The abundance of weapons and equipment in the game can feel overwhelming. As you advance, your equipment will also gradually become obsolete.  
- The limited number of slots and bank space you'll have, as mentioned above, makes this situation worse. Upgrades are a way to increase the amount. It remains too low, however, despite that. If you are a gaming hoarder, you will detest this. 
- The game restricts exploration by putting up invisible boundaries and kill zones.
- Echo devices, which are voice recordings, are not preserved in the game; instead, they respawn for some reason. 
- Other voicelines can cancel voicelines, which can be annoying. 
- You can't track multiple quests at a time.
- The game occasionally feels repetitive.

[b]The Neutral & Informational:[/b]
- You can bypass the initial start-up videos by typing "NoStartupMovies" in the Steam startup settings.
- A lot of extra optional side quests.
- It might be hit or miss when it comes to quirky dialogue. Though the quirky dialogue isn't as awful as in other games, if you dislike this type of dialogue, you may dislike this game.
- Is divided into segments in a semi-open world design.
- Has no fall damage, which is great but unrealistic.
- Cutscenes/Cinemamatics are capped at 30fps.
- Because levelling can feel a little slow, character building is mostly an end-game activity.
- Completing the main story and all of the side quests and DLC took me 33 hours. 

[b]Performance:
Windows 11, 165hz 1080p Monitor, GPU: 8GB RTX 3060Ti, CPU: Intel Core i7-12700F, 16GB DDR4 3200MHz RAM, SSD [/b]
- Performance can be easily fixed by installing DXVK and setting PhysX to low. https://github.com/doitsujin/dxvk Extract the 'd3d9.dll' from 'x32' to 'BorderlandsPreSequel\Binaries\Win32\'. By doing this it solved all frame rate issues I had.

[b]Bugs & Glitches:[/b]
- When you initially start the game or alt-tab, it changes your default desktop resolution and refresh rate to match the game's. 
- During the mission "Eye to Eye" the audio is bugged.
- I encounter far more bugs in this game compared to Borderlands 2.

[b]Difficulty:[/b]
- Since each player won't have the same equipment, the difficulty can vary depending on their gaming experience. As a result, the difficulty can fluctuate depending on the quality of your items. The degree of difficulty was reasonable during my time, and if a mission was too challenging, I would just do several side missions to level up and acquire stronger gear.

[b]Additional Information:[/b]
- Conclusion: This game has held up exceptionally well over time, just like Borderlands 2 did in terms of gameplay, graphics, and artistic design. This is essentially more of Borderlands 2, if you enjoyed that. Also the addition of Co-Op is great as always.

Entertainment: 34/40
   + Fun to shoot bad guys.
   - Not fun to loot.
   - Some characters are simply not as fun to play as others.

Design: 14/20
   + Wide spread of playable characters.
   + Enhanced movement that comes with arenas designed with it in mind.
   + The most interesting and difficult bosses in the series.
   - Many bosses do not respawn.
   - Several unique items do not have dedicated drops.
   - Cars feel really bad to drive.

Story: 13/20
   + Voice acting is well done across the board.
   + Felicity :)
   + Has one of the best story DLC's I have played.
   - Pickle >:(
   - Relies on you having played Borderlands 2 to get the full experience.

Presentation: 7/20
   + Character design is nice.
   - A large portion of the game looks repetitive.
   - Muted and boring color pallet.
   - Graphics did not improve from Borderlands 2.
   - Characters have stiff animation.

Total: 68/100

It's lot like borderlands 2 what was to be expected anyways seeing as its squeal it's in the name and so go overs what took place before the events of borderlands 2 with few things that for sure sets it apart seeing as your in, SPACCCEEEEEEEEE! Now. (sorry i still love space core) :3 

It still has most of the great writing and jokes that borderlands 2 did what i loved and got me quite few laughs but, the content within is quite lacking to what i know of borderlands are like. Really finished everything within 63 hours. (DLC's included btw for that total) The very first borderlands had more main, side and dlc length content then this. Also due to how short of it there are also way less bosses and i kinda feel 4 of them at least were quite lame to fight due to how lacking, i didn't feel the need to even play TVHM. (true vault hunter mode to anyone reading this that isn't in the know of that community term name its just a newgame+ kinda thing but harder enemies)


Oh and don't get me started on the moonstones it seems you need heaps of them to even get really great loot outside of farming some bosses or to upgrade your ammo storage/backpack/bank. The need for every single moonstone got so bad i always cried in pain to see a moonstone go off the edge, sometimes i would nearly die for it just to grabbing it mid air before it was lost to a edge or any instant death areas of the maps for real i would put my cash pocket at risk just for one single bit of moonstones.


As for major problems with this game is mainly the servers. They keep borderlands 1-2-3 and the from what i hear tiny tina one severs healthy too. But pre squeal, nah some days the connection is really poor where other then the host you be teleporting all over the place with how many times to connection dips and even then me and my bro trying to play this together also had days where the servers were fully down meaning we couldn't play together at all or even get any redeem codes. Out of all the BL games this is the far worst one to play co op with unless you ok with putting up with how bad the servers are for this game aka you wouldn't mind just suddenly being teleported back on like a jump pad to die and other BS stuff like that.

Oh and idk how but my very first day i played this game i broke the game so much it wouldn't even run without me reinstalling the whole thing luckly didn't get set back too much but the way i broke the game was crazy all i did was run over a enemy in the moonbuggy as soon as i unlocked the moonbuggy. And me and my bro playing together found quite few more other bugs too, for real what ever you do don't crouch up and down in most lifts when its moving you will phase through most of them by doing so and in some of them could solflock you to leave and rejoin.


Anyways spite it flaws and yeah kinda lacking content compared to the other games that came before it and the dang poor server connections. It was still quite a great fun borderlands to play, with sure enough, some epic and fun weapons and gameplay ahead of you in store, not as great as BL2 but it came tiny bit close. 

Yeah i do very much recommend to get this game on at least a small sale. And also get yourself the claptrap DLC while your at it, for real, its soooooo good and lets just say i no longer hate claptrap due to this dlc its changed my mind about him of like all the times i've laughed at him, even the boss battle in that dlc is so much more fun and epic then the main game ones.

AS OF WRITING THIS I am currently on the last mission and I am what you would call a "I do not care for side quests and I prefer to just stick to the main story" enjoyer and the boss is 4 levels above me AND HE IS KICKING MY Aâ€‹Sâ€‹S. 

Let me put this in bold so whomever is reading this can get the message clear:
[/b THE BORDERLANDS LEVELING SYSTEM SUCKS MASSIVE Dâ€‹Iâ€‹Câ€‹K AND BALLS]

IF YOUR GAME REQUIRES ME TO DO YOUR DOGâ€‹Aâ€‹Sâ€‹S SIDE MISSIONS IN ORDER TO DO MAIN MISSIONS,
I'M SORRY. BUT THAT'S Râ€‹Eâ€‹Tâ€‹Aâ€‹Râ€‹Dâ€‹Eâ€‹D.
What if I don't care for side quests that don't do anything for the story? What if I don't feel like doing fetch quests? What if your "humor" isn't for me? These reasons and more are why I typically don't do a lot of side quests in video games because a lot of games don't do side quests right let alone fun. Borderlands, IN MY OPINION, does not do that right.

Back to the topic of leveling systems. Why in the flying fâ€‹uâ€‹câ€‹k is it that if enemies are even A SINGLE level above me they can ground pound my aâ€‹sâ€‹s into oblivion despite me unloading 2 magazines with lead into their fâ€‹uâ€‹câ€‹kâ€‹iâ€‹nâ€‹g skulls. Why is it when I fight same level or higher enemies they can just shred my entire shield while not using shock or corrosive weapons? Why is it when I fight the same level or higher enemies the only way I can reliably do damage THAT WILL KILL GUARANTEE is using snipers and rocket launchers??? I don't have an issue with leveling systems in games, I just hate how the world DOESN'T level with you. Until it does. By that, I mean, when I decided to do a few side quests (stopping my progress on the last mission) I went to the beginning areas and everything there is now my level. So this game will level around you?? but not on the final boss??? 

Brushing my issue with the level aside, idk wtf they did to the pc release but I've had constant frame drops during fights and just exploring the world, some quests straight up break and I have to reload, AI can't comprehend the moon gravity at times, sometimes certain events won't trigger so there will be a locked door blocking my progress. This game just hurts to play. The "humor" sucks and again, the humor is attached to the side quests THAT REALLY AREN'T SIDE MISSIONS BECAUSE YOU HAVE TO DO AT LEAST SOME OF THEM to progress. Pistols, Rifles, and lasers feel AWFUL to use. A lot of the "side" characters are as interesting as my love life. 

Missions for some odd reason like to give you a straight goal but never make it simple to actually get to that objective. To elaborate. Lets say there was a mission where you had to go to the store to buy milk. In borderlands terms, you exit your house, find out your car doesn't have gas, walk out of your neighborhood and fight 20 enemies that come out of clown cars, find out a UFO crashed in the middle of the road so you have to jump off a bridge into a river, swim up creek and fight 20 more enemies that come out of clown caves, climb up a hill onto a construction site and fight 20 enemies that come out of clown forklifts, you go onto the street and have to plug in the intersection lights so the traffic jam in the street can be resolved, wait for the traffic to clear, enter a loading screen, then meet a character in a lab who won't have any plot relevance till the end of the game but first you have to fight 20 enemies that come out of clown tubes, THEN that guy gives you a jug of milk. Did I mention some annoying Aâ€‹Sâ€‹Sâ€‹Hâ€‹Oâ€‹Lâ€‹E AUSTRALIAN IS SPOUTING NONSENSE THAT ISN'T FUNNY AND JUST MAKES YOUR EARS BLEED, then he reveals himself in person to you, you fight him, kill him, then backtrack, fast travel, listen to boring dialogue, turn in, done. I wouldn't have an issue if there was a mission like this every here and there but unfortunately this is the entire mainline story quest.

Anyway,

Update 2020: Gearbox, in all their infinite wisdom, have updated Borderlands 2, and the Pre Seque, to add in additional DRM, in the form of mandatory SHiFT accounts to play. Even singleplayer!

All 2K games now come with a 2K launcher, which is not optional, and requires constant updating. Some titles (Xcom 2, Chimera Squad, Bioshock, Borderlands, etc) have had this launcher installed retroactively.

This launcher collects and shares your information, gathering it from your computer, and heaven knows what other connected devices within your home, and does whatever they wish with it!

Theres not even a warning on the Store page!

[b] Overall : 5/10 [/b]

Borderlands the pre-Sequel is not a bad game per se, especially if you like the Borderlands serie. It remains the same, but where it fall short is basically on every aspect save the story of Handsome Jack. The introduction of Space is a nice concept, but it gets really boring after some time, affecting the gunplay and the movements in an uncool way (at least to me). The story is not very long compared to the main episodes, but you feel that it stretched across large areas with lots of back and forth, impacting negatively the pace of the story unfolding. You can definitely forget this one, and skip to Borderlands 2.

[b] Gameplay : 5/10 [/b]

I like the Borderlands serie, but this one really killed me with its overpresent Space environment. While cool at first, it gets really annoying after some time, especially with its impact on the gunplay. Otherwise, it plays like a usual Borderlands.

[b] Graphics : 6/10 [/b]

The game follows the Borderlands graphic design, i.e. cell shading style, so nothing impressive. It's ok, but definitely not the best of the serie.

[b] Story : 6/10 [/b]

Story wise, it's rather simple and quick, and the main interest is to unfold the backstory of Handsome Jack. And the guy is pretty cool, I'll give him that :). However, I felt it too stretched with no surprises.

[b] Achievements : 5/10 [/b]
