The peak of the Borderlands formula and the most refined the original gameplay loop ever was. Also one of the best and refreshing story changes with writing that wasn't pure meme cringe. This game shakes up the meta by introduction zero g combat and massive open areas. Precision weaponry such as pistols, sniper rifles, or any weapon that has a unique modifier that makes it hyper accurate can now be useful at plinking flying or distant targets as you're not just confined to closer quarters combat. Incendinary stacking is also no longer the default go-to as in a vacuum there isn't oxygen for targets to burn. But there's some unique combat mechanics that make up for this such as being able to toggle oxygen generators with shock, jetpacking, and cryo weaponry.

Also, the UHD pack still exists for anyone who wants it. 2K has had STEAM hide it:

https://store.steampowered.com/app/941180/Borderlands_The_PreSequel_Ultra_HD_Texture_Pack/

It gets even better in coop when theses abilities can affect your teammates and you can high five too.

The Good:
-The gameplay we all love from Borderlands is still here, but with a fresh spin of low gravity, jump pads, and air boosting
-Lasers are a new fun weapon type, and the added element of ice makes shattering enemies enjoyable
-Slamming adds a new way of attacking and knockback, with the added bonus of elemental damage
-Venders actually sell decent gear, making money more than slots fodder
-The Grinder gives use to crappy weapons, making them more than vender fodder
-Uses legacy characters from Borderlands 1 and 2 well, including the playable vault hunters
-Moonstones is the new eridium, with the added bonus of Luneshine weapons with unique bonuses
-A new set of vehicles

The Bad:
-Story suffers from the prequel disease, not allowing it to do anything radical or stretch it's own wings because it has to play to the tune of Borderland's 2 plot and canon
-New characters are at their best forgettable and at worst annoying and unlikable

The ugly:
-Oxygen is an annoyance, especially in the beginning
-Map is riddled with death pits to account for low gravity air boosting
-Low gravity physics leads to loot flying off into death pits

Overall, I'd recommend it if you're a big fan of the borderlands games. Get it when it's on sale.

Sure, it was really interesting to see what's been going on before shit hit the fan in Borderlands 2, but nothing else was new really. It felt just like Borderlands 2, and I felt like it needed more to be a new released game into the borderlands franchise. This really should've just been a DLC and not a new $40-50 game.

This game I feel is very underrated. Obviously it gets compared to Borderlands 2 but I feel it's a better sequel in almost every way. In fact I would also say that this is the first game in the Borderlands series that actually feels like a SciFi game. The first two were set on the planet of Pandora, but there weren't really any Scifi elements to them.  They both had a more gritty and industrial feel to them. This game is instead set mostly on Pandora's moon (Elpis) and just the change of setting alone I feel helps to give this game its own identity and is overall a nice change of pace. The game looks amazing! It's actually breathtaking to stand on the moon and  look up into the sky and see the background of stars. The game-play is also much better and includes two big changes that I feel make this an overall better game.

Firstly the slag element is gone and has been replaced with ice/freeze. This new element can freeze the target in place and make them more vulnerable to melee attacks. It's a cool new idea that I feel works much better than slag from 2. 

Another new idea are Laser weapons, they are a vast improvement over both Eridium guns from the first game and E-Tech weapons from the second. These weapons always have an element attached and they have a good rate of fire too. Sometimes they fire a consecutive beam instead that you can use to hit targets for continuous damage. They stand out on their own and don't feel as though they replace any of the others, other weapon types will still be useful in the right circumstances (and also depends on the Class you're playing as). Again bringing in laser weapons helps this game feel more SciFi and I like how powerful lasers can be. One of my favorites being the ZX-1. I almost always keep a laser weapon in my inventory as I find them very useful. I hope laser weapons will come back in future.

I should also talk a bit about the Vault Hunters, they're an interesting group this time around, but honestly they feel more developed than in either of the previous games. They talk a lot more in this game and will comment on things as well as give their opinions on situations. This is something that was sort of present in the earlier games, but not utilized as much. Some VH had interesting personalities but this is the first game where I feel they all are more unique and more than just characters you play as. I love the new dialogue that they gave them as I feel it brings them to life in a way that wasn't done before, another feature I hope gets brought back in the future. Also it's good to see that the Vault Hunters in this game are all good. There's not one that's bad to play as, they each bring something useful to the table in their skills. The skill trees are a bit more refined in this game, overall it feels like most of the skills have a use and that they synergise better. Also you can start investing in skills at level 3 instead of 5 another GREAT improvement!

As for the story, well.... it's interesting to see some of the events that made Handsome Jack who he is. I say some of the events because even at the start you can kind of see that he's not exactly heroic. In a way the story is tragic because we know what's going to happen in the end, and it does a good job of both making you feel for Jack, but also showing that he may have brought some of it on himself. Although it's a "prequel" you should still probably play Borderlands 1 & 2 before playing this game to understand the story fully. I will say I did enjoy the story, it still has a lot of great writing that the series is known for, and while you might know it won't end well for Jack it is interesting to see some of the moments that ended up making him who he was and seeing him fall from hero to villain.

The only thing I really wish this game had done better was DLC. There's only one and it's a good DLC but I honestly wish there was more. Still if you buy this game at full price I'd say you're getting your money's worth. Overall a great game and a worthy follow-up to Borderlands 2.

[h1]Welcome to Cosmolands[/h1]

This could well have been a unusual game and parallel to the [i]Borderlands[/i] universe as it was with [i]Wonderlands[/i]. It feels familiar and known, but at the same time something different: itâ€™s spacey, cosmic and above all enthralling being outside of Pandora. This assumes two things: this pre-sequel was released after Borderlands 2, and you've played both games first. Since everything happens on Pandora, on solid land. In its epoch, it was something new and exciting: an RPG with a story and a gameplay in outer space.

The game seems to be born as a DLC. There was a need to expand the story, deliver more content and there is no better way than to craft a prologue to Handsome Jack. Although I still donâ€™t understand the word of Â«pre-sequelÂ» that it has in its title. But as would happen with Tina's dlc, it would soon be a separate game and, why not, a new game based on Borderlands. At first glance it offers: New playable characters, some difficult and challenging bosses, an art related to the myth of Eridium, everything pointed to another game. However, what is it that makes it dissimilar from the rest? And is it worth playing?

[h1]The comic descent of a hero[/h1]

Although I'm not sure if the developers intended to conceive an RPG with space gameplay, even though it indicates to something neoteric and innovative. Borderlands 2 has been depicted by having a good story to tell, with hilarity and captivate through a well-created script. This instance it presents something from Jack's past as a prologue. Weâ€™ve witnessed a hero suddenly becomes a villain seduced by power upon seeing the contents of the Vault. Since his story takes place between the Pandoraâ€™s moon and the space station of Hyperion. The mercenaries known as The Lost Legion commanded by Tungsteena Zarpedon take control the station. Its giant gun is used to fire on the planet. So the mission is to assist Jack stop them. But the plot twists in a startling way.

The mode to relate the story is performed through the memory of Athena, since sheâ€™s captured and taken to Sanctuary. By assent to her tell her tale, she becomes the protagonist. So hindsight and flashback are recurring in the game. This allows us to understand a little about their context of many characters in Borderlands 2 and how they came to be who they are. However, assuming the plot is comical that doesn't mean it can't give its story a little gravitas. Sometimes congruence is mislaid when characters like Lilith seem to have amnesia when hearkening about her encounter with Athena. Details are often not spelled out, so theyâ€™re filled in with vaguely elaborate narration where there are gaps.

Itâ€™s true, we have many new or familiar characters and an Eridium myth that take prompt courses in the story. The script and story are still good, but sometimes their characters require better personality development. Also the transformation from villain to hero was sudden, overnight, in a jump, without really taking us by the hand to feel that love-hate with Jack. Like Darth Vader who leans towards the dark side. The idea is good, but it isnâ€™t being performed in the best way. I consider that the story would have been better created for a different universe, since it has the potential for something even deeper. Even so, itâ€™s a worthy outline in the form of a prologue for an invention of a new adventure.

[h1]Into the Void: The art of outer space[/h1]

Something thatâ€™s worth noting is its art and soundtrack. Both constitute the integrity of the plot. Most of the time we can appreciate dark space from the moon. Those open areas whose view of the sky is the immensity of darkness. I be fond of the effect of the light of its star reflecting on pale land, while the giant H and Pandora can be perceived in the background. In some places it achieves to offer a feeling of abysmal loneliness and of floating in an infinite void. The locations are like colonies and alien creatures abide around them. Concordia is the small colony where it be noticeable as does the mesmerizing architecture of Hyperion. Although I deem where it steals the stare are the alien locations. It applies a colour palette common to Eridium, the purple, and organic symmetry because of its myth about that element. That will be picked up again in [i]Borderlands 3[/i].

The environmental proposal is also interesting: From the effects of the explosions to the opaque sound, assuming there is no air for the sound to travel through. Soundscapes are a stimulating experience. As for the soundtrack, itâ€™s quite exotic and exquisite. It was composed by Jesper Kyd, Des Shore and Justin Mullins. They portray and interpret outer space, colonies and Eridian alien scenes. I like that unique combination of IDM, space disco and space ambient mainly. It offers a petrifying atmosphere of a distant, dark and unknown open space. Many of the most energetic, effervescent and vibrant musical pieces will be in the moments of combat. Instead, where we explore, ambient music predominates to give an inhospitable feeling of the moon. Itâ€™s an enjoyable soundtrack from beginning to end. It achieves its mission: to take us to other corners of the dark universe.

[h1]One small step for Pandora, one giant leap for Elpis[/h1]

If something be conspicuous quite a lot Borderlands is an outstanding combination of FPS with RPG. Always it brings characters with classes and perks with a clever imagination. New characters for a new story, why not. In such a way its gameplay has other elements that contrast from its well-known style. Thereâ€™s something else. I fairly adore is its effect of slight gravity. It's fascinating to make big jumps and have a pack that propels me further. Although it depends on the oxygen. This is another plus point: the huge jumps, the big strides and a buoyant feeling when playing on the moon. Of course all guided by the narrative of the game.

If the plot takes place in a lunar setting, the gameplay will proceed and perform according to its atmosphere. Since thereâ€™s no breathable air, we must look for oxygen wells or air supplies. Another plus point. New objects such as the helmet or weapons that use freezing ammo were added, but without leaving the FPS style aside. Something that be prominent a lot â€”itâ€™s due to its structure of the DLC with tough enemiesâ€” is the increase in difficulty of the bosses as progress is made. Some of them seem to be invincible. The advantage: you can level up quickly without the need to do side quests. Tungsteena Zarpedon was a taxing boss to beat, I died many times, but it was worth a try, just to mention one example. The rest of the game is familiar if you've played Borderlands 2.

[h1]Ending transmission[/h1]

Perhaps this game tries to unify both Borderlands. It can't do it, because it requires recurrent work on all characters, which theyâ€™d suffer from narrative wear and tear. Because itâ€™ll be required to go to the origins. That would lead to a new game. Or bring more unnecessary releases. Although it also seems to be time lag. It was able to offer a new game, since it has the necessary elements to stand out. It just needs a steady step to explore new worlds â€”as Borderlands 3 didâ€” in other possible ways.

First of all, I recommend you buy the game as a bundle. The game is long, although it gives the air of complementing or expanding the main story for Borderlands 2. It has the side quests and, as I mentioned, some tremendous bosses. Secondly, play it regardless of the order, since it oscillates between a Â«previousÂ» stories but without going back to the origins. It's better to play it with friends, like I did; but if you play it alone, be prepared at all times. Despite having diverse characters and an effort at a new plot, maybe itâ€™d have been cool to permit some dissimilar outfits, dressing up in a spacesuit. It wants to link both games, but I insist thereâ€™s an attempt to have created something new.

After owning this game for years by now, I finally sit down to write a review.

I do not really understand why so many people hate on this. It is for what it is ... very interesting and fun to play. The 6 characters you can play are as different as can be ... compared to the 4 characters in the original Borderlands or the 6 characters that where in Borderlands 2, you can clearly see that they tried to create fun and engaging characters to play with.

The areas you run around are also very diverse, Low Gravity hopping on the Moon, exploding crashed spaceships, space stations, the not-yet completed Helios Station or even Clap Traps mind in a [i]Tron[/i] like Virtual Reality experience ... there is [b]allot fun[/b] to be had in The Pre-Sequel not to different then what is offered in Borderlands 2.
And boy is that [i]Claptastic Voyage[/i] good! For me that rivals with [i]Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep[/i] ... something they did not surpass with [b]any[/b] of the DLC they brought into Borderlands 3.

The one and only negative thing about The Pre-Sequel is ... that it is from landmass and enemy variety not as big as Borderlands 2. There is allot content that could have been made for it, but didn't. But for what it is ... it is well worth playing, in my opinion.

Bar none, the best Borderlands game in the entire franchise and it's a prequel. Has some fun characters, more likable than usual and not as annoying. It's an Aussie dev team so it's got a lot of Aussie characters, stereotypes and humor. I enjoy a lot of the grind even if its pretty much an updated Borderlands 2 grinding. Styles of grips and shit are still a thing still but doesn't feel too horrible since most weapons have several meta styles. MOST weapons. Bosses are fine to fight, and enemies don't feel as spongy. Story is fun and has a lot of heart in it. Sad to think the studio got defunct in 2015 shortly after the game's release. I highly suggest this game over the rest of the franchise, even 3.

I don't get why so many people give this game hate. I mean it's no Borderlands 3, but it's still fun to play. I just wished they gave this game more attention with the lackluster season pass.

EDIT: After having played 3, I'm glad this game isn't THAT. Unlike 3, this game is actually worth your time, though not at full price. It's a little lacking in content, but it's still fun.

You fuck around in space with the most wackass guns I've ever seen in my life, and I love it.

One of the Borderlands games ever made (To be fair, a mediocre Borderlands is still a pretty good game)

UPDATED REVIEW AFTER SECOND PLAYTHROUGH WITH WILHELM

I would like to give TPS more credit - of its new mechanics, several of them are actually fun with the right playstyle. Double jumping is a good mechanic in absolutely any game and this isn't an exception (though sometimes climbing up places feels like it should work but doesn't because of some weird geometry) and the slam is actually a viable way to damage several enemies. The Grinder is a great way to make collecting loot more engaging than just selling them at vending stations and accumulating so much money you'll almost never use except for maybe getting a Shield or two (but there should be more than just the one in Concordia). The Ice element is absolutely the biggest winner of them all though, especially towards the end

In its quest construction and story structure I do find some fault though. The way it delivers that Jack is becoming a big enemy of Pandora is clumsy at best, and it feels like everyone is just as much of an ass as he is, except they're not destined to be the villain in the sequel so they get away with it. Quest structure wise it feels like there's one or two too few Fast Travel stations for some quests, and Jack's Office being a hub but having no facilities feels wrong and adds unnecessary load times. There are some quest lines that require you to go to a map, come back for the reward, and then there's an immediate follow up quest on that same map, and it just feels like too much backtracking. This is probably why immediately after finishing I didn't and don't feel like replaying with a new character, though after some months or maybe years I do plan to play it again and do the DLCs

ORIGINAL REVIEW AFTER ONE PLAYTHROUGH AS ATHENA

You can check my hours on the other Borderlands games compared to this for a benchmark. I like the base game qualities of a Borderlands game.

I've played through Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel once. I did do most of the sidequests up until the end, had no problem finishing one of the trees on my played character, and generally had quite a bit of fun with them, but had no inclination to replay it with a different class.

It has a slow start, but all of the Borderlands' do and there's not much you can do about that, as you need levels and interesting guns to start creating real chaos. The new air mechanic, however, does not make for fun movement and also removes usability of flame weapons, and as a person who really likes elemental weapons this wasn't very desirable. While the effects of being out-of-breath are fairly minimal and you can get oxygen very easily from enemies, the audio and video distortion made it really annoying and pushed you indoors as much as possible. Using shock also became a nightmare around the oxygen stations.

The ice elemental is wonderful, and I liked it a lot more than the purple from BL2. Freezing enemies in order to get a good shot at them is wonderfully cheap, and works on about every enemy. Add to that the fact that my entire build was around doing as much elemental damage as I could in order to build stacks, and my hop and shock gameplay was absurdly fun (with the exception of trying to defeat a helicopter. Defeating a helicopter has never been fun any BL).

My one major issue is that I felt no need to replay the game. None of the other classes looked as fun as the one I initially used. Every tree had a "stacks" theme to them, and by nature this means that your fun gets exponential the more you kill, but there are several, SEVERAL lulls in the game where you're fighting a small amount of enemies or none at all, and having very small effects from your skills at those times almost always feels underwhelming. 

I recommend this as a play-it-once kind of game, with the class you like (you probably know what kind of gameplay you prefer if you're into Borderlands).

pros: unlimited frames per second menu option, humor and dialogue, weapon variety, multiple classes to choose from, vehicle options, three skill trees for each class to choose from, soundtrack fits the theme, online multiplayer available

cons: some sequences are locked at 30fps, invisible walls, backtracking, tedious side missions, only 4 maximum weapons to carry, only one activatable skill, the felicity boss fight is tedious (the game forces you to do side missions to level up, I had to go online and beat the boss with a team), zarpedon tedious boss fight, RK5 tedious boss fight, tedious final boss fight, texture pop-ins, the no-oxygen mechanic, bad loot drops, shift friends invitations does not work

Overall, for the most part this is another Borderlands game using the same ole formula as the previous games. Pick it up on a steam sale.

I wouldn't recommend this game. Here are some of my issues with it:

- The low-gravity jumping feature is fun at first but it seems to be a constant in the game. I had expected to move back to pandora or some other normal gravity location, but that doesn't seem like it's going to happen. The problem with the low-gravity is it undermines the unbridled mayhem that was a defining characteristic of other Borderlands games. It slows everything down. Fights are slower. Getting around is slower. 

- There are jumping challenges. They're not hard, though I could see where some might struggle with them, but my main complaint is I want to fight and kill stuff not bounce around trying to get to certain locations. The jumping detracts from gameplay, slowing the game down. 

- The writing is godawful. I think this is probably the same team who gave us B3. The characters yammer on and talk endlessly when all you want to do is get the quest and go do it. Dear writers: It's not funny to make me listen to what you think is funny when it doesn't even rise to the level of stoned teenager humor. 

Please stop trying to be the original writers of Borderlands. Oh, and get a copy of Strunk and White, and read it, please.

- Getting around is tiresome. Please respect gamers' time. Every game has realized we don't want to drive back across the world to hand in a quest. We can hand it in where we complete it or, at least, tp to the spot we need to hand it in. But not this game. 

Sure you can teleport but it's not convenient. 

- Too many golden keys. I got over 100 of them. Just take this out of the game. Why? Because they completely undermine the whole point of getting loot.  There's no fun in opening a loot box in regular gameplay if you know you can "cheat" the system by using one of your many golden keys.

- Not a major issue but the hover craft is a missed opportunity. They could have been fun if they had better flying options, but they handle like a bag of stones.

- I do like the new characters. Seems a crime to stick them in this version of Borderlands.

tldr:
- Combat is slow and crippled.
- The story writing is tedious and tries too hard to be funny when it isn't.
- Getting around is difficult and takes too much time.
- So many golden keys undermine the fun of getting loot.
- The hover craft is a fail when it should have been fun.
- The new characters and their skills are fun.

Not as good as Borderlands 2, perhaps just slightly below Borderlands 1, but still a good (ish) game.

Things done better than BL2:
[list]
[*][b]Level scaling[/b] - less grindy, you can progress through the story more naturally without stopping to level up. Stats for both players and enemies scale more slowly, so equipment retains utility for longer;
[*][b]Skill tree progression[/b] - getting the action skill at level 3 and being able to jump the third row of skill trees by only spending one point on a skill makes for a quicker progression to the skill tree's game-changing skill.
[/list]
Things done differently than BL2:
[list]
[*][b]Playable character dialogue[/b] - subject to player taste, some may like it, some may not;
[*][b]Movement[/b] - the lower gravity makes for more of a jumpy gameplay, so you gain more vertical exploration and the ability to get close and stun enemies by slamming downwards, but I felt like this nullifies sniper usage.
[/list]
Things done worse than BL2:
[list]
[*][b]Story[/b] - unnecessary, taints a bit on Jack's character;
[*][b]Pacing[/b] - too many sequences of dialogue that go on for minutes before allowing players to get back into the fun stuff;
[*][b]Enemy design[/b] - Elpis creatures are weird-looking, which makes it difficult to locate critical spots and understand their movement and attack animations;
[*][b]Soundtrack[/b] - fits the scenery, but the space vibe makes the music forgettable, kind of bland and empty.
[/list]
The rest is basically the same as BL2: same engine, so same combat feeling, same graphics, art style, quest design, currency gimmicks. Still a good looter shooter if you're tired of BL2 and want different characters, builds, and guns to play with.

After Borderlands 2 being barely any different with zero improvements on core gameplay and considering past games of Gearbox such as Duke Nukem Forever and Aliens Colonial Marines - I was afraid that The Pre-Seque will be another nothing sequel to already dull franchise but I was very pleasantly surprised.

From ALL of Borderlands games (Borderlands 1, Borderlands 2, The Pre-Sequel and Borderlands 3), The Pre-Sequel is hands down the best one of them!

It's not even a competition. It's just that good.

Heck, unlike Borderlands 2 - The Pre-Sequel actually feels like a proper sequel to the franchise.
Unlike Borderlands 3 - The Pre-Sequel actually have good content, good humour and zero cringe inducing whiny children.

Less boring and grindy sameish quests without dull story, 
less cringe humor, no horrible crappy boss fights and this time with a villian that did not exist purely for memes?

What sorcery is this?

A Borderlands? Being actually a good, fun video game for once???

I never even did smirk at those stupid memes and jokes in Borderlands 1 and 2 but The Pre-Sequel actually made me laugh.

Even Claptrap is actually funny this time. A freaking! Claptrap!

Borderlands The Pre-Sequel have entertaining script, engaging sidequests and good gameplay loop?

Handsome Jack is actually a great developed character now and not crappy voice from the sky that appear for like two in game scenes only?

There is no painfully average gunplay and playing boring as f*ck DLC's doesn't want me to kill myself?

I am shocked! Finally....... FINALLY I see some improvements in this franchise.

Low gravity combined with platforming, air mechanic 
and helmets giving you different boost feels actually super refreshing. 

All playable characters have this time unique and fun abilities, unlike characters in two previous game (which was just copy-pasted from each other anyway) makes this game so much better than Borderlands 1 and Borderlands 2.

 The Pre-Sequel brings actually new ideas, new completely different and fun vehicles, good boss fights (including my favourite final boss in First Person Shooter over the past few years), 
new enemy types, new status effects, way more types of guns and weapon grinder improving loot farming SO much! 

Even Moonstone (aka Eridium from Borderlands 2) is not pain in the butt to find now and you can use it in way more different ways than just for ammo and backpack upgrades.

Overall Borderlands The Pre-Sequel is totally worth of your time, unlike majority of Borderlands 1 and 2.

The underrated Borderlands game, my old favourite to comeback to from time to time!

* Classic Borderlands 2 formula with more stuff to shake the gameplay - gravity, oxygen, jumpads, laser weapons, cryo elemental damage - and to me all of them are super fun, especially lasers and cryo mechanics! I can see how oxygen and gravity can be annoying for less experienced players, but for seasoned Borderlands fans it's more good stuff - Oz kits have various bonuses bases on vacuum/atmosphere/amount of oxygen, and gravity makes combat much more fun with vertical layers, flying enemies and acrobatics in space!

* Fantastic playable characters and their skill trees, arguably the best in the series (even better than in Borderlands 3). Unlike in Borderlands 2, characters also talk, react in dialogues and overall have more personality. Moreover, we're playing as bad guys, which adds some spice, especially later in the story.

* The skill trees are not just passive bonuses, there are unique interactive elements to them. For example, Wilhelm changes his voice and visuals if you invest into "Cyber Commando" tree. Or Aurelia has tree that has coop-focused playstyle, where you make a "contract" with other player and you receive various bonuses for protecting each other.

* Each skill tree has multiple variations of playstyles you can do and there are corresponding Class Mod that improve skills for that playstyle. For example, Aurelia has "Cold Blood" skill tree that focuses on cryo damage, and it has 3 distinguished playstyles - being "untouchable" and doing heavy damage to enemies that attack you; an opposite of it, having smaller shield but very fast shield recharge, which is high risk, high reward gameplay - you basically spam cryo novas around you and kill everyone, but it's also easier to take you down; and lastly, the gun focused gameplay, where you throw your action skill and shoot into critical point, doing tons of cryo damage with gun through the shield. Of course, in later levels where you have 2 skill trees maxed you use everything at the same time, but these smart gameplay design decision is what makes The Pre-Sequel characters so unique and fun, especially on the first walkthrough in normal mode.

* Dialogues are maybe not as good as in B2, but story and lore itself are amazing. You can see how all of the Borderlands 2 world elements were created and players who pay attention will appreciate the story of Hyperion robots, moonshot cannon, skags, etc. And, of course, the story of Jack himself!

* Locations are beautiful and well designed. From big moon landscapes, to Hyperion space station. There are various points of interest and side quests to do, a lot of hidden chests and challenges to complete.

* PhysX is still great tech and well implemented in-game with various fluids and particles flying around, adding more "oopmph" to the game visuals.

* The soundtrack is chef kiss. Each location has its own ambient and battle theme.

* Claptrap DLC is one of the best Borderlands franchise DLC.

I am a 55 year old biker and trucker father, and probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

[h1]Gameplay: 9/10[/h1]
[h1]Graphics & Sound: 10/10[/h1]
[h1]Narration: 9/10[/h1]

NB: I'm mostly copypasting my review from Borderlands 2 because it's mostly the same game, with a new story, some new mechanics, and a different group of playable characters.

âœ”ï¸ Very beautiful graphics that age well.
âœ”ï¸ Great juicy visual and sound effects.
âœ”ï¸ Fun loot and progression systems, with cool character abilities that actually give personality to the different characters' gameplay.
âœ”ï¸ Enjoyable story with colorful characters. Oh and you play bad guys.
âœ”ï¸ Excellent completion of Borderlands 2 story focusing on what happened between Borderlands 1 and 2, with some additional sweet story about known characters (including some who barely had any story going on), as well as a few completely new ones.
âœ”ï¸ Wonderful soundtrack.
âœ”ï¸ Fun gravity-based gameplay.
âœ”ï¸ The one and only story content DLC is excellent. Way better than most Borderlands 2 DLCs in my opinion.

âŒ Co-op loot sharing is still a bit tedious, like in Borderlands 1 and 2 - you kinda need to fight for the loot that interests you, especially with teams of more than 2, since there aren't that many different kinds of weapons, and good weapons can be interesting for a lot of characters, so it requires a bit of organisation and diplomacy. The game would really have benefited from instantiated loot, or some kind of smarter interface that would put loot in common between players, I don't know.
âŒ Like in Borderlands 1 and 2, the narration can play during tense battle moments with no way to replay it, which can make it a bit difficult to follow. And it's possible (and very easy) to start several dialogues at the same moment, which completely overrides the one started first, making you just irreversibly lose some plot.
âŒ The oxygen system added by the game doesn't really do much for the experience in my opinion. And it's the best we could have hoped for, because if it did matter, it would have made things waaay too frustrating. Kinda feels like they realized it, but had invested too much into its development and refused to let it go.

A complete recommendation to anyone who played and enjoyed Borderlands 2. To anyone who would like to play it but DIDN'T play Borderlands 2 before - please do, the quality of the game is very close, and you'll get some major story spoilers about the events of Borderlands 2. And Borderlands 2 is definitely worth playing.

By now, after playing an handfull of Borderlands games I concluded that no BL game will reach such peak as Borderlands 2 did. With that said, this game is not as good as BL 2 but not worst than BL 3, you will feel like you are playing a BL game and will probably have fun if you are not a picky eater. Just make sure to pick Athena and to buy it during a sale. Have fun!

Don't play alone unless you have a death wish. Minmaxing is VERY important in all the Borderlands games, and your equipment will become obsolete quicker than you can imagine. If your gun is more than like 3 levels below your current level, it won't save you. At all. Having said that, I love all the characters in Borderlands and all the humor is great. I beat BL2 a few times and the Pre Sequel I think just once, all on console. It's a hell of a lot easier with at least one other person to play with who can revive you when you can't seem to get an enemy to get close enough to you for a kill revive. Which happens very often. I find that I actually die more often from falling to my death though than anything else. Some of the vehicle jumps are particularly near-impossible and you will die trying them at least 4 or 5 times before you get it.  Being downed in combat is basically the key element of every Borderlands game, and you will spend a great deal of time in "Fight for your life" mode. Some enemies are so overpowered that they will one-shot you and sponge up so much of your DPS that you just want to run away. But you can't, because you have to beat them to progress. Expect to yell at your screen a lot. If you love a challenge, and like platforming FPS games, Borderlands is hard to beat. And this one is my favorite in the series.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is the third game in the Borderlands series. It continues the proud Borderlands tradition of not changing a goddamned thing and just producing more of the same.

Okay yes, there are additions. Moving the story to Elpis, Pandora's moon, allows the addition of a few interesting mechanics: low gravity and no oxygen means big jumps, boosting jumps by expending oxygen, slamming down on oppoents from on high in the middle of a jump, managing your oxygen resources, and shooting an opponent's face mask to make them asphyxiate. There's a new type of elemental damage, cryo, which allows you to freeze opponents solid and even smash them into bits (although the slag element from Borderlands 2 is gone), and a new type of weapon, lasers (although E-Tech weapons are gone). Aaaaaaaaaaand...that's it, really. We're playing the same game, essentially, just experiencing a new story within that game.

And how is that story? It's...okay, I guess. It takes place between the events of Borderlands and Borderlands 2, and gives the backstory of Handsome Jack and how he came to be the tyrant of Pandora. Your character is a mercenary summoned to Helios, the Hyperion space spation looming in the skybox of Borderlands 2, in order to help Handsome Jack, who has just arrived in said space station (they move around in the world of Borderlands, apparently â€“ maybe this is taking place in the same universe as Star Wars?) in order to observe events on Pandora, namely the aftermath of the opening of the Vault in the first game.

 However as soon as you arrive the station is attacked by a mysterious force led by the equally mysterious Colonel Zarpedon, (and some other thing which doesn't even get a name), and you are sent down to Elpis in order to help (yeah, they explain within the game why that makes sense, but I'm not going into it here). From there it's pretty standard: the first act of the game you're working on getting ready to assault Helios, which has now started destroying Elpis in order to raise the stakes; the second act you're on some ill-defined revenge mission because the NPCs that were helping you previously suddenly decide they want to murder you (Lilith and Moxxi, who's now a technical genius in order to explain her inclusion in the story), then you're tracking and entering the Vault on Elpis in order to fight the giant monster that's in there, because that's what happened in the previous two games and video game writers don't know how else to end stories. It's all pretty underwhelming.

I'm not sure what else could have been done with the story, to be honest. The decision to have the next Borderlands game set between the previous two is an odd one. I heard that Gearbox wasn't ready to start making Borderlands 3, so gave 2K Australia the task of making a pre-sequel, in order to keep making more money, uh, I mean, give the fans what they want. Fair enough, I guess. But that makes even its reason for existing somehow lesser than a proper sequel. For the first time with a Borderlands game, I found myself regretting pre-ordering (and now that I've seen some of the DLC, I'm regretting my decision to get the Season's Pass, as well).

Another thing I found underwhelming this time around is the humour. The Borderlands series has a reputation for being fairly humourous at times, and while the style of humour isn't exactly Oscar Wilde (about 95% of it is either pop-culture references or some variation on â€œhaha life sure is cheap on Pandora!â€) I certainly got many chuckles, and a few outright belly laughs. Up until now. I'm sure a big part of it is the fact that this game was written by Australians, and humour has always been the most regional of beasts. What plays in Aus doesn't necessarily play in North America, and when your humour style consists chiefly of referencing other things, you may as well just give up. Practically every so-called joke fell completely flat, as I stared stone faced at the screen, utterly confused as to whether it was a reference that went over my head or whether it was just plain not funny. This is why refernence-checking is considered a low form of humour, folks.

And as a result of the game being underwhelming, all the little annoyances that I'd been willing to overlook on previous outings started to loom large. The inventory system is still not great â€“ for reasons I won't go into here, comparing weapons is still not as smooth as it could be. Key quest- or story-related dialogue is routinely delivered while you're in the middle of a firefight, or broken up and distributed randomly over a map so that you might have 1/5 of a particular character's motivation, and that one part out of order. The game talks way too much, and I frequently found myself wishing the characters I was listening to would just shut the hell up already. And it's still way too easy to get hung up on a tiny little bump in the ground.

I do not dislike this game. I had fun playing through it, and as always the co-op multiplayer makes it worth the price of admission. But for this franchise to survive, Gearbox and 2K Games are going to need to shake things up. They've made exactly the same game 3 times in a row now, and it's time to challenge themselves. Mix stuff up. Tweak the art style. Change the tone. Come up with some new NPCs that don't suck (Janie Springs and Pickle are an accent and a cheerful attitude and absolutely nothing else). Find some way of expanding the mythology of the Vaults and the Eridians who created them. For the love of the gods, don't end the game by having the players open a Vault and fight a big monster that comes out. You're better than this.

What happens if the game that got a sequel was really good? Milk the crap out of that sequel! Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel. As the name suggests, this game happens before Borderlands 2 but after Borderlands 1. So, it's Borderlands 1.5. Choose from 4, or 6 vault hunters, each with their own abilities and powers unique- well, for most parties; Athena, Nisha, Wilhelm and Claptrap. Then, the two additional DLC, Jack and Lady Hammerlock. Every character in a way is related to the main protagonist turned antagonist of the game, the big man himself, Handsome Jack. Traverse the given world using a special gadget, also known as Oz kits, or O2 kits. Jump everywhere and any- many places because this world is- you guessed it, IN SPACE! Play with new guns exclusive to this game: Laser guns. Pretty darn amazing, if you ask me... but I'm not the best to ask.

The core shooting and looting mechanics remain unchanged from Borderlands 2, which is good. The overall quality of this game however is lower with the exception of the Claptastic Voyage DLC.

There's something wrong with the coding for flying human enemies. Multiple times I had those units clip through walls and get stuck outside the terrain. Once during a "Kill Everyone" objective, fortunately I was playing Baroness and her ability noclips and homes in on enemies.

I remember the hitboxes in BL2 being very tight. Not so here. Many cover objects have invisible fuzzy edges that block bullets. In addition, the Lost Legion Marines specifically have terrible hitboxes that don't match their models. Putting the crosshairs over the deltoid/jetpack region brings up their health bar but bullets pass through there with no damage. Semi-related: I never use the railgun weapons because they seem to have hit registration problems. Speaking of which there are several places where the terrain has invisible edges that you get stuck on trying to walk through and have to hop over. Minor but distractingly low build quality.

All of these critiques pale to the worst problem of all: BAD WRITING.
TL;DR BL2 is one of my most played games. At least one full playthrough of main storyline with every character. But Pre-Sequel? On my initial playthrough of Pre-Sequel I got so bored I put it in my backlog for 5 years before coming back to finish it this month. It just had so little hold on me. I left thinking I had only played 30% of the game and it might improve. Turns out I was basically at the finale (I stopped at the RK5 bossfight). It never got better. What a waste of anticipation.

I'd heard this game revealed Jack had a backstory that made him a tragic figure rather than the straight love-to-hate-him Joffrey-level bastard villain. Nope. He starts out "normal", not a villain, sure. But I expected some kind of reveal of a heroic sacrifice. Maybe he opened the Elpis Vault and took the brunt of some kind of Eridian energy blast that was about to kill the player's Vault Hunters and it cost him his sanity plus scarred his face? Nope. We have characters spoonfeed us that he's a good guy, look he's still a decent guy see? And then follows a disjointed, inorganic transformation into villain Handsome Jack. It's like the old trick I used to pull in highschool Algebra when given a formula and the answer and instructed to show my work. Sometimes I would just work from the formula until I got stuck then work backward from the answer and then hope my teacher wouldn't notice the seams.

I still give it a thumbs up because it's fun despite yadayada but this is another one of those times I wish Steam would allow verdicts of Neutral.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is an interstellar adventure that shoots for the stars! This action-packed first-person shooter takes players on a thrilling journey through the moon of Pandora. With its unique low-gravity mechanics, diverse set of playable characters, and trademark Borderlands humor, it offers a fresh take on the beloved franchise. The combination of frenetic gunplay, outrageous weapons, and humorous dialogue creates an addictive and entertaining experience. Whether you're a fan of the series or new to the Borderlands universe, The Pre-Sequel delivers an out-of-this-world adventure that will keep you hooked from start to finish. Prepare to embark on a cosmic ride filled with explosive fun and memorable moments.

If you even slightly enjoyed playing Borderlands 2, you should try this one.

The main reason why I liked this game is because I didn't expect much from it. Borderlands 2(B2) wasn't exactly the best gaming experience for me with its tedious story, boring locations and one-shotting bosses, so I thought that The Pre-Sequel(TPS) doesn't differ much from its predecessor... but I was wrong. 
Level design, playable characters, boss-fights, scaling system, writing(characters' lines) is where TPS does an awesome job in comparison to B2. Though there're some elements which might require some getting used to and those are: space setting, futuristic music, vacuum environment. From my own experience I can say that I got hooked only after 5-10 hours of gameplay which is funny because I had quite the opposite situation with BL2. 
TPS even managed to get me into grinding, not because I couldn't defeat a certain boss(as it was in B2) but because I was enjoying the game. 
Now, with that said, I want to add that the game is unpolished: poorly made textures, stucking enemies and NPCs, unfinished characters' lines, lines interrupting one another - those are the ones that lie on the surface but I'm certain it's not the end of the list.
It's a real shame that the game didn't get the time and attention it deserves because it definitely has much more to give.

Often overshadowed by Borderlands 2, but really adds some unique mechanics and a slick presentation. Playing all the games in a row makes the differences really stand out, and in some ways this playthough is my favorite of the series. I love the jump slams, the planets and environments and think the characters are the most interesting to me.  

The downside is how the gameplay loop really just ends after the final boss - the new game+ is really good and adds new dialogue, yes, but the pacing in the first quarter does throw off the fun of a second run. 

That all said, I love this game and think it is underrated. On sales is the best way to get it, but if you like any other games in the series and slept on this, it's 100% worth it.

I honestly can't say this is worth your time or money. 
It's a short romp in the BL universe with very poor, uninspired dialogue that tries too hard to be funny or edgy and sadly, consistently misses the mark in a big way, not to mention you are forced to listen to everything. All the time. Everywhere. There is no skip cinematic/dialogue button (AGAIN!) and with this game copy pasting the TVHM & UVHM from BL 2 you have to sit through this schlock 3 times just to get a max level character. I'm not even there yet, but the thought of having to do this is definitely turning me off the game in the long run. 

Combat is largely unchanged, super inaccurate ADS, any weapon under purple rarity is practically useless, Legendaries and uniques so far have been usable at best, honestly they are more of the same shit from prvious games, "funny" shot patterns, non-stop nova shields, that kind of stuff, sure they added Lazers in this game but nothing that truly feels new and exciting. 
Quests consist almost primarily of fetch quests, so look forward to trekking through the same large, barren areas again, and again, and again, and again, and again, and again... You get the gist.

This is a lesser scion of greater ancestors, everything this games does it's predecessors did better. Every aspect of BL is overused and undercooked in this game. It feels like the gaming landscape evolved since BL2 but Gearbox and 2K decided to keep milking the desicated remains of this franchise. 

I still think BL 3 is the weakest BL game to date, but this is a close second. Avoid unless you are a fan of the series, but even then, wait til it's on sale.

[H1]So what's it about?[/H1] 
In Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel a new group of vault hunters learn the story of Handsome Jack and the Hyperion company. The events take place between BL1 and BL2 but it is a flashback so you should complete BL2 first to avoid spoilers.

[H1]The good[/H1]
It has one of the best BL intros that I have seen so far: great music, a good story and cool visuals. There are six character classes to pick from - you can even play as Claptrap and the Doppelganger of Handsome Jack. The level design is different to that of BL2 - you play mostly on the moon for 2/3 of the game; so there is more of a space theme. There is less gravity on the moon and even the sound is different. 

Even though the game was released in 2014 the graphics are good. The HD texture pack helps although I ran into similar issues as with BL2 when playing the Claptastic DLC: the game is 32 bit and when it tries to address more than 4GB VRAM it will crash. The solution was to lower PhysicX and save often.

Most of the mechanics that made BL2 amazing are still present. The developer improved a couple of them: 
[olist]
[*] Vehicles are more interesting and have better weaponry. 
[*] In BL2 you could indicate whether an item was favourite, junk or no status. This is changed to if an item is not your favourite it's junk to improve the speed of selling it. 
[*] There are laser weapons.
[*] There is a crafting station called the grinder: add three weapons or combine it with other items and it will generate something new.
[/olist]

There are some great easter eggs hidden in the game.

[SPOILER]It's good that on normal there is a secret "raid" boss (Iwajira) that is do-able solo and you don't even have to pay any special currency[/SPOILER]

[H1]The not so good[/H1]
Why are there ads in the main menu in a full priced game?

There are so many tedious fetch quests in the game. There is also quite a lot of backtracking even in the main quests. As the environment isn't that interesting it feels like a drag. It felt that these mechanisms were put in to make the game feel longer than it really should be. If the fetch quests were not annoying enough, jump puzzles are added. The walking mechanics feel not as snappy as before: it's like you're skating. 

The game starts slow - especially if you already have completed BL1 and BL2: the first two hours you walk slowly over the moonscape with easy missions until you unlock your first vehicle. I wish there was an option to skip this part for returning players. Then the pace changes from a lot of stuff going on to almost nothing especially when you are back-tracking most of the time. What also doesn't help is that the great songs from BL2 are no longer there - I didn't find any music appealing. 

Most areas blend into each other; unlike BL2 or even BL1 where you could feel things were different when you enter a new location, in The Prequel it's all pretty much the same: there is not a soul to it, itâ€™s mostly generic. This changes when you get to the space station though - that is definitely the better part of the game.

The developers fell back to the BL1 DLC philosophy with "less fast travel points = better?". Unfortunately, it's not and the work around is to just save-quit to main menu and then continue. It will have you start at the closest exit or fast travel point so you can quickly go to where you want to be.

Glitches:
[olist]
[*] Jack tried to "moon walk" into the elevator but got stuck on the elevator; I had to restart. 
[*] My character suddenly exploded while driving the moon buggy. 
[*] I had to manually collect money (like BL1) at several points.
[*] A mission objective was dropped out of the world: I had to restart the mission to complete it.
[*] At the Hyperion Hub of Heroism the screen got a yellow filter applied over all graphics. Something similar happened to the Eleseer level - possibly a limitation of the engine?
[*] Picking Up The Pieces: getting up on one of the pillars was glitchy - it took 14 attempts to hit the right spot and suddenly the pillar became walkable.
[*] Bugs can crawl through solid glass. 
[*] The mission Z8N-TP got stuck and it was not possible to progress further. Only when I completely quit the game and returned could I progress.
[*] The raid boss fight crashed every time I used my rocket launcher. I had to do the fight without it otherwise the game would just crash. 
[*] After I closed the game sometimes I couldn't restart using the desktop shortcut and I had to launch from Steam.
[*] I had multiple CTD while playing the Claptastic DLC.
[/olist]

Some achievements can be missed. Other achievements are multiplayer only. If you are unaware or can't find up to three friends to play with you, you won't be able to get 100% (and even if you do there are glitches that can stop progress on certain quests). 

The map achievements require that you need to find every single named location. This means you may have to click on something that is in the map even though you explored everything. [SPOILER]A great guide is given by [url=https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=330160497] JagarKlato on Steam [/url][/SPOILER]

Some of the enemy hit boxes are not correct causing you to miss a target when you should have hit it. 

The voice acting is super annoying at times. Other time it is (also) performed badly; like some dude just winged while sitting inside a bathroom.

None of the bosses are interesting or memorable. 

[H1]The DLCs[/H1]
There are three DLCs that offer some new missions and locations (my rating: [x/5]). You should play them after you've completed the main game.

[olist]Claptastic Voyage[5/5]: Jack needs to get data that was put into Claptraps mind. Through a mind melt it's your task to retrieve it from the inside. This is one of the best BL DLCs that I've played. Amazing level design, interesting enemies and a good story. There is lots to discover with high level loot (including a new type of weapons), easter eggs and mechanics. The best of all: the great BL music is back. I really enjoyed it and consider it the best part of the Pre-Sequel (the side missions in the DLC were not so good and you can safely ignore those). 
[/olist]

[olist]Shock Drop Slaughter Pit [0/5]: On a map you have to fight five rounds of three waves of scaves. It's terrible. 
[/olist]

[olist]The Holodome Onslaught [2/5]: In six rounds of which each has three or more waves, you need to defeat the same enemies over and over again. The area is too large and the space floating mechanics don't help either. The DLC rewards you for being a camper using a sniper rifle. There is some nice loot and cosmetics but the DLC is not good. The only challenge is to have enough ammo. [/olist]

[H1]Summary[/H1] 
Borderlands: The Prequel is not as epic like BL2 and it misses the atmosphere from BL1. It does offer some QoL improvements, but it is a shorter game and even then, it is still too long. Having completed the game, it would have been better just to cut the moon part out of it together with two of the DLCs. The game mechanics that made BL1 and BL2 great are put aside for a part, and the game is riddled with tedious backtracking, jump puzzle style fetch quests in areas that all look the same. 

It was quite glitchy and buggy as well. I was not having so much fun and found myself having to put the game down several times. I did continue and found that the last 1/3 of the game is much better. 

The Claptastic Voyage was fantastic and is one of the best BL DLCs that you can play. You can skip the other DLCs as they are not good. 

If you played BL1 and BL2 before then you should definitely play the Pre-Sequel and especially the Claptastic Voyage. If you have never played a Borderlands game before, then play at least BL2 before you start with the Pre-Sequel.

All in all, well worth it!

The story is better than both 1 and 2.  But there are big problems that make this game just not fun. The new setting is mostly to blame:

- fighting areas are bigger, so second wind is less valuable
- no atmosphere nerfs fire weapons
- enemies that butt slam with the new o2 jumping are very mobile, do high damage, and are bullet sponges
- tons of instant-death cliffs
- no atmosphere + low gravity + instant-death cliffs = tons of lost loot, including skins and moonstones
- laser weapons can't be dodged (even worse with bigger levels)
- flying enemies (not just aircraft) create a 3D fighting space (even worse with bigger levels)
- not a lot of fast travel points, at one point you won't return to the hub town for a considerable amount of time
- less side missions, that means you can't over-level for story missions like in Borderlands 2
- kraggons are just the worst
- enemies level-scale closer to the player, but that means a lot more dying
- most locations are just dead rock, not a lot of good variety
- DLC is weak
- enemies want to be below you so your butt slam is thwarted
Stupid game stupid IP block or some screwery.

Note: I played nowhere near this many hours in this game. Cut it in maybe 1/4 and it's there. I leave games running while I play for hours. When I eat, and sometimes even sleep. You COULD play this game that much, but I definitely didn't. 

OK...I guess I decided to finally play through this legit after quitting several times in the past due to boredom. 

This game gets a "Meh"/10. It has some interesting mechanics with the double jumping, and the slams, but overall feels quite hollow. Exactly like a game that lost corporate support halfway through its shelf life than predicted. 

I played through this only to finish the main story missions, and most of the side quests in one run. First time I played I quit midway through using whatever the Siren's name is in this one, and the second I used the DLC Doppleganger of Jack. A pretty bland character overall, with unexciting skill trees. 

The main story line is typical...whatever fare that this series has remains the same, but this one begins to slide into deeper levels than the previous ones as the perfect prequel to the more and more childish humor that time has passed, and dips it's toe a little bit into the cringe "identity" writing that follows. This game isn't quite yet there on the super annoying part, although has a few of those annoying characters in it like the girl "scientist" using the stupid sci-fi TV tropes that came around that time like "SCIENCE! F** YEAH!", and as dumb as "EXPERIMENTS! YAY!". Then of course failing miserably like all people who don't know s*** from Shinola would when pretending that watching a video makes them an expert on "science". 

Why I say it lacks depth is because the Main Story feels rather short, and the abundance of side missions you find in other entries feels to be very slim comparatively. 

The Season Pass consists of just one story DLC, which is a solid entry, "The Claptastic Voyage". The rest are the dreadful "Hollowdome" type of crap, and 2 extra characters. All the DLC can be obtained in the "Handsome Jack Collection", which also includes all of BL2, and has sold for as little as $5 many times. So never buy any of these 2 games outside of that pack. 

Let's talk a bit about Borderlands in general...

This game just makes me realize how stale the Borderland formula really is. The idea of creating a game where you can only upgrade to like half the total levels in a full run, then having to play a "more difficult", but identical runs, maybe even 3, or 4 like BL2 ended up as. Then having 6 characters in which you can do this as, making you have to play through the game no less than 12 times, while you experience IDENTICAL dialogue, and quests each of those times. Borderlands is the definition of tedium. 

Borderlands has even taken the same tactics that the Fallout series has in which they release games 1/4 of the way done, and require you to buy DLC, after DLC simply to just MAX LEVEL your character. BL3 split this up into TWO Season Passes btw. Using the "+10 Levels" formula as Season Pass portions, while giving you yet another stupid non-story DLC each time because they know you wouldn't buy them without the level increases. This one includes 2 new playable characters, Doppleganger Jack, and The Baroness. Jack is super boring skill trees, and the Baroness I haven't played, but it seems she's a beast with guns. Especially pistols. 

Unlike the Fallout series, however the amount of content provided for one play through isn't even remotely close to "Max Level" your characters in one run. So you are left with what I described above, playing through the game dozens of times. Achievements to get 100% are also made to force you to play through the game a minimum of 4 times, one with each main character to get them all. Not to mention, you have a handful of ONLINE ONLY achievements. Those you can likely cheat on with faking co-op partners, or whatever, but I don't care enough about cheevos to do anything remotely close to any of that. 

This series needs to improve their formula. Maybe make the game long enough, with enough quests, that even with the extra levels you can Max out in one playthrough. TVHM doesn't need to exist. Quests can easily open up, as they are all leveled quests as it is. Enemies level up. Everything levels up with you, so all you need is just a LONGER main story line, and more side quests that are consolidated into ONE playthrough. With a minimum of 4 characters in the main game alone, it would still be quite tedious to trudge through the same game 4 times, but at least the content would be much deeper, and you wouldn't have to play the exact same game 12 times. 

Also, this game has an easy formula that can be fixed entirely by doing one thing: STOP HIRING ACTIVISTS TO WRITE FOR VIDEO GAMES. Hire real writers, who aren't just out of woke college, and let them write coherent, well structured stories, with character development that isn't designed to make you cringe. "Condescending" isn't funny as EVERY JOKE. Watch this video to understand what NOT to do in writing anymore please:

https://youtu.be/FyHG8EfcA5c

6/10 game probably. If you like Borderlands it's passable, and has some interesting mechanics that won't be seen in any other BL game. Not to mention that the Borderlands 1 Eridium aliens come back to the main storyline to fight again, which were always awesome enemies. 

Tl;dr: Boo!

I will preface my recommendation with the fact that I only recommend this game to veterans of the Borderlands series. It has some decent story beats, helps expand the lore, and the Vault Hunters are all pretty interesting.

That said, the game suffers from a bunch of issues that make it hard to recommend for extended play. The biggest problem being the movement mechanics. 

Everything feels extremely clunky. Low gravity is literally painful as everything feels like you are moving through molasses. Then, the regular gravity sections feel bad after getting used to the low gravity stuff.

Movement in video games should be consistent and fluid and this drops the ball something fierce.

These movements only accentuate the issues with Borderlands' core gameplay loop of "do thing -> stop to deal with issue -> go deal with another issue - finish thing"

Borderlands The Pre-Sequel is a good game, occasionally great, that is seen less fondly on due to comparisons to Borderlands 2. This is in no part thanks to the fact that it did not get as much post-release support as Borderlands 2, due to 2K Australia's closure in early 2014. It lacks in endgame content, but has some unique ideas, the zero-gravity being the largest, along with a charming cast of characters that I think sets it apart from 2.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is an incredibly fun and engaging game that is sure to please fans of the original Borderlands series. The game features a huge arsenal of weapons, an engaging story, and an impressive cast of characters. The visuals are top notch, and the action is intense. The combat system is very rewarding, offering a variety of ways to take on enemies. The game also features a huge selection of sidequests, making it easy to get lost in the world of Pandora. Overall, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is an exciting and rewarding experience that will keep players coming back for more.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is an outstanding game that takes place between the events of the first and second games in the series. The game follows the story of four new vault hunters as they explore the moon of Pandora and work with Handsome Jack to uncover the secrets of a powerful weapon. The game features the same addictive and engaging gameplay as the previous installments, with the addition of new mechanics such as low-gravity environments and oxygen management, adding a new level of strategy to combat and exploration. The game's unique setting on the moon of Pandora offers a refreshing change of scenery for long-time fans of the series. The game's storyline is well-written, with memorable characters and plenty of humor to keep players entertained. The game also introduces new playable characters, each with their own skill trees and abilities, allowing players to try out different playstyles and strategies. The game's co-op mode is exceptional, allowing players to team up with friends and experience the game's challenges together. Overall, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is an excellent addition to the series, offering players a fresh take on the franchise while still retaining the elements that made the previous games so enjoyable.

Having given this game a second chance after a false start a few years ago ([strike]because Claptrap is bad[/strike]), it's absolutely a worthy entry in the Borderlands series that I intend to revisit in the future.

[u]Note:[/u] I played Nisha through 3 playthroughs of the main story, 2 playthroughs of Claptastic Voyage, and 1 playthrough of the Holodome. I also "speedran" TVHM, beating it in about 7 hours to get on to UVHM as fast as possible. I ended at LV62 with about 80 hours of Steam time or 2:14:00:00 in-game.

First of all, there's a lot of small additions, tweaks, and quality of life adjustments made versus Borderlands 2.
+ Stat scaling is sort of a hybrid of the systems from Borderlands 1 and 2. For example, starting damage/health/etc in TPS is closer to that of BL1 than BL2. You also level up at the same XP values in all three, but TPS is shorter than 2, so you don't level quite as far in each playthrough (and skill tree progression is tweaked as a result). This is a refreshing change (one of many) that keeps the game from feeling like a reskin.
+ Very very good class design with tons of depth. I played Nisha, and coming from Gaige in BL2, Nisha feels broadly similar to play, but with a way more nuanced skill tree. I could tell that there are tons of slightly different adjustments you can make to skill point allocation to tweak your skills to fit your loadout. As just one example, you could build Nisha with an Oz kit that focuses on improving gun damage, and consequently spec more into skills focused on fire rate, movement speed, and health regen.
+ Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode is noticeably easier than BL2, as enemies do not have health regen. It can be annoyingly challenging at times in BL2, so I welcomed this change.
+ The oxygen mechanic adds one more thing to keep track of, but generally speaking it's pretty easy to do so. This adds depth without feeling too annoying. Suffocation is rarely an issue in practical gameplay.
+ The grinder is a cool new way to deal with an excess of loot. I have some less positive things to say about it, but I'm glad it was added to the game, because it constantly changes how you approach inventory management, and can potentially make useless trash useful again. You may hold onto items 3-4 levels below your level in the case that you can get a high-damage blue or purple from the grinder. But, when you get to LV50+, you may only want to hold onto items 1-2 levels below, if that.
+ Although the item pool is smaller, there are some really cool new items, especially unique guns and shields -- Boomacorn, The Machine, MINAC's Atonement, E-GUN, Haymaker, etc. More thoughts on uniques later.
â€¢ The ability to mark an item as trash in inventory was removed.

Let's talk about low gravity...
+ On the one hand, it's fun to be able to jump long distances, and boost and slam as movement mechanics adds a whole new dimension to the skill ceiling. Mastering these skills can make combat way more fun!
â€¢ On the other hand, [i]the map design can make it way too easy to die due to the low gravity[/i]. I will call out Triton Flats in particular. It's a nightmare for vehicles, as you can very easily run into bad geometry trying to jump over a chasm, fall into lava, and die. (And, even as a massive Borderlands fan, I have to admit that some of the geometry in these games is impressively bad.) Similarly, the Drakensberg can be really bad for being blown off a ledge into the abyss, or falling to your death from a jump pad.
â€¢ On the subject of map design, the extra distance you cover is counteracted by the more spread-out and larger maps. This can run the risk of making travel feel slow and cumbersome.
- It always feels bad when you kill an enemy and their drops get launched at Mach 5 into the void, especially when those items are [i]mission items[/i]. For example, I had to relog into Stanton's Liver during one mission because a mission item was launched out of the map.

Now for nitpicks that stuck out during repeated playthroughs:
â€¢ A little too much dialogue that felt nagging or dragged the pace. Some missions I ended up outrunning the objectives of, because I knew where to go already.
â€¢ The raid boss is pathetic. I had never beaten a raid boss before because in BL1 and BL2 they're actually hard.
â€¢ The drop box for "To Arms" is located inside a bandit camp, so that means every time you deposit guns, you have to deal with a turret, a bunch of bandits, and potentially shugguraths. :(
â€¢ There are several Fast Travel stations that I would move or add, or one-way Fast Travels that I would make two-way, just for the sake of reducing the amount of travel. For example, the Outlands Canyon and Holodome stations are a bit out of the way. [b]Furthermore, I really dislike the Veins of Helios, and the lack of a Fast Travel there contributes to that.[/b]

Other nitpicks.
â€¢ I think uniques are a little bit too common or overpowered. You can easily obtain Boomacorn and E-GUN, which together are a disgustingly powerful combination that can last for multiple levels. Don't get me wrong, they're awesome weapons, but they're a little *too* meta.
â€¢ The blue color of Oz is too similar to the blue rarity. You adjust to it, but it was annoying at first.
â€¢ The side missions on Helios feel like a drag at times.
â€¢ The level cap of 70 is too high to reach in normal gameplay, IMO. It requires grinding or a fourth playthrough.
â€¢ To avoid the RNG of the grinder, you may need to ALT+F4 over and over. This makes the game very unhappy. Sure, moonstones exist, but the cost of a moonstone grind is too expensive to justify doing it regularly. Also, there are combinations that you can't use moonstones with, so you're forced to bash your head against the RNG if you want a legendary.
