[h1]Borderlands: The Pre-Seqel[/h1]

[h1]"Hello, old friend. Been a while, hasn't it?
Let me tell you a story."[/h1]

[h1]Introduction:[/h1]
Where to begin? I'll begin with the release of the new DLC for Borderlands 2, why there? Because I have played Borderlands games 1&2 mostly so many times that I don't feel like playing anymore anytime soon. That doesn't mean I don't love the game, it is, in fact, one of my beloved game franchises on my list of favorite games. The history and connection I have with this game is astounding. Now, where does the new DLC for Borderlands 2 factor into all of this you may ask? When I first played it, I remembered just how many fun Borderlands is when you play something new. It was so fun that I wanted to play some new, while Pre-Sequel wasn't exactly new because I did play it way back on the Xbox 360, it felt new as I had played years ago and only once. Whereas with Borderlands 1&2 I played countless times exceeding to at least the number 20. 

And let me tell you, a lot of people have mixed opinions on the game, some will even go as far to say that it is the worst Borderlands game to date. I will disagree, the game is essentially a clone of Borderlands 2 with some new gameplay features. I wouldn't say it's a clone in terms of locations, story and even gameplay but it is a clone in terms of the looks, art style and graphics of Borderlands 2, even has many of the issues that Borderlands 2 has.

[h1]The Story:[/h1]
The story of Pre-Sequel is a direct Sequel to Borderlands 1 and a Pre-Sequel to Borderlands 2. It tells the story of some of the most well-known characters of Borderlands 1&2. Athena the ex Atlas employee, Wilhelm the Cyborg in Borderlands 2, Nisha the sheriff of Lyncwood and CL4T-P with his FR4GTP combat mode. Yes, Claptrap is in Pre-Sequel and you get to play as him, love the little guy. <3 all four of you are recruited by Jack, back when he was a low-level programmer on Hyperion and you're tasked with finding the secret Vault on Pandora's moon. Elpis. Only for that to be put on the side as an abandoned DAHL Brigade now known as the DAHL Lost Legion invades the under construction Eye of Helios in order to stop Jack and destroy the Vault on the moon. [b](Figures, DAHL loves to abandon their own people.)[/b] You're forced to now deal with not only an ex-Military unit but you also have to survive the wildlife on Elpis as well as it's local inhabitants.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
â— Great plot [b](Not as good as Borderlands 2 but still very good.)[/b]
â— Great character development [b](Learn how Jack rose to power and became the sadistic villain he is, learn how Claptrap ended up becoming the last robot in his production line, learn how Athena coped with her life after the fall of Atlas and more!)[/b]

â— Lots of character comments [b](The player characters in Borderlands 2 were pretty dead, they rarely spoke apart from the usual battle chatter but never commented on missions and such, in TPS, the characters voice their opinions and minds on various topics making them feel more alive and developed.)[/b]

â— Lots of fun and awesome side quests
â— Steam Achievements
â— Steam trading cards
â— Well crafted soundtrack
â— Awesome playable characters
â— Very fun action skill & skill trees for characters
â— CO-OP

â— Cyro weaponry [b](Since it takes place before Borderlands 2, Slag hasn't been invented yet as an element and we instead have Cyro which let me go on record and say that it is 10x better than Slag. Slag sucks. Cyro rocks. Freezing enemies and shattering them is lots of fun.)[/b]

â— Laser weapons [b](Alongside Cyro, we also have four different types of lasers, I have always wanted for Borderlands to add more unique and crazy weapons, I hope to see more in Borderlands 3. If you're sick of constantly having to use the same weapons all the time, you will be happy to find out that the four different types of laser rifles in TPS are lots of fun.[/b]

â— More fluent movement [b](I love Borderlands 2, but playing TPS and then going back to Borderlands 2 feels wrong. The lack of double jumping, slamming and boost jumping is so much fun and it's a change that is really badly needed in Borderlands 3. Luckily we will have that change, there will sliding, barrel kicking and most likely lots more.)[/b]

â— Awesome DLC [b](Claptastic Voyage)[/b]
â— Well designed surface and locations

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
â— Unoptimized for higher-end hardware [b](GTX 10 series, RTX series etc:)[/b]

â— Locations can get boring over time [b](You're on the moon in the end, there is only so much that you can do make the surface of the moon look unique, whilst I love the locations and I think it is very well designed, some people might get bored of the same locations over and over.)[/b]

â— Unfinished DLC [b](There was supposed to be another DLC for TPS called Luxy's Space Adventure, honestly when I learned about it I was extremely saddened and quite pi**ed, the entire premise of the DLC sounded so awesome and if you ask me. TPS needed a DLC like it but it ended up being canceled because of the poor sales of TPS making the DLC unfinished leaving you with only one story DLC and two-character packs. If you would like to learn more about it then check out this [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=wDSEEILN7QA]video.[/url][/b])

[h1]Conclusion:[/h1]
If you're looking forward to Borderlands 3 like I am but have to wait till next year because of the Epic Bulls**t then this game will keep occupied for a while. Pre-Sequel is not a terrible game, it is a good game, sure it has some issues but no game is ever perfect, Pre-Sequel does improve upon may features from Borderlands 2 whilst still remaining that fun action-packed looter shooter. You will without a doubt get a good enjoyable experience wherever you purchase this game to play solo or CO-OP, full price or even heavily discounted. It won't be as long as Borderlands 2 but if you're planning to do multiple playthroughs then you will easily rack up 100 hours if not more. 

[h1]Overall rating 8.5/10[/h1]

This game has the best vault hunters out of every Borderlands game. It just suffers the unfortunate fate of getting a bad launch and a subsequent content cut off. This is worth your time, and I say it is best enjoyed with the Exodus or community patch mods. If play Borderlands for the interesting abilities on Vault Hunters and the build-crafting with them, you might just love this game more than Borderlands 2 like I do. I'm serious, the BL2 vault hunters look uninspired in comparison to this game.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a game that offers a lot of familiar fun for fans of the Borderlands series. The humor is still there, the weapons are still crazy, and the loot is still addictive. However, the game also suffers from some notable drawbacks that may frustrate players.

On the positive side, the game features some new gameplay elements that add to the fun. Players can now jump higher and further with the low gravity on the moon, which leads to some interesting combat scenarios. Additionally, there are new classes to play as, each with unique abilities and skill trees to explore.

Unfortunately, the game also suffers from some issues that may turn off some players. One of the most notable is the repetitive mission design. While the game still offers plenty of loot and shooting, the missions themselves can feel like they're just going through the motions. Additionally, the game's story is not as strong as its predecessors, leaving something to be desired for those who enjoyed the narrative in previous Borderlands games.

Another issue that may frustrate some players is the game's difficulty spikes. Some missions can be particularly challenging, with enemies dealing massive amounts of damage and the player's health and shields dwindling quickly. This can lead to some frustrating moments, especially when playing solo.

Overall, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a game that offers plenty of familiar fun for fans of the series, but it also suffers from some notable drawbacks. The new gameplay elements are interesting, but the repetitive mission design and weaker story may turn some players off. Additionally, the difficulty spikes can be frustrating at times. However, for those who love the Borderlands series and can overlook these issues, the game still offers plenty of loot and shooting fun.

I never understood what people at the time did not like about this game. The most common criticism I heard was "It should have been a BL2 DLC", but BL2 already had more DLC (and mostly good, at that) than any other game I have ever encountered, and TPS has enough different mechanics (low-gravity, oxygen management, cryo element) that I think it deserved its own release. The other criticism was that it's the same engine as BL2, but again, that game is so wildly popular and universally beloved that this criticism is null. TPS has its own slew of DLC, 6 playable characters, and a fairly interesting story, not to mention the same (if not slightly improved) gameplay as BL2. I think people just wanted their minds blown like BL2 did, not realizing that it would be the series' high water mark. TPS is a perfectly good game and a fresh coat of paint on the top-tier co-op experience people have come to expect from Borderlands.

so much better than the first game, and in some aspects it's better than the second. characters respond to mission dialogue and the dialogue is much funnier than the first or the second game from my knowledge so far. a lot of the first game's dialogue is cheesy and repetitive, and the second game's dialogue is cocky, overconfident, and stereotypical heroic attitude. the hero of the story slowly becomes the anti-hero, and you can see this progression throughout the game. it's got a great ending to it, and many of the people you come across in the first game appear in the second. the cutscenes are awesome and the story goes full-circle.the only things i dislike in this game is janey springs and tiny tina. these two have the most annoying voices i've ever heard in a video game, and tinas' missions are the most annoying wastes of time in the whole game. that's all i can really think of for the downsides to this game for me, but i have to say so far in the series that it's my favorite.

Firstly,let me just say this game,at it's core storyline,is not a bad game.
It's what the developers built around the storyline that left something to be desired.
I enjoyed Borderlands 2. Played it...well,alot. Over and over. (That,along with other games
like it,is my background for this commentary.)
 On my play-through as Athena,I started to notice the game made you walk/run alot. If there
might have been a good spot for a fast travel,or an option to shorten that desert you had to
slog across,the game devs did not take the option. I slogged. On stopping for awhile and
quitting out of the game,I returned later to continue my progress only to find myself back at
the place I had started that area of the game. Forced to slog some more through baddies and 
navigate hazards again. And again. Annnnnnd..... You get the idea. Slog. That,and practically
anything you could think of that would make a game like this tedious. i.e. overly difficult 
opposition (for a first play-through). Playing though the story missions,you complete an area
and,in the context of the events taking place,proceed quickly to the next area. But when you
arrive you see the enemies all have little warning skulls next to their names. Yup. You need at
least 2 more levels before going on.
 And this happens quite a bit. So. I give this game 4 out of 5 'slogs'. And one big 'Why?'
Didn't the developers play this through themselves? Don't they know better,as professionals,
than to add immersion-breaking situations into a storied game? Flow? 
 Sorry. But not 'sorry'. And,believe it or not,it's still hard to give this game a thumbs down.
Because I'm a fan. But... Slog! Grrrrr.
...And another thing to the devs: The video game tradition of the 'Boss fight' goes back decades.
But...you've changed it,or at least taken the most tedious of options:
 The player fights the 'Boss' to the death,overcoming several minutes worth of hazards that challenge
his/her reflexes and skills. The reward? Another,fully refreshed Boss?!?! Like many things in games these days,you can't just give the player a bit of well-earned satisfaction? I mean,that's the other option. 
 I won't deny the apparent miles of hard work put into this game. Don't deny the players,please.

This game was SO MUCH better than Borderlands 2. 

1) The dry humor i grew to love from BL1 makes a comeback. No more cringy incest jokes from BL2 Scooter.
2) The original Vault Hunters, for as little as you see them, act like their own selves again. No peabrain Roland, no lovestruck middle schooler Lilith, no drunkard Mordecai, and no "i'm a white gangsta" Brick.
3) The gameplay feels like it was created for singleplayer again, but optional co-op. No massive armies of enemies, no bullet sponge bosses and no getting melted within 3 seconds anymore.
4) You get to play as a CL4P-TR4P and it's actually a GOOD class instead of just being comic relief.
5) Having the Vault Hunter you play as actually comment on stuff makes them feel a lot more alive, like an actual person instead of a NPC. 
6) Pickle is the best Bri'ish lad, i say.

The only gripe i really had with this game was that it froze up on 4 occasions. This always seemed to happen whenever an enemy with a laser or elemental attack would strike me in melee range, as if the overload of close up particle effects froze up the engine. Luckily this never lead to massive setbacks because of the properly placed checkpoints, and was quite easily remedied by mastering the art of sniper rifle headshots. It's definitely my favorite entry in the 3 games i have played so far. Will check out BL3 in the future.

On launch this game was pretty mediocre. No offense to 2k Australia (RIP), they did a good job making a spin off of a pre-existing IP with a particular audience/gameplay type. 

The issue with TPS was/is mainly the lack of content. You've basically just got the main campaign, and then one DLC (Claptrap's). Two other DLCs are just for characters, and the others are garbage slaughter domes that have been a staple tacked onto every borderlands game. It's nice in moderation but very played out and needs to be done well (Torgue's in BL2). Aka not the main DLC for a game and not costing $10 for 20minutes of repetitive gameplay. 


Likewise, there are 2 major bosses you can fight endgame. Prior installments had several, and you could farm a ton of other bosses later in the game to get better legendary weapons to face said bosses. This game has none of those. A ton of the bosses are not able to be fought again and even more are in really annoying locations to run back to for farming. No invincibles, no great farming spots, etc. When people complained, Randy Shitford said go buy/play another game franchise (even though these were staples features of the game series you incompetent *****)

The gameplay is smooth and the verticality helps it stay fresh nearly a decade later. The base gameplay is great and outside of some slowdowns running through some long slog areas the base campaign and Claptraps voyage are really good. 

With the price its on sale for half the time its a great deal. It's mainly the fact that it comes after two fantastic videogame mainstays without their content but charging the same price. Whether or not that doomed 2k Australia is beyond me, but I'd hope that wasn't the nail in the coffin. They did good and the Aussie wit and their attempt at a Borderlands entry is great.
It's been a royal blast!

This is easily the worst Borderlands game.

Enemy respawns are neverending and happen very fast (of course ammo crates don't respawn). Every time you kill 1 enemy 2-3 new ones will spawn out of thin air all around you. Then on top of this they put in TIMED missions with very little time to do them. So you have to run through the chaos of neverending enemies and turrets etc. trying to do the mission without having the time to clear them out. All the while one of the incredibly annoying voice actors jabber along without you having any chance of hearing what they say.

This is just an example of how the game works. It's utter chaos and just an annoying experience to play. Wonder if they ever tried playing it themselves. Can't imagine it. Seems to me like they just threw in random content without any thought as to how it would all work together.

As someone who loved the previous Borderlands games, I was really looking forward to playing Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel. However, I have to say that I was really disappointed with this game. While the gameplay and humor are still present, the game just didn't feel as engaging as its predecessors. It feels like the game developers were trying to milk the franchise for all it's worth, without really adding anything new to the game.

One of the major problems with this game is the lack of content. The main story is short and doesn't provide much replayability. The side quests are fun but ultimately don't add much to the overall experience. Furthermore, the game suffers from a lack of variety in terms of enemies, environments and weapons. This made the game feel repetitive and boring after a while.

Another issue I had with the game was the character customization. While the previous games had a wide range of character customization options, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel felt like a step back. The characters look and feel uninspired, with limited options for customization. This was a real letdown for me, as I enjoy creating unique and interesting characters to play as.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel. While the game has its moments, it just doesn't measure up to the previous games in the franchise. If you're a die-hard fan of the series, you may enjoy it, but if you're new to the franchise, I would suggest starting with the earlier games.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a fun and entertaining addition to the Borderlands franchise. The game's setting on the moon adds a new level of excitement and danger to the gameplay, with low gravity and oxygen levels affecting the player's movements and abilities. The game's writing is just as sharp and witty as the previous games, with new characters and old favorites adding to the game's overall appeal. The new playable characters are a welcome addition, each with their own unique abilities and playstyles. The game's co-op mode is just as fun as the previous games, allowing players to team up and take on the game's challenges together. Overall, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a great addition to the franchise and a must-play for fans of the series.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is one special kind of Fuster Kluck, So I think at this point most people who are looking into buying this game knows what the Borderlands games are, so I'm not going to explain all the little details about the game as a whole if you are looking to get into the Borderlands game series I'd say start with Borderlands 2 or 3 but if you are already a fan of the games and are wondering if this one is worth it then I think I can help with that!


Starting off with the story, while the Borderlands games aren't really known for good writing I think Pre-Sequel can stand on its own pretty well and does get a few laughs out of me every now and again but it's not a cinematic masterpiece by any means. It's great to hear more from Jack as Dameon Clarke did a great job voicing him, as he did in 2, and the banter from the vault hunters and other NPCs' is fairly charming and quite funny at times, The motive and descent into madness are fine but not overly focused on with is a bit of a shame as the whole point of this game is to be a Pre-Sequel to Borderlands 2, with Jacks descent into insanity feeling somewhat forced at times, but overall I can still say I somewhat like the story, though I guess as long as it's somewhat amusing I don't really mind the holes in it.


The gameplay is fairly good, Heck I even think it's a step above 2 at times! The Vault Hunters have more to their skill trees and more interesting abilities to boot with the DLC Characters in mind you have a diverse cast of characters to choose from, Athena the Gladiator a tanky and melee focused Character, Nisha the Lawbringer a high damage gunslinger, Wilhelm the Enforcer an allrounder Summoner type, and...Fragtrap, And the two DLC Characters are, Jack the Doppelganger a different flavor of Summoner that's made to look and sound like Jack And Aurelia the Baroness a cold-hearted hunter that does high damage at far ranges, with an ensemble like this it makes replaying the game a lot of fun and its even more fun with friends. the quest design however can be a bit lacking as most side quests lack diversity and while the main quests are fun the bosses leave something to be desired. The biggest disappointment was with legendary weapons, legendary weapons make up a huge part of what makes the Borderlands games so fun, and in this game, there is just a lack of spawn locations which makes the whole game feel a bit hollow as instead of killing a boss and getting some sweet loot you mostly just get Moonstone and some nothing weapons. The late game as a whole is lacking for the former reason and there's just not any real endgame content outside of New Game Plus which I'm not counting here while it's a big part of the Borderlands games it would be nice to have something else to do post ending besides killing one raid boss and finishing up all the side quests you missed.


The Graphics are pretty good, and a lot of the areas are well-lit with funky colors which makes them pop out more, everything has that signature cell-shaded look which helps it still look good 9 years later, and the general art direction is fairly decent, the weapons look great, even though the iron sights suck, the environment is often times gorgeous with some of my favorite areas being the nice reds and light blues of the early game, the fake industrial lighting of the Hyperion space station and the deep purple of the later game areas, really I think they knocked it out of the park on the visual design!


The music is kind of forgettable...that is all, hell as I was writing this I had to go back and write that the music exists I guess, nothing groundbreaking.


And Finally the DLC, ill keep it short. I've already talked about the DLC characters and I do really like them, it is just the other three that I think are...subpar. I won't add to the negative reviews on The Holodome Onslaught as I think it's fineish just a waste of money to buy it really as it doesn't add much and the 10 extra levels are incidental at best, I haven't and won't get the Shock Drop Slaughter Pit...I just won't. Finally, the Claptastic Voyage is fine, not great, and not terrible, if you can get it on sale then I'd say do so as the environments are still really cool, the ending is cathartic and the glitched weapons are pretty neat but that's about it really as the story is pretty bland overall the Claptrap is well... Claptrap so I guess buy at your own risk.


My closing thoughts even though my review isn't the most positive in the world is still one of my favorites Borderlands games as I think what it brings to the table is fairly unique looking at the franchise as a whole however I do understand why some people do not like or even hate this game as its nothing outstanding and it came after that titan that is Borderlands 2. Overall I can recommend this game but if you are still a bit iffy about it then I'd say if you want to play it wait on a sale first and get some friends together, just make sure to bully whoever plays Claptrap.

I've played a lot of game sequels that have been panned by their fans in my time as a PC gamer. [i]Mass Effect: Andromeda[/i], [i]Dead Space 3[/i], and [i]BioShock: Infinite[/i] are all games that I would describe as being heavily flawed, but still possessing a solid foundation in one way or another. I wouldn't ever lump this game in with the others though, as I consider it to be one of the most underappreciated sequels in gaming. 

Developed by the now-defunct 2K Australia, and set in-between the first and second Borderlands titles, [i]Borderlands: The Pre-sequel[/i] has you take on the role of one of four vault hunters hired by Hyperion to find a vault on Pandora's moon, Elpis. However, rather than focus on the hunt for the vault, the vast bulk of the game is spent chronicling the descent of a man named Jack into the villain known as Handsome Jack. You see him go from an affable antihero to a despot who will stop at nothing to take his revenge on those who slight him. 

[h1]PROS:[/h1]

 - Possibly the best set of playable characters in the series, with a diverse set of abilities, and what I consider to be the best character progression system in the series. 

 - Weapons feel far more diverse than BL2, although it still doesn't feel nearly as fleshed out as BL1s guns. Two new additions to the weapon generation system- the laser weapon type and the cryo elemental type- are fantastic additions that greatly enhance the player experience. 

 - The low-gravity movement and oxygen system is a fantastic addition that feels great to play around with, and gives players much more mobility through the game world. 

 - Other great gameplay features include the Grinder (which allows you to take old weapons and create newer and better weapons, meaning that even white-rarity weapons have a use now), bounce pads, and much faster access to character abilities than BL1 and BL2. 

 - Excellent character writing, including fully voiced player characters, a series first. 

 - Level design, while slightly less open than the second game, is well-done, with a wide variety of locations. 

 - The art style has also changed from the post-apocalyptic setting of Pandora to a more space-age look befitting Elpis. 

 - Music is also less western-inspired, and has a much greater focus on electronic instruments and synth-music. 

[h1]CONS:[/h1]

 - As a player character, Claptrap suffers from a very random special ability that often makes him a liability in multiplayer and singleplayer alike. The fact that the series' pet punching bag is also the fourth playable character is also quite annoying, as you will have to endure his frakking voice for twenty hours of the campaign if you pick him as your vault hunter. 

 - Boss fights are both rarer than in BL2, and suffer from reduced quality, smaller loot tables, and were initially not replayable outside of a UVHM New Game + run. Indeed, Zarpadon still cannot be fought a second time to get any unique loot you missed, meaning her boss fight feels less rewarding from a extrinsically motivated perspective. 
 
 - The balancing in this game is extremely poor. I completed almost every side quest I came across, and still ran into beefy enemies who downed me very quickly in the end game. Even in the early game, you will often run into enemies who down you very quickly regardless of whether you've been grinding out levels and loot the entire time. 

 - While the story is fantastically written, it is one of the worst paced stories I've ever experienced, with a endgame that drags on for far too long, and suffers from extreme checkpoint starvation. Sidequests also dry up around the time you finish the Helios section of the game, so good luck getting more levels without endlessly grinding enemies in the world! 

[h1]CONCLUSION:[/h1]

Overall, I would say that fans are often way too harsh on this game, considering how much it experiments with the Borderlands formula. [i]Borderlands 3[/i], while I haven't played it yet, seems to be far weaker than this game, with the main antagonists being bloody [i]Twitch Streamers[/i] for crying out loud. While this game suffers from problems that could have been remedied with more resources and more post-launch content, it is far better as a story, and has far greater potential as a elevator pitch. 8.5/10, recommended.

I am never buying another Borderlands game again. I have bought the first and second games twice, once on Xbox, once on PC, both times because I was convinced people would play it with me. I don't know why I thought this time would be any different. I have no doubt this is a fun game, but games like this I only have fun when I get to enjoy them with my friends, I don't like playing them alone. I have tried, and tried, and tried to play this game by myself and I never can, I know I can turn on matchmaking but it's different playing games with a friend you've been playing games with for years and playing a game with a random person you have no connection with. I don't recommend this game because every time I try having fun in it I'm always shafted, every time I start having fun in it I get pulled to another game by the same people who got me to buy Borderlands in the first place. No, these games just aren't for me. When I know a game has the potential to play co-op with friends I can't have fun when I'm alone. I play single player games when I want to play a game alone.

Go play Borderlands 2 before buying this game. You'll be asking yourself why you're playing this game,  and most regular people who come across this game won't enjoy it.  
That's because most of the people who will ever decide to play this game is for the sole purpose of Knowing more about jack.  This game is a story about how Timothy Jack became Handsome jack...
This game is lacking in all aspects...that make it replayable.  I played through it once and can't replay it quite like BL2,  I'll try but sometimes I sadly have to force myself.  The only saving grace of this game is the DLC Claptastic Voyage.  That's a great story arc too because it features....Claptrap.  and I always loved claptrap.  He's the first face you see in both games.  
At this point of the review I'm just ranting about the game and my feelings towards the BL franchise....
I remember the first time I tried Borderlands 2.  It was for a free weekend.  and I tried it and played Co-op with my friend who reccomended it to me.  I remember doing the Bunker Run during a stormy night.  The storm was raging and I kept on playing BL2....sadly I had to log off that night because of it.  I couldn't wait to wake up and keep playing.  That's how good BL2  Is!!!  
 (at the time I couldn't really buy games because I Didnt get an allowance and I was too young btw to use a card or go to gamestop because my parents were very overprotective).  
I remember asking my best friend to go to gamestop for me and to buy me Borderlands 2.  I remember playing it all day and almost all night...
Borderlands 2 has a huge impact of my life....and the fact that 2K Australia abandoned this game really hurts because this game had potential...this game still has potential......it just needs some TLC and a couple more DLCs cmon.

It's a little buggy (never crashed though), but more fun than 2.

Adds low gravity, oxygen management, and double jump/boost to BL2 formula. Play as Claptrap if you don't want to deal with Oxygen BS (it's a tiny DoT if you run out). Unfortunately the world design is the same as 2 with invisible walls and fake objects/floors so you're always paranoid about what you can actually land on without getting pushed off or slipping through to your death, which kind of discourages exploration in some bits. I also constantly got stuck on...nothing (misplaced collision walls on the floor?) forcing me to jump to continue moving.

Maybe I got lucky, but weapon drops were much more generous than BL2 in my normal mode playthrough. 

The story (Jack's descent into madness) was good...when the audio isn't bugging out and skipping lines. It's a darker story obviously and the humor is about the same as 2.

The Claptrap DLC is the only one worth playing (after you beat the base game) and is on par w/ Tiny Tina's adventure.

Fun Videogame

Without a doubt, the worst follow-up to 2 that could have happened. The mechanics aren't fun, the gameplay isn't enjoyable, and it's definitely not a game you're likely to play solo successfully. It's like they took everything that wasn't fun from 2 and doubled down on it, then added new things along those lines to make this even worse. It took them a significant amount of time to even address the character types that were bizarrely omitted, that made previous games remotely enjoyable or even playable.

There are some inspired parts, but overall this isn't likely to keep you coming back. I can't imagine even if you liked the series that you would enjoy this. As someone who liked the first one fine but hasn't been that impressed by attempts to follow it up, this is just painful and not something anyone should really feel obligated to play, ever. Amusing voice acting here and there can't make up for how unpleasant this is to play. The oxygen mechanic alone only adds inconvenience, not complexity or more exciting gameplay, and thus becomes an obstacle to enjoyment rather than something that enhances it. It is a textbook example of a perhaps well-intentioned idea that was not realized well at all, and thus it brought down the quality of the whole by its inclusion.

Don't bother. Just get the original on sale sometime. That's the only one that's at all impressive.

OLD Review : I honestly believe that TPS was hated because it wasn't borderlands 2 again. It was different. It stood out compared to 1 and 2. The story was/is good, not as good as 2s but it IS a good story, the game-play mechanics were/are good(better than 2s in my opinion), the characters in it are individualistic and honestly had more life breathed into them here than in 1(once again BL2 had it better but that doesn't mean TPS isn't good.) People wanted to play the same game again but have it have the ' new game feeling '. 

TPS is worth $60 with all the DLC at this point, but I paid full price at release and still believe it was worth it. Lots of fun to be had. Worth the price, catch on a sale if you're skeptical of the game.

While this is far from the best Borderlands game it is definitely worth playing if you're a fan of the franchise. I really enjoy the gameplay overall, the new movement options this game brings with jump pads, O2 boosts, and low gravity makes it quite enjoyable to play and differentiates it from previous Borderlands games. The gun play is identical to Borderlands 2, but with the addition of laser guns, which are pretty cool. The changes to UVHM that make it so slag (cryo in this game) isn't essential to be able to play the game like it was in Borderlands 2 is nice.

The Vault Hunters in this game all feel super unique and fun to play, which is true of all of the Vault Hunters in the Borderlands franchise. All the skill trees have something interesting and unique to offer. The fact that each Vault Hunter has unique voice lines and interactions with the characters just makes me feel more engaged than in any other Borderlands game. While overall the story isn't as good as Borderlands 2 I felt disconnected from the story in Borderlands 2, but the fact that the Vault Hunters actually speak and have interactions with people makes it feel much more alive.

It really is a shame that this game was abandoned, it had so much potential to be great. The end game is severely lacking in this game but its still worth playing in my opinion.

I am a 88 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 74 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2023 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. I think this is my favorite Borderlands game in the series. It just needs more content. Another large DLC + Another NG+.

It's a little buggy, starting quest-lines occasionally doesn't trigger special events. Can be rectified by quitting out and re-entering the game but this is mainly a problem when multiplayer because you and your friend can't as easily disconnect, so the Quest location needs to be exited and re-entered which is slightly more troublesome luckily this is a rare occurrence.

The characters are in my opinion the most interesting with multiple builds in this game as oppose to the others games. This game is the first that I have thought of multiple builds for one character AND wanted to re-play through the game to try the build. All characters have subtle Co-op potential which makes playing with friends more fun.

At first glance and early play I assumed the Low-gravity space setting wouldn't fit for Borderlands, but I enjoyed some of the platforming involving the low-gravity. 

Unlike Borderlands 1 and 3, the Pre-sequal does not have many tedious quests. One side-quest involves donating 50 common quality weapons. This is the only quest that feels like an absolute drag to get through. The rest are fun!

The game needs more content, only one endgame raid boss, maybe you could count the Earworm boss at the end of Claptraps voyage as a raid boss? (WHICH TOTALLY NEEDS A UNIQUE OZ KIT CALLED "THE BOOMBOX" AND IT CONSTANTLY PLAYS MAINFRAME WHILE EQUIPPED!) As it is an optional boss that is unlocked after beating the last boss of the DLC? But it isn't advertised as such. The game does lack bosses, bosses are fun and they truly challenge your character (Or team if you're playing with friends). And for endgame raid bosses, something about grinding Raid bosses for extra rare-currencies or unique items feels very rewarding.

I assume they made this game purely to build some story and didn't expect or plan for it to be as fun as Borderlands 2 or be played as much as Borderlands 2. But I think another DLC for it would be worth it if it included an extra NG+, some kind of new area (that isn't an Arena) an extra Raid boss or two. Maybe it could elaborate a little on another corperation that isn't touched upon as much as Torgue or Hyperian. And maybe a couple of high grind high reward items just to top everything off to make a final goal for those players that like that sort of thing. 

Thank you for reading.

If you liked Borderlands 2, it's the same game, but on the moon! I love the moon jumping and "jetpack" mechanic, alongside the new laser weapon type and playable characters. This franchise's pre-sequel was a fun experience. It's familiar to Borderlands 2, but we're introduced to new characters, environments, and story. One major difference of this game with the two before it was the way the character moves. The movement feels like you're floating in a zero gravity atmosphere since you're exploring the moon, Elpis. This sucked in the beginning since it had a different feel from the previous Borderlands games, but I got used to it eventually. The oz kit system where you had to prevent your oxygen from depleting still sucked though.

Characters from previous installments were introduced as the new generation of Vault Hunters. Surprisingly, one of the characters was Claptrap. The one who we all hate apparently. There's a downloadable content for this game that Claptrap was heavily involved in. I highly suggest playing the DLC after finishing the main story. It's fun, quirky, and it also introduces a bunch of overpowered weapons, and the hardest Borderlands boss I've fought to date.

I highly suggest any Borderlands fan to try this game out as it adds additional lore to the game and bridges the gap between the first and second games. The game is shorter and has fewer content than the first and second games developed in the series, so make sure to get this game while it's on sale to get the most bang for your buck. For achievement hunters like me, the game features the standard achievements you need to get from any other Borderlands game, so it should be easy but will take awhile to accomplish.
The writing is good and the laser guns are fun... but that's about it. The map design is quite terrible imo.

The Pre-Sequel has by far the best and most fun character builds in the Borderlands series and one of my favorite DLCs in the series, The Claptastic Voyage, which has a plethora of fun content too, namely glitch rarity weapons.  The introduction of cryo element weapons and lasers are also some of the best and most fun additions to the series! The story is quite enjoyable and ties into Borderlands 2 quite nicely! While I'm probably in the minority when I say this, the low-gravity movement and Oz kit system was quite fun too and gives some freedom in combat. My main gripe with the game is the limited amount of content as you can accomplish everything quite quickly. The vehicles are also quite clunky to control in comparison to Borderlands 2, but they thankfully play only a minor part in the game. Overall, this game is an enjoyable experience that I recommend checking out!

If anyone one knows the meme template of "the strongest _ VS the weakest _", this is that meme as a borderlands title. It is perhaps one of the worst entries in the series, but it is still pretty god damn good. On a scale of one to ten, I'd generally give it a seven or an eight. It does some things slightly worse than other titles, but it is fun in spite of it. After hearing the reviews from longtime fans, I was ready to let this game rot in my steam inventory. But now that I've PLAYED it, I can say firmly that this game rocks just as much as the rest of the series. 

      The Pre Sequel may not be the best of the titles, but It is leagues beyond anything I could have expected out of it. It often goes on sale for cheap either stand alone or as part of a borderlands 2 bundle deal, so If that happens, take a shot at it. Also, its comedic and story writing is pretty much just as good as Borderlands 2. Much more than can be said about certain, newer titles in the series. It is definitely a few leagues above New Tales From The Borderlands in this regard. The only thing this particular entry falls short of consistently is small things in level and quest design. It can be slightly more repetitive and grind centered than other entries, but it is not as as bad as it sounds. 

   I can wholeheartedly say you'll have at least some fun with it if you are a borderlands fan in any regard, no matter how hardcore or casual.
my first time playing first person Shooters has been borderlands. I love the play style.

So far it just feels like a reskin of BL2 but with so much less love put into the game. Environments are similar, too similar. I'm not really a fan of the low gravity and dealing with O2. It honestly feels like a chore to play this slog of a game, but I will play it a few more times, hoping that I just haven't reached the fun part yet, otherwise I'll be putting the game down for good. To me, I just feel no excitement playing this game, just the same ol' boring fetch stuff side quests, brainless combat, and running sim. 

And my god, is it just me or does Athena's ability feel like non-existent. I remember in BL1 when you used Brick's fists, Roland's turret, Mordecai's bird, or Lillith's phasewalk it felt awesome, but this shield thing just feels garbage and so insubstantial. I know the game is a few years old, but there are some games that really are timeless...this is not one of them, I am bored to death playing this. It feels soooo antiquated.

More on the traversal in this game; it's not that I despise the low gravity, it's the fact that you can't clamber in this game. It's so damn annoying when you feel like you should be able to make a jump only to miss it slightly, and then fall back down, and then have to rinse and repeat again. Maybe the thrusters you have access to become more powerful later on ig, I hope they do because they feel useless.

Overall, it feels like they put so little effort into making this feel like a different BL game from the first two, largely disappointed so far. I've seen a lot of negative comments dismiss this as a BL2 DLC and now I see why; the game does not stand on its own two feet whatsoever.

I really enjoyed Borderlands 1 and 2, but this game is just bad. The story and characters are fun but the gameplay and design is horrible. I can't even count how many times I yelled at my screen "What happened!?" after dying. I died about five times outside my own fault in Borderlands 2; the Pre-sequel has killed me out of nowhere dozens of times. You can do everything perfect and the game will still find a way to cheaply kill you. I am fine with a challenge but this is just straight difficult due to game design. It makes no difference what level you are or how much shielding you have, you will still get one-shotted by most enemies and objects. In fact, in my experience, you will mostly be killed by people and objects that you won't even see or appear on-screen or on the mini map. You will be in a fight, hiding behind a corner out of sight when all of sudden you are fighting for your life and die due to no one being around to gain a second wind off of. 

Worse than dying for no reason may be all the backtracking in this game and how lost you can get. You have to continually revisit places you were just at, over and over again. It makes this game incredibly monotonous. You have to continually fight the same group of bad guys a bunch of times.  And if the map design doesn't kill you, it will surely frustrate you as you spend ten minutes trying to figure out how to get to your destination. There were a bunch of times I had no idea how to get to where I was supposed to go or how to accomplish the missionâ€™s goal. I donâ€™t think I ever got lost once or didn't know what to do in the first two games, they were very intuitive; not the Pre-Sequel. The map design is just so bad that it really hinders the enjoyment of this game.

I really wanted to like this game but the longer I played, the more frustrated I became - the exact opposite of Borderlands 1 and 2. I cannot recommend this game until they fix all the cheap, unnecessary dying and completely overhaul the map design to actually make it fun rather than punishing.

Certainly not the strongest game in the Borderlands franchise; as it feels really short.  After completing the game on Ultimate, and still only being level 50, there isn't much to do to get to level 70, if you want to reserve quest rewards for max level. I picked this game up when it first came out, played through once, and put it down.  I picked it back up in 2022 and have been enjoying playing with my friends, this time on Aurelia, who wasn't available initially.  I feel much better about the game on the whole, than when it first came out.  That said, BL2 and BL3 are substantially better games.  More gameplay, more depth, etc.  I am giving this game a good rating, because it is a great game for what it is - I just encourage you to have measured expectations going in. I did really enjoy the story aspect though, and the history that lead up to Handsome Jack's time in the spotlight of BL2

Now, the First Borderlands game was something I read about for months in the various gaming mags, and I fell for the hype way back when. When it released, it coincided with some kind of holiday break, and I spent a number of days without sleep just glued to that game. the story, the environment, the loot..  

I got real excited for the second one, and it scratched that itch..  Then the third, was..  the third..  Couldn't get into it, couldn't get behind it..  They just started missing something...   This game, less than an hour in, and I am very disappointed with the seeming soullessness this title brings..  It feels like this game and outer worlds were cut from the same damp cloth. Soulless, hamfisted, and the humor that was once something that was actually funny, is now just falling flat.

In the hour played, the gun play seems alright.. It's a functioning game.. It's just empty though.
mhmm

I could never get fully in to Borderlands 2- partially because it felt insurmountably expansive, especially with the DLC.

I decided to try out Pre Sequel after getting it as part of a bundle and without having heard of the middling reviews from its launch period.

This game has less to it than Borderlands 2- Having played some of that one and all of this one I can tell the criticisms have merit- but even then, I enjoyed my first playthrough (as a combat-modded Claptrap unit no less!) enough to immediately start a new game as Jack's body double.

The alternate lines pertaining to your character (and the re-telling of the story for New Game +) are great fun, the low gravity/jump mechanics are an interesting spin on the old format, and the ability to freeze flying enemies solid then watch them fall and shatter never got old for me.

If anything, this was a great contained experience that has made me more excited about trying 2 again

TL,DR - Borderlands 2 is more bang for your buck, but don't count this one out *especially if you can get it bundled

If it wasn't for BL3, I doubt I'd be able to appreciate this game nearly as much.

The Pre-Sequel is like DLC for Borderlands 2, taking the base game and adding lasers, low-g and slams. The story has some great moments as we watch Jack starting out as a guy with good intentions paving his way to becoming the villain he is in Borderlands 2. This makes for a fun experience despite a serious lack of fast travel points. You end up running to find something then backtrack to turn in the objective (Quit > Continue is faster most times), some regions also lack these points, so try to complete main objectives before save quiting.

Liked it more than I thought I would. Worth a playthrough for fans of the Borderlands franchise.

The Gameplay:
More of the same os BL2 + new stuff, so it's good.

The Story:
I want to get behind it because of Handsome Jack but a lot of the inbetween is just boring.

The Visuals:
Slightly sharper than BL2 but I still can't really get behind it.

The Sound:
The interactions with characters is a very nice touch. Everything else is pretty standard.

The Experience:
This game is very far from bad but it just doesn't have the same charm of Borderlands 2. I played it for a good bit with a friend and more and more as we got through it I f started to feel like I was forcing myself to play through it, The character interactions do make for what seems like interesting replayability but the enemies and story just seem dry. I will at some point beat it, but it is hard to build up the drive to.

Why this game has a bad rep is beyond me. It's a pleasure to play. The humor is still great though not quite on par with BL2. The game-play, weapons, farming, etc is all comparable to BL2 besides the story... The story is honestly better. It has the strongest story in the series. The fact this game was cancelled and we didn't get to see what would unfold with Handsome Jack in the next 3 DLCs is simply a travesty. Please give this a try if you like BL2. It connects so many things together story-wise and does a fantastic, enjoyable job of doing so.

I would write a long detailed review, but this game does not deserve it.

It is annoying and cringey. The humor is just not Borderlands-worthy. Playing co-op is a downgrade and will make you suffer more than necessary. Everyone has an exaggerated Australian accent probably because people thought that would be funny. 
The more you play it, the more you hate it. The level design is just aggravating and aims specifically to frustrate you. It's just bad all around and should not be played.

The Pre-Sequel is the lesser sibling of Borderlands 2; it has a few too many annoyances and there's little it does better, but it's still Borderlands.

When it comes to gameplay, the guns are more Borderlands, which is always good. stomp attacks and mods are fun, but having a constant ticking oxygen bar is more than annoying. Quests are dull and have you standing around listening to the quirky characters try to make jokes. The main villain is a joke, and the ending is a joke. Story-wise, the good portions are few and far between. It's nice to see more of Jack, which is really the main selling point imo. I'm glad that Athena's not butchered by poor writing. 

Side quests are boring as hell, even more so when you've play through the game multiple times. A lot of waiting around and doing menial tasks.

It's not that Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a bad game, it's that it isn't a great Borderlands. It's alright.

It's basically Borderlands 2 DLC. Don't expect much new in terms of mechanics, besides some fighting in low-gravity. While the events take place as BL1.5, the story itself is narrated [u]after[/u] the events of BL2, so play that first. Note also that [u]the quality of the early part of this game is dreadfully low in comparison to the rest[/u]. I nearly gave up on it numerous times due to boredom and frustration. It's like an entirely different team made the first half dozen maps or so, and then were promptly fired and replaced by qualified developers who steered the environments and story back on track.

Don't pay full price for the game. Get it as part of the Handsome Collection when on frequent sale and it's only a few bucks.

[h1]The Good[/h1]
+Fleshes out background on many characters and events
+LOL'd (after the early areas...have I mentioned how bad they are?)
+New energy weapons
+An airborne slam attack
+Skippable opening cutscenes!
+Grinder vendor to attempt to recycle drops into better items
+Tons of BL guides available online at this point
+Pickle

[h1]YMMV[/h1]
~It's basically Borderlands 2 DLC. Not much really changes.
~Early game can be difficult based on RNG
~Swearing is toned down and often bleeped (personally prefer this to BL2's overuse)
~Some characters are optimized for limited weapon types or coop play
~Slightly more emphasis on melee attacks
~Voice actors obviously re-used on too many characters

[h1]The Bad[/h1]
-First few areas of the game are very dull and lack fast travel
-Same BL invisible walls, unmarked instant death areas, clippable surfaces
-Melee attacks still lack visceral oomph! and indication that they landed
-Dead enemies still occasionally graphically spaz out
-Inventory/shop menus still occasionally select wrong items
-Enemies fly through or get stuck in or under surfaces
-Vehicles still occasionally handle strangely
-A number of frustrating vehicle jumps
-The oxygen meter discourages early exploration (especially for challenges)
-NPCs using laser weapons are ridiculously accurate - even across the map
-A number of challenges have frustrating hidden requirements
-A number of bugged challenges
-Some continuity errors
It's clear they are using the same foundation as Borderlands 2, but this game has a different enough feel from 2 that it's def worth checking out
one of the best game series I have played, the movement dynamics compared to the others are interesting but I love the story in these games

More of the borderlands formula! Contrary to popular opinion, I really like the freeze mechanics and the gameplay and I think the movement is really smooth. After playing through every single borderalnds game, the playable vault hunters are also my personal favorite due to their narrative significance later on and it was bittersweet to learn more about their backgrounds in the context of their later actions. I think this game is worth full-price but this game does go on sale pretty often.

Is this as good as the other Borderlands games? Nope. Is it still a good, enjoyable game? Sure, but your opinion of it will no doubt steadily decrease the longer you play. You'll start noticing there aren't that many guns, you'll get real tired of the grey moon rock environments, you'll get sick of the constant levitating jump-attack enemies, and the story, which starts off great fun, will just randomly crescendo and become rushed right by the end. 

But all that aside it's still a funny, fun and easy to play Borderlands title with some great characters. You don't want to miss it if you're playing through the franchise, but you'll start missing the other games in the franchise before you're done with it.

[b]Pros[/b]
[list]
   [*] +Decent gunplay and a large variety of weapons to find and use
   [*] +Low gravity lets you jump around higher and further, giving you more ways to move around
   [*] +Your character talks, adding to the story
   [*] +Four different characters to play as (six including the two dlc characters), each with their own skill trees
[/list]
 
[b]Cons[/b]
[list]
   [*] -Loot sometimes goes flying in low gravity areas, meaning that you might not get it
   [*] -Some areas feel like they are too big and feel empty. There are not many fast travel points either, making traveling tedious at times.
   [*] -If you mainly focus on the main quests, you will be underleveled, meaning enemies will feel like they have quite a bit of health. You will need to do the side quests to level up, but some of these quests send you to different areas and can take a little while to complete due to the large maps. This can make the gameplay repetitive.
   [*] -The main story is not that interesting
[/list]
 
[b]Comments[/b]
When I first started playing Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, I found it enjoyable. However, after a while, it started getting boring. The main reason is some areas feel like they are too big. In addition, there arenâ€™t many fast travel stations, making traveling tedious at times since some side quests take you to different areas. Even some of the main quests involve you running around a lot. I cannot recommend buying Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel because of this. I did have fun playing as the Doppelganger, but the large areas, few fast travel points and quests that involve you going to different areas made me stop playing the game.

It's not bad, just a little flat and uninspired. All of the Borderlands elements are there, but something is missing. It feels tacked on, with nothing new. The guns, missions, characters, and even the jokes are boring. It all seems like a rehash of things in the previous titles. Also, the environments are fairly monochromatic and monotonous. The low gravity atmosphere is annoying; it makes your character is little hard to control.

Honestly, the developers tried to make a good game, so I'm a little hesitant to give it a thumbs down, but this could have been better.

Not the best of the Borderlands Game but it is still a fun game to grind and I love the Laser weapons (Go Maliwan for DAMAGE). However, the main thing I disliked was the fact that it didn't provide as nearly enough DLC like Borderlands 2 and also the drops for Legendaries in this game seem pretty bad but maybe that's just me, considering I'm having to have to fight the Invincible Sentinel to get the Prismatic Bulwark (very low chance of drop; i.e invite other players to increase Loot Drop rate, although that doesn't always help). The only shield that I've gotten was the Black Hole. Also, another thing to note is that there isn't any OP levels for this game, though I am not sure, as I never did attempt to do the Holodome DLC. Nonetheless, Borderlands series has been fun for me with BL2 being the obvious favorite (Never played BL3 but will do so once I finish installing my new gaming PC).

It's another brilliant game from Gearbox that I would recommend to everyone.

Follow up to the stutter issue:
I fixed it myself because that is how it now works in the always online age...
If you have the stutter:
Go to network setting and change from Offline to Online friends only.
I found that Online friends only's sub-setting does not effect this.
You might have the change booting you in a pseudo in-game boot loop...
Alt-F4 the game till you have the settings manually apply or 
it sometimes defaults back to Online friends only.
With Online friends only as your network setting, the stutter is no longer present.

When I started the game, I saw all the same Borderlands 2, but something told me - something is buried deep here and is in no hurry to show itself, but I need to dig deeper, much deeper - after all, am I a shelter hunter or not? Oh yeah, damn it, I'm not a hideout hunter - S-U-R-P-R-I-Z!
Slightly improved graphics, a few new locations, new - as many as TWO - vehicles, low gravity imitation (in the end, the place of the event requires, and the Australians did it very well - in general) well, and perhaps everything. How not everything? Oh yes, of course - we play for evil, but the evil that only sleeps, sleeps and waits to be awakened - by someone or something. An attempt to show the reverse side of the coin, to show where Jack came from and what happened to him, the developers succeeded with a bang. The plot in the game is interesting and reveals most of the unresolved issues that could arise after passing the first two parts.
In the game, as before, everything is fine: the Easter eggs, and the sound, and the picture, and most importantly - the plot did not let us down, and the atmosphere in the game was created with taste for details, and secret achievements ... but, as usual, there is a spoon in a barrel of honey tar ... there are several of them, Iâ€™ll name a couple:
-probably the first is a set of weapons... the developer assured us that there is a huge selection of weapons in the game, yes, there is a large selection of weapons in the game, BUT no... except for the fact that CREO weapons were added to the game instead of SLAG weapons, there are no changes as such at all... everything the same weapons, sometimes even copies of guns from Borderlands 2 - and this is sad.
-the second thing that upset this value for money ... for the money that they asked for pre-order is too small a story, albeit interesting and good, BUT small ... one can only hope for future DLCs, as a rule they are of high quality to the game and do not weakly add hours of gameplay time.
-the third is the classes in the game, if in the first two there was some kind of division into: serena, contact, support, sniper, now it's all combined in each of the 3 heroes, but it develops over time in its own way. (but this is IMHO, maybe of course I just read superficially in the classes)
-the fourth is, to my regret, Clap-trap... oooh yes, I so hoped to play for him, probably like many Borderlands players, but no one expected that he would be such a "hero"... this is probably the most SOLO player for all Borda that I know, because burying his companions is as easy for him ... as nothing even crosses my mind. In general, in a company with such a character, you often ask not to turn on skills than to turn on and help, I'm upset, although as a hero, he certainly invigorates and amuses.
Probably these are the pros and cons of my IMHO, as well as questions and the desire of the developers to tell a different story of all the same participants and events related to Pandora. It inspired the creation of the PRE-Sequel, and it's... it's brilliant and simple.
In short: the game is fun, good, made with love and feeling, it is clear that the developers have put a lot of effort into showing the story of Jack in such a way that you no longer know whether to feel sorry for him or hate him ... I behaved in his place?!"

TLDR: I reccomend getting the Pre-Sequel even though it's my least favorite out of the three. Make sure to get Claptastic Voyage at the very least if you don't end up getting the season pass.

If you choose to get only one game in the series I highly reccomend getting Borderlands 2 even though this is currently the newest. The Borderlands series is a First Person shooter with RPG elements including character building and different methods of completing various missions. Character building includes choosing perk trees to fill as well as unlocking and choosing from a variety of differnt class skins and head customisation. 

BTPS QUALITY AND DLC: It may not be as good as the first two Borderlands entries but it's still definitely worth getting. Despite what some people may say I don't consider this entry in the series to be a cash-grab. I do believe they charged a bit much for DLC than they should have this time around. The first two Borderlands entries featured quality DLC that was well worth the amount charged for it. I still reccommend getting the season pass for Pre-Sequel however but only if you plan on trying out "Lady Hammerlock", "The Doppleganger" and Claptastic Voyage as iIt's personally my favorite part about The Pre-Sequel.  

VEHICLES AND TRAVELING ELPIS: Compared to the first two games the best part that makes this entry stand out is how fun it is getting around with low gravity and jump pads. There are only 2 vehicles in BTPS. The Moon Buggy is basically the light runner with lasers or ice missle clusters rather than heavy machine gun fire or missiles. The stingray is a one-person hoverbike style vehicle perfect for low gravity.

HUMOR AND CHARACTERS/VAULT HUNTERS: BTPS features memorable characters from the first two Borderlands entries as well as some new ones which will be seen in Borderlands 3.  The game's humor still feels like it belongs in a Borderlands game. I have had a decent amount of experience with every Vault Hunter in every Borderlands game and the Vault Hunters in The Pre-Sequel stand out well.

==========================================TL;DR====================================
Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel at the end of the day is essentially, a standalone expansion for Borderlands 2 that offers extended story context of the events before and after Borderlands 2. So if You enjoyed BL2, You'll probably enjoy this too.


In typical Borderlands fashion, our story begins following 1-4 of the 6 playable vault hunters as they arrive (or rather crash) aboard Hyperion's flagship orbital space station, Helios. Our "Heroes", answering lucrative hails of mercenary work for any to assist acutely-assailed Hyperion executive, Jack (Before the Great Handsome-ing of 2661). 


Instead of the usual locale of Pandora, T.P.S (mostly) takes place on Elpis, Pandora's Moon. It shows both the rise of Weapons and Tech Conglomerate Hyperion, and the Descent of Jack into everybody's least favorite villian; Handsome Jack.

You'll spend most of your time on Elpis, exploring the barren moonscapes and craters of a post-cataclysm event Lunar Surface speckled with the remnants of Dahl's Industrial and Research facilities occasionally dotted about breaking up the monotony of such an empty setting. Don't be fooled, even the moon is infested with all kinds of baddies to blow apart in traditional series fashion, and certainly isn't lacking in interesting locations and settlements. 

Later areas impress, featuring a return to monolithic space stations sprawled with Labyrinthian corridors clad with futuristic advertising, dripping with cyberpunk flair and hyper-corporatism chic, or mythical alien vaults containing unimaginable power and wealth, guarded dearly by an ancient race of powerful Promethean beings.

Quest design this time is kinda lackluster, featuring almost exclusively collect-a-thons and escort quests, and most of the time, underwhelming rewards. I have nothing noteworthy to say, I did every sidequest and don't really have a standout. They're *ok*

The gun-play and Inventory systems are identical to that of Borderlands 2. Major differences being the replacement of premium currency Eridian, for Moonstone, and the addition of the Laser category of weaponry in a wide assortment of variations from blasters to beam guns. Slag has been replaced with the Cryo element as-well, which functions in much the same way while immobilizing the target as-well. Finally, due to the lack of a native atmosphere, oxygen is a precious resource on Elpis, and the addition of "Oz" kits and an additional gear slot, you can increase the time you spend in the bitter vacuum of space.


===FINAL SAY===
Besides some small changes to freshen the experience, and a new planet, you really do just have Borderlands 2 here with a different set of Vault Hunters. This time assisting Jack instead of assailing the pompous arse.

I can definitely see where some popular criticisms of the game hold up, and my main complaint is among them, Elpis is poorly designed, and frankly just annoying to trek across. Outside of a lot of tedious backtracking in one-off areas for side quests in "filler" areas used in the story, this is my main complaint.

Overall, It's a shorter, less cohesive Borderlands 2 with a tedious setting and arguably weaker story, but I still enjoyed my time. 

7/10 - Worth a play for series enthusiasts, or those who like the full story.

[olist] [*] It's well written. [*] It's got that mix of comedy and action (with epic-ness and drama too) that Borderlands 2 players will love. [*] It has a diverse amount of guns with all kinds of fun effects. [*] IT HAS MR. TORGUE! [*] It has interesting additions to the game mechanics that are fun to play. [*] It' s got acceptable levels of grinding required to get the loot you want, and you'll be getting plenty of other interesting loot while you're doing that. Sure, it has a few bugs, like sometimes you can cause the dialog to interrupt itself, making you miss some of it. And yes, it's not as long (play time-wise) as BL2, but let's be honest: BL2 got a lot more add-on content than most games, even the good ones. (Not complaining about that, the add-ons were awesome, it's just an unfairly high standard to measure other games to.) But over all, if you like Borderlands 2, you'll like this game, ==== Edit: After finally getting around to finishing the 100% of this game, I still love it. I did have to wait for my....dislike of BL3 to die down first though. If I had to pick between the two, I'd pick this game, not BL3. Unless they actually fixed every last bug in BL3. Then maybe I'd reconsider. As for how this compares to BL2...eh, hard to say. I think this would have stood up to BL2 if it had gotten that cruise ship DLC, but as it is it's too close to call. Meanwhile, still doing the BL1's (trying to wrap up BL1 OG b4 importing to BL1 Remastered) so idk how they compare. Short version: I will still gladly play this game after the 100%. A very rare compliment, which less than a handful of games (N<5) have gotten from me. So, yeah, game is good.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel

10/10

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

I'm really puzzled where so much of the hate for this game is coming from. It's not quite Borderlands 2, but that doesn't have to be a bad thing. It's a game with a very creative atmosphere and levels, as well as introducing some new mechanics, sometimes while ditching old ones (goodbye slag, hello cryo!) which end up being positive additions/changes.

This time you play on the side of Jack and learn about his backstory and how the events in BL2 were shaped. In a way, it feels like an extension of BL2, but it is its own unique game that can be enjoyed individually, regardless of the rest of the series. It once again has six characters to pick from, but somehow I always end up picking Wilhelm, who can later be seen in BL2 in his fully augmented form.

A fun game that has amassed some negative attention, but I think most (if not all of it) is bogus. It's a great game and I'll gladly play it over and over, just as I have with BL2.

[h1][u] My Overview Of This Game [/u]
I personally think this is a mediocre game in the franchise. Having since played and owned borderlands 2 since its release, I was shocked to find out that this game was coming back then. Despite me wanting it on my Xbox 360 previously, I lost interest as time passed on. Eight years later, I bought the game alongside borderlands 2 because there was a sale for $15. Speaking of the game I'll be explaining the takeaways and drawbacks of this game.

[h2][u] Takeaways[/u]
Starting with the positive side of the game, it's pretty cool just to see how the campaign went through. Playing as familiar characters in the pre-sequel was a bit strange at first but it seems like you've been playing an existing character. There were no custom characters that represented each class. It was all from scratch and you would have to make it your own. The story was very good and I got to experience how Jack was the villain the whole time throughout the end when other characters saw his corruption in the vault.

[h3][u] Drawbacks[u]
Things I don't like about the game:
[*] It's kinda short compared to Borderlands 2 (from what I remember)
[*] Bosses are very difficult around the end
[*] Too many irrevelant side quests

A lot of what makes BL2 good is present in the Pre-Sequel, possessing the same combat mechanics, art style and everything. I personally don't get why people seem to dislike this game or think it's out of place. In fact, I can even confidently say some parts are better.

The gameplay adds a few new things. The main part is the addition of oxygen tanks, which you need to go across Elpis or else your health will slowly dwindle. It doesn't really change much, but it does allow for new special effects like Eridian artifacts as well as modifying ground slams (low gravity and ground slams are also a great addition to movement). Additionally, instead of having slag that just makes enemies get hit harder you have cryo that damages enemies but also slows them down, which in my opinion is a welcome change. The story itself is also great, which is essentially Handsome Jacks' origin story. The whole storyline gives you a whole new perspective on who he is as a character as well as the characters who were supposedly your allies, and you can really see how Jack changes throughout the story. Great game overall.
