I first played this game back when it came out in 2014, on an Xbox with my brother. I had a bit of fun, but my brother moved away before we had the chance to even get halfway through the story(about drakensburg). I picked it up again with the handsome collection sometime in 2018/19, and played it a bit, about an hour, and it was kinda fun. But recently, I decided to play through all of the Borderlands games with my partner, and by far, this has been the worst of the experiences.

1. Design
The design of this game is a bit lackluster. Everything from the levels to the enemies just feels rather unintuitive. The bossfights having up to 6 phases, the new laser additions really only serving the same purpose as every other gun, it being confusing where to go during the main missions, it just feels a bit off. Now, I do like the O2 system. I enjoy jumping around and slamming into my enemies, but this also plays into its downfall, as when my weapons start to drop off, I just stunlock every enemy and either throw them off a cliff or just keep stunlocking them until they die, and it makes it really easy to get underleveled and overwhelmed later in the story.
2. Story
While the story is nice, it's really frustrating that the audio prompts keep clipping into each other. This feels like what Mass Effect: Andromeda was at launch, but these issues just haven't been fixed 8 years later. I'm aware the studio went defunct after DLC 2, but that's after DLC 2. This should've been fixed, and rather quickly. Handsome Jack clearly carries this story, and everyone else feels a bit out of character, especially Lilith, feeling more like a common bandit in this entry than a proper, nuanced former protagonist, and former deuteragonist, and former tritagonist in the series. It just feels wrong, somehow.
3. Gunplay
The gunplay just isn't the best. Most of the weapons I find are kinda trash, Torgue weapons especially suffer here, as there's just no reason to use anything under a legendary, which you really won't find during a casual playthrough, I found 2 drops, and got 3 from the grinder, after using ~200 golden keys. Unless you're a dedicated farmer, there's really nothing that makes the gunplay special like borderlands 2 or 3, or even 1 for that matter, with some of its unique blue/purples. While the laser weapons seem like a nice addition, it's pretty clear why they don't make a return in the proper sequel.
4. Characters
This is where borderlands usually shines, and this game is no different. The characters are absolutely amazing. for our run, we picked CL4P-TP and Nisha, and they complement each other really well, which is something even other borderlands games struggle to do at times. With their sometimes weird, sometimes quirky voice lines, and their solid skill trees, it makes up a bit for the lack of proper gunplay
5. Pace
The game just lacks pace. Deadlift, Sentinel, RK5, all 3 are just, weird skill gaps, deadlift being 2 levels above you usually, unless you do the ONLY available side missions, and all of them, RK5 being about 3 levels above you, and Sentinel, we started with it being 6 levels above us, and ended with it being 4 levels above us. We leveled up twice during the fight alone. This is probably a subjective point, given we weren't really interested enough in the game to do most of the side missions, some of which do give a proper exp boost, but the game should definitely scale a bit better on the low end.
6. Bugs.
Lots of them, and not the fun kind. If you travel through areas and use your action skill, sometimes it just locks you in an animation. Some characters just A pose the whole time. Sometimes you get stuck in completely random places. Sometimes the audio clips. Every time I restart the game, I get 60 golden keys. It just feels littered with a lack of polish, and definitely could've gone an extra month or two with some touching up, even if 2K Australia was on borrowed time.
That's mostly my gripes with the game, I wanted to like it a lot, given the Borderlands series has had a lot of impact on my adolescent and even prepubescent years, but this one just doesn't do it for me. If you prefer story, play Borderlands 2, see if it floats your boat, that game has a lot of mods, a lot of unique guns, a lot of proper DLC content, and a lot of lore, as well as some decent, but similar gunplay to this. Borderlands 3, I would recommend to anyone who prefers a more fluid gunplay experience; its story is rather lackluster, but it's nothing that detracts from the experience in any way. It has a ton of replayability, it's fun in almost every way, its characters are not as good as in this game but still solid, and its gunplay is just *mwah*.

Unless you're a diehard Borderlands fan, I would say to skip this one, and maybe watch a longplay, see if it's your thing. It wasn't mine, and that's alright, that doesn't make this a bad game by any means. I'm just disappointed at the overall lack of creativity brought to the table in a spinoff game. Because spinoffs are meant to take the original formula and actually do something with it, or throw the original formula out of the cards, like Tales from the Borderlands does, which is another solid entry in the franchise. It's just not for me, and I can't really recommend it. Thanks

Apparently this isn't a port but it plays like the shittiest port imaginable when playing in co-op which is like "[i]the entire point of the Borderlands franchise[/i]"

[b]1[/b]. Cutscenes do not load with any regularity as non-lobby-leaders, often they are replaced by a still frame with no audio, and sometimes the Cutscene will play with audio delayed or disjointed
[b]2[/b]. Game crashes are frequent and can persist through the host re-creating the lobby or the crashing player re-launching the game entirely 
[b]3[/b]. Vehicle physics are godawful and exacerbated by whatever netcode Gearbox is using and results in Vehicles clipping and shooting into the stratosphere, warping around when exiting, or just outright duplicating for no rhyme or reason
[b]4[/b]. The whole point of Borderlands is the fucking loot and it takes upwards of 2-3 seconds for each container to reveal what was in them, even for simple ammo and money boxes. The process of checking for stuff is ridiculously tedious for anyone who isn't the host

The rest of the game is [i]fine[/i], its a Borderlands game with a coat of Australian paint on it. The environmental storytelling is great, large setpieces changing, moving, or blowing up. Guns got a little more variety and the Borderlands humour is still there

[h1]Vehicles[/h1]
Vehicles are still dumb and frustrating and dont add anything to the game besides a way to travel long distances ([i]why[/i] are we still restricted to Fast Travel Stations?). They're floaty (worse given the setting), give less xp, lack sufficient gameplay depth in customization or improvement, and just serve to traverse large empty (frankly, [i]boring[/i]) areas that connect on-foot locations with thought and detail put into them

[h1]Guns[/h1]
[spoiler]The grinder[/spoiler] is a huge boon and makes hoarding guns fun, but sometimes it wont work for inexplicable reasons. It feels like an obvious quality of life thing to print an error for why a [spoiler]grind[/spoiler] cant be submitted. [b]YES[/b], I understand they wanted it to be a puzzle, [i]but 8 years later[/i] I have the fucking chart up on my other monitor and I'm fulfilling the correct conditions but the [spoiler]grind[/spoiler] isn't working and [i]I can't tell why[/i]

This is also the third game in the franchise and there still isn't [i]at least[/i] an option for player locked or player localized drops, loot, or chest content. Nobody likes the multiplayer gun bureaucracy Gearbox, get over yourselves

[h1]Space[/h1]
The setting in space did not age well for gameplay mechanics

Looking to refill your oxygen [i]isn't exactly fun[/i], its just stapled onto the existing Borderlands formula and feels like a time waster. Oz kits have some unique buffs for being airborne, in vacuums, in rich environments, and for slamming, but they just feel like random situational stat padding at best and annoying to capitalize on at worst

The floaty low gravity is personal preference but I'm not a huge fan for any particular reason

â€œIf it ainâ€™t broke, donâ€™t fix it.â€ I can imagine that mantra circulating the 2K Australia office as the team worked on Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel. Gearbox had a huge hit on its hands with Borderlands 2, and there is not much reason to mess with a winning formula.

To be clear, a lot of what matters is new. The story, playable characters, environments, dialogue, and physics are all new. Despite that, it all feels very familiar. Where a number of core systems were significantly upgraded between the first and second games in the series, The Pre-Sequelâ€˜s additions are much less pronounced.

Set between the first two games. Specifically, it is set after the events of Claptrapâ€™s New Robot Revolution. Taking place largely on Pandoraâ€™s moon Elpis, the first regressive parallel to the original title in the series reveals itself: the moon is largely made up of desolate gray-blue rock dotted with industrial complexes. In the same way that our first adventure to Pandora spent entirely too much time in vast brown deserts, the first half of the romp across Elpis occurs in areas that are indistinct from one another. 

Some of the smaller areas have no Fast Travel station, an annoyance compounded by side missions that require returning multiple times. On top of that, not every area has vending machines near the entrance, which makes dumping junk loot a bit of a pain when visiting the offending locales. One area in particular (Stantonâ€™s Liver) has everything going against it: unmemorable environmental art design, no Fast Travel, no vending machines, and several optional missions pointing toward it.

A lot of the time, traversing the environments is made easy through circuitous layouts and the new freedom afforded by the low gravity of Elpis and the Vault Huntersâ€™ ability to double jump. Indeed, one of the most touted new features of fighting on Elpis as opposed to Pandora is the use of the moonâ€™s lower gravity. On paper, it does not seem like a big deal, but it surprised me to find out just how much it affects gameplay. In addition to being able to jump higher, the double jump allows for a lot of aerial control, and the new Gravity Slam move is both satisfying and useful.

In fact, the low gravity combat is so fun that I became noticeably irritated when the story takes the Vault Hunters back to Helios, where there is more standard, Pandora-like gravity. It is not that the standard combat is bad, it is just that the moon combat is so good.

The story opens in Sanctuary as it floats among the clouds. Clearly taking place after the events of Borderlands 2, Athena is forced to tell the story of the time she helped Handsome Jack years before. The playable portion of The Pre-Sequel is all told as Athenaâ€™s flashback, regardless of which of the four available Vault Hunters is in play. What Athena describes is meeting Jack, a middle management Hyperion employee who saves her life and eventually the lives of countless people living on Elpis. Players get to see firsthand why Jack considers himself a hero, and they get to watch his slow decline into depravity, and his eventual transformation into Handsome Jack, the man wearing the mask.

Without spoiling too much, the ending upset me initially. I felt betrayed, and I felt like it would not have and should not have happened like it did. Upon further reflection, I realize that while it caused me to see a character in a different light than I previously had, it perfectly encapsulates a major theme in the series. The bad guys are at least a little bit good and the good guys are at least a little bit bad. Sometimes it is difficult to tell which is which. (But Lilith is still a bÃŒtch)

On the downside, the plot left open a few points that I was expecting to be addressed. Clearly, Athena is alive and in Pandoraâ€™s vicinity between the point of her introduction in The Secret Armory and some indeterminate point after the events of Borderlands 2, so she lives through the Pre-Sequel, but the story never gives an explicit explanation on her whereabouts during Handsome Jackâ€™s tenure as CEO of Hyperion. Considering she was there to witness his insidious rise to power, there should be a good narrative reason that she would not help to bring him down.

The writing as a whole maintains the classic Borderlands charm, though it does seem a little less wacky than that found in Borderlands 2, again striking a balance between the two previous titles. A few familiar faces show up; most current characters have at least small speaking roles. There are several new characters as well: the eastern European Nurse Nina, the not-quite-as-lovable-as-Tiny-Tina child Pickle, and my favorite new character Janey Springs.

Springs is one of many denizens of Elpis, most of whom are the Australians to Pandoraâ€™s Americans. She is immediately endearing, and has some of the best lines in the game. There are a few laugh-out-loud moments, and overall the writing is smart and snappy. 

One of the best new developments for the writing in Borderlands was the decision to have the Vault Hunters participate in conversations, giving each one more personality, and offering a non-gameplay reason to play through with multiple characters. This is especially important through Jackâ€™s campaign to save Elpis, as each character will react differently to his methods and evolving morality. Although Athena is my girl, the morally bankrupt sadist Nisha has some of the most hilarious retorts and insults.

A new weapon element makes an appearance with cryo, which slows enemies, damages them over time, and can eventually freeze them solid to be shattered into hundreds of shards.
 
Lasers also appear as a separate weapon type. There are several different flavors of laser weapons, including Ghostbusters-style streams, Star Wars-esque blasters, and powerful railguns. Most useful is that laser weapons generally have low recoil and good hip fire accuracy. This pairs extremely well with the aforementioned low gravity combat. It is common to double jump across a pit and headshot an enemy with a railgun from the hip in the process, and it feels totally rad to do it. Where combat in Borderlands was like Call of Duty in a lot of ways, the fighting in The Pre-Sequel feels more akin to Halo.

Of course, some of the most fun in Borderlands comes with multiplayer, and The Pre-Sequel has made some strides to make this even more interesting. While each of the four Vault Hunters can be built to play solo, Athena, Wilhelm, and Claptrap have skills that benefit the whole team in unusual ways. 

In case it is not already obvious, I love the Borderlands series. I have followed it since its debut in 2009, and I have put hundreds of hours into using bullets to make numbers pop out of bad guys, digging into the lore, and hanging out with friends. Loving the series means knowing just how good it can be, and it means always measuring it against those high standards.

2K Australia nailed the combat with The Pre-Sequel. It is fast, fresh, and more tactically interesting than ever before. The writing hits the right notes, although the overarching plot is not quite as emotionally powerful as other entries have been. For many, that is enough to be a great experience. 

Despite that glowing praise, I am torn, because I also recognize that it is far from perfect. The environmental art direction gets dull too quickly, the level design is lacking in basic conveniences, and a general sloppiness is present when looking closely. Some of the cool new features like multi-leveled areas and combining weapons could have been enhanced further if the user interface and systems had been updated to play to those strengths. Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel was a solid entry to the series, but I wish that 2K Australia had the chance to take some of the failings to heart and deliver further excellence in the future but sadly they'll never get that chance now.

INGREDIENTS
1 lb. spaghetti
1 lb. ground beef
1/3 c. bread crumbs
1/4 c. finely chopped parsley
1/4 c. freshly grated Parmesan, plus more for serving
1 large egg
2 garlic cloves, minced
Kosher salt
1/2 tsp. red pepper flakes
2 tbsp. extra-virgin olive oil
1/2 c. onion, finely chopped
1 (28-oz.) can crushed tomatoes
1 bay leaf
Freshly ground black pepper

DIRECTIONS/STEPS
In a large pot of salted boiling water, cook pasta until al dente. Drain.
In a large bowl, combine beef with bread crumbs, parsley, Parmesan, egg, garlic, 1 teaspoon salt, and red pepper flakes. Mix until just combined then form into 16 balls.
In a large pot over medium heat, heat oil. Add meatballs and cook, turning occasionally, until browned on all sides, about 10 minutes. Transfer meatballs to a plate.
Add onion to pot and cook until soft, 5 minutes. Add crushed tomatoes and bay leaf. Season with salt and pepper and bring to a simmer. Return meatballs to pot and cover. Simmer until sauce has thickened, 8 to 10 minutes.
Serve pasta with a healthy scoop of meatballs and sauce. Top with Parmesan before serving.

[h1]itâ€˜s not that borderlands tps is a bad game. itâ€™s just much more of the exact same.[/h1]

if you played borderlands 2, then you already played borderlands the pre-sequel as well. similarly to the case of bioshock 1 & 2, borderlands tps is the exact same game like its predecessor, apart from the different story and two or three very small and unimportant gameplay changes. 

the story takes place on a moon now and is set between borderlands 1 and 2, to show how handsome jack turned from an inconspicuous hyperion employee to the evil villain he is in borderlands 2. itâ€™s an interesting premise, but since the gameplay gets extremely dull and repetitive very quickly again, youâ€˜ll end up not caring too much about the narrative either.

there are three little changes compared to borderlands 2:
1. there are laser weapons now, too. (pewpew meh)
2. since it is set on a moon there is much lower gravity.
3. you have to handle your oxygen level when on the moon surface.

like the game itself, those changes are not for the better or worse, they are just completely unnecessary. the only slightly positive thing i noticed after roughly 20 hours of gameplay is, that there are not as much enemies that downright annoy you like some of the foes in borderlands 2. the enemy roster is slightly stripped back to mostly humanoid foes, which makes the fights slightly more fun and faster paced. trading stations seem to be a bit more frequent as well now.

when it comes to the technical aspects, there is not a single change here as well. the only thing that might be worth mentioning is that the music, while certainly far from bad, sounds more like an unimpressive copy of the mass effect soundtrack than an original score to me.

in the end those minor changes do next to nothing to differentiate borderlands tps from its predecessor or improve on it. it is literally the same experience with all its many strengths (interesting cel-shade grafics, satisfying gunplay, freaky characters, ideas and humor) and many more weaknesses (repetitive gameplay, inconsistent difficulty, a couple of really unbalanced areas and bossfights, technical hickups like crashes and glitches, longwinded and contrived quest design, a serious amount of filler content, etc.).
not that the game is worse than borderlands 1 or 2, but it is a completely unnecessary game with an unnecessary story, unnecessary characters and unnecessary gameplay changes. the game is still good, but there is not one single aspect that hasnâ€™t gotten very old at this point, especially in case of the humor. needless to say that just like borderlands 1 and 2 the pre-sequel produces a serious gameplay fatigue that sets in no later than the 30 hour mark. the game may hold your interest until the main questline is completed, but anything else beyond this point, wether it be any remaining side quests or the available dlc, just drags and leaves you totally oversatured.

if this would be sold as a dlc for its predecessor i could certainly speak more fondly of it, but borderlands tps is a rather blatant trick played on the consumer: it strongly feels like DLC from start to end, yet is sold as a full prized â€newâ€œ game.
nevertheless, the quality of the game itself is stable. if you are looking to get into the borderlands series, this is as good a point of entry than any other preceding borderlands game, and if you are a big fan of borderlands than there is no way of skipping this. Those who donâ€™t fit into either of those two groups of people wonâ€™t miss out on much if they let this game go by. and thatâ€˜s what ultimately gets the game itâ€˜s final score: viewed only by itself itâ€™s a legitimate 5/8 with one or two strengths of its own, but when put in context of the series, it simply has too few new things and improvements to offer to be anything more than decent.

This is an opinion that'll divide the entire community but it's just the way it is. Everything about it is fantastic. The story is compelling and gives you insight into a villain you already know the end of, the new guns are cool, the bosses are unique and an experience to fight and the difficulty is JUST right. It's neither too hard ala Borderlands 2 or too easy ala 3. Characters are great too. Each one has compelling, unique abilities  that make you want to play them all. My personal favourite is Wilhelm who ranks only barely above Claptrap for the progression he makes as you get more and more cybernetics. His voice grows more and more robotic with each specific skill, adding a sense of change that fits the overall theme of the story.
Claptrap, while a plague upon the ears to listen to for a playthrough, is hilariously fun to play with his random ultimate. You have no idea whether you'll be decimating everything you can see or put into a position where you're absolutely screwed and I love that little touch of random.

Combine this with the fact that we get to truly understand WHY Handsome Jack turned out the way he did, and we get a fantastic game even without the equally great DLC.

Ignore the masses, play it for yourself: It's a great game.

I have mixed feelings about this game. While it retains a lot of the core elements that make Borderlands 2 so good, it also lacks a lot of what people keep coming back to that game for. The story is much worse, feeling forced and badly executed. A lot of the new characters are forgettable and unlikable. The only ones I found that I liked were the ones I'd seen before or were fleshed out in other games. The humor is not as funny as in 1 and 2, it falls flat most of the time, however that is mostly personal.

From here on I will be delving into spoiler territory so skip to the second last paragraph if you don't want any.

When I'm talking about the story being forced I mean when Jack basically becomes a psychopath. I can understand him turning into one right after seeing some crazy shit in the vault, his "friends" turning on him and making him feeling betrayed. Really? He barely knew Roland and Lillith, Moxxi is just a whore who's slept with most people that you meet. We already know that he doesn't care much about Moxxi as he talks about them being together more like a one night stand. I can somewhat understand Jack being upset with Moxxi betraying him, however Lillith and Roland are just very experienced mercenaries to him as we barely see them interact outside of Jack giving them an objective. This is a part of what terms him into the Handsome Jack we know? Him being betrayed by two people he just met and a one night stand? This is what people point to the most when I ask how and/or why he turned out as he did. No. This is not how people would act especially someone who's as self righteous as Jack was in the beginning of the game. On another note God are the children annoying in this game. Pickle is a little kid who annoys the fuck out of me. Would he just shut up!? And don't even get me started on Lunestalker...

This game has a lot of flaws that I have experienced first hand, however I cannot bring myself to give it a negative review as I still enjoyed myself a lot with it. As I said in the beginning it retains some core elements to 2 that made it still pretty good in the gameplay department. It also made some welcome to spruce up the gameplay a bit. For example the addition of an entirely new element was a nice gameplay change and it quickly became my most used element, and favorite. The low gravity also made you rethink a lot of the game and how you approached some things. The skill trees of the new characters are also very unique and fun to level up and use (although I haven't played as all of the characters, just the base four).

I'd recommend to buy this game in the Handsome collection so you also get Borderlands 2, which is one of the greatest games of all time and a much better start if you want to get into the series. I'd recommend playing this game after Borderlands 2 (although chronologically speaking TPS comes first). This game is not worth it at full price Imo, you should just pick up the Handsome collection during a sale as it usually goes for 15â‚¬.
fun stuff

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel's name is a joke made at the expense of off-year sequels and filler content that popular series use to buy time for bigger, better things.

This is particularly funny because that's exactly what The Pre-Sequel is. It's not like original developer Gearbox isn't in on the joke. This is the first Borderlands game developed outside of the Plano, Texas-based studio, as they've handed the reins to 2K Australia.

The result is ... well, more Borderlands, really. In many ways, shy of a setting full of Australian accents (no, really, it is), it's an exercise in covering the series' bases as competently as possible without rocking any boats. But Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel stakes a valid claim on the series with a mechanical quirk that sounds like just another bullet point on an off-year sequel's checklist.

In the event that you haven't played a Borderlands game, here goes: Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a hybrid loot-based action role playing game and first person shooter. As a Vault Hunter, you'll gain levels and earn more health and unique ability modifiers for your character as you complete missions and take down enemies.

Set primarily on the Pandoran moon Elpis, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is populated by a mostly different cast of characters than its bookends. Taking place between the first and second games, it's an origin story for Borderlands 2 villain Handsome Jack, ostensibly to show how he "fell" from hero-ish to big bad. He's not the only origin story though. All of the new character classes in The Pre-Sequel appear in various capacities in Borderlands and Borderlands 2, as friends or not-so-much.

Three out of the four "new" characters (I'm talking about the four default characters not the DLC ones) are relatively recognizable to Borderlands vets. I personally preferred the Lawbringer, who focuses on revolvers and sniper rifles with a skill that gives a brief period of auto targeting and rapid fire. Then there's the Gladiator, who absorbs enemy damage in a shield that she can later use as a weapon; the Enforcer adds more and more tech and augmentations over time. 
The only truly new-feeling class is Claptrap, newly christened the Fragtrap. Claptrap has been given new programming that takes bits of each pre-existing vault hunter class and sort of "remixes" them when you activate his special ability. It is completely unpredictable â€” there's no way to know if you'll pull out an identical, second weapon and fire both until you're out of ammo, or, say, a spinning rainbow disco deathball. This unpredictability is fun ... assuming you're not running solo. Claptrap is easily the character most dependent on other classes to stay alive.

Not that death means much. Maybe more than either previous Borderlands game, The Pre-Sequel doesn't really care if you die (outside of boss battles, that is, where dying allows heavies to regain their health and shields). There's not much penalty or consequence aside from the same minor respawn fee that's always been there. You can keep throwing yourself into the same firefights until you conquer them, if that's what you want to do.

It's all very Borderlands. And that's ... sort of The Pre-Sequel's biggest problem. This is the least essential game of the series. It feels smaller than either previous Borderlands. There's less variety in environments and enemies, and it's considerably shorter â€” about 18-24 hours to mainline the main story with some side missions thrown in. And if that were all that was there, just about anybody could skip The Pre-Sequel and continue living their life without worry or care.
But Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel fixes one of the biggest detriments to the series' moment-to-moment play: It makes movement fun.

Before, simply getting from point a to point b in a mission was tedious and plodding. Areas were frequently gated by low platforms that you had to find a way around to make your way up. Combat movement was the same circle strafing and mild bunny hopping over and over again.

Apparently, low-gravity is the answer to all of this.

As Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel takes place mostly on the surface of a moon (or in deep space), gravity isn't the hindrance it is on Pandora. This allows for absurd jumps and, once you have a life-saving oxygen kit, the ability to give yourself an extra bump, slow your descent, and even change direction while in the air.

This does several things. First, it allows for even more involved vertical traversal problems that are fun to solve in a way nothing in the previous Borderlands games was. Second, it adds a new kind of item to the game with O2, or "Oz" kits as they're called, each of which has its own perks and allow for variations on the air stomp attack you have when you're hovering. For a game like Borderlands, more kinds of loot and more gear to min-max is a great thing.

But most importantly, it's more fun to move around, and it's more fun to fight enemies with that newfound mobility. Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel has better gunplay than any previous installment because there's more to do at any given time.

This is assisted by a less jagged gating of parts of the world than Borderlands 2 exhibited. There are fewer instances where I collided with enemies I couldn't kill while sticking to the critical path of the game. It's worth mentioning that some sidequests hid entire systems as rewards, such as an item grinder that lets you break down unwanted items for randomized new gear. This makes for a mostly easier game, but it also allows you to finish the main campaign and unlock harder, more loot-rewarding game options. It also means solo-ing the game the first time through is a reasonable option, underlined by boss fights that aren't extended damage sponges â€” at least in comparison to previous games.

This revitalized movement and gunplay keeps Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel interesting to play once the series' routine gear-grind has set in, and it makes moving through previously explored areas on the way to new missions much less of a chore. It's the kind of thing that seems like a complete no-brainer once you've used it, and the idea of playing another Borderlands without it is barely fathomable.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel doesn't feel like a game that needs to be, exactly. It's a story filling in gaps, adding a bit of nuance to a world that's already had two games worth of exposition rather than exploring new ground.  It's the same recipe that's driven two full, long games and a host of downloadable content. But the lark of low gravity proves that the tedious parts of previous games don't have to stay an anchor holding the series down. That addition makes this one last run through the world of Pandora (or its moon, anyway).

We've all heard that this is many peoples least favourite borderlands game, and for me its true also. Let me tell you why.
1. The levels are a poorly thought out design, some maps are definitely better then others, however some are so bad it feels like a sloppy game of *throw shapes at a board* and whatever sticks is how we'll make this map. They tried leaning to heavily on the jump pad mechanic, which was a fun introduction, but it would have been fun if they left it at just randomly placed jump pads used for basic/non essential travel/exploration as well as it did make for some fun innovative combat, Like I said they leaned to heavily on it and basically made labrynth maps based solely on figuring out jump puzzles, this isn't portal or darksiders, its borderlands. 
2. Jacks not so lead character. Some characters were fun while others not so much.  Jack was very memorable in BL2 and in TPS he is the protagonist, yet I don't remember him at all. He had really no good lines or anything that truly popped like in BL2. The worst part is you're running missions for him, constantly interacting with him, following him around listening to him mumble on and nothing stuck. 
3. The DLC's. The DLC for the arena (shock drop slaughter pit I believe)  was way to big  you spent more time running around the arena trying to find enemies then you did fighting them. Not to mention the arenas are kind of getting boring after each game. Claptraps caltastic voyage was an interesting yet dark story actually. However again with the sloppy map design.
4. Claptraps character skill ability. 
Holy mothertrucking hell what an idiotic idea that was, whoever thought of it, I hate you. 15 RANDOM SKILLS that 75% of the time don't really help that much.
Funzerker- Cool thanks for wasting all my ammo. 
One shot wonder- Great I love being launched off the map 
Clap in a box- Hopefully there is any enemy nearby or I guess Im dead, and even then sometimes it still puts you in fight for your life. (This skill removes your gun/melee and places a bomb that isn't guarented to kill all enemies in 1 hit) in your hands and you have seconds to explode it by someone or go into fight for your life) AGAIN, sometimes even detonating it by someone you still go into fight for your life. What the actual fk. This one especially caused me so much anger. 
There is many more stupid abilities he has.

The grinder and the character skills are the only two good things about this title, so make sure you get to abuse the heck out of these two things during your playtime. I know I kept 'read only' grinding weapons until I got a Maggie that fit my level every time I progressed further into the game. 

The true enemy of this game is the level design being a confusing mess that makes you lost, leading to not knowing where to go for a laughably long amount of time. The dialogue and the story are also incredibly un-witty, un-inspired, and ironically un-important to the greater story going on in the background. I would skip this title and only watch the cinematics. I'm still mad that the cliffhanger wasn't incorporated in the third game.

Smaller game, feels a lot like an expansion for Borderlands 2 but certainly worth the money.

- Story is much simpler and yet it feels like there is so much at stake. You will get a closer look into Jack's past and meet some cool new characters. The game however has many weak points. The main story is great apart from the scenes where Jack kills people for the first time. His comments feel kinda weird. There are some events that only closely fit the canon. If you pay attention to the story you will probably notice things like that. For example (spoiler) Lilith questions Athena about what happened during the pre-sequel, while Lilith herself is present in most of the events of Athena's story. You'll have to come up with an explanation like: Lilith just wasn't paying attention half the time. (end of spoiler) Sidequests are a mixed bag. Some are good and funny and some are really annoying to complete with weak writing that tries to be funny.

- Atmosphere is good, it really feels like Borderlands on the moon. Gameplay is the same, with new elements which are very well done. You can again pick up only what you need by holding "pick up" like in Borderlands 1. However the navigation is awfull. Quest pointers point directly to the place you should get to and don't mark the way there, which is annoying since the new areas are complex and huge both horizontaly and veticaly.

- The DLC characters are great. The holodome DLC is just a huge arena with minimal story but the second one is nice again.

Also I have to mention: at one point Mr. Torgue says friendzone is misogenistic... WTF? Makes no sense! That said, this is the only such stupidity in this game.

I usually do not like the Borderlands games because I grow tired of the looter shooter gameplay a few hours in, however the crafting system where you can fuse weapons into better weapons makes this title stand out as more fun to pick up and play.

Roland's got Lilith, Axton's got Gaige. Maya's got Krieg, Athena's got Janey Springs. Jack's got his Handsome title and a badass GF sheriff Nisha. Even Claptrap gets some - his mind gets fixed. And what does Wilhelm get? Paid.

A very meh entry in the borderlands series, more done to pad the time in between Bords 2 and Bords 3 than to make something actually good. It has some unique features with the space-environments without atmosphere and some cool world design, but really it's a lot more of the same.

One of the most evident part is the fact that is brings back Handsome Jack (well actually goes back in time) because Gearbox wrote themselves in a corner when they let their best antagonist die (sorry, spoilers alert) in borderlands 2. So you're back to having to banter with the same guy, and while it's still funny, I think Pre-Sequel is the step too far.

A decent distraction if you get it for cheap, but don't expect anything mindblowing from Pre-Sequel.

I still recommend this game, barely. Get it on sale if you want to play all Borderlands.

Neutral:
- I don't mind this being more of the same. Laser guns/stomping/oxygen management are all right. I don't love or hate them in particular.

Pros:
- Moon-jumping adds verticality to the action.
- Cryo element is a lot cooler than slag.
- While the new character classes aren't anything to write home about, it's refreshing to see the devs try something new.

Cons:
- The biggest con: You don't feel progressively more powerful. By the end of the game at level 27, my Enforcer still lost all his shield and half his health to just a few shots. Enemies are annoyingly bullet-spongy if you don't carry guns with the right elements to deal with them. And they spawn behind you and shoot you from off-camera all the time. That makes your character feel flimsy, even with 2 character levels above the mission level.

- Loot drops are crappy. By the end of the game, you're still getting the influx of white and green stuff. At level 27, I still had to hold on to my level 16 shock-beam gun because other guns barely damaged the shield on Lost Legion soldiers and the Guardians. I can see that the devs probably nerfed the drop rates of higher-tier weapons to push players to use the Grinder, but that leads to the next con.

- The Grinder is RNG-based. You can kind of control what you get. For example, putting in 3 pistols will likely net you a new pistol. But it doesn't always give you a new gun of the next tier. I put in 12 green guns in a row and ended up with 4 worse green guns. You can up the odds by throwing in some Moonstones but those are not easy to come by and you'd better save them for expanding your ammo and item bag capacity because...

- The game can be stingy with ammo and money, especially in the early game. I'd never played a Borderland game where I used up all ammo and money (to buy ammo) before. So, I ended up having a dilemma between grinding all guns and risk getting nothing or selling all guns for ammo, medicine, and respawning. This situation improved in the latter half of the game, but by that time, I already got sick of it.

Summary:
It's more Borderlands but very restrictive in many aspects, therefore, less fun. But it's still worth a try, when on sale.

Borderlands: Oceania Edition. Want the joys of Borderlands but with an additional great back story, Australian and Kiwi culture references, playing as a villain (including "Jack"), and butt slamming in low gravity? GET ON THIS GAME, SON! It's got something for everybody, including you Steve Irwin fans. It's not as long or in depth as Borderlands 2, but it features new aspects that are worth it. And if you make it through Normal playthrough, you're rewarded with True Vault Hunter mode... with commentary from Tina and Brick. The Clap Trap DLC is also a fun Tron like trip into the physical and mental core of robo insanity. What it lacks in raid bosses it makes up in atmosphere, story, and big nods to sci-fi. Though 2K Australia disolved, it left behind one hell of a fun game. 

I may be a bit biased as I'm American Australian, but this is my second favourite Borderlands title. If you love the Borderlands games, this needs to be in your library (if its not already). All the right flavour and still has that classic hilarious charm that Borderlands 3 failed to reignite. There is also a few fun playable references and items in the game, including a shield that is a homage to the late and great Robin Williams. See if you can find it...

Whether or not you will like this game will depend on how you feel about the O2 and varying gravity component of the gameplay. Other than that this game is pretty much on par with Borderlands 2. 

+ The main story greatly enhances the main story of Borderlands 2 by providing a good history of what led to Handsome Jacks maniac genocidal attempt to cleanse the borderlands of all "bandits". Many of the key bad characters are the main classes of this game.
+ The player characters talk for the first time during various conversations providing additional insight into the character you play as and some comedy.
+ Laser weapons are a nice extra weapon class.
+ Cryo. The freezing element replaces the worthless slag element. Freezing has a meaningful impact to combat and also adds some visual details with enemies shattering into blocks of ice and slowing moving through the air in low gravity.
+ New Classes have great variety and meaningful skill trees.
+ DLC. The Claptrap expansion is welcome and fun story taking place in Claptraps mind. Learn about him and see the worlds events through his prespective.
+ Full experience. The claim that this should have been DLC for Borderlands 2 is false. This is a shorter, but full experience. The stories are just as entertaining. Fetch, kill and talk quests are all borderlands quests so its no surprise that there is more here.
+ Physx. The physics supported SFX are back and are even more visually interesting in low gravity environments.

+/- O2 Mechanic. This mechanic is serves as a challenge to the players movement while giving you access to the ground slam and light thrusts. IMO this worked out well and its impact is greatly overstated. The slam is a great attack opportunity allowing you to exploit long drops and turn them into powerful attacks. It does help immerse you into the environments as well.
+/- Gravity. This has been typically been pretty light in past borderlands games, but this time it varies depending on where you are from stronger to even more weak. 

- Weapon grinding is poorly balanced and doesn't offer anything impactful. Its entirely obsolete.
- Some unique weapons simply aren't useful as their oddities often result in them being to unusable compared to other weapons.
- Respawning limitations on some unique enemies is a big negative on replayability and collection of some unique weapons.
- Glitch weapons are cool, but simply aren't strong enough to compensate for their short comings in most scenarios.

[u]Story:[/u] Pretty good story about rise of Hyperion Corporation and Handsome Jack. Story DLC Claptastic Voyage tells us story about secret code inside Claptrap's mind, worth it.
[u]Gameplay:[/u] Looter-shooter as expected with the addition of verticality and Oz Kits as new equipment item, Cryo and Glitch weapons (DLC), new Grinder mechanic that combines 3 items into a new item.
[u]Graphics:[/u] Good as always and unique art style that will look good for a long time.
[u]Sound/Music/Voice:[/u] Good, more Australian vibe jokes (2K Australia).

[u]Optimization:[/u] Good, runs well on low-end PC.
[u]Bugs:[/u] No bugs, but once my item fell under textures.

[u]Singleplayer:[/u] Yes (100% playable solo).
[u]Multiplayer:[/u] Yes (highly recommend to play with friends),  cross-platform multiplayer.
[u]Player Count:[/u] Average (some queue wait time).
[u]Pay to Win:[/u] No (only content and cosmetic DLC, no lootboxes, no microtransactions).

[h1] Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel [/h1]

This part of the story is set between Borderlands and Borderlands 2, where the three former Vault Hunters Lilith, Brick, and Mordecai interrogate Athena after having captured her from the Atlas Domes. Athena then recounts her story about helping Handsome Jack with three other vault hunters. But they witness him slowly transforming into a ruthless tyrant murderer, to the man he is in Borderlands 2

If you enjoyed the first and second Borderlands, you will most likely enjoy The Pre-Sequel as well. Other than low gravity and limited air gimmicks, it's pretty much the same as Borderlands 2 but you're on Jacks side. There's a lot less story in this one but if you're into the Borderlands storyline I would buy this game without any hesitation... besides, the humour is amazing!

So many laughs to be made if you're playing with friends 8.5/10 rating, i'm expecting more from this story!

I was really hoping that when I revisted this game, I would realize that I had been too harsh in my judgment when I first played it, but...it's actually worse than I remembered.

The writing is weak, and the humor this time around is so forced that it feels aggressively unfunny, the new NPC characters run the gamut from uninteresting to obnoxious, the low-grav and O2 mechanics are annoying, the areas are bland, most of the new enemy designs are boring, and the level design is some of the most irritating and least intuitive that I've ever seen. 

On the plus side; Jack's voice acting is still great (even if the actual writing is weaker than in Bl2,) the laser and cyro weapons are decent additions, and it is nice that the story fills in the gaps between the first 2 games (even if it wasn't strictly necessary.) Also, The Claptastic-voyage dlc was enjoyable enough, although it does still suffer from the same issues that plague the base game.

Rating: 7/10

Pros

- Cool laser weapons. Some are pretty powerful and awesome to use when you find the right ones
- Decent story and humour, about what you'd expect from borderlands
- Enjoyable gameplay. Great timesink
- Love the double-jump and launchpad mechanics. Good platforming

Cons

- Killing enemies in low grav spits the loot everywhere and is sometimes impossible to grab. Gets really irritating at times.
- Some of the mapping feels lazy - invisible boundaries, bad terrain for driving etc
- Weapon progression and side quest rewards could have been better IMO. There's an excess of garbage-quality guns and not enough powerful ones.
- Some of the humour is downright cringey but this is barely a factor being honest

Overall, the Pre-Sequel is a mixed bag but does enough right to get a good recommendation. Worth playing if you've never tried it before. Get it on sale.

[h1]Borderlands 2.5[/h1]
The game looks, feels, and plays exactly like the sequel. Same gameplay, same menus, same inventory system, pretty much the same guns. The point of the game is to describe the eventsâ€¦ before the sequel. So you do get a new story, new environments, new characters with new abilities, and a new weapon element and category (which basically translates to 3 new gun types). Another difference is in the way you get to move around with a glide jump and a little double jump boost. It was pretty fun to glide around the map and slam to the ground on command; itâ€™s something different, a welcome addition.

This game is pretty much an obligatory playthrough for any fan of the series. If you like the franchise, its humor, its crazy story and characters, then I donâ€™t see why you would not want to play this game. It presents some very important backstory that ties Borderlands 1 and 2 together. Simply put - itâ€™s just more Borderlands, which is always welcome.

Don't think this deserved all the hate it got on release. It a lot of fun to play, the element and rarity types introduced are great. The story is interesting and the playable characters have personality.

What's not to like about the Borderlands series in general? Loot? Check. Shoot? Check. Annoying robot named Claptrap that won't clap a hand over his trap? Check and double-check. The love for this game lies in the fact that not only is the game fun but it fills in some of the gaps in the lore of the Borderlands franchise. Watching Jack's spiral into villainy (If he is, in fact, really the villain.) proves to show that we can sympathize with the bad guy and still want to take him out. In this particular story, you get to play as the Vault Hunters that sided with Jack and understand his hatred for Roland and the Crimson Raiders which just adds more depth to an already fascinating game.

Can't wait to sink more hours into this game!

The real star of the show in The Pre-Sequel is Jack. In Borderlands 2 he was perhaps the most gleefully sadistic, and effective video game villain since Final Fantasy 6's Kefka. Seeing his journey from hero to maniac is perhaps the biggest reason to make the 20-or-so-hour trek across Pandoraâ€™s moon, Elpis. Writer Anthony Burch shows a real knack for storytelling here, drawing a more sympathetic portrait of Jack without ever making him into the clichÃ©d misunderstood villain. He's every bit the hilarious, ego-centric asshat here that we remember him as, and his excellently written and delivered dialogue is responsible for the lion's share of the laughs.

Itâ€™s a good thing too, because those laughs were often all there was to carry me through the long stretches of purposeless wandering around with barely anything to fight. This is part of a problem Borderlands has had since the beginning, and The Pre-Sequel hasnâ€™t solved it. The inadequate waypoint system that doesnâ€™t save you from going in circles while looking for your next objective, the boring trek back to your quest-giver at missionâ€™s endâ€¦ itâ€™s all still here. The early hours on the moon were particularly trying, since everything is incredibly spread out, and every low-gravity jump takes seemingly forever. I just donâ€™t want to walk towards a diamond on my mini-map for god knows how long to get to where the fun is.

And I really donâ€™t want to go on a multi-step wild switch hunt to trigger said fun once I get there. The Pre-Sequel is cardinally guilty of this one. Apparently neither the Hyperion or Dahl corporations know how to make doors in space, because almost every single one you need to go through requires you to throw a breaker or manual override somewhere back in the area you just slogged through. In a game about shooting and looting, I should be doing those things almost constantly, but in The Pre-Sequel there were times when 10 or more minutes could easily pass without me doing much of either. Things do pick up in the latter half of the campaign, but this sort of buck-and-stall pacing has plagued the series for years, and it gets harder to forgive with each iteration.
But once The Pre-Sequel hits its stride, we get down to what Borderlands has always done best: the bullets start flying, the loot starts dropping, and joyful chaos ensues. The Pre-Sequel delivers a whole lot of that, starting with its four new playable characters and their positively nutty skill trees. Their action skills feel wildly different from one another, and from any of the vault hunters that have preceded them.

Wilhelmâ€™s flying drone duo, Wolf and Saint, really stands out. Not only does one of them go on automated bombing runs against nearby enemies, but the other hangs back to heal him, or even your allies with the proper skill points invested. Nishaâ€™s washes the screen in classic Western sepia, turning her into a godless, gunslinging killing machine for a short while, which is a bit more straightforward, but no less satisfying. Athenaâ€™s shield allows her to go all Captain America on fools, but Claptrapâ€™s is by far the craziest, granting him different abilities depending on the situation at hand. Those who love a more anarchic, unpredictable approach to combat will get all the mayhem theyâ€™d like out of it.
In fact, everyoneâ€™s  skill trees are flush with abilities that reward specific playstyles with powerful temporary effects, like mini achievements you unlock over and over. Borderlandsâ€™ mascot robot Claptrap, now playable for the first time, is the best example. I happen to be a compulsive reloader with a mild death wish, so his Boomtrap skill tree seems to have been made just for me. By rapidly reloading, I can get a variety of big buffs that have explosive results, but at the cost of some health and accuracy. Oh and I have chance of actually griefing my teammates with my action skill (serves you right for joining my game without an invite...jerk). Just reading some of the other charactersâ€™ high-level skills made me think, â€œHow does THAT work?â€ A copy of whatever gun Iâ€™m holding appears in my off-hand? I turn into a walking nuclear bomb? I just had to try this stuff out.

The Pre-Sequel has a few other tricks up its sleeve too, and most of them work out. Not the new Stingray hovercraft â€“ which handles like a wet mop with a ceiling fan strapped to it â€“ but the new low-gravity mechanics are a success. Coming to grips with my elongated jumps took a while, but once it clicked, I started using my new freedom to deadly effect. It becomes so easy to put space between you and your enemies that sniping becomes a more viable option, and being able to bound over cover to slam down behind your foesâ€™ cover makes getting up close and personal easier, and more satisfying than ever.
The new gearing options are a blast too. Freezing enemies solid with cold-based attacks and burning them to a crisp with the new laser-class weapons feels great, but just wait until you see some of the mods that come on the Oz kits that keep you breathing in space. Some grant you accuracy and damage bonuses while airborne, while others give you an entirely different set of buffs depending on whether youâ€™re in vacuum or atmosphere. The Pre-Sequel is really generous with loot, too, so youâ€™ll have plenty of opportunities to shape your character in interesting ways. I mean, my Claptrap basically waltzes into the middle of groups of enemies and decimates them exclusively by reloading and dying. I canâ€™t think of another game I can do that in.
Despite its tendency to make you jump through hoops before getting to the good stuff, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel delivers where I expect it to as a Borderlands fan. The new gear and low-gravity mechanics mixed with the zany skill trees makes for a fresh experience, and with Jack at the center driving the story forward, you get a deeper dive into the always entertaining, if well-traveled universe of Borderlands.

This game got a lot of hate, but honestly I thought it was a really fun take on Borderlands 2. At this point, if you haven't bought this game but you've enjoyed whatever other one you've already played and you're now here reading this review, you'll enjoy this game too. 

While the plot is a bit wonky and has some weird plot holes, it was still funnier and better than BL3. Gameplay wise, low gravity was a very fun take. If you have played BL3's low gravity mission *Space Laser-Tag,* don't worry, you should know that those mechanics were a serious downgrade over this game. The low gravity feels very natural and fluid, and some O2 tanks can provide you with even more control mid air (the rest are mostly the usual gun, health and shield buffs, including mid air specific ones). Gearbox Australia did a really nice job with this game, to the point where i would argue that the mechanics and gunplay were superior to BL2!

Oh, and vending machines are actually useful and regularly provide blue and purple gear, unlike BL2 99% of the time!

[h1]Summary[/h1]
Another adventure in the world of Pandora with all the familiar game play, style and wit we know from the previous games. This is probably best played after some time has passed since you played BL1/2, to bring you back into that familiar world, but in a different location.

Very similar structure to BL2, not much difference in how the game plays. At times it feels like an expansion pack for BL2, but it's enough to be its own episode and worth it on sale.

[h1]Positive[/h1]
Familiar game play from BL2 wrapped in a new story and location. Bring backs some good memories from BL series

Aussie voice acting reminds you of the similarities between Pandora and the Mad Max world.

I liked the sound track, ambient space synth sounds.

[h1]Negative[/h1]
AI has issues sometimes where they get stuck or can't follow you from outdoor into indoor sections.

Lot of enemies have different names but look and behave similar to ones you met in BL2. That's why this sometimes feels like an expansion pack for BL2. Though still plenty of original locations, art and story.

I can't honestly recommend Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel unless you absolutely MUST play the whole series. Low gravity sounded fun; turns out it's just irritating floating around when you'd rather be on the ground grabbing much-needed health and ammo. And it is much-needed as the overall difficulty feels higher than any other in the series, while the drops seem lower. Maybe I have an unlucky face. Handsome Jack's back story was reasonably interesting but that's about all this title had to offer for me. I'm unlikely to replay, unless I suffer advanced memory loss.

A few additions have been made, but most of them feel very slight compared to the huge leap Borderlands 2 made from the first game.The Borderlands Pre-Sequel offers freshly designed air combat thanks to the low gravity of the new planet.A decent continuation to keep the borderlands players happy until the new borderlands series come to the new generation of consoles.Overall it's a decent good game that still gives you the Borderlands experience.

Final Verdict: [b] 7/10 [/b]

Nice

[h1]Positives[/h1]
+ Handsome Jack origin story

+ Traditional Borderlands loot system

+ Challenging enemies

+ Able to beat main story without doing any sidequests and underleveled

+ Last boss feels like an epic finale to the game

+ Harder difficulty after beating the main game to get upgraded loot


[h1]Negatives[/h1]
- Weapon variety suprisingly lacking

- Fire and Corrosion elements feel weak

- Low gravity areas are irritating, makes the movement a lot slower and floatier

- Oxygen is an unimportant gimick

- Strange hitboxes for some objects and enemies; bullets will seemingly travel right through enemies at times or hit an invisible surface right in front of you

- Lack of Badasses


[h1]Summary[/h1]
Base game completed:  YES
DLC completed:  NO
Rating:  7.5 / 10 - Good

Borderlands the Pre-sequel is a major spoiler for people who have not played Borderlands 2.
There are a few changes in this game that are not part of the aforementioned game which is all a plus in my books.  I find the Pre-sequel to be very unbalanced towards cooperative players.  It is the most grindish of all Borderlands titles including the newest one Borderlands 3 which was excellent (I bought upon release from Epic) conversely it is the least liked game in the series from my perspective given the above gripes and with the need to purchase from Epic Store being one of them.
The new mechanic features this really annoying floating feature and ground slams.  This seems a bit cartoon'y even for a Borderlands game furthermore it makes moving around the map tedious and time consuming not too mention very little control while airborne.
As a 100% solo player the game is grind due to enemies always having a higher level then you and/or having very lousy gear available in the first quarter.  Weapons are pretty cool for the most part...it's space so I have a penchant for the laser guns.
The story is quirky, the environments are pretty neat although the story pales in comparison to Borderlands 2 but does provide a linear lead up as intended.  There is a good variety of characters for the player to choose from, in fact one could even say the game offers the best choice of all the other games especially since this feature has yet to be introduced in Borderlands 3. Borderlands 2 character selections are merely upgrades of the original Borderlands characters.
Plenty of popular culture references and assorted tokens of geekdom throughout the game.  I think the 2nd half was better than the first.  I can't bring myself to down thumb this game because after all it's a Borderlands title and ALL the main instalments are winners in my opinion.

Back at its release, this game got mixed reviews from gamers: it was accused of being too much similar to "Borderlands 2". I absolutely loved "BL2", but let's all agree we don't want games being the same thing again and again. And so, sceptical as I am about expending my hard-earned money, I decided to ignore this game for a while. Until I saw that the game had got a lot cheaper, so I finally decided to give it a shot. Here's what I think.

The game indeed looks a lot like the previous game, and all the basic mechanics are there. In fact, one would be justified in believing this was originally meant to be a DLC for "BL2", but got so big that 2K decided to make it a stand-alone game.

The game is set in Pandora's moon Elpis, which means lower gravity, longer jumps and trickier platforming. But the gravity slam is actually awesome, and floating around with the trusters is great (just be warned it costs oxygen). You'll also come across a lot of jump pads, and they are as fun as they sound. But the maps, while not big, can be confusing, lacking that simplicity of "BL2" - this may be because the maps now are much more vertical, with more climbing and platforming required.

On top of that, there's no oxygen outdoors, but thankfully this is not so much of an issue since you can find pockets of oxygen, breathing domes and oxygen canisters everywhere - otherwise, playing the game would be a frustrating experience. Besides, playing with Claptrap nulls this issue entirely.

Because the game takes place in space, the developers may have thought the inclusion of lasers would be a good idea. But they're not very accurate, meaning you need to get close and personal for them to work. Needless to say, you may find yourself using only a few of them.

The game claims that is both a prequel and a sequel to "BL2". But it's not a really a sequel: all of the events you partake in take place before the events of "BL2", and the story is narrated from afterwards. The story also portrays Handsome Jack differently, presenting him at first as a relatable down-on-his-luck anti-hero. But as the story unfolds, we get to see his "transformation", from a poor sod in a bad spot to an ambitious monster. Also, playing as Claptrap is great, not only from a gameplay aspect (again, he doesn't require oxygen), but the game becomes immediately funnier with him, with his voice lines and abilities. In fact, I think playing as Claptrap was the main reason I finally gave in on buying this game. Who wouldn't want that?

And speaking of which, the characters now are much more responsive to dialogues. In the previous game, they would just listen to orders while muted, as if they were Gordon Freeman. They would say some things during combat, but nothing beyond that. In here, they actually respond accordingly to what they hear - and each character has different responses, and hear different lines.

The "Borderlands" franchise has always been known for having some great electronic music, and here is no different - specially given the space setting. The soundtrack goes for a synthwave vibe, putting this new genre to good use. Both the ambient and combat tunes are great, and the soundtrack doesn't make a big show of itself.

This game was largely developed by 2K Australia, and by God, this shows. Everybody has Aussie accents, almost as if Elpis was meant to be the Australia of the "Borderlands" universe. I was half-way expecting a "Mad Max" reference to pop up somewhere, and lo and behold, there's this mission in which you take on a dwarf riding on a massive scavenger, like in "Beyond the Thurderdome" (plus, they're collectively called "Red Kelly", because of course). I feel there should have been a sniping achievement called "Sniping's a good job, mate". Also, since this a "Borderlands" game is set in space, there obviously must be references to "2001: A Space Odyssey" and "Star Wars".

All in all, the game is very worthy to buy on a sale. It may be shorter than "BL2", but it packs quite a punch from beginning to end. I know that right now, people are review-bombing this game because Randy Pitchford is as terrible at being a CEO as he is at being a magician - or a basic human being, for that matter. But in this "Borderlands 3" hype we're at, I decided to finally play this game just to see what's what. And my sincere opinion is that, even with its flaws, it's a very good game after all.

I'll be waiting for "BL3" in 2020. Six months aren't so much time.

I recommend to play Borderlands 2(BL2) before.
Please keep in mind i review full game(with all DLCs)/or if i compare to BL2 i also mean full game(with all DLCs) as its the way how to play them now(imo).
Technically very similar to Borderlands 2.

[b]What i like:[/b]
Graphics looks nice, you can tell its not new game but still holds up very well.
Runs good and dont have many big bugs(didnt encounter any crash, few times needed to reload to continue quest/or if i was stuck).
Gameplay is solid, weapons feels as they should.
Game is semi open world, bigger areas have vehicles you can drive and also shoot.
Playable characters now talk(with other NPCs and during story moments) and its great, adds more personality and its more interesting to play story with all characters.
Golden Keys(SHIFT codes), can get great gear and they still release codes to this day. Its must be random but i got more grenade mods/shields/class mods/pistols and less other weapons compared to BL2
CO-OP but its optional and you can play solo if you want.
Have many playable characters with different skills and is meant to play multiple times so if you like this game you have tens hours of enjoyment.
Claptastic Voyage DLC is really good, some consider its best in series.
Levels/difficulty is imo better than in BL2, also less content so you can't accidentally overlevel too much.
Laser weapons.
Cryo elemental effect(freezes enemies), Slag is missing but im happy with it.
Low gravity/double jump/slam damage(everybody may not be enjoying it but i like it and helps to distinguish from BL2).
Story is good and interesting see how Jack became the villain(its take place before BL2). Also can see some other familiar characters.
Have many Challenges you can complete to get little bonuses(kill x enemies y times, get x kills with certain gun etc), it feels you always working towards something.
Glitch rarity weapons are good and something different.
Moonstones(BL2 Eridium equivalent) have more uses(Grinder) and drop more frequently.
Mainframe song :P :D

[b]What i dislike:[/b]
Much less content than in BL2, also less varied.
Sadly have only one story DLC(BL2 have one great and 4 good ones).
Some maps feels little bit empty and boring.
Good for playing once/twice but not to get max level or complete UVHM.
Holodome sucks, arena is too big and rounds take too long also need to chase enemies.
Much less popular than BL2 so it may be harder to play CO-OP.
Same QOL things like in BL2(dont collect Moonstones automatically, cant refill ammo with one button press etc).
Vechicles steer with mouse, you get used to it but still it would be nice if have option to use keyboard.
When starting with new character you get annoying tutorial text popups you cant close few seconds.

[b]Which version to buy?[/b]
Not worth full price, wait sale.

[h1]The Antagonist Experience[/h1]

The Pre-Sequel is to Borderlands 2 what Saints Row 4 is to Saints Row 3. Even though it's technically made by a different developer, it recycles a lot of elements from BL2 to expand the story, pretty much like a game-sized DLC.

Story-wise, this is the best Borderlands game (even compared to 3) since it actually made me care about the series' [I]lore[/i] than Borderlands 2. The latter felt like it focused entirely on Jack and Angel's storyline, and never really dived into Hyperion, the other weapons manufacturers, or how the previous Vault Hunters ended up where they are now. In this game, you play as NPCs/villains from past/future Borderlands games, and TPS' purpose is to humanize the antagonists of those games by showing us their point of view and struggles. This spin-off could've only truly worked for Borderlands 2 since there was no character in this series like [I]Handsome Jack[/i], and seeing his descent into madness seemed justified with respect to how the world treated him. Even though the voice acting behind every character in the series was supreme, Dameon Clarke takes the cake in terms of materializing a character like Jack into an otherwise goofy game.

Gameplay-wise, it's pretty much identical to BL2's gunplay except for the Moon Gravity and stomping. At first, I thought the Oxygen mechanic was gonna be a pain, but after a while, I didn't seem to mind it as it was abundantly placed across the levels and truly does differentiate it from the other games with its atmosphere-[i]'spheres'[/i] and cosmic/iridescent aesthetic.

[b][u]Nisha Appreciation Paragraph:[/u][/b] But if we're talking about the difference in gameplay, the newest thing about any Borderlands game is its new set of Vault Hunters. While I started co-op with a friend, I picked Nisha (the Indian Sherrif of Lynchwood) and he picked Clap-trap (Hyperion's greatest invention). Since I main'd Gaige in BL2, I didn't play any other character on that game, so trying a new Vault Hunter was the first time was refreshing. Nisha is the complete opposite of Gaige in a sense... they have the opposite focus on accuracy; Nisha loves it while Gaige hates it. Nisha has one of the shortest Action Skill Cooldowns, while Gaige has the longest. Talking about Action Skills, her power is the most game-changing and impactful one to use as it basically gives you [i]aimbot[/i] and you're chaining kill combos by flicking your mouse to a direction while aiming down sights. The duration of this mode is extended with each kill, rewarding you upon using your power when there are more enemies around rather than spraying into a boss like a tank (Gunzerker, Moze, etc). Deathtrap doesn't stand a chance against the sheer adrenalin you get when helping out in co-op with Nisha's Action Skill. Her Passive Skill (which is Dual-Wielding pistols at the final skill tree) doesn't come close to Gaige's [I]Anarchy[/i] though.

[b][u]Co-op Troubles:[/u][/b] Unlike BL2, this game had terrible desync, and someone tells me that it's due to terrible netcode. Apparently, it existed with BL2 too, but it wasn't anywhere as abhorrent as here. Whenever anyone other than the host is playing with a slightly above normal ping, their physical character rubberbands throughout the stage (in an almost [i]'dedicated server'[/i] fashion) even though the game is P2P. You are pushed and pulled without your consent and every time you jump, something or the other makes you teleport back down. Your bullets don't do any damage because the host server thinks none of it is connecting even though you are literally spraying the entire magazine onto an area where you think the enemy is. This gets WAAAY worse when there are multiple small enemies on screen as compared to 1 or 2 high-HP enemies. And since sometimes enemies push you/move your position in the hosts' side, you are teleported into a nearby pit without giving you sufficient time to react and adjust your position accordingly. In the Holodome, the Guardian Gondors and Ophas are annoying as they push you down into the spinning blades even when you use jump pads... (which now that I think of it, are ripped straight out of Portal 2, sound effect and all)

Another curious case of stuttering was on the [spoiler]'Subconscious' map in the Claptrap DLC, and it was getting to a point in which I never saw any map made in Unreal Engine stutter as much as it did period. It was terrible to play the missions that took place on it.[/spoiler]

This game has the same issues I have for the second game. However, the movement in this game (the low-gravity combined with the slam attack) mad the game's jankiness more bearable, and surprisingly I had a great time during the game's first half. However, when I got to Helios the game becomes a pain in the ass, and it's also when I started to notice the game's problems. First off the section with Helios gets rid of the low-gravity mechanic (except for one section) meaning that I have less options to move around. Second, the gunplay in this game sucks (somehow worse than borderlands 2). The best way I can describe it is by comparing it ti another gearbox game Aliens Colonial Marines, as in your bullets don't always go where you're aiming, and this is worse with laser weapons because I often see my lasers go through enemies and yet they don't deal any damage. An example of why the gunplay sucks is when you get a sidequest that tells you to find a code in one room and quickly enter that code in another room before it cahnges. The problem with that quest is that you can only change the combination by shooting the arrows next to each number because the combination is out of reach, but when I shoot the arrows most my bullets don't do shit, so by the time I had put in the code (despite the game screwing me over), the code had already changed so I got to do that bullshit again. I mention this one specific mission because it made it plain as day that the shooting in this game sucks.
[strike]I'm still gonna try finishing this game like I did with borderlands 2 (despite my problems with both games), but after that I'm only gonna play borderlands 3 for my shooter-looter fix because at least the guns in that game function properly.[/strike] Nevermind. I just got to Raum who is a boss that flies around the map shooting rockets that may as well travel at the speed of light, meanwhile a bunch of bullet sponge melee enemies constantly spawn to harass you in an area where there is practically no cover. Hardcore fans of the series may like this game but I'm done with this unfun bullshit.

I found it inferior to Borderlands 2 in pretty much every way - and even Borderlands 1 (have not played 3).  I would only recommend it if you are a die hard Borderlands fan and want more.

First thing is that it runs smoothly on Linux with Proton with no tweaking involved.  I couldn't get the free texture pack to install and have read it might be a Linux thing, but I din't really test it that hard and it wasn't a big deal anyway.

It does a lot of new things such as you now fight on a moon with an appropriate mechanic - oxygen.  If you run out you take damage until you get more or die.  You get something to equip much like a shield and enemies have "bubbles" on their heads you burst. so they also take damage when in space.  There are various areas where you can refill it.  Nice touch is fire doesn't work in space - you can't set people on fire in it (as expected) and you can put out a fire by running into space.

I thought getting affected by elements was particularly annoying as too often I seemed to get affected after the last enemy was defeated so I was left with no one to kille for second wind.

Since there was low gravity, you can jump a little higher (and boost yourself at the cost of oxygen).  The game was designed around this as there are lots of areas where you have to figure out the best way to jump up to get to an objective.  This jumping also carried over to vehicles as there are lots of areas where you have to jump ravines with your car and will fall to your death. Something that was way too common for me -  I think I died more from failing jumps than i did to getting killed by enemies in the entire series (1, 2, and pre-sequel).

I don't really play Borderlands for story (which I don't think is anything special), but this one seemed even worse than what I noticed in Borderlands 1 & 2).  Also annoying was the fact that characters scream at you for not doing something fast enough... even if you literally just accepted a quest from them and had no time to even begin to do what they asked.

All-ln-all, I just didn't care for the game - I have enough to not force myself, but again if you really like the Borderlands series, this might be worth a try.

It's got all the cartoonishly violent silliness of Borderlands and introduces new twists like the laser weapons, jump pads, hoverbikes and the need to conserve oxygen in an environment that has no atmosphere.  The characters are cool and seeing the story of Handsome Jack's descent into the madness he had in Borderlands 2 was dope af.  Also I just love the characters, especially Athena.  Hearing Janey Springs' adorably awkward attempts at flirting with her was a big bonus in Athena's story for me.  Getting to know some of the other series villains like Nisha and Aurrelia Hammerlock was interesting and fun too.   On the negative side, the main story seems a bit shorter than the others with fewer side missions to do, orange and purple weapon drops seem harder to get, and the characters' action skills in this one seem the most inconsistent in their usefulness out of all the Borderlands games I've played.  I was a little disappointed by the DLC not expanding the story as much as the ones for 2 and 3 did - although the new characters it added were great.  Also, having played 3 before this made me miss some of the QoL improvements that were added in that one like fast travel from anywhere, one-button refilling your ammo and individual loot drops.
It took me a long time to get around to playing this game but I've really enjoyed my time with it both solo and with friends.
