Original Review: Actually pretty good, and i played as claptrap!

New Review: Yeah i made the old review very quickly, but i do think this is an underrated gem
Maybe it's because everyone praises Borderlands 2 as the Holy Grail, and everyone considers Pre-Sequel that "You can skip it" kinda game, but i do think this is the better game if given the choice.
The New Gameplay elements are fantastic, the story is on par with 2, and the characters (Yes i did play as claptrap on my first playthrough) are great, and the shorter length compared to Borderlands 2 makes it much more accesible.

That said there are a couple of thing i didn't really like:
1. Half of the characters are nothing special. Jack, Claptrap and the Cowgirl were my favorite characters, the rest were just kinda there.
2. There's barely anything to do after you complete the game. There's only one extra campaign DLC, and it's super short but i do think it's one of the better ones.
3. This game REALLY benefits from playing with friends....Too bad my friends prefer CS:GO so pfffft

Other than that, a hidden gem, definetly worth it, it's on sale for 10 bucks, you might as well (Just don't play it right after you finish Borderlands 2, or you'll burnout quick)
9/10

[h1]Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel[/h1]

After the Borderlands 2 soundtrack and the short preview video with Sanctuary that welcomes us at the opening, we come to the character selection screen and the great humor of Borderlands shows itself before the game even starts. (I don't want to write the detail that made me laugh at the character selection screen, you should see it first hand)

Unlike the first two games, the Pre-Sequel has new classes along with new characters. I'm not going to take a quick look at all the classes and talk about their strengths and weaknesses, as I haven't spent a lot of time with them.

[b]But it is useful to take a look at our new characters, albeit a little.[/b]

Athena: We can say that she is the most 'tank' character in the game thanks to her special ability. Introduced as a 'gladiator' at the beginning of the game, Athena uses a special shield. This shield absorbs the energy of direct attacks and when you throw it at the enemy, it both damages itself and the energy it collects.

Willhelm: Remember the giant, yellow robot that came after you blew up the train with Tiny Tina's help in Borderlands 2? Here Willhelm becomes the old version of this friend. Willhelm, who is trying to turn himself into a cyborg to make himself a better warrior, uses two drones with his special ability. While one of them is constantly trying to keep you alive, the other attacks the opponents. In fact, we can say that it is the new version of Wilhelm, Axton and Roland.

Nisha: He's kind of a berserker. When Nisha, a former bandit and then got bored of it and started bandit hunting for fun and profit, uses her Showdown ability to upgrade all her weapon characteristics and automatically locks onto enemies and attacks with 100% accuracy.

Claptrap: aka Fragtrap. He is perhaps the most enjoyable character in the game. Unlike the other three classes, Claptrap doesn't specialize in anything other than talking all the time. When Claptrap uses his special ability, vaulthunter.exe, he analyzes the situation he is in and uses an ability accordingly. By the way, the abilities that Claptrap uses are not the abilities of the new characters, but the abilities of the old characters. When you use vaulthunter.exe with Claptrap, you can also have an ax in your hand to jump on your opponents, you can also throw a turret like Axton's. Get ready for surprises and laughter.

We start the game by coming out of a wreck again. This time we are a Vault Hunter recruited by Hyperion and Jack, against whom we fought before. Compared to the previous game, Jack gives us goosebumps with his sane, even trying to help appearance.
After reluctantly saving Jack from our enemies, we can say that the game starts slowly. Because it is only the music and low gravity that can break the atmosphere of Borderlands 2, which is the whole game.
Jack saves us and sends us to Pandora's moon Elpis. As soon as we land on the surface of Elpis, we meet the low gravity and Oz capsules, the new addition to the game.
Because there is no or very sparse atmosphere on the Elpis surface, we need these capsules to breathe. We use oz capsules not only for breathing but also for movement. The low gravity atmosphere of Elpis allows you to make higher and longer jumps when you jump. When you press the jump button while in the air, you can throw yourself forward or you can press the tilt button to land suddenly and stun your enemies by creating a jolt around you.
This feature, which you don't mind too much at first, turns into a very fun job when you get used to it, and allows you to make strategic moves or find great sniper positions during combat.
New laser weapons, features such as freezing your enemies and a tool called Stingray have been added to the game. We can say that the Stingray is a motorcycle that can float in the air and can make vertical jumps.
The atmosphere of the closed/non-Oz areas in the game, the menus, Badass ranks and the vendors you can buy items are exactly the same as Borderlands 2. In order to feel the difference of Pre-Sequel, you have to go out to open areas.
I can say Jack and Claptrap are the most crucial things in the Pre-Sequel or the things that make the game unique.
It was really interesting and nice to see how the sane and heroic personality of Jack, who appears in the game, gradually changes and turns into an old psychopathic Jack.
Claptrap, on the other hand, is a subject in itself and I think a special article should be written for it. Claptrap's useless conversations, non-funny jokes and great (!) intelligence are always with you with the playable character, and most of the time you can't hit the target because of laughter.

[b]Pros[/b]
 - Playing with Claptrap
- new classes
- low gravity
- Jack's story
- Borderlands' great sense of humor

[b]Cons[/b]
- Too close to Borderlands 2
- It did not bring any tangible innovation to the series.

[h1]Decision[/h1]
Although the Pre-Sequel may not seem like a Borderlands 2 imitation in many respects, one should not be fooled by this. The interaction of the new characters in the game with the story, the fact that Claptrap is a playable character and the usual great Borderlands humor are details that should be experienced especially for the followers of the series. Pre-Sequel may not sound very binding or enjoyable when you play it alone. But when you play co-op with your friends, everything changes and you can find yourself in a great fun. If you are a Borderlands follower the Pre-Sequel will give you what you expect from Borderlands.

[b]Thanks for reading![/b]

2K and Gearbox have broken the games. They are not able to be played with buddies anymore. Ain't that fun.


Seems like they've fixed the issue that didn't allow players to play together. All in all, I'd have to say, this is my favorite modern Borderlands. The game itself is padded, because the game was originally supposed to be a DLC for Borderlands 2 (yay, exactly what we all needed, another DLC for a game that has too many DLCs). But they had to instead flesh the game out enough to make it a whole game. That can be felt quite a bit at quite a bit of places.

That out of the way though, there are a lot of fun things that this DLC has to offer, and all in all, I really like this game. Ever since I played through Borderlands 1 back when it came out, I wanted Cryo weapons, that's here in this game. They got rid of Slag, which is amazing. All in all, expect Borderlands 2, but with Space, and Aussies. I think they really did a good one with the atmosphere here, making it really feel like a different place when compared to that of Pandora (by making everybody an Aussie). The story, I'd have to say, is better than that of any other in the series.

Some characters are very obnoxious to listen to, my personal favorite (made me turn down dialogue volume to 0) is Rose, I don't think I've EVER hated a video game character this much.

I'm not willing to put up with the amount of walking and backtracking, but for those who are willing, I think it's worth it, just... do yourself a favor and avoid as many sidequests as you can to limit the walking, fetching and backtracking, there are very few fast travel stations and often times they're in spots that take a long time to get to.

extremely underrated. VERY creative. To me it doesnt just feel like a dlc like how some criticism will say, due to the differences and length of the story. There is a lack of side missions compared to other borderlands entries possibly and lack of raid bosses but this was due to the fact that production was under means. Seeing Jack go bad is already a reason that i really enjoyed this game, He is the best video game villian I've personally seen in the games I've played at least. yes it plays just like bl2 but the differences make it stand out in a different way. I almost feel like no one talks about this game, people are missing out. very fresh. I've almost played all borderlands games fully and i LOVE all of them for different reasons. 2 is my favorite though probably if I had to pick, so TPS definitely in certain areas i like just as much (still doesnt compare tho), its enjoyable and has certain game mechanics that are extremely fun. Claptastic voyage DLC  is so on point. favorite BL dlc so far other than pirates booty. The claptrap song had me GEEKING. Life without claptrap is a joke, such a lovely robot. best song ever. Also seeing the entire claptrap population get merked is kinda equally sad and funny. The color palette and atmosphere, story progression/ areas to explore and their coexistence, as well as being different but similar as with all other borderlands games this does what it needs to achieve. as well as having interesting new loot (yes some is recycled from bl2 i know which is annoying but whatever) and fun new mobs &bosses (lack of raid bosses tho, but shadow trap is SO FUN and hard)  9.4/10 (maybe im generous) I took off mostly for pacing being slow in the first quarter, and LACK of content and raid bosses/ new legendaries that werent from bl2. but this was due to the lack of hype for the game which you cant control. I understand that production inevitably controls art forms in the real world, rather than the means of production. Nothing is perfect. also if you for some reason dont like that everyone is australian in this game idk you need to relax mate

Great prequel/sequel to BL1 & BL2.

It's funny. When I got in late with BL2, I wrote in my review that I wish I would have gotten it at release instead of many years later due to how much of an awesome and fun game it was. I even wrote down that when and if BL3 drops, I'll pick it up day one.

But then the Epic Games Store exclusivity happened, and I vowed not to purchase BL3 even when it came to Steam like a year later. I won't be buying BL3 until it's super low on sale with all of its DLC. They can kiss my bass after pulling that nonsense.

So instead, I picked up the Pre-Sequel and finished it from beginning to end with a friend, and I felt that same feeling I did when I first played BL2. Why didn't I play this as soon as it came out, or when I first finished BL2? I have no idea. It's such a good game. It felt a lot shorter compared to BL2, but I still enjoyed my time with it.

I look forward to playing BL3, however many years that will be. Not yet. Even on sale, that one year of Epic exclusivity has made me uninterested. I got plenty of other games to play. Like the Pre-Sequel.

First negative is the glitching. Maybe some people don't get this problem but I played with someone and a jump-pad glitched them so they were offset and we had to quit. They could see themselves stuck in a corner whereas i could see them aimlessly running around the surface. We had jumps in the car that sometimes just wouldn't work even fully boosted, random de-sync/crashes, and once a car exploded because it nudged a rock.

Second is the dogshit humor. Most of it relies on "look how australian we are",  like yeah theres memes about australia but its not THAT funny.  Some parts like claptrap randomly mentioning "staging a revolution" are really lazy ham-fisted references to make people say "omg they mentioned that thing from another game" because they couldnt find a way to organically bring it up in dialogue. 

Third is the terrible voice acting/dialogue. It was shit in general but certain characters that shared a voice actor (janey/cybil for example) just didnt sound any different at all. 


The mild pros are the oxygen system was okayish, the boost-jump and slam were nice to use.

What a low effort shitshow considering the magnitude of the company putting this out.

I bought the Handsome Collection for Borderlands 2's massive array of content, and found this game after purchasing it in the bundle. After giving it a try though, and after completing 100+ hours in Borderlands 2 , I came to love both of these games. As to provide further background on my playing habits, I also have 1100+ hours of experience playing Destiny 2, 1000+ hours of experience playing Dragon Age Inquisition, a bit of experience in Dragon's Dogma, a little experience in Destiny 1 (Before the sequel released), a bit of experience in Dragon Age Origins as well as in Dragon Age 2 and Dragon Age Awakening, among other games. For what ever reason, if you're a fan of FPS and RPG-genre games, I can say, somewhat assuredly, that you will come to enjoy these games as well.

Builds on the solid gameplay of Borderlands 2, but doesn't offer quite as much as far as story goes. 
Outside of the low-gravity environments that allow for some of the new mechanics to shine most of the level design before the final chapters feels kind of samey and uninspired.

The combat is fast and satisfying, but the game is lacking in a few other areas- especially pacing issues the unnecessary backtracking grind.

Not a bad entry to the franchise, but I can see why this one is not as beloved or replayed as 2.

i can neither play this game further nor recommend it:

1) The low-gravity gimmick gets really old really fast. It makes movement difficult and tedious, especially when swapping between this game and games which have normal gravity. Having to jump 10 times to reach *just the right spot* five meters up a wall to stick a poster (as a mission goal) is not fun, it's just frustrating, especially when...

2) i cannot tolerate (HATE *HATE* **HATE**) timers on in-game missions and this game effectively adds a timer to *everything* via its quickly-depleting oxygen tank. That flat-out ruins the game for me. i could, in time, get over point (1), but this one is an absolute experience-killer for me.

I'm on a Borderlands kick again and saw I never left a review for this one. Plus it's on sale as of writing this, so may as well bring some attention to it.

Honestly, I don't have the slightest idea why people seemed to hate this one so much. The oz kits were a fun mechanic but never killed me, the new laser weapons were a blast, and I personally found the jokes hilarious. Sure, the humor was [i]different[/i] on account of being made by 2K Australia, but... I thought it was funny. It still felt like Borderlands.

I liked the story and thought it did a decent job at following continuity. It had flaws here and there, but that's pretty standard for these games. It had the best playable characters, referring to the [i]character[/i] part, with narrative dialog actually varying depending on the vault hunter. Something the next installment scrapped for some bizarre reason.

It only got one campaign DLC due to 2K Aussie getting shut down, but that DLC rocked so hard.

The Presequel was good and I stand by that.

it's more borderlands. a bit uninspired, terribly unfunny despite its constant (CONSTANT) jokes, characters are just as linear as the game and with lots of mechanics that make you question why this series is still going to this day. but yeah, it's more borderlands and yeah, if you enjoy borderlands, you'll most likely enjoy this one.

now that i'm living in australia, some of its jokes, names and overall humor make sense and it's nice to see that the developers added them, gives the game some soul. but everything else is contentious to have any sort of positive arguments on my side. the space theme makes the game slow, bordering a walking simulator in some parts. backtracking is constant. enemies are the same for the rest of the game after you play the first hour of it (ignoring the end part which is even worse somehow). the loot is never satisfying (at least on a first playthrough, i wouldn't be surprised if they only drop the good stuff after you grind for it as usual). sigh, anyway.

it's more borderlands for the borderlands fans. frustrating but playable i suppose.

I would say Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel was probably my second favorite game in the series (behind 2). I will admit that a lot of what made this game enjoyable for me personally were the DLC characters like Handsome Jack. The game itself and the original story were great but being able to go through that as Handsome Jack and Claptrap elevated the experience even more for me. I typically try to not weigh DLC too much into my reviews given the base game is what I am reviewing but I was just continuously blown away at the extra dialogue and jokes so much so that it felt disingenuous to not mention it in my review.

If you are looking for a good entry way into the series I would say definitely do not start with this game and start from the beginning with Borderlands 1. All I can really say is that if you play 1->2->The Pre-Sequel you will definitely not regret spending your time in this game!
If you enjoyed other Borderlands games you will like this one too.

Yeah, it feels like a stand-alone expansion more than a sequel, but hOLY CRAP is it a fun game. Writing is as top notch as ever, the new characters are fun to muck around with, the laser guns are fun to use, and the oxygen mechanics are an interesting idea that's excellently executed. Yeah, I may be biased since this was my first Borderlands game, which means I in no way, shape or form agree with the arguments that Pre-Sequel is the worst in the entire series, but look at it this way: at least it wasn't as mediocre as 3 is.

So much fun!

Improving upon the original Borderlands, you get a better variety of weapons, more unique missions, and improved enemy AI.

New to the series is a moon setting (including low gravity and an oxygen requirement that doesn't bog down gameplay), an entirely new roster of characters (including some powerful ones via DLC), and a far more coherent, engaging, and cinematic storyline that serves as a backstory to Borderlands 2.

Shorter story than 2, but the gravity and boost jumping are fun.

A middling and forgettable Borderlands experience.

Sure the game looks and plays like Borderlands 2 but the constant travelling, the backtracking is more than enough to make the game feel like a chore to play. It's a lesson in how bad mission structure and level design can really hamper the core gameplay. Its flaws are also more pronounced due to being a 2014 game. Gunplay feels stiff, UI is clunky, your character not being able to sprint slide. I might be able to look past those issues in Borderlands 2 because that game was released in 2012. For a 2014 game though, considering what its contemporaries at the time brought to the FPS genre, it's unacceptable and the game was clearly constrained by the PS3/X360 era of video games.

I don't think the game is straight up bad, As of writing this, halfway into 2021, I'm having a harder time understanding why this game needed to exist. It feels like it could have been a DLC, but instead, the whole experience feels padded and stretched out with mindnumbling backtracking and fetch quests.

the game is pretty fun so far and i love seeing jacks decent into madness but there is two problems i have with it.

the game doesn't give you the ability to level up properly, im currently level 20 but entering into the retaking of helios section of the game i was a level 17 fighting enemies that eventually went on to be level 23. i had no problem beating them because ive dumped a few hours into other borderlands game but if this were my first experence with borderlands id quit the game like i originally did with BL2. the thing is this is after doing litterly every side quest in concordia which is supposed to be the equivalent of sanctuary which i still havent cleared all the side quests of on my maya save file. not only does the story line not give you enough levels to fight through the story line itself the main area where all the shops and characters are don't either. this requires you to either throw your body at the story line over and over until you get lucky enough to win or actively roam the maps to find side quests to fill a sliver of your exp bar which as a person who just likes to run the story line then do side quest later isn't very fun in my opinion.

the second gripe i have is that despite the game a full release and a standalone game the story line feels like a DLC. ive only sunk 6 hours into the game so far which was one night of gaming and ive already made it the the beginning of the end. the story really needs more substance to it whether that be a boss or more, more could of been done with felicity for example or the lost legion could of sent more bosses other than the two they do send. 

the game is extremely fun though and if you've played BL2 before and really enjoyed it like me id suggest grabbing this game to give a playthrough. it provides alot of lore to the world and helps kill the time.

Many people say that this game is worse than BL2. It maybe true in some way, however I still think The Pre-Sequel is a really good game at the end of the day.

Many people complain about the O2 system, which in my opinion does not have any drawbacks as it is rare to die from lack of O2. As a trade off, you get the boost jump which is both fun and really tactical. The movement is so much better than that of BL2, and it is fun to fly and slam enemies.

For weapons, yes, they are mostly reused from BL2. Is it bad? I don't think so. They are still good, and even better compared to its BL2 counterpart which is due to the game's better balance, so that weapons which were discouraged in BL2 UVHM are actually really viable in TPS's UVHM. The introduction of Cryo is really nice as it is not something everyone must has in later game, instead it is an element designed to make the game easier. Unlike slag, you dont need to always equip a Cryo weapon in UVHM thanks to much better balance and actually a "hard mode", rather than ridiculous x4 health pool of all enemies.

The story explains many plot holes in BL2: Jack's backstory, his rise to power, his relationship with Moxxi, his hatred for the 4 original VH and even Claptrap. The story also feels sadder as it centers around betrayal, especially what happened to Jack and Claptrap. 

The classes are more unique than BL1 and 2. There's no the typical sentry/turret, siren or sniper. In TPS we have a Botmaster some sort, a defensive based class, an aimbot class and FragTrap. They are unique, they are new and especially much more fun to play as.

My only real complain is: Australians in space?

Overall I greatly enjoy this game. Most reviews on YouTube put the bar too high for TPS, but at the end of the day this is purely my opinion.

Like Borderlands 2, Pre-Sequel advertises itself as a co-op game but in actuality the way the game handles scaling, as well as its shoddy netcode, means that trying to play this game as a group is an absolutely joyless experience.
The campaign is short and consists mostly of running from place to place fighting bandits and soldiers who have stupidly accurate aim and will knock off your shield and health with only two or three shots if they are just one level higher than you. There aren't many bosses and pretty much all of the sidequests are busywork meant to pad out the game and give you extra experience so that you can level up high enough to match the main campaign's level.
The writing is chock full of retcons and poorly thought out character motivations. Lilith blames Athena for Roland's death when it's just as much her fault for not killing Jack when she had the chance, for example. But you don't play Borderlands for the writing.

Unless you really, really loved BL2 and want more of it but worse, skip this one.

The game isn't bad per se, but it doesn't bring much to the Borderland series in terms of content. 

The oxygen management is a cool idea along with the gravity butt slam on paper, however it doesn't change combat for the better. Fire is indirectly nerfed because you need to be in an oxygen bubble or area for fire to actually ignite otherwise it'll do piss poor damage. On the other hand, the new element Cryo is pretty damn sick because it helped against enemies who keep running away and lets them take even more damage when frozen. The laser guns sound cool as well, they're pretty much just smgs with barely any recoil and a longer(?) range except that they consume a bit too much ammo.

In terms of content, the story is basically there to fill in most of plot holes from the previous games (Borderlands 1 & 2) specifically about Jack's backstory and his relationships with other titular characters in the series. I'd say that the plot is pretty damn good compared to Borderlands 3, [spoiler]which pretty much retconned this plot and had Aurelia turn into a bitch boss[/spoiler]. Gameplay is pretty much the same as in BL2.

If you want this game, try to get it on sale. It's not bad, it's barely different from BL2 with less content.

Welcome to the Handsome Jack Expansion Pack for Borderlands 2.

You will play as a group of Vault Hunters that Jack hired to help him save the world! (Pandora) Some of them you might already know, such as Nisha or Wilhelm. You follow Handsome Jack on his quest to be the hero and defeat the Lost Legion led by Colonel Tungsteena ZARPEDOOOOON! 

Playing through the story using the new additions as Elpis' low gravity and laser guns you will come to realize what a monster you were in Borderlands 2 and you destined Pandora to an endless cycle of violence, death and misery and stopped the only man... nay, HERO! who might have turned things around and that Lilith and her merry band of child killing psychopats were the reason Handsome Jack became who he was. And it was the pain and betrayal they inflicted upon him made him go a bit far in his dream to civilize Pandora and bring peace and order to the hostile planet.

After you finish this game, you will get a daunting feeling of regret everytime you think back to the ending of Borderlands 2 and Jack's final words and only then you realize that you truly and absolutely chose the wrong side in this story.


For serious now:
Good stuff:
- Laser Guns
- Low Gravity
- Low Gravity Super Slams
- More Handsome Jack

Not so good stuff:
- Game is shorter
- Ending feels rushed
- No worthwhile DLC's (Claptastic Voyage is the only story DLC, others are arenas and pretty bad ones at that)

Bad stuff:
- It's short
- Worth only on sale (I got Borderlands 2 and PreSequel with all DLC's pack for pretty cheap)


All and all, I'd recommend this for the fans of the series and Handsome Jack. Get the Borderlands 2 first and play that.

Yup, this was made by the guys who had a meltdown when a fictional robot was missgendered; what can one expect? Actually a game that is mechanically well-made; no denying that. Definitely better than Borderlands 2. The two main complaints about TPS are that the maps are too empty and the late game is lacking. (See edit) Borderlands 2 was egregious with its sprawling, open, EMPTY areas that had catch-a-ride stations few and far between. TPS, meanwhile, has more densely populated areas with moon zoomy stations located much more frequently. Not to mention the incredibly fun advanced movement system. TPS in general is much faster paced in its gameplay, and that alone gets a win from me.

EDIT: Once you finish the base game, there's just the Claptastic Voyage and the Holodome, both of which are extremely lacking in terms of endgame content. There just isn't enough here to entice someone to play for more than 30-40 hours unfortunately.

Borderlands the Pre-sequel is a good game.

The said, even though I do love the series, this game is not without a few flaws. 

One. The Oxygen system is an annoying gimmick that rarely punishes you since there are so many air spots for you to breath in.  Even if you run out of air, if you have a big enough health pool you can literally spend minutes standing in one place without fear of dying.  Not including combat scenarios. 

two. Kinda wish we had more to look at than the moon.  Borderlands 2 had you go from place to place with unique looking areas and crazy new people to talk to.  This version just has the moon. .  and more moon stuff.  oh, look a big building to walk through, oh look, a giant factory!  Only two places give you some unique vibes like the Helios space station or the vault door itself.  Nothing else to write home too.

three. The grinder system isn't that great. I thought it would be more fun, but the recipe system is pretty simple once you look it up. But I rarely use it, since I normally just sell my guns and move on, even with the moonstone boost your guns get from it. I generally don't see much difference in performance. 

four. The story kinda drags on a little too long in the finale, once Jack loses his collective shit. I was just ready to be done with this game move on to something else. 

That's really all I can think at the moment, but other than these issues. I still find myself buying this game again on Steam.  

So if you like the Borderlands series, then this a game that will stay true to its run, shoot, murder, and explode things lifestyle!

Borderlands: The Pre Sequel is an okay game that turned really bad inside Claptrap. You play as one of Athena's team working for Jack before he became Handsome Jack. Colonel Zarpadone has taken over Hyperion. You and Jack need to retake control of the Hyperion. Playing through the game, you will unveil parts of the buildup towards Borderlands 2. The main objective of the game is to level up, kill monsters and bosses, collect loot, rinse and repeat.

Gameplay-wise, it's a First-Person-Shooter. Shoot, level up, loot, rinse and repeat. As long as your level is higher than the creeps, you win the battle. If you're significantly lower, go do stupid grinding to level up and win. 

I played as Claptrap. This was a really lucky choice as I didn't know there was an oxygen mechanic. You play mostly on a moon and in space. If you run out of oxygen, you start to lose health points rapidly. If you are Claptrap i.e. a robot, you don't need to worry about oxygen.
The same oxygen is also used for boosting your jump and can only be refilled in atmosphere.

If you fight and kill the Sentinel at the end, you get to play the inside of Claptrap. It's meant to be an additional stage after Sentinel but it's so draggy. You have to access Deck 13.5 to trigger it.

Conclusion, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequal is so grindy. I couldn't play any further once I got to the inside of Claptrap. The overall world design is extremely disjointed. You have bits and pieces of weird parts that don't make sense. 

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. Simple to Play
Jump, point and shoot.

2. Decent Amount of Stuff
I thought killing Colonel Zarpadone was the end but no, there's the Sentinel. It will backfire later with Claptrap

3. Low Gravity
sv_gravity 0.3 is a good idea. Keep it. Traverse the map so much faster. 

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. So Repetitive, It's Boring
The gameplay just grinds on any positive emotions I had for the game. Just be a higher level with high level weapons and you win the bosses. Just grind to victory, it's so boring. The general phase is shoot, level, loot, rinse and repeat.

2. Half-assed Combat Design
The bosses just do the same thing over and over again with different colours. E.g. Sentinel battle part 2, Lightning, Corrosive, Armour. All of the faces do the same action, floor damage with floating rocks, blackhole ball, explosion floor, etc

3. Smash Pads
Copy, paste, rotate 360? Why are there smash pads that explode in random locations?

4. No World Building
It's just randomly outsourced maps. There's no world that they built. E.g. Random Lovecraftian creatures like the Shuggarath. It's disjointed. Like combining horror mental creatures into sci-fi and steampunk. 

5. Dead World
Yea, it's just full of lamp posts. The world is really boring. Concordia is really boring. It looks like the concept for Mad Max. On top of a tower.

6. Vehicles Don't Have Space to Play
You don't have huge flat land to drive about. There's pitfalls and random buildings in the middle of nowhere in space.

7. Stupid Side Quests in the Main Mission
You get to Hyperion, it's filled with Lost Legion. You have to take over ASAP and..... side quests on Hyperion. WTF? 

[h1][b]NEUTRAL[/b][/h1]
1. Concept of Claptrap's Insides
Looked good at the start but the random glitches and fragmented memories. OMG.

[h1][b]SUGGESTIONS[/b][/h1]
1. Better World Design
Since Borderlands 3 is due by 13 September 2019, I think there's nothing much you can do in such a short time, but could you work on a Citadel? *cough* Titanfall

2. MMO Gunner
You have dedicated servers. Why not send players into an MMOG from the start of the game? Players will enter a central city and play with other players. It will help reduce the extreme grindiness. *cough* Destiny

3. AI Help
At the very least, could you give us the option to add AI as a meat shield?

4. Huge Flat Map Solely for Vehicle Combat
Stingray and Buggy are extremely limited. I know you have a sand skiff. Please add that into BDL 3. Make a giant snake monster that burrows in and out of the sand. Then you drive around avoiding its attacks and shooting the sand monster in its weak spots. Like those arcade shooters, Time Crisis or Resident Evil. Vehicle dies, you die. You don't get the luxury of running around on that map.

5. Train Fights
Moving train, time limit. Start from the back and work your way to the engine. Engine compartment has a boss. I have a few twist and turns to add but I'll see if you do it.

6. Change The World as The Game Progresses
Change the environment, bring new characters to Concordia. E.g. Spring was brought to Concordia. Bring Pickle, then Torque, then Marcus Munitions, etc. You already have Nina.

7. Make A Torque Dispenser
Only Marcus Munitions the whole game? Give Torque his Explodie dispenser. 

8. Make a Pickle Dispenser
Shields, special grenades and what-not

9. Claptrap Dispenser
Now, a dispenser that dispenses robots. Hmmmm....

10. Quests
Make a quest to find all the Torque/Pickle Dispensers in the game

After deliberating on whether or not I even wanted to put the time to play enough of this game to write a review, I broke down and played through the story hoping that perhaps this game actually held some kind of value over the first two. And since I obtained this stupid thing in a bundle, I've had it staring at me from my library of Steam games. If you're looking for a sunshiny disposition to accompany this review, you're barking up the wrong tree.

As a gamer, I am specifically drawn to story elements (for the most part). If a game doesn't offer boundless sandbox building capabilities, it needs to have a narrative that draws the player in and immerses you in the world. The Borderlands series doesn't have that. It's shiny on the outside, and utterly hollow. Once you strip away the game-play mechanics, there is absolutely nothing that this game offers. There's little in terms of story, and what story remains can be summarized in one sentence: One nut-job tries to destroy a moon as the player helps a different nut-job save the moon before nut-job number two becomes the Borderlands 2 villain. That's it. There's no nuance to it. It's drawn out with ornate but ultimately tedious set-dressing and meaningless obstacles. That's all there is.

I'm not saying that you might not enjoy this series, but I'm at the very least going to be honest about it. If you're looking for a tale to sink your teeth into or a world to immerse yourself in, Borderlands is going to leave you feeling unfulfilled.

I had initially played this game for only a few hours and then passed on it only to come back to it after playing Borderlands 3 recently.

 It tells the backstory leading up to Borderlands the earlier Borderlands. 

Overall if you are familiar with the Borderlands franchise, well it follow the formula to a T. You pick a class, you shoot things, you get loot, you shoot more things, there's some kind of story in there but really that's not what you came for anyways. 

The biggest twist between this one and the others is that this one seems Aussie made with many Aussie accents, and what I would guess is Aussie humor. This is good or bad depending how much you enjoy such Aussie humor. Me? I can take or leave it depending so I found it at times great and some times terrible. It seemed the longer the game went the worse it got. 

Also a big change from all the other games is that the game takes place in space. In space areas you can just very high and floaty. You also get and have to manage an oxygen supply, but honestly it's really only a factor in the early parts of the game. Eventually you get so much oxygen dropping form killing enemies that it really does not become much of an issue. Both of these mechanics are a downgrade in your experience in every way.

The game is somewhat short at ~15 hours to complete, but toward the mid and late game I didn't do that many side missions and pushed through somewhat under-leveled. The side missions seemed mostly forgettable.

This game does have some really interesting classes though which I thought where interesting. I played though as a body double of Hansom Jack for example, but there is a Clap Trap wizard class that I thought was pretty interesting too.

When I compare this game to others in the series it seems like a very mediocre game. Don't get me wrong it was still enjoyable but not really memorable in any way. If you enjoy any of the other games in the franchise then you should give it a go.

Unfortunately, I can't recommend this game. Up to a certain point it's all fine and dandy but there comes a point where you realize you are playing a running simulator, rather than what you'd expect from a Borderlands game. The missions become a real chore. ''Pick up this on this side of the map'', ''Now run across the map and get this thing'', ''Now, go put this in that... but not here... there'' ''Now, almost done, you see that thing on the other side of the map? We're gonna need that, go pick it up''. Which I would have much less of a problem if most of the maps didn't look the same. I was really hyped to play Borderlands in space, only to be let down by the poor map design.

It feels like 2k Australia tried to stretch the missions out as far as possible. Also, I didn't give zero sh**s about the characters. I just wanted them to shut up so I could go on about my day. 

I thought the grinder would be a welcome addition but it kinda ruins co op gameplay in my opinion because everybody wants weapons they can grind. Because hey ''3 blues equal a purple''. It's not like in BL2 where if a blue dropped and nobody needed it, it wouldn't matter who gets it.




I guess there are pros to the game too but they overshadow the cons by a long shot, but to keep it simple: The game feels like a chore and isn't as good as BL2 (where I don't mind doing missions multiple times, seriously, the replay value on that game...)

Greetings as I hope all is well! Below is my Steam Review for Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, thanks for reading as I wish you well in all your gaming adventures...

STORY/LORE - 8/10

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is great for the sole fact that you get to finally find out what caused all the events of the Borderlands franchise, especially around Handsome Jack and Claptrap. Iâ€™m not going to lie, theyâ€™re both hilarious and just to see how they became what they are is more than enough for wanting to play this game. Itâ€™s basically a continuation of Borderlands 2 but in my opinion, there really was no need to make another brand new game thatâ€™s a pre-sequel to the first two games of the franchise at that point in time.

This could have been a mega huge DLC at $30 and put into Borderlands 2 after all the other DLC was done as a final DLC, then repackaged as â€œBorderlands 2: The Complete Editionâ€ or something along those lines. Either way, the story is good as youâ€™ll meet some familiar faces and connect the dots to why things happened in Borderlands 1 & 2.

GAMEPLAY - 7/10

LASERS!!! All jokes aside, the laser weapons in Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel are amazing and a ton of fun to use. The only problem is, you tend to not get them until youâ€™re halfway if not almost done with the game. You start out with pretty much the same weapons in Borderlands 2 and nothing really fun or big comes along until much later down the road. Of course, it all depends on peopleâ€™s games since itâ€™s a looter shooter/randomized loot kind of experience so maybe it just was that case for me. Perhaps others get some fun weapons in the beginning and go from there but unfortunately, that wasnâ€™t the case for me.

The biggest letdown to the gameplay was the loot that dropped from bosses. Youâ€™d expect some pretty insanely unique weapons that let you rip through enemies but nope, I didnâ€™t get any cool weapons until I was nearly done with the game. Besides that, the boss fights are pretty linear, not all that challenging, and itâ€™s a breeze to get through Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel. This furthers my opinion that this really should have just been added to Borderlands 2, there isnâ€™t anything new to experience here except the ultra-fun laser weapons and the campaign.

I also absolutely hated the mechanic of fighting in space and needing to get oxygen all the time until you found better oxygen items to basically hold your breath as you explored and fought enemies. Sure, oxygen canisters were dropped by every single enemy in the game but I felt this was an unnecessary part of this game. This was beyond annoying as one of the big features of Borderlands is exploring, looting, and killing. Not exploring, looting, killing, and trying to find â€œbreathing areasâ€ to reset your oxygen because it slowly eats away at your health and will kill you if you let it go on long enough. I get that this is in space and everything but it was annoying to have something else to keep track of as you played the game.

GRAPHICS - 10/10

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel came out in 2014 and still holds up to this very day. The graphics are nice, level design is good, and all the details to some awesome looking weapons are great. Itâ€™s Borderlands and well, the cartoony graphics that is a signature staple of this gaming franchise continues to get the job done.

SOUNDTRACK - 7/10

I didnâ€™t like the soundtrack all that much in Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel as itâ€™s a bit generic. It has that spooky space feeling to things that I guess was designed to bring that kind of immersion to the game. Either way, whenever you got into fights or boss fights, it did change but eh, nothing all that epic or fun. This would have been a 6/10 in my book if not for the Claptrap song in the final DLC of this game, that alone bumped it up to a 7/10!

MULTIPLAYER - N/A

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is an old video game and nobody is playing this at all. Iâ€™m sure you might see a few people jumping in but the multiplayer functionality is a hot mess and has a ton of problems trying to connect with others online. If youâ€™re looking to get any of the co-op Steam Achievements or anything involving multiplayer, your best bet is to get some friends to jump in with you that are specifically looking to go through this game and focus on playing together at the same time progressing. If not, sorry, this will be a single-player experience from beginning to end.

FINAL SCORE - 7/10

Overall, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel was a fun experience but basically a continuation of Borderlands 2 just done to fill in the storyline gaps. There isnâ€™t anything groundbreaking or all that new except obviously the tons of new weapons you can use with an emphasis on laser weapons. Let me tell you, burning through waves of enemies with laser weapons was a lot of fun and that was the biggest highlight of the game for me.

The bosses are easy but donâ€™t drop any extraordinary loot as in Borderlands 1 & 2 with the exception of two or three tops that I can remember. The characters are fun, and well, Handsome Jack and Claptrap stole the show. The banter between these two, especially in the DLC was hilarious to go through. I still feel that Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel would have been better off as a massive DLC for Borderlands 2 but thatâ€™s just me. Either way, if you love the Borderlands franchise as much as I do, I highly recommend playing this game just to continue the story and be kept in the loop as the franchise currently continues on in future video games and even an upcoming live-action movie. I hope we get to see Claptrap dance in real life...

There are a lot of complaints about the story in other reviews, but I think that's because the game sort of slows on some maps. There definitely should have been more fast-travel stations (especially on Helios) because all the running around makes things take longer than they should, which is unfortunate considering the devs seemed to be avoiding that. For example, those god-awful timed side missions all over the place in BL2 are FAR fewer in the Pre-Sequel! The oxygen, jump pad, slam, low-gravity and cryo mechanics are incredibly fun and innovative for the franchise. Going back to BL2 after playing this actually makes me feel a bit helpless, as the Pre-Sequel has so many options that allow for diverse playstyles. Love this game and the franchise, the Pre-Sequel definitely doesn't deserve its reputation as an outlier in quality.

To the point: This game's online PC multiplayer is atrocious with connection. Gearbox has shifted to SHiFt services in an effort to allow cross-platform multiplayer. In effect, lag is abundant, ever-present, and sometimes debilitating. The whole reason anyone plays Borderlands is to enjoy with friends, especially this installment in the series. If you value your sanity, be aware what awaits you here.

While I'd say games like Borderlands 2 is objectively better for the stupid amount of content it holds, and Borderlands 3 for the overall intricacies and pace of the action-packed gameplay...I personally think the Pre-Sequel is actually my favorite of the Borderlands series. Even though I see many deem it as a "black sheep" of the series in many ways.

I think some highlight features for me would be the story, Vault hunters, and setting.
Seeing the origins of Handsome Jack, and how he became the villain in Borderlands 2 was really neat.
And as for the Vault Hunters; I just found their playstyles and skilltrees more fun to use than in Borderlands 2. Even though I think 2 had better Action Skills. And while yes, the Pre-Sequel's action skills are more simple overall, I felt like there was a lot more going on in their skilltrees that made many of the classes more fun to play overall. (My personal favorites being the Doppelganger and Baroness classes.)

And as for setting: while I love the wasteland setting of Borderlands 2 (Especially the beginning with the icy tundras), I absolutely love the space aesthetic, and it also gives some unique additions to th gameplay I like. Such as the low gravity, jump boost/slam abilities with the Oz Kits, and the differences of atmospheres with and without oxygen.

So...yeah. I really love the game. And while it's not as big as games like Borderlands 2 and 3, I actually kinda prefer the more compact nature the game has.

(Also on another side-note: Cryo element is super fun. And that alone is a big plus in comparison to Borderlands 2 for me.)

Awesome game! If you're a fan of Borderlands 2 this is definitely up your alley. Being able to interact with Handsome Jack (just Jack in this game) more is great. His character is that jerk that everyone loves. What I like about this game is that it doesn't just feel like Borderlands 2 with different environments and storylines. The additional of the Oz kits means you have to not only think about oxygen deposits, stations, etc. but it also adds the function of being able to glide and use your remaining oxygen to perform a melee attack that can have elemental damage depending on what kit you have equipped. There are plenty of wonderful NPCs to interact with and fun new classes/characters to experiment with. The fact that there is a doppelganger class of Jack and a type of ClapTrap to use means that there is so many ways to experience the story and game. Great for varying play styles and replay value since the characters have different ways they react to dialogue in the game. Just like the 2nd this one has missions to play after you beat the main game and a new game plus which is great for an extra challenge as well as a way to beef up your character to take on any side missions/expansion missions. Definitely worth checking out if you're a fan of Borderlands 2 and/or the FPS/RPG genre!

So, I see a lot of hate on this game, but I wanna prove you this is really worth it. 

I wanna point out that I am a huge fan of Borderlands series, so my opinion might not be so objectiv as I wanted, but I will try my best.

[u] Gameplay: [/u]
 This game runs on the same engine as BL 2 with some changes, for example lower gravity. I dont know why, but lot of people tends to hate on low gravity, but I really like it actually. But thats personal preference right?
We got some new weapon types which are really fun to use, we got oxygen which could get a little anoying and we got slams and something like a double jump/glide thingy, Big plus for me are the playable characters. They all are well-known characters either from the past or the future. Timothy and Aurelia was in BL3, we got Athena from BL1 and Tales, Wilhelm and Nisha from BL2 and of course Claptrap. Like tell me this isnt one of the best sets of characters ever? And the best thing here are the skills. There are so many different and unique skills, that I was really mind-blowned how deep the skills trees are. So guys, in short, the gameplay is good, its almost like BL2. 

[u] Story: [/u]
Story in Borderlands Pre-Sequel is probably the strongest part here. Atleast if you love Jack as much as me, because this is story about him, the story about how he became the greatest villian of all time. You are a victim of his fall, you see those moments that really changed him and made him who he was in BL2. And I really like that. Its just perfect prequel and sequel, which is actually funny. For me the story is really good, the stronger part of this game.  

[u] Final thoughts: [/u]
I wanted to make this review, because I really think this game is underrated. It has its downsides, but if you love this series, if you love Jack, just play it. Lots of people probably got this in Handsome collection, so atleast give it a try. I really struggled, but now I am finally finishing this and I am happy, because its great game. After BL3, its really refreshing and the story does not suck. The last thing I wanna do is write down pros and cons so you can have a nice recap. So I hope I encouraged you to try this game, you will not regret. Hope you have a nice day and see ya around kiddos!

I'll admit, this will be pretty biased since I got this for free as part of the handsome collection, but my point should still stand. I do not like this game. I'm not saying it has no redeeming qualities, as the laser guns, Oz kits, low gravity and actions skills are good, and story is better than 3's, The downside are that, unless you're fine dying to bosses higher, or hell, equal level to you, you're going to not be happy. I did somehow manage to complete the game and it's dlc a while back, but I did die many times fighting the bosses. Playing it again more recently only shows why I uninstalled it. Death is to be expected, and while I know I am not a god, I do often get frustrated at the fact that I often go down, due to status effects, with enemies either far away behind cover, or there being no enemies at all. As well, the economy of this game is annoying, as it's cheaper to die and respawn with full health than buy health boost from vending machines, since the spawn rate for health boosts from supply chest, barrels and other sources. 

I really want to like this game, since it does attempt to make a name from itself from Borderlands 2. But it just makes itself feel like a chore with it's boss battles and many deaths that will most often slow you down. If you're buying it as a part of the handsome collection, that's fine. but if you're going to buy it on it's own, I would advice you to reconsider.

If you haven't played a Borderlands game before, it's a series of highly polished looter shooters, and this one is mostly par for the course. It's about the backstory behind the main villain in Borderlands 2. A lot of people aren't fans of the humor in the game series, but I find it mostly inoffensive.

The biggest thing that sets this apart from the others is that it mostly takes place in low gravity in a vacuum, so you need to worry about managing oxygen. Also, since you can jump pretty high and there's no fall damage, there's a lot of verticality that the others don't have.

If you're a fan of looter shooters in general, this one certainly scratches that itch.

I mean, still not as good as the first one. As the crowd that originally played the first one gets older, the audience for Borderlands in general seems to get younger each iteration--that seems to show with the overall design/plot/dialogue of the game. The story is painstakingly long and drawn out, nothing really hits the original humor of the first one, and as with many modern games, there is a lot of wokeness to overcome to enjoy (or to prevent enjoying) any of the actual characters. Speaking of, if your main character is the Baroness--first thing you need to do is to find the dialogue volume knob and crank that shit all the way to the left. The quests in this game follow an annoying format: find the thing, wait for a few minutes of dialogue to progress, put the thing somewhere, rotate the thing, stack the thing on top of something else, listen to more dialogue, observe the thing, dialogue, touch the thing again, dialogue... Pretty annoying--especially because you can't skip dialogue to progress the quest faster. 

On the flip side I think this is still a few tiers above the second one which I thought was a chore to play. Although this one lacks the charm that the first one had in RPG terms (character leveling is not as exciting and loot in general is horribly bland--especially if you are sitting on any more than like 30 golden keys), the guns themselves aren't as weird and wonky as they are in the second one, and some of them are even fun to use. The environment is a... breath of fresh air... so to speak. The addition of the whole space environment thing led to some cool mechanics, double jumping, new vehicles that served somewhat of a purpose--all of which I thought was welcome. Also, I thought adding cold as an element was much more enjoyable than slag. The grinder utility is a neat idea, and a third type of currency that can be used for upgrading storage is ok. I still miss rescuing clap-traps for inventory expansion, but it is fair to allow the player decide what they want to focus on in terms of storage.
Noice

Preface

Finally, I managed to master all the parts of the legendary Borderlands and now I'm ready to express my opinion about this wonderful series. Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a kind of prologue to the second part. Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a wonderful experience of exploring a mysterious and unexplored area-a satellite of the Earth-the Moon.

The main part

At first glance, most would not have believed that this is Borderlands, if not for the original and easily recognizable drawing. Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a rather dubious part of the great Borderlands series, since it is short and there is no Legendary Pandora familiar to players in it. On the other hand, this part brought a lot of new and interesting mechanics, a new gaming experience in the Borderlands series.

Personal notes

DLC is the weak side of Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel, however, for me personally, they will still be more interesting than the DLC for the first part.

Conclusion

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel should not be bypassed, at least in order to find out how the great Hyperion company was born and how Handsome Jack became the way we used to see him from the second part.

Great game, if a bit repetitive. 
A few of the good points are:
The new Oz system is, in a way, an ingenious way of adding vertical movement to an otherwise standard movement system.
The laser weapons are a way of revamping your arsenal of already great weapons, though they can be mistaken for E-Tech weapons sometimes by the way they are handled.
The new Vault Hunters are unique without being too out of the box, except for Claptrap, which was a wildcard that paid off weirdly.
Having another story in which you hear Jack's voice constantly is a plus.
Some of the bad points are:
You always need to be sure that you have enough Oxigen when going outside a building unless you are playing as Claptrap.
The vehicles are too bland and simple.
The Aussie accent and outback aesthetic get old fast.

I do recommend the game because it is a Borderlands game at heart, but it's not my favorite game in the franchise.

Borderlands - The pre-sequel is a looter shooter in the Borderlands universe. As the title suggests, it treats events before Borderlands 2, but was released after that. It introduces some new game mechanisms : the air supply, the jump redirection through a single air jet. Some places will have reduced gravity, allowing for longer jumps, and there will be also frequent jumppads, that propel you over great distances. The meta currency will be called Moonstones, but will act exactly as Elerium in the previous game. At release there were 4 classes, and 2 new classes were added through DLCs. I got this game through the Handsome Collection, and as such had all the DLCs available. I intended only a single playthrough, and wanted to play with the easiest class. In Borderlends2 I played as the gunzerker, and that was an easy mode. Here I chose Handsome Jack doppelganger as my character. Based on some internet research I wasnâ€™t sure whether it will be the easy mode character, but by playing through the game I can say that past level 30 he is probably the most easy/safe character to play. That is due to his decoy summons, which capture almost all of the enemy aggro. Not only that, but they do put out a decent damage too. I chose to complete the middle talent tree at first, and some entries there increased the offensive capabilities of the summons greatly, like the addition of more powerful weapons, or the triggering of an explosion when they are summoned, which deals damage only to the enemies. At higher levels when I got overwhelmed, I just summoned them, and literally run into the packs of enemies. They targeted my decoys, and as they were resummoned (they are kept resummoned automatically frequently, as long as the skill is active), each times they dealt explosive damage to the enemies. By holding down the special skill button, the skill can be ended prematurely. The benefit of that is a slight decrease in the cool-down of the skill.

As it is a shooter, I naturally played it with keyboard-mouse, I didnâ€™t even bother to check for controller support. The save system is the same as in Borderlands 2. You cannot save manually, but there are scattered savepoints, where you will be resurrected after deaths. Also there are â€œhardâ€ savepoints, usually at the entrance of the map. If you exit the game, you will start from this hard savepoints, not from the place where you logged off, or the closest savepoint. Also all enemies will respawn after a new load. Later maps might have hard savepoints at specific locations, so you are not required to fight through the map again if you log out with a lot of progress on a story mission. Also the final save point before the Claptrap story DLC boss fight preserved the defeated state of the first boss. Had it not been for this feature, I would have given up on completing that DLC, as fighting two tedious boss fights where a single death resets everything would have meant me stopping wasting my time on tries. And I am glad that I persevered, because there will be a cinematics after that detailing the fate of the Claptraps, and seemingly a few more quests are unlocked after that, which I enjoyed playing through. 

There are local quests marked with a yellow exclamation mark on the map. They are also listed as undiscovered in the zone list for quests, so at least their zone will be known. Going there the yellow exclamation mark will be visible on the map. However that doesnâ€™t mean that getting to them will be trivial. Some quests can be reached only by very convoluted ways, not readily apparent. For example, in the Claptrap story DLC, you will have to drop out from the auto transport tubes with the slam button, a mechanism that is not explained. Also some zones can be accessed only by progressing the main story line. The main story-line is marked by a distinct vault symbol in the quest list. For the selected quest a target rectangle will appear in the map, so it can reached following that. If it continues in a different zone, multiple target rectangles may appear, some leading to the adjacent zone toward it, some to a quick travel post. The quick travel posts are some predetermined save points. Once you unlock them, you can return to them freely from any other quick travel post.

Some zones will have no air. There are still cracks leaking air, where you can refill mid-field, clearly marked on the mini-map. Also there are air generator stations, which can be switched on or off, and entering any air containing building will replenish the air too.

The voice acting is excellent, as usual for the Borderlands games. There are a lot of returning persons from previous games, some just for a cameo, some are given more time. The two characters with the most speaking is Handsome Jack and Claptrap. The music is the generic music associated with Borderlands, with the Claptrap story DLC having a lot of chiptune music.

The graphics of the game are on par with Borderlands2, but with some completely different sceneries / themes. Also in the Claptrap story DLC, there will be a few levels with parts from previous games, as a kind of homage to those games.

The weapons are largely similar to the ones in Borderlands 2. The two notable additions are the laser weapons and the cold effect. The laser weapons use a different kind of ammo, and come in different roles : some are fast firing with high accuracy (similar to a rifle), some are slow firing with high scattering (similar to a shotgun). The cold effect does cold damage, and also has a chance to freeze enemies. Frozen enemies wonâ€™t be able to move/fight, and are susceptible to shatter attacks. Probably explosive weapons are great against them, but I just resorted to simply punching them to death. That way I didnâ€™t loose time on switching to another weapon and back, and also saved some ammo. Weapons can have moonshine effect, which is another source of modifiers for them. Also in the Claptrap story DLC there are pink rarity level weapons, on par / higher than legendaries. They will have glitch effects. The only one I understood was rapid fire, which can trigger randomly when firing.

There is a grinder in the central hub of the game, where you can sacrifice 3 weapons of the same rarity, and obtain a random weapon of the same rarity or one higher. I expended a lot of weapons there, generally getting crap. A safer method of upgrade is selling the weapons, and buying some deal of the day items from the wending machines. Every now and then there will be a nice upgrade available there. The downside of that is that on death you will loose a good chunk of your amassed money.

There are two character DLCs, one for the Handsome Jack doppelganger, one for the baroness. I played with the doppelganger. There is an arena DLC, and the Claptrap story DLC. The arena DLC I largely ignored. I only used it after unknowingly started the Claptrap story DLC prematurely at level 29. That DLC will drop weapons of level 30+, so I couldnâ€™t equip any drop from that DLC at the start, even more so because soon I got level 31, 32 weapons too. So I went to the Arena DLC and kept trying to progress there till I got past level 30. After that I didnâ€™t bother with the arena. You fight several large waves of enemies there. If you have the Claptrap story DLC, after completing a quest there you will get access to a much shorter version of a repeatable arena, where you will have to complete 3 small waves. There you will have to choose some modifier effects before start. In the single run I did, I choose lower gravity and higher slam damage. Also you can dial the difficulty manually from 1 to 10. I completed it on difficulty 3.

The game was stable, it didnâ€™t crash for me. I was lucky to already have an account required for Borderlands back from my Borderlands2 play, but if you donâ€™t have one, you will have to create one before you are able to play, even if you intend to play it exclusively as a single player game, like I did.

Gearbox has built a solid reputation in the gaming industry and this game only strengthens it. The Pre-Sequel builds on top of the success that Borderlands 2 had in 2012, even using the same engine from before. It's actually pretty impressive that Gearbox cranked out this game in 2 years of development with the quality that the game has. If you've played Borderlands 2, I would say this game has the combined quality and quantity of content that roughly 5 Borderlands 2 DLCs would provide. Many people criticize the Oz (O2) system in place of Borderlands 2 Relics, but it never bothered me. If you're a Borderlands fan, the Pre-Sequel would be a fine addition to your collection. *General Grievous wheezes in his grave*

Since this game closely follows the core gameplay loop that Borderlands 2 has, it doesn't retain the same replay value. It's still definitely replayable, especially with friends, but my desire to play this game suffers just because it feels very similar to Borderlands 2. There's still a lot to be seen at least once, however.

It took me roughly 15 hours to complete the main story once before I unlocked New Game +. For some, the first playthrough might be enough for them. Because of this, I give the playtime rating a score between Short and Long (10 to 250 hours). Some people might want to play even longer, and more power to them. But I think it's safe to say that the vast majority of people will not invest more than 250 hours in this game.

What was great about the first Borderlands was the prospect of adventure.

"Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel" is a non-sensical, meaningless and random mess of a game, that begins with copious amounts of cut-scenes that you can't skip, and boring dialog dribble that adds nothing to the story or character progression/development. In my first hour of gameplay I spent more time watching cut-scenes I didn't want to watch and listening to inane monologues about garbage I didn't care to listen to, than I actually got to experience the actual gameplay itself. The people who created dialog for this game need to see a psychologist ASAP. 
Their ideas of funny quips and nods to pop culture and their own borderlands references remind me of an old out-of-touch indie hipster that wrongfully conflates indifference and apathy to their incredibly obnoxious personality, to a lack of intelligence, when in reality, a wacky personality does not equate to good comedy, it's weird, not funny.
This game tries too hard to make you laugh and fails on all fronts.

Loved the setting, the gameplay and the funky graphics. The Borderlands universe is one of my favorites so I definitely have a soft spot for all things Borderlands.

Pros:
- Aero/low gravity combat
- Loot, grinding loot for better loot, LOOT!
- Stupid, over-the-top characters
- Watching Jack turn into a psychopath
- Claptastic voyage
- Puns, insider jokes, the humour overall is on point for me

Cons:
- For some reason I liked the loot better in B2 - can't really put my finger on it (maybe the novelty wore off for me)
- I don't love the story but I wouldn't not recommend the game over it
- As with all Borderlands games, the latter playthroughs are a drag especially if you want to try new characters..yes, you need to get to grips with a new character and how they behave but it is what it is

All in all I loved the pros and was only mildly annoyed by the cons. If you haven't tried it yet, go for it! You won't regret it if you loved any of the other Borderlands games.

I honestly enjoyed TPS more than BL2. It does very much feel like a DLC for BL2, it has many of the same guns, while adding many new ones. I enjoyed the fact that it seems easier to access these weapons earlier in the game than at a comparable level in BL2. The addition of laser weapons is neat and adds an interesting, albeit challenging element to the game when they end up in bandit hands, as they often possess very high accuracy and obscene projectile velocity. 

The main difference that gives TPS its real flavor is the areas that take place in the vacuum of space, either on a moon without an atmosphere or the exterior of a massive space station. I played mainly as Claptrap, which sidesteps the issue of a limited air-supply, but I also played as the Baroness for a bit, and it added a challenging element to the game without feeling like a hassle. You gain a new method of attack, basically a "butt slam" made via high jump in low gravity that deals splash damage, and your currently equipped oxygen cylinder can boost the slam damage, change its elemental damage type, and even add other bonuses much like BL2's relics (because the TPS oxygen cylinder equipment slot replaces the BL2 relic).

I am a huge BL fan, and I absolutely loved playing as Claptrap. And despite the impression the game gives you that Claptrap might be a little challenging to play is misleading, as at higher levels, with the right build Claptrap can be an absolute beast in combat.

Overall, if you enjoyed BL2, you'll probably enjoy TPS.

Ah, geez. Where do I begin with this one...?

Pre-Sequel is an otherwise normal Borderlands 2 DLC that has been drawn out into a full-release title. In nearly every sense it's a step backwards from the refinements of BL2, even when you take into account the changes due to setting and so on, it just doesn't make the game any more fun. It makes things more tedious, unfortunately.

Several of my friends bought this, tried it once and returned it and I can understand why. You get new classes which is a good thing, but you are hamstrung by Oz, which is a bad thing. You have new vehicles, which is a good thing, but they're not that fun to use and the landscapes tend to just be a mix of gray with a pretty skybox, which is a bad thing. The enemies are almost all new, which is a good thing, but they just don't give us that much extra variety, mixed with the above two, which is a bad thing.

I'm Aussie so I like the injection of Aussie vernacular and especially loved the cameo of Shazza as a shotgun, great call on that. For pretty much everyone else I think this just annoyed them to no end. Everyone remembers the legendarily annoying Australian marine from Halo, it's practically a meme. Well, Gearbox made an entire game that acts exactly like that guy. Just... so much that could be good, ends up not working out the way I think they had hoped. I appreciate them trying on this one though.

I left the worst for last though - the story. My God is it horrible. The actual character arc of Jack is good, I like that part, but almost everything else is either (A) designed to draw out your quests to make them take way longer than they have any right to or (B) completely useless exposition that has absolutely no bearing on anything of great consequence, just running the clock out. The good parts are there, they are just buried in a mountain of waiting and backtracking and wishing the game would just get on with itself. It was difficult to make it the whole way through, I won't lie.

All in all, Pre-Sequel feels like an entire game of the bad BL2 DLC made into a game. If it was an expansion to BL2 with all the additions being cross-compatible this would be an awesome addition because it augments the base game with the additions, while allowing you to choose to ignore the negatives it might introduce (such as Oz in moon areas, boring landscapes, enemies etc). Unfortunately, as a release title it just doesn't stack up.

Grab it cheap, or give this one a miss.

Another Borderlands Game, but with FREEZE and LAZERS!

It has its moments but it's not nearly as good as Borderlands 2. I think logistical problems constrained the writing too much, and the product has a lot of quest bugs and level design bugs that you will definitely run into. If you lower your standards and just accept it for what it is, it is a decent game in the Borderlands universe. If you really like Borderlands it is worth rushing through.
Fun gameplay, solid story

You know, a lot of people do not like this game within the Borderlands series, but I actually liked it a lot, and I thought that this was way more interesting compared to Borderlands 2. There were still problems that I had with this game, such as with how unbalanced the classes are in this game, as well as the anti-gravity of the game sometimes getting in the way of itself, or depending on the class having to deal with oxygen, but I found this game to be very different, but with that a sequel that is also a prequel (confusing I know) that manages to do enough different within the series, which was my previous complaint about Borderlands 2. Also, this game also did not handle its DLC well, again, although I did have more fun with it this time around. 7.5/10 game for me.
Me like
interesting being the bad guys from Borderlands 2 and seeing their perspective.

Unfortunately, a jetpack, new enviroments and some great new mechanics as well as amazing characters doesn't stop The Pre-Sequel for being a lesser (and somewhat unexciting and recylced) version of the fantastic BL2. The humor would be hard to understand for non-Australians. I understood it, but many of the jokes were cringeworthy.
just all around fun

It's basically more BL2 and explains the backstory of Handsome Jack. The low-gravity mechanics are a fantastic and satisfying addition to the frenetic combat. 

Be that as it may, the progression of the game is unbalanced. Players will have to wait far too long to holster 3-4 weapons at once, and the number of side-quests are rather slim until you get back on Helios, after which the game throws a dozen side quests at you at once (perhaps for the purpose to inflate the length of the campaign towards the end). Some of the humor was rather forced, too. But overall, it's still a good Borderlands game.
ok
Unless you are getting this game at a discount, the amount of gameplay is not worth the price. This game is the middle child in the family that no one cares about.
Funny moon people speak australian lol
this game is just fun.  it's HUGE, like O_o HUUGE.  so you'll play for a long time.  and it's very satisfying play.

Played this right after Borderlands 2, and I think it's a must. The story (and game as a whole) is shorter, but does such a great job giving you an insight to everything that led up to Borderlands 2. There are a lot of complaints about the space setting, and for the most part I don't have any issues with it. There's still a decent amount of variety in the environments and the lower gravity is an interesting change. You're also not constantly in low gravity environments, so I felt it was balanced well. My only complaint with it is that your air reserves still go down while you're talking to NPCs, so you hypothetically could die while receiving a mission or picking between two post-mission loot choices. While I'm on the sorta negatives, the little issues like occasionally getting stuck on/in objects hasn't been fixed, and if you're going to play the Claptastic Voyage DLC then give yourself A LOT of time on the final boss because it's a bit of a slog. Even with those negatives, just like the Borderlands games before, I still really enjoyed The Pre-Sequel and would recommend it to anyone who's played Borderlands 2.
bang bang pew pew
best game ever

My first Borderlands game. I got this game with the Handsome Jack collection and I just got it cause a friend told me to play it. I just gotta say hot damn this game is so good. As the presequel stands alone, I had so much fun and the story is pretty ok to understand. As far as gameplay, I had so much fun. I replayed this game 3 times already, (once with true vault hunter mode) with 2 different classes (Athena and Ms Hammalot). I think the fact I memorized the characters names is something most games cant do.  I just bought Borderlands 1 goty so imma play that next.  Highly recommend this one if its on sale with all the DLCs. Playing with other people or alone is really fun nonetheless.
