Border Border

honestly one of best experiences I've experienced. Probably my favorite borderlands game, endless content, a great zero gravity feature, fun weapons, and great dlcs, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel might be a negatively looked upon game in the publics eye, but its a great game in my heart

this space adventure is like a rabid stalker on my patience, biting me into a wall and stun locking me until death. ive uninstalled it 4 times and for some reason because of my appreciation for borderlands, i keep coming back to finish it. part of the problem i think is that having all the DLC installed from the get-go unbalances the modes following normal. no matter what level you get, the story line will keep jumping a level or two ahead which makes the already difficult BAs and bosses a real nuisance. the drops are so often junky that relying on grabbing the 3 golden keys every game startup is the only way i can stay on top of enemy difficulty. Why couldnt story missions just scale with current level? AS IF i want to keep running side missions or farming some area just to play a pointless catchup game with story missions. its certainly worth a playthrough on normal but beware true or ultimate.
I must say of all these games, this does tend to get stale compared to the others. my persistence to finish everything is the only reason i want to keep playing through the endless deaths and waves of same-same enemies. ugh
Borderlands series is pretty great

When this game first came out I was not impressed with it, however now that it's been years later I gave it another shot. Now that I've actually played through to the end (have not finished the dlc's yet) I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed the story and actually got invested in the characters. 

Game-play wise I was not a big fan of the anti-gravity but it is probably one of the best Borderlands games when it comes to skill trees. It was also much, much more fun co-op, a lot of skills help who you play with so most of the time it's a win win. I also enjoyed laser weapons and the cryo weapons. My favorite character to play as was Wilhelm, but all in all it's probably the only Borderlands game where I enjoyed all the characters. 

The beginning of the game is a bit of a drag but if you can get through that then I'm sure you'll have lot's of fun, especially with a friend.

Getting tired of the Restoring or Creating online Session message, just kicks you off the game, most annoying at Holodome. Drop the game in a Offline state rather than kicking me out and loop in creating Session forever, when this happens have to force kill it and relaunch.
For the game, it's more like a DLC. Gun count and the lack of interesting enemies or even character skill trees makes it less likely to replay that often.
Edit: I'm simply going to recommend it because I like Borderlands. Wish they at least used the already functioning mechanics from BL2 here, kind of uninteresting. Like every character story build up, needs more action on introduction, the lack of need to test out different load outs and skills, not many loot options (I never got a legendary item in any of the container during the 200 hours. this made the special weapon cases less exciting), even the legendaries - only the odd ones from BL2 are here. I bought it at a discount so might as very well recommend it.

Borderlands 2.5
its good, not as good as 2 but better than the 1 and still pretty dang fun

Though I find this to be the weakest game in the series, it's only an opinion, which I can gladly say doesn't matter in the end as I still can recommend this game.

As always, you're presented with a variety of characters who offer unique ways to kill walking loot containers in search of weapons that can assist you in your cycle of murder. But on top of that, I feel like this is the one game where you're given the most variety in gun/character skill builds, even more so than Borderlands 3.  

For what's in this game, many people find it to be the best of the series, and though that's saying little as nearly every game in the series has people placing their flag on it as "The King of Borderlands", it's impossible for me to argue that this game is somehow unworthy of the praise.
Actually a really great game, i thought it was going to be way less rich than BL2, but it is just as good!

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a game about a lesbian (optional) working with an idiot CEO to save the moon from aliens.
      All of the Borderlands games are a blast. Almost all of the attainable items are randomly generated, and every playable character has a unique skill tree. The Main story is good, and the side-quests and DLC are even better.
     This game may be easy at times, but there are some particularly frustrating areas. Some bosses are annoying, and a few of the weapons are a bit unbalanced. Most of the deaths that I have attained in this game are either caused by the environment and bull-crap. Death isn't much of a setback, though.
     Overall, I would say that it's an expansion to The Borderlands world(s). Buy this along with the others with the handsome collections, and get your friends to play with you.

Good Game, it is shorter and has less content then Borderlands 2. Combat is virtually unchanged from Borderlands 2 except for some minor additions like ground pound and a jet pack for Low-gravity environments. 

The graphics have aged well thanks to the cell-shaded art style. And the humour like its predecessor also lands most of the time, and the gameplay loop while fun isn't nearly as engaging as Borderlands 2. Also co-op is a welcomed addition and at least 1 playthough should be done co-op with a friend

If you enjoyed Borderlands 2 chances are you will enjoy this too.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is probably a great game but I just couldn't get into it. Maybe I was just too 'burned out' from playing so much Borderlands 2 or maybe I just didn't like the setting / characters of this prequel - who knows....Honestly, I just didn't really get the 'Borderlands vibe' during the short time I spent with the game. It seemed to me that the game should have perhaps been a DLC to Borderlands 2 rather than a full-fledged standalone title.

If you're a 'gung-ho' Borderlands fan, you'll probably enjoy the game. If you're a more 'casual gamer' like myself, you can probably pass on this one.

Absolutely not worth purchasing at full price. Get it on a BIG SALE only.

Honestly, after completing all games in this series multiple times I've come to the conclusion this might be the best Borderlands game out there because it fails to be a Borderlands game. Here me out:
- The story is actually interesting and the characters you play as are a part of that story (not the case in previous game or BL3).
- No motivation or need to end game grind (yes, this is a weird preference, but I am a college student and simply do not have time to grind for that perfect roll on my legendary weapon).
Other things this game does very well:
- The character abilities might be the best (and most overpowered) in all series
- You get to play as f*cking Claptrap
- You get to play as f*cking Handsome Jack (double)
- You get to play on the f*cking moon
- Laser weapons
- Ice element
- Oxygen kits
- Slam attacks
- Many other things
Things this game does not well:
- End game grind (this is a pro for some of us)
- Many other things
Conclusion:
Play this f*cking game, it's just BL2 but better (yes yes no)

I played as Clap-Trap, and I enjoyed it. While the mechanics are different ( low gravity and double jumping) it is still Borderlands. I thought the bosses were challenging and the levels were decent. Early loot was weak but eventually I got 4 Orange grade weapons in my play-through and had a good mix for the end game. The Pre-Sequel gets a lot of grief,  But I had fun , YMMV.

It's not a masterpiece, but it's still good. I feel like a lot of the hate this game got was understandable upon release, and to be honest, it's not very engaging. However, it is still fun to run around in space and travel inside Helios. This is a solid game, but not a brilliant one. I'd recommend this to Borderlands fans; just wait until it's on sale to pick it up, preferably with the doppleganger and the claptastic voyage DLCs.

Despite the bad wrap this game got, it is a much more true Borderlands experience than 3 will ever be. If 2 doesn't quite scratch that itch you need, this might be just what you need if you can get past the old pretenses.

When you consider the "Handsome Jack" arc as a whole you HAVE TO include TPS.

Borderlands 2 -> The Pre-Sequel -> Tales from the Borderlands is one of the greatest gaming experiences as a whole.

Don't go into TPS expecting the replayability of Borderlands 2.

Absolutely one of my favorite games ever made, in some ways it's the best BL, and in many others it can be shortsighted and frustrating. 

If you're a Borderlands fan I highly recommend you play through TPS at least a handful of times.

This game isn't as bad as I thought it would be? 

The problem with it is that it was marketed as its own individual game, when it should've been marketed as an expansion on Borderlands 2. 
If you hadn't played borderlands 2, it makes absolutely no sense. This game is well made, the environments are pretty, and the gimmicks work well. If this game was a stand-alone game, it'd be boring, but the gimmicks are never seen again, so. The moon, less gravity, cool guns, callbacks, unique mechanics! Play it, I'd say its completely worth it.

Trash. Fucking TRASH. I really wanted to like this game, but It's literally the Borderlands 2 engine with some new graphical assets and a voice acting line-up that just makes you scream "WHY SPACE AUSTRALIANS??"

It seems like this is by far the shortest game despite having the hardest final boss compared to 1 and 2, while I have not played the third game yet I certainly hope it is better than this. It seemed so promising but it came out like some kind of 2K AUS inside joke.

Americans: You will not understand a majority of the jokes here (more than likely).
I shot a body and it went off a cliff at the speed of light. 10/10 game needs more ragdoll physics.

This Game is great if you have Borderlands 1, 2, 3, and Tales all 100% and you REALLY want to play the FartTrap DLC. Still a 6.5-7/10; Just weaker than it's siblings for sure. I'd say it's definitely worth a play for the story and some of the missions, but the replayable aspects that you are used to as a borderlands fan are almost non existent. For me, the things that knock that game down are not the obvious Pickle or non existent endgame. For me it's both the balancing of loot pools and underutilization of the loot they made. As shown in the community patch, a few numbers switched around can make a WORLD of difference.

There's just no charm. That said, the heart of any Borderlands game is the co-operative experience, and that is as good as ever. Getting four people together to save Pandoraâ€™s moon makes for a great time, with easy drop-in, drop-out. Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is easily the lesser game of the trilogy, but itâ€™ll scratch that loot-and-shoot itch. Recommended if youâ€™ve just got to have more Borderlands.

The Pre-Sequel is the title that I liked the least, due to some issues that hurt the quality of life of the title. There are features that are expected in every Borderlands. The amount of travelling, the grindy festival of enemies everywhere, and the loot, which I personally don't like, but this one adds another gimmick:

A gravity with less gravitational pull than what we're used to. Jumps are higher, falls are slower, and the damage from it is smaller. It also is very boring; it can be fun for a while, but after ten hours of watching your character slowly falling or jumping, you irremediably get tired of it, it wastes your time. This, adding the negligible amount of vehicles, and the useless they are (since there are rifts and stones everywhere), makes for a pretty time consuming travelling, which you'll have to do all the time in quests and between them.

The humor and writing are without doubt worse than what we're used to in the saga. Maybe they grew stale since we've seen the same randomness and type of comedy over and over again, with little evolution. Or maybe it's because they lack a certain quality, but what I can confirm is that I didn't really enjoy them.

The soundtrack is forgettable, so are the sound effects. Graphics are run of the mill in Borderlands, expect nothing new, nor prettier than what you're accustomed to. There are some new enemies, but again, they're forgettable at best.

All in all, it's a pretty poor experience if you're not into Borderlands. In the eyes of a fan, I've heard that it's just okay. I do recommend it though, if you get it for cheap. I wouldn't spend anything above 15â‚¬.

borderlands, a beloved series of games. a good one, great even. Ive found myself spending a lot of my time growing up enjoying most of the games. ive had fond memories of playing with my friends and what an amazing adventure it was. Most is the key word in the review though, as what id barely even describe as a functioning working "game" and more of person hell, consider it the modern age "The Twelve Labors"

The first point of issue with this carcinogenic divine comedy, is that despite having a near flawless foundation to build upon, the mongoloid cretins devs at 2K Australia, dropped the ball so hard it crashed through thier floor and shutdown their pathetic excuses of "game development" and the studio as a whole. now celebrate not, as their personal magnum opus resides in a world that we as people can put ourselves through, that is, of course if you can even get the game to fucking launch. Who and how are my biggest questions here, but enough of that tangent. My game could barely maintain a state of even running while having a somewhat solid build for a pc. This shit should not be happening and its not my end. Unless someone in the office is completely oblivious to the prerequisite of how a game functions this should be a red flag for the torture me and my friend induced onto each other.
My second point to make about this smouldering pile of 2k Australias ashes, The moon.
i understand the context behind setting some of this game on the moon, its the story that's being told and its relevant. I didn't pay for a 30 hour long water level, that's all the zero g combat can be compared to, is an amalgamation of all the reason why you shouldn't fucking run a game Solely on the moon. I hope you like the colour grey, that's all your gonna be seeing. you'd think that anyone with half a mind would put some colour somewhere, anywhere fuck me. 30 hours of being colourblind and i get to experience what its like to constant have to gunfight underwater. Oh and there is a handy feature of the gun play that makes every gun you use feel like its got a quarter of a second hit registry, its like trying to muster up some form of woodworking while you've just downed 8 bars and 6 shots of vodka.
The Third reason i find this "video game" to be less enjoyable than being waterboarded in a viet-kong prisoner camp, Voice acting.
I live in Australia so i hear different accents all the time from all parts of this great nation. I've yet to find anyone push wind through their body and have to sound strikingly similar to jamming hammer drill into my nasal canal and performing a self lobotomy, every character is Australian bar the returning character, and you'll hate each and every single one of them. If you've ever wondered what its like to go to the smoking area at an Australian brothel this is the closest you'll come to hearing it, every whiny nasally fucking voice, has its own special way of penetrating your eardrums and leaving you with the same hearing as an Israeli street vendor.
my final thoughts on one of the single worst games i've ever played.
the only real thing i can say about this game and the people who enjoy it. take a hard look. this is the reason why the gaming industry is heading towards a creative collapse. people consume and digest this trash and preach about this amazing experience riddled with their own subconscious need to want the game to be good. don't buy this. don't gift this. and for fuck sake, save yourself the trouble and don't even launch the game. fuck knows its not gonna launch. R.I.P. 2k Australia. Randy Pitchford you foreskin gobbling money hungry big nosed jew fuck. if your reading this, quit your job, get in your car and hit the highway at 160. Wrap that car around the closest pole you can for giving the green light on the shit stain on Borderlands franchise.

Okay so I'm an avid Borderlands fan. I played this game AFTER playing BL2 so please keep that in mind while reading this. 

So lets begin.

[h1]Story[/h1]

This is an interesting take for the prequel to Borderlands 2. The story essentially is the reason that BL2 takes place. Jack or who'd be known as Handsome Jack later is the guy who employs different vault hunters for his work. There are some neat twists and turns around in the story and I can say that it was nice.

[h1]Characters[/h1]

I haven't played all the characters yet but they do represent different characteristics in themselves. Some like Wilhelm, Nisha are pure mercenaries with no real morals while others like Athena, Claptrap show hesitation doing some nasty stuff and also relate a bit to the humane side. I'd say that's great so you can pick up a Vault Hunter of your choice.

Talking about skills and abilities, i feel all are pretty unique and fun to try out. I definitely dont want to list them all here but just check em out. It feels different from BL2 very different gameplay.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

There are a couple of unique elements added into the game compared to borderlands 2, mainly the lack of atmosphere and new weapons : LASER.  The new high jump with a boost felt pretty good and fun to play around with and was absolutely needed given how HUGE the areas are. All the guns types from BL2 return (changing BANDIT to SCAV, they need a name change after going to moon cmon!). Though new weapon type LASER was added in TPS. Overall say on weapons, most seem good enough (AR's actually feel better than the shitshow from BL2) and some lasers feel pretty OP with insane damage outputs (the beam lasers) but also eat ammo pretty damn fast. I'd like to know what the laser ammo is and how is the gun powered.

In short, some new and fun elements to check out.

[h1]Map Design[/h1]

Coming from BL2, I was [b]DISAPPOINTED[/b] with the map design. The moon maps are TOO big and almost oversaturated with stuff. I liked the BL2 maps, they weren't large and were properly accessible whether on vehicle or foot. TPS map sections feel too large, dull and just filled with Scav camps around for no apparent reason. For example, take Triton Flats. It's the biggest part of the moon which connects to numerous places, it's filled with so much stuff that whenever I want to just do a mission nearby it's a pain to navigate through and those damn big Shuggarths just basically everywhere. 
The jump pads look cool but in some places (e.g. Pity's Fall Drakensberg) it feels like they overused the pads. I don't like a map design where the only way into a ship wreck is some weirdly placed jump pads. There is an entire bandit camp inside, it just doesnt make sense to have some weird jump pads around as the sole entrance and most of the navigation. Same for the maintenance section in Helios, unnecessarily high number of jump pads. How do people even perform maintenance work there like that?

I DO NOT like the map design in this game, the gameplay elements are unique and fun but I will always hate the map design. Only place I like on the map is Concordia because it's not overly saturated, isn't big asf and looks better. Borderlands is not an open-world game so small but meaningful map pockets feel better than big ones.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]

To summarize, I feel it's obviously a nice game to play around but I feel it would've been even better if the map design wasnt as horrible as it is. This game will make you hate Jack even more if you're coming from BL2. A great game with a bit off execution imo.

[b]6.5/10[/b]

Sure, at its core it is a carbon copy of Borderlands 2, but at least it expands the story in an interesting way and introduced some of the most fun weapons and gameplay mechanics of the entire series (no, not you limited oxygen!). Things like lazers, cryo and stomping outshine many mechanics of Borderlands 2. On top of that, the skills and four classes are excellently designed, as are some of the bosses in the game.

Sure, this is not what people wanted it to be back then and it still has a lot of issues that the game series could never really overcome in the first place (mediocre writing, boring quest design, etc.). Nonetheless, be it only for the great gameplay mechanics and one of the best story DLCs in Borderlands history (Claptastic Voyage), if you are a Borderlands fan this makes for a great game!

My first entry to Borderlands franchise and I really enjoyed it!

Pros:
- Art style and environments look beautiful, some of the landscapes are incredible to look at.
- Gameplay is fun and responsive for the most part.
- Voice acting is mostly great, especially Jack's VA. He did a fantastic job.
- DLC is fantastic, so unique.
- Some of the quests are really funny, there are some great bits and moments.

Cons:
- Story is meh, nothing special, but I guess this just serves as a bridge between the first and second game, so I get it.
- Some of the characters are sooooo annoying and not interesting (yelling and screaming â‰  funny).
- Somewhat repetitive gameplay.
- Some minor bugs I've encountered.

Overall, not much to it, but still fun and enjoyable game.

For whatever reason, [i]Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel[/i] seems to be the black sheep of the franchise. A lot of people really don't think it holds up to the precedent set by [i]Borderlands 2[/i]. And yet--blasphemous though the opinion may be--TPS is by far my favorite Borderlands game. The gravity and oxygen mechanics, and the newly-introduced laser rifles, make combat so much more dynamic and interesting, and there's a lot of flexibility in the vault hunters' skills.

Separately, I find TPS's narrative and themes to be a fantastic deconstruction of the loot shooter formula; it leads you down the road to hell with wit and charm all along the way, only to punch you in the gut when you [spoiler]painfully kill Felicity, execute the Hyperion scientists, and outright [i]genocide[/i] the claptraps[/spoiler]. It's just a few shades darker than Borderlands 2, and surprising though this may be, I think it has some genuinely thought-provoking things to say.

Mediocre RPG mechanics on every steroid and SARM to try and make it look good. Same "lel STYLIZED DURR" cell shading graphics. This is just busy work with drawn out running between waypoints. Only escapist suicidal do nothings with no personality will like these types of slogs for games. I will never buy BL3. These types of uber grindy non-competitive time wasters need to go away for good. 

I am clearly not the target demographic tho, as I am not a father with a deeply unsatisfied wife, dead end job, and needs something that distracts him from real life because real life intimidates him. His destiny is to produce a fine ass daughter to bang Chad, and with any luck, Chad will wife her up if she's a virgin and under 20, thereby producing more Chads to spread their Chad genes into this weak world. If not, he'll play this type of video game for years, completely ignoring his baby girl's descent into deviant behavior until she either gets a sex change, or morphs into an aging spinster who's favorite time of the week is wine-o-clock. The humor in this game is tailored exactly to these types. Just watch, everything is a thinly veiled dad joke with that extra cringe. Time goes on and Lame Dad retires to this game most nights with his favorite overpriced craft brew giving him bitch tits. "ooooh what LOOT am I going to get today?" he croons, putting his Turtle Beach headset on so he doesn't hear his wife melting in utter writhing pleasure while her personal trainer slams her still-tight beaver (dad only ever got some a week after the honeymoon). "It's ok though, she's going to the gym every day and getting healthy so I can brag to my fantasy football friends about how hot my wife is. At least her getting pounded by him prevents her from asking me to take the trash out. I love her so much!" Years down the road he's at his parent's funeral. He feels very little because he is a pathetic bugman and doesn't believe in God. All he's thinking about is the marginally better loot he will get after sinking another 5 hours into Boringlands. He retreats to the church bathroom and looks up Moxxie on his Soyphone X and, staying on the first few results of google images, jerks his frail mushroom tip. He lets out a slight grunt after climaxing into a single ply piece of toilet paper. Good thing he's a dribbler and not a shooter, otherwise he'd have to carry around an extra sock in his pocket...and he *hates* doing his own laundry. Later, at the reception, he loads his plate with the mac-n-cheese instead of the steak because he still harbors infantile cravings and could care less about taking care of his body. An old friend from high school shows up and gives him condolences, and not 5 minutes into the conversation, Lame Dad tries to insert a reference to Borderlands, probing for someone else as uninteresting as him. To his luck, his old friend lights up and starts talking about the shiny orange rarity gun he got in that one dungeon that has 5 barrels and shoots laser rockets with fire elemental damage and every bullet has a 1% chance of turning the enemy NPC into a rubber ducky. He mentions that his wife and daughters don't understand his love for this game. Lame Dad shows more enthusiasm than ever before for the next 3 hours. "Why am I wearing this suit? Who died?", Lame Dad wonders. He returns to the table after getting his 5th Bud Light from the open bar because the NFL advertises it alot. He is genuinely happy that he found someone just like him. Birds of a feather really do flock together! They agree to play online together when they get home, and Lame Dad and Lame Friend sheepishly play together for a long time. Suddenly around the New Year, Lame Dad finds out he has asshole cancer. "Dang shouldn't have eaten that paint chip when I was a child," says Lame Dad as he schedules his 50th covid vaccine. "At least I'm safe from this deadly disease. If we all don't get vaccinated, there will only be 99.9998% of us left!" Lame Dad righteously struts into the emergency immunization pod and gets jabbed. After, he stops by the grocery store to pick up some tv dinners, salt and vinegar chips, and Beyond Meat for the wife to cook. He still wears a double mask because you can never be too safe. After he gets home he opens the chip bag. 

Suddenly his eyes start to water, his throat gets tingly, it gets hard to breathe, and rashes start appearing all over his skin. He tries to get out of his $300 gaming chair but he ends up falling over. Uh oh, his legs are paralyzed. He tries to scream for help but can't due to his throat being so swollen. Everything gets hot, and he passes out before dying from asphyxiation. His wife discovers him the next morning after she goes in to tell him she's going to the gym to train. His death was ruled a covid death, and Lame Friend gives a eulogy at his funeral, using it as a platform to use tongue in cheek life metaphors based on their travels in Borderlands. "He was the best skallywag hunter around. No bullet sponge boss could contend with his super rare fancy gun. Rest in pepperoni my fellow vault hunter. May you be reconstructed in the afterlife if there was an afterlife." 

And so was the life of the average grindy FPS RPG player

I'm reviewing this from the perspective of Borderlands 2: While the story retcons a few things, the retcons don't detract from the overall Borderlands continuity in any serious way. The added O2 mechanic adds a satisfying layer of latent difficulty. The addition of Cryo elemental damage isn't vitally important, but it does add to the versatility of elemental damage types overall, in the sense of both what you can dish out and what you'll have to prepare against.

Overall, The Pre-Sequel is more filler than essential to the franchise, but if you're looking for what amounts to Borderlands 2 plus reduced gravity plus the option to play as some of BL2's (and in one case at least) BL3's bad guys, The Pre-Sequel is where you'll find it.

I enjoyed the game a lot. It's much, much shorter than the other Borderlands games, but it's well worth playing if you loved Borderlands 2.

You unfortunately do need the DLC, however. At least the claptrastic voyage DLC. 

Without spoiling anything, the game lacks a level 30 area where you can grind, which makes the game (and bosses) much harder than it should. The claptastic voyage DLC somewhat fixes it.

It is an improved version of Borderlands 2. Most aspects were improved in this game. Questing, writing, boss fights, lootdrops over original Borderlands 2. While original is a mess of a game, this one is a lot better. Though, it does retain a lot of flaws of the original. Cheesy dialog meant for kids, non-functional drop system which often does not drop better, more interesting guns. Mobs sometimes are unbalanced hp/damage wise. Co-op is also a mess with its scalling. While classes are more interesting, it still has many questionable skill trees. 

In conclusion, since it had made significant leaps in game quality from its original, I would recommend this version of a Borderlands. However, it is strictly inferior to Borderlands 3 in most aspects and it is only good if you like childish humour and writing of the originals OR you simply want to play more of the Borderlands.

It's been quite a long time since I had last played this game. A friend and I have been playing through each of the Borderlands games and this was the one that we were skeptical about returning to. Now that I've played it again I actually enjoy this game for what it's worth. A lot of complaints about this game come from the fact that it lacks content and is too close to Borderlands 2. These complaints are understandable, as yes, the game does lack end-game content other than 2 below average DLC packs and a disappointing raid boss. However, the actual main story of this game was a lot of fun to return to. The features added in this game were all great: Cryo weapons, lasers, OZ kits + oxygen mechanics. While a lot of the visual style and charm of this game is clearly taken straight from Borderlands 2, the playable characters are still unique and have their own special builds and styles. The music was actually a really nice surprise too as I hadn't really paid much attention to it when I first played it. The new NPCs in this game are, to put it bluntly, obnoxious and annoying. There weren't many that I enjoyed, and in fact, I found myself disliking returning characters such as Lilith, Roland, and Moxxi because of their actions in the story. Overall, I don't think this game deserves as much hate as it gets. It's definitely flawed and lacks its own unique personality but it's still fun for what it is.

7/10

"Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel" has a rather clear intention in its name. It narrates the events leading up to Borderlands 2, more specifically the character arc of Handsome Jack. Rather than being an antagonist, he is the one leading your character this time around. As such, you see a different side of him, still grating and endearing. There is also the opportunity to meet other Borderlands characters and see them from a different point of view. While I enjoyed the ending overall, I found it a bit abrupt. Also, the beginning of the game is rather weak. Couple this with how boring of a villain Zarpedon is. It is not until the mid-game that the story picks up in my opinion.

The side quests are great and keep a generally consistent quality. Some of them are tedious, such as one mission that has you farm 50 common weapons, but most are, thankfully, quite entertaining. My favourite has to be one relating to a window. I'm certain fans of the game will know what I mean. The writing is once again a major component to the storytelling's success, yet I found it weaker than BL2. It's not bad, but I found it rough in places. Some jokes very much did not land and left me rolling my eyes. Nonetheless, most of the humour was entertaining and the serious moments were able to pack a punch.

Perhaps my biggest issue with the game is its art direction. While it makes sense due to the space thematic, everything is so dark in The Pre-Sequel! Even colourful locales have such an unpleasant tint that I can hardly recall any of the environments in the game. No matter how different some of them try to look, it all blends in together, creating a rather boring world to explore. I won't say that locations stood out that much in "Borderlands 2", but I certainly found them to be more pleasant and inviting than the dim lighting here.

What separates gameplay here is once more related to space, specifically the mechanics of gravity. Being able to float around and mess with these forces adds a whole new level of verticality that brings more action and thrill to an already exciting form of combat. I was constantly on the move here, flying in all directions, trying to hit my enemies. Furthermore, the mechanics are complicated and detailed. There is an oxygen meter to look after, as it will deplete in low-oxygen environments and with each boost you use. More interestingly, playing as Fragtrap, a robot, the game gladly joked about how I need not worry about breathing. And speaking of classes, there's a decent chunk to pick from here, with two additional DLCs. I chose Fragtrap, and as RNG-based as he is, the good ol' bot is just too much fun to play. Collecting loot was a driving force behind my playthrough, and was made far more interesting by a mechanic as simple as the Grinder. I wish the annoying dude didn't need to spit sexual innuendo every 10 seconds, though. It was funny the first two times, and annoying every other one.

Graphics-wise, The Pre-Sequel is almost iddentical to the second game. In fact, some might argue that there are too few things to separate the game from it and it's no more than glorified DLC, but if you play the game for yourself, I'm sure you'll disagree. There's more than enough content here to justify its separation.

All in all, "Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel" is a good game, a 7/10 in my book. I enjoyed playing through it and will recommend it readily to "Borderalnds 2" fans. Not anyone else, however. If you have the choice, opt for BL2. It's a much more memorable and ambitious experience, whereas this is meant to expand on it further. Worthwhile if you want to learn more about Handsome Jack and/or wish to play more Borderlands. Otherwise, I point you to the amazing game that precedes/follows.

I played Borderlands 2 like 10 years ago and I kinda skipped this one, I have no idea why though. Perhaps it was the reviews saying this wasn't that good or something. Well. I have now played through the campaign by myself and with a friend Co-op and I have no reason why I thought that way at all. 
Sure, it doesn't have that much content as Borderlands 2. Sure, it has less variety than Borderlands 2. Sure, it has less interesting characters and plot than Borderlands 2. Big Deal. As a standalone game it has it's merits and works quite well. The story was a good introduction to the characters in the universe and was actually interesting how the Handsome Jack character came to be. 
The campaign was okay to play through and had some funny (well..quite outdated memes to be exact) moments and Claptrap DLC was excellent. It had lasers and cryo weapons and they were so much more fun than anything in Borderlands 2. 
I played with Nisha and Doppelganger and they both played quite unique. Tho Nisha did WAY more damage in the end and was a bit unbalanced. Playing with Doppelganger it felt so much slower and not as fun. 
Only thing this game was lacking was some endgame. Only couple big bosses and nothing else is kinda meh and it kinda drops the replayability a bit. I played Borderlands 2 way more just because the varied DLCs you could do. 

But in the end it's a fun game and you can get this CHEAP nowadays with Borderland packages. And it has cross platform multiplayer so I could play it with my friend who had it on Epic Store. Tons of things to do for a while.

[i]It's basically a BL2 skinjob, it does some things better than BL2, a few things worse but mostly it's the same as BL2 in terms of mechanics, style and gameplay although with far lesser and varied content.[/i]
[hr][/hr]
 [h1]What's Good.....[/h1] 
[hr][/hr]
[list]
    [*] Skill trees are much more robust and personalized for each character. The final skills in each tree are wild and very fun to use.
    [*] Seriously, all characters are so much fun and different to play from each other.
    [*] Characters are actually voiced and react differently during story and side quests in-game.
    [*] Lasers.
    [*] Low Gravity combat makes combat less tedious and much more fluid.
    [*] Dahl Soldiers are much more fun to fight than Hyperion loaders.
    [*] If you're a fan, the backstory of Jack and his Vault hunters is pretty cool.
    [*] Game still looks pretty, environments are cool but mostly same throughout.
[/list] 
[hr][/hr]
[h1]What's Hood.....[/h1] 
[hr][/hr]
[list]
    [*]There are only 2 basic Environments - Helios space station and Ellpis, the Barren Moon. Both of them are pretty well designed but they eventually get stale half way through the game because there's only 2 of them. Remember BL2 had glaciers, tundras ,dust bowls and everything else in between.
    [*] Side quests are not as fun in fact, main quests are a bit of a drag as well.
    [*] Newer Wildlife not from BL2 like Kraggons and Shuggarths are too easy to kill and never pose a challenge. 
    [*] DLCs are mediocre and no where near as good as BL2.
    [*] I had trouble finding people to Co-op this game because most people play either BL3 or BL2 these days.
[/list]

This is probably my favorite Borderlands game, or one of my favorites. Maybe I'm a bit biased because I absolutely just love the character interactions that happen throughout the game, It's a lot like Bl3 in that aspect, just not a trash story like Bl3 is. The story in this is really good, second best to Tftbl. If you really like a game with good story, then this is probably going to be a great game for you. I personally disliked Bl3's story, and coming off of playing that to playing this was very refreshing. 

Spoilers below:

It depicts the story of what happens regarding the vault on Elpis and Jack taking over Helios. I personally really like it because before playing this game, I just hated Jack because he was an awful man. Great villain, honestly, but I just hated his character because of that. Because he's made to be hateable. But TPS shows a different side to him, shows how he was before he became like how he is in Bl2. I can really appreciate him as a character now and even feel a little bit of sympathy towards him because of it, even if I still hate the guy for all the bad stuff he's done. 

With that said, the game also made me rather dislike Lilith and Roland. I was never really fans of them both in bl1 and bl2, and after playing this I can say that it only gave me more reason to dislike them. I didn't really see a reason for them to betray Jack, and I can say that it probably only fueled his becoming into Handsome Jack even more. 

The game gives you an understanding into the events that shaped the whole "Handsome Jack" persona that Jack plays into in bl2, and makes you feel sympathy for the villain of the series. Which is something I never thought I would do. It is pretty well written, the characters feel developed and like they play a part in the story, and the ECHO logs throughout certain parts give even more backstory on the Vault Hunters in this game. Which I really really liked. I'm a huge lore nerd and character development nerd, so I love seeing these sides to the characters and seeing them grow through playing. For example, Timothy starts off as just trying too hard to be like Jack, but then ends up having his true personality shine through a bit. The personality you see in the bl3 dlc where he's just annoyed with Jack and having to act like him. But there's reasons why he doesn't act like that for the entirety of TPS, which I really did enjoy learning. 

Also claptrap as a playable character is great. 10/10.

People say this is the weakest of the Borderlands Games, and maybe they're right, but there's still a lot of  good going on.  The jumping and movement adds an interesting twist to the game as do the laser weapons.  The negatives compared to other Borderlands: some annoying characters, side missions that make you trek back across the same areas over and over again, inventory system is a slight downgrade from B2 with no ability to mark as junk, revenue from selling collected items is pathetically little making it hard to buy what few worthwhile items do show up in vending machines.  Story is superior to the base story of B3 and creates an excellent bridge between B1 & B2 explaining characters in ways you didn't know you wanted to know.

[h1] Clap-in-the-Box [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

The classes are great, far better than any other Borderlands game I have played.  I played Claptrap and it was hilarious the things that were happening with his ult and the combinations I would come up with.  It was also nice to see a variety of locations and colors in the game.  Borderlands 1 and 2 felt drab, so this was a good change of pace.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

There is too much story in my FPS.  The NPCs talk forever and it gets old after awhile.  There were times I felt like the shooting was getting in the way of the talking.  Also, I died in so many stupid ways it wasn't even funny.  It was annoying.  Dying is a part of a FPS game, but it just felt stupid in this case.

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

I beat it!  And I enjoyed it, at least when I was able to shoot things and not die.  I know it's not a fan favorite, but it's my favorite Borderlands game by far.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

So this game is based heavily on Borderlands 2, if you liked that game then this is more of an extension of that game, not so much a separate game. 

Good:
1. Cryo based stuff is interesting in a way
2. Classes with expanded skill trees and more options when it comes to fine tuning a character to suite your playstyle
3. They have learned some things from previous games, and improved upon it (i.e. Critical Ascensi0n from Zer0 is split on Aurelia)
4. Generally there is [i]some[/i] improvements, fresh-ish content (Oz kits are better than Relics in BL2 for instance) and so on

Bad:
1. The XP and health curve is not set right. Enemies have, in general, too much hit points while you're playing the storyline
2. The storyline is an insufferable drag that just goes on and on with a lack of fluidity. You get the sense that that because of point (3) below, they extended it with redirects and blocks, meaningless tasks and high HP enemies to make it work. It's not even that great of a story either: honestly, if you want to see the story, just watch a Let's Play on YouTube and be done with it
3. There is very little to do after you complete the storylines and DLC content except farm kit and weapons. The other games have a similar situation but I feel like there is less "to do" or "test out" or try out different things
4. The sidequests have to be done as soon as they become available to keep ahead of the XP ladder, otherwise you'll be looking at skulls pretty soon and dying a lot unless you really know what you're doing (speedrunners for instance)
5. The gear that drops or is available in vendors is not adequate enough in quality to complete the storyline and/or deal with enemies sufficiently. You have to farm the SHiFT chest in Concordia to have decent enough shields, COMs, Oz kits and weapons. Honestly without having the Gibbed save editor available to you to transfer kit from character to character and stuff the game isn't even worth playing
6. Like many "Post 2010" games producers/designers still haven't learned from lessons in the past: Unskippable cutscenes, boring plots, characters that just ramble and ramble (Pickle comes to mind), badly designed bosses (Deadlift is really really hard to beat with trash tier kit, which you'd be using all the game gave you anyways, there's other examples), badly designed enemies (Stalkers with huge health pools, their high damage and other properties would be fine if they had low HP for example, then there's the Lost Legion Eternals). Most of enemy flaws can be corrected by fixing the HP/XP curve, I feel, however that's never going to happen

The [url=https://hardcoregamer.com/2014/10/13/review-borderlands-the-pre-sequel/]Hardcore Gamer[/url] review is probably the most accurate from my point of view. In short, if you get this game for peanuts, or as part of the Handsome Jack BL2 collection (as I did, so it was effectively free), that's fine, but [u]you should not pay full price for this game[/u]. It's simply not worth it. You should get this game to round out your collection, check out the content and the characters (yay FR4G-TP!) but if you didn't like Borderlands 1 and/or 2, do not buy this game. It's too half-baked.

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Edit: I should also mention I've had to rely on a lot of exploits / glitches / save scumming / bit of Gibbed save editor work to make this game work enough for me to tolerate it.

Exploits such as: The UVHM reset progress XP method done about 120 times gets you from Level 50 to 70 (only took like 5 days to do that); locking your profile.bin OR save0001.sav file to farm the SHiFT chest OR farm legendaries (respectively); save scumming / locking your save file to farm a specific mission reward; Gibbed save editing to copy items from character to character and editing the character level to Level 29 (P1), Level 50 (P2) to skip all the annoying grinding of side missions. 

It's got a lot of neat things, such as mentioned above, but also a lot of downsides (vehicle control was something Gearbox never really figured out) and many other annoyances that tips the balance scales in a negative way. Also the entire weapon scheme was literally copied from BL2 and many of the Unique items and Legendaries are copied straight from BL2, so if you love them there you'll like them here too. If not then well it's not going to be that great. 

I think overall there's probably a big reason there's still a more vibrant Borderlands 1 community (in terms of activity and resources) than TPS. Which is sad.

This is, I think, the weakest installment of the Borderlands series and it didn't age well.

I'm replaying it now with friends, and am finding many of the jokes unfunny; some of the acting (e.g. Nakayama's) overdone (it's supposed to be funny, but isn't); and the gameplay is noticeably worse than in Borderlands 3. You spend too much time trekking around the game world because quick travel isn't available. You can't mark items as crap and sell all crap with one keypress. You can't zoom out to see the entire map. The story is OK, but the player characters are mostly not very relatable.

On the whole, while I like the Borderlands franchise and have finished all the games, I don't think The Pre-Sequel is much fun in 2021.

Game five of my 2021 challenge to finish all the games in my Steam library and write a review of them. My challenge for this game was to finish the main quest line (and do a few sidequests on the way) - in total it took me around 25 hours.

A few hours into Borderlands The Pre-Sequel I thought I was really going to have to push through this one. Although there were hints of the combat mechanics from Borderlands 2 the space / low grav element and some properly annoying jumping segments really got to me. But as I continued playing and the story developed I found myself enjoying it more and more. 

Borderlands The Pre-Sequel is published by an Australian company and the accents work well in the 'space hillbilly' universe of the game - which happens to be my favourite sci-fi concept. There's level design that keeps the same open exploration of BL2, with interesting things to be found off the beaten path that aren't always telegraphed. There's also the looty shooty combat with the enemies becoming more interesting and varied the further into the game I got, some epic bosses toward the end it had all the elements I loved in BL2, plus a plot that takes you into the origin of one of the best video game baddies of all time.

I'd played Borderlands 3 to the end last year and although I'd finished it, those long, linear levels made me want to give up long before the end. This is far more of a spiritual (pre)-sequel and if you haven't bought this game yet and didn't like BL3, or played it a bit and got annoyed with the space elements I'd recommend playing and pushing on for more of your Borderlands fix. It's worth it.

An awful and disgraceful entry to the series. Animations are subpar, sometimes the enemies jump without any sort of animation at all leaving it to look like they just levitated, and i am not talking about the jetpack enemies who can actually do that. hit boxes for the vehicles need work, something 1/8th the size of my tire can dead stop the entire vehicle upon collision. on the topic of vehicles the moon buggy occasionally just sticks into the ground or a piece of rock and self destructs, killing the player. NPC pathfinding is glitchy as hell, characters walk in reverse with a forward animation during conversations, jack got stuck in the wall of the merrifs elevator. furthermore, and this may be due to my dlc (i purchased this game as part of a borderlands bundle) the game allowed me after the first few missions to teleport back to the hyperion station. i figured this would just be another area i could use, but instead it jumped me into an endgame cinematic that ended up giving me major spoilers for the plot. finally this entry really seems to punish you for playing solo with enemies that can down you in seconds and that are too well armored to get second wind from. while this type of enemy (the down you in seconds kind) has occurred across the series it has felt much more balanced in other entries, whereas here it seems tilted to punish you for playing without backup. all things considered this is the worst time i have ever had playing borderlands, a series i normally enjoy. unless you get it on sale or in a bundle i would not waste your money on this particular entry in the series.

Awesome game. Would highly suggest. Play as Claptrap, it is not as bad as they warn!

UPDATE & TIP:  I progressed in the game until I was notified about the "Ultimate Vault Hunter Mode" (UVHM) and that I could participate in it.  I was level 27 and thought it would be worth a try.  After all, if I didn't like it, I could at least go back and pick up the game in "Normal" mode, right?  WRONG!

Once you agree to try UVHM, THE GAME STARTS OVER FROM THE BEGINNING AND *ALL* OF YOUR PROGRESS IS LOST!!!  This means, you have to go through all of the gameplay you so diligently fought through AGAIN.  ARRGH!

Oh, and at the level you left off at.  You might be thinking, "What's the big deal?  The NPCs are level 1 and you are level 27."  No so fast, grasshopper.  All the NPCs are at your level, just like before... EXCEPT they are 2-3 times harder to kill and you still have your crappy 1/3 powered weapons to rely on.  Needless to say, expect to do a lot of dying, WAY more than the first time around.  

The new weapon drops are more powerful, but no where near powerful enough to make up for how much more powerful the NPCs are compared to you (same shield and health).  I must have died about 20+ times trying to kill DeadLift because he can kill you with 2-3 shots... and almost never misses.

I'm still not sure I'm going to try to play through the game again.  It is VERY disappointing that there was NO INFORMATION provided to guide the decision, just "Whoohoo!  You can be a super duper "Ultimate Vault Hunter".  Wanna try it?"  

As Wilhelm would say, "Uh, sure?"  

CL4PTP:  "Whoops!  We forgot to tell you that you are starting over.  Ooopsie!  Silly us!  Have fun dying!  And starting all over!"

And don't even TRY grinding unless you are using moonstones as you will likely get "leveled up" (e.g. green to blue), but lower powered weapons than you put into the grinder.  I lost A LOT of really nice weapons before I realized that (yeah, my bad).

ORIGINAL REVIEW:  This game has been much better to play than I thought it would be.  I was afraid that the "A Scanner Darkly" (2006 movie starring Keanu Reeves) style of graphics would really be a turn-off during game play.  Yeah, I guess I was a bit of a graphics snob.

However, the gameplay dynamics have been good enough that I don't mind them at all.  In fact, I believe that they help keep the framerates up when other games would struggle on my GTX 1080Ti.  I have experienced ZERO lag while playing and I wouldn't be at all surprised to hear that people with lower end graphics cards have a similar experience.

Anyway, I'd highly recommend the game.  It takes a bit to get used to this game's quirks, but once you do, it is smooth sailing.  

I'm looking forward to trying Borderlands 2, which is supposed to be pretty similar.

PS.  I initially had some trouble getting the game to play.  It wouldn't start because of some permissions issues in the "Documents" folder, where the Borderlands save config and progress files.  I had to go into Windows 10 Firewall an explicitly allow the game .exe files to access that folder.  I don't know why this game had this problem.  I have already installed Borderlands 2 and it didn't have a problem.

The only thing I can think of is that they haven't talked to Microsoft to get this particular .exe file permissions in Windows Firewall.  I hope I'm alone in this, but if I'm not, then I hope this helps others get the game installed and running correctly.  It's worth playing, especially at 50+% off!

I couldn't get through this game, and I loved both Borderlands 1 and 2. Maybe it gets better, but it doesn't seem like it would. The Pre-Sequel is the Gary Cherone of the Borderlands series, in that it is basically the exact same as Borderlands 2, but somehow 1000x worse. 
Firstly, Pros:
-New weapons are cool, but not exactly much of a deviation
-Cool characters to play as
-Different setting
Cons:
-Not funny or interesting in terms of writing and story
-Gravity is often annoying
-Weapon scaling is gone; one of my favorite parts about Borderlands 1 & 2, as you felt like you were getting stronger. Here, you might keep the same weapon for 5+ levels, and most of the weapons are garbage.
-In Borderlands 1 & 2, it felt as though you were reaching benchmarks. For example, in Borderlands 2, you have to fight your way through the Fridge to get back to Sanctuary, and it's difficult. But anytime you go back there after you level up a few times, every enemy dies after one shot. It's hard to explain why that aspect is so fun, but it is completely missing in this game, and none of the locations are at all interesting. Honestly, just go play Borderlands 2 again.

Borderlands is a game praised for its co-operative experience. However, as the only of my friends with a gaming PC, I don't have the same opportunity that console users have. Split-screen on PC has reached the same accessibility as consoles through Steam remote play, the Steam link, the many controller options, yet the games that boast multiplayer options lack a trait that should be the standard.

I cannot, in good conscience, recommend a multiplayer game that doesn't allow actual access to reliable multiplayer.

Simply put, I like this game. I loved Borderlands 1 and hated Borderlands 2. This installment feels like more of the same from Borderlands 1, minus some of the cooler original weapons. This version emphasizes co-op and group play and is almost impossible to solo; especially on the hardest level.  But, the quests are fun, and the performance is incredible. The amount of detail in the gameplay is incredible. No, it doesn't look like other games, but the tiny details are awesome, and I'm surprised it doesn't need more RAM. All in all, it's a solid title with solid fun gameplay, and it's compatible on many systems, unlike more-popular fps combat titles. Thanks for making this game.

After Borderlands 1 & 2, The Pre-Sequel comes somehow dissatisfying. As if the developers were running out of ideas.
While the overall story is not bad, the main flow is interrupted by numerous slow and boring quests and the end is quite unclear and makes no sense. Also, I was expecting a deep psychological story of Jack's descent into madness, but nope - he just turns into a jerk and that's it. Most of the (newly introduced) characters are redundant, uninspiring cannon fodders and the story would work fine without them. The jokes are really bad.
Gameplay-wise, I appreciate the addition of laser weapons. The rest of weaponry seems rather unsatisfying - in previous games, I always found a revolver/rifle/shotgun/something that was both effective and fun to play with. In Pre-Sequel, the only weapons I can really play with are either lasers or sniper rifle. The rest is just so inaccurate and low-damaging they quickly lead to frustration.

[h1]In short: This game is Borderlands 2 but your loot drops into death pits. Also WAAAY less to do here. But at least you have broken ass lazers. Get it on sale so you can try it out, but don't spend your money at full price. [/h1]

In long: 

[u] The Plot [/u] - This game takes place between Borderlands 1 and Borderlands 2, detailing a bit of Jack's rise to power and how he became a massive dickwad. You'll be playing on Elpis, one of Pandora's moon's as well as Helios, Hyperion's space station. You play as some vault hunters doing a job for Jacky Baby. These characters are the reason why people even get this game a chance. Three of them are villains while  two of them are forced to work for him and one feels like they are obligated to finish the job. This gives a kinda different feel to everything, as you get to play as the characters you eventually fight in other games. 

[u]The Gameplay[/u] - Like I said, Borderlands 2. If you like Borderlands 2, this gameplay is more of the same. Replace slag with cyro. Problem is since you are in s p a c e, there's low gravity that even effects drops. This means that if someone drops something, there's a high chance they will kick it into a pit. Or better yet, be a flying enemy that drops an legendary (Boomer :v).

[b]The Problem[/b] - Why is this game seen as a black sheep then? Some people may not like the story, others may think that this game took too much from Borderlands 2 to be called a full game. The most problematic thing about this game is that if you even so much as compare it to Borderlands 2, this game just pales in comparsion on paper. Even with the base story of Borderlands 2, you get sooo much more than this game. 
Not to mention that since this game didn't get that much on launch, it didn't get that much on DLC. By the time Claptastic Voyage came out (great dlc btw), this game was already dead. 

Now I'm just going to list a bit of grievances that I have with the game that I don't know how to put into a single section without going on a rant lol

- Only one raid boss, and it's just the same boss as the ending boss, but just one shots you. Imagine if Borderlands 2 had the Warrior as a raid boss but just one shots you.

- I know I already said this, but FUCK loot being kicked off into space. Some of the scavs you fight has this animation that actually fucking kicks the loot they drop. Also the ned fight takes place were there are cracks in the surface of the place that leads to a kill zone. The fact that Ned can drop a fucking Skullmasher into a hole makes me MALT. Not Mald, MALT. I'm legit turning into foam at the thought of this shit happening.

- The general lack of fast travels. ESPECIALLY DURING THE VEINS OF HELIOS. With levels being way larger than Borderlands 2 levels on average, the lack of fast travels really makes this game feel like alot of running around. Which gets me to...

- Poor pacing in enemy spawns. Coupled with the long time of just large empty spaces you can go, this is why this game feels like alot of running around. Also, if you wipe the map, the enemies won't respawn.

- The lack of dedicated drops for legendaries and uniques. If you've played Borderlands 2, you'd know how some farms can be done for some weapons. Boll for the Fastball, Warrior for the Volcano, BNK-3R for the Bitch, etc etc. There's alot of returning legendaries that don't have a dedicated person to farm it from, which also leads too...

- Iwajira farming. This is one reason why the game died. Iwajira is a boss that drops a legendary. It doesn't matter what legendary it was, the point is that players would farm this boss for a legendary, take mutiples and then try their luck in the Grinder to get other legendaries. Because of the lack of dedicated drops + the fact that people were fighting the same boss over and over again, was one reason why this game died.

- Lack of refarmable bosses. Yes, some bosses on launch were non-farmable. Meaning, if you wanted to farm them, you would have to alt+f4 each time you don't get what you want. There's alot of mini bosses that now can be farmed, but there's still many bosses that are one and done. Want a Nuke'em? Fuck you. Want to fight Zarpadon again? Sike.  

- Lastly, the fact that Borderlands 2 and 3 exists. Hell, even Borderlands 1 can seem more fun than this. Huge amounts of DLC that really brings out the game or its good sides. This game only has two DLC's and one of them is just a combat arena. 

In conclusion: Fun game, No content other than Clap's, many issues with the base game. I probably missed a few issues, but that's why I allow comments. If you really care that much, then please correct me or add more issues that I finished. I can't recommend this game at full price, but I sure can recommend at least a full playthrough of this game on at least one character that isn't Claptrap* during a sale.

*Claptrap is my least favorite character because most of the time, I die after hitting F, meaning I don't even get whatever package that I'm going to get. Plus, most of his damage comes from Pirate Ship mode + Explosive boosts.

It's not Borderlands or Borderlands 2 good, but the story is good enough but that's mostly due to Jack spiraling into insanity throughout the course of the game, which by the way, was done well. You have other supporting characters like Torgue that provide some entertaining commentary and conversations throughout the journey as well so that was a nice touch too. 

Much like the first two Borderlands games, the mechanics here are identical but the additional of an O2 (Oxygen) system that allows for new build diversity specifically for Melee characters, and can be taken advantage of by other classes as well. They also had a lot of fun in creating the skill trees as well, so there's new skills for you to play around with, specifically Calptrap who has this RNG built into his abilities that can be a double edged sword at times.

And thanks to the release of Borderlands 3, this is no longer my least favourite game in the franchise, so that's a plus!

Compared to other games in the borderlands franchise the pre-sequel is one of the weaker entries. However, that doesn't mean it's bad. The pre-sequel continues to deliver on the RPG FPS genre with more borderlands humour and gameplay. The low gravity and Oz kits give a different feel to movement, and the added laser weapons are pretty neat.

A lot of people don't like this installment, and I completely understand why: it's uncomfortable.  Sure, it runs on the same engine as Borderlands 2, but that just makes the new elements seem that much stranger; there's a familiar look and feel, but something is just... off.  Spend some time with it, though, and approach it with an open mind, and you might find that The Pre-Sequel has a lot to offer.  It's certainly not without its frustrations, but there are a lot of unique elements here, and once you get your footing, it's a total blast.  I had my doubts at first, but it planted a seed that blossomed into something wonderful.

The first thing you're likely to notice, once you get into the game proper, is that a lot of the game takes place in low-gravity areas.  This, along with the fact that you can perform a mid-air boost with your oxygen unit, took me quite some time to get used to, since the boosts aren't just a simple double-jump; how they'll affect your jump and its trajectory will be determined by where you are in your jump arc.  This consumes oxygen, which you'll also have to worry about while you're in a vacuum, and they actually thought to make it impossible to light enemies on fire where there is no oxygen; not a good sign.  But then, I had this moment: I was ducking in a trench, where there was an air pocket, while scavengers were above, firing at me, and there was only one solution: flying low-g headshots.  This was my moment; this is when it all clicked, and I understood the sheer joy of the experience.  You have to learn to work with it, but once you do, the mechanics are SO satisfying; it's like nothing I've ever played before.

The RPG elements are great, too, both the new and the old.  For starters, the new laser weapons are fun to use, and the new cryo element adds the satisfaction of shattering enemies in a variety of ways.  The character classes are all interesting, too; the first game didn't stray too far from the old wizard/rogue/brick/balanced archetypes, and 2 put those in a blender, but here you have a Captain America/Wonder Woman hybrid, a big dude with an entire skill tree devoted to adding cybernetic enhancements to his body, a sadomasochist cowgirl, a clone who fights with holograms, an aristocrat with ice magic, and Claptrap.  Friggin' Claptrap; I haven't seen a character like this since the goof-offs from Dragon Warrior 3!  The only real drawbacks in the gameplay department are that the challenges haven't had their quantities decreased to meet the much shorter length of the game (not a [i]huge[/i] deal), and that the enemy leveling is a bit aggressive; it wasn't unusual to have massive hordes or even bosses spawn several levels higher than I was, and I did every sidequest available, just like always.  Well, that and once you get toward the end of Helios, they get REALLY carried away with escort missions; can we just finally agree that nobody likes these?

The visuals are just unbelievable; the amount of thought put into the environments is jaw-dropping.  I've been on plenty of video game moons before, but I wouldn't hesitate to say that Elpis is the best of them all.  There's something romantic about going to the moon, standing alone on a pale, rocky surface as you stare up into space with all manner of celestial objects scintillating above, like a black-sand beach glimmering in the midday sun, and they completely nailed that.  Space is also terrifying, so by day, the surface is an uncomfortable shade of yellow, and above you is a black void of burning horror; they nailed that, too.  What really ties it all together is the music, which sounds appropriately spacey at times, and just desolate and unfriendly at others.  You get some neat high-tech areas, and the scav weapons - the bandit analog, and the only ones that really look different from Borderlands 2 - have some cool patterns, but the real star of the show is the surface of that moon.

The story's not bad; its job was to fill in some of the blanks between the first 2 Borderlands games, and it does that very well, with a few surprises here and there.  It was interesting selecting player characters from a pool of NPCs you already knew from previous games, and they're fleshed out a bit more here; they even respond to certain NPC dialogue.  What really stands out is the uncomfortable atmosphere of most of the game; there are very few moments of the usual over-the-top lunacy that you've come to know from previous entries, for one thing.  For another, many familiar faces are replaced with new ones; Nurse Nina really grew on me, and Janey Springs has her moments, but you miss Dr. Zed and Scooter.  Concordia is no Sanctuary, either; rather than feeling like your own base - like home - you're just in some run-down spaceport where even the random NPCs are largely hostile toward or at least dismissive of you.  I think that's the point, though; it wasn't going to be Borderlands 2-2, because you're technically playing as the bad guys, and you know that going in.  If you loved Chrono Trigger/Secret of Mana and hated Cross/Evermore, you're probably not going to like the tone of this, either, but if you're willing to try something a bit different, there's a lot of good to be found here.

There isn't much in the way of DLC this time; you have 2 new characters, 2 expansions that are nothing more than arena modes, and one more expansion that's actually quite good.  If you play any of the expansions, Claptastic Voyage is the way to go; you take a trip into the mind of Claptrap, and while that goes largely as expected, there are a few very cool surprises, too.  The early areas are very cool futuristic cyber environments, and they're really neat to explore.  What comes later, though are some old memories, some new memories, and one of those "Journey to the Center of the Mind" types of deals.  These are great on their own, but they don't entirely ditch the cyber elements, so the end result is a unique and [b]gorgeous[/b] experience all the way to the end.  As expected, the story and tone are partially humorous, but also awkward and uncomfortable; what better way to cap off an experience like The Pre-Sequel.

I've been playing [i]Borderlands: The Pre-sequel[/i] since its release in October with a co-op partner.  This past weekend, we finally finished the main game, and now have gone back again in True Vault Hunter Mode to see what that has in store for us.

We've been having a [i]lot[/i] of fun with the game.  The game does not have a lot of big UI or engine differences from [i]Borderlands 2[/i], except for four, and those range from pretty fun to really fun.

[h1]The Additions[/h1]
First, they've introduced cryo as an element type: after you freeze then melee-shatter your first enemy, you'll be hooked too.

Second, large areas of the game are low gravity, which means your character can jump a long, long way.  In combination with the Oz kits (oxygen kits for breathing in those areas without air), the low gravity also allows for double-jumps (for extra floaty spacetime fun) and for gravity slams ("butt slams"), where you power your character downward from a low-gravity jump by releasing oxygen from their kit and then slam into the ground, knocking back any nearby enemies.  (Oz Kits also come with elemental modifications so you can do, for example, electrical or corrosive butt slams.)

Third, they've included a new weapon type: lasers.  Lasers vary anywhere from single-shot and burst-shot varieties into a full, continuous beam I like to call "firehose mode", which can be a great deal of fun, too -- just point and spray damage at your enemies.

Fourth, but not least, there is a new vehicle -- the Stingray.  There is the standard two-person, four-wheeled vehicle which, in [i]B:TPS[/i], called the Moon Buggy (or the Moon Zoomy). but the Stingray is a single-person hovercraft that can jump and slam; think of it like a space bike.

[h1]The Characters and Classes[/h1]
There are four classes to play in the base game; as they introduce them, we have Athena as the Gladiator, Wilhelm as the Enforcer, Nisha as the Lawbringer, and Claptrap as a Mistake.

Athena you may remember as an NPC from [i]The Secret Armory of General Knoxx[/i] DLC.  Athena's skills focus on shotgun and SMG, with her special ability being the Aspis, a shield that absorbs damage coming from in front of her and can be thrown to deal damage â€” in fact, this shield is why her preferred weapons are the point-and-shoot variety rather than the precise-aiming variety since, with the Aspis out, she cannot zoom in for a scoped shot.

Wilhelm you may recall as an NPC from [i]Borderlands 2[/i] where he was the first major boss faced by the Vault Hunters in that game.  Wilhelm's skills focus on heavy weapons, especially lasers (but he's pretty good with all guns).  His special ability is Wolf and Saint: Wolf is an aggressive attack drone and Saint is a passive support drone, and they can get quite powerful.

Nisha may be remembered as the Sheriff of Lynchwood in [i]Borderlands 2[/i].  Her general focus is on pistols, and her special ability, Showdown, puts her in an auto-aim mode that drastically increases her gun damage, fire rate, accuracy, reload speed, and bullet speed.  Her skill tree allows her to dual wield pistols, as well, though she does loose the right-mouse aim mode when doing this.

Finally, there's CL4P-TP, who needs really no introduction as Claptrap.  Except he's actually FR4G-TP -- the same Claptrap as the Interplanetary Ninja Assassin Claptrap from the [i]Claptrap's New Robot Revolution[/i] DLC.  Was he meant as a serious character and class?  It's hard to say but do note that in choosing Claptrap as your character, you have to confirm  more than once that this is what you really want to do.  Claptrap's special ability is VaultHunter.EXE, a somewhat random collection of things that occur when the ability is triggered -- some may be quite effective, others humorous, and some potentially disastrous.  His skill tree is equally ludicrous, with specializations of "Boomtrap" (explosive damage and guns), "I Love You Guys!" (support), and "Fragmented Fragtrap" (rewarding versatility and adaptability as his strengths and weaknesses periodically change).

[h1]The Milieu[/h1]
[i]B:TPS[/i] takes place on Pandora's moon, Elpis, and on the Hyperion space station that you can see in the sky in the other Borderlands games (you know, that giant H-shaped satellite by the moon).  Time-wise, the story takes place between [i]Borderlands[/i] and [i]Borderlands 2[/i] -- in playing [i]B:TPS[/i] you get to find out what happened to Brick, Mordecai, Lilith, and Roland from the original game in the immediate aftermath of the Vault's opening, and what made Handsome Jack (and Wilhelm and Nisha) into the characters you meet in [i]Borderlands 2[/i].  Some old favorites make appearances as well -- Moxxi in particular shows up as the proprietor of Moxxi's Up Over (a pub on the moon).  It can be a little confusing at first, though, because the story you're experiencing is actually being told to Lilith by Athena after the events of [i]Borderlands 2[/i].

While the bulk of Pandora's denizens in the first two games are voiced with American accents, Elpis is, apparently, Pandora's Oceania.  A good many of the accents are Australian, and a lot of the jokes and references are Australian, too.  This is fairly pervasive, from the O2 kits being called "Oz Kits", place names such as Burraburra, and "Springy Shiela" grenade mods, to talk of billabongs, jumbucks, and tuckerbags, and a roving enemy known as the Swagman.  While some people seem to really hate this aspect of the voice acting and find the thick Aussie accents distracting or annoying, I find it pretty charming and a nice change from the North American hicks and rednecks of [i]Borderlands[/i] and [i]Borderlands 2[/i].

[h1]The Game[/h1]
The game itself seemed a little short to me, but not so short that it's "just another DLC" as some complain.  It can actually take a lot of time to do all the side quests and to work on challenges and achievements, if you're a die-hard completionist.  The extra game features and four new classes add enough that it's definitely a whole new game in the franchise.  I think the "too short" impression mostly comes about because the writing in the latter third or fourth of the game seems rushed and a little disjointed, and those story missions are prone to push, push, push you through too far quickly if you let their intense urgency get to you.

There are some annoying aspects.  There are bugs that really should've been worked out by now, and by this I primarily mean mobs clipping into walls where they can shoot your character but not, apparently, be shot by your toon.  And it's bad that it's so damned easy to fall through the scenery and die that I've done it at least a dozen times just in the course of normal hunt-for-Vault-symbols style exploration.  A few days ago my co-op partner and I took down one of the "secret" boss mobs only to find that it was bugged, and didn't spawn the exit it was supposed to, and so our characters had to die to get out of its lair which shouldn't happen.  My co-op partner and I also found a too-large number of Challenges that could only be triggered by one character in the zone (we had to reload the zone for the other of us to be able to get it) and at least one that I have not been able to complete even though he got the completion on it when my character picked up the fifth of the five necessary items.

Still, if you like the Borderlands series, this is more of the same and you will enjoy it, and it's actually a very fun ride to boot.

This game is great if you've already played the first two and are looking for something more. If you haven't bought it, I'd highly recommend you do so.

The movement in this game feels even less restrictive than Borderlands 2 with all of its low-gravity environments (and the little speederbike - called a Stingray - you get later on, love that thing). The lazer weaponry was a lot of fun to play around with, legendary weapons all felt extremely unique, and the final boss was one heck of a fight. The voice acting was great.

I played as Nisha in my playthrough and honestly her Ability is so much fun to use - if a little short-lived compared to the others. Her other class bonuses make up for this though. Even while playing BL3, I often find myself missing Nisha's abilities and still wishing I could be using them to play the other games now. By far my favorite playstyle in the Borderlands Franchise. Her voice lines were also great - she was a bad guy through and through, playing an Antihero like her is a lot of fun.

My only complaint was that it does feel shorter than the other two, though there's no lack of content.
