Borderlands 2 in space. Main complaint a lot of people had about this game was a lack of post-game and another was a lack of DLC. It's very enjoyable, however. I found the combat more enjoyable due to the gravity and oz kits (pretty much just jetpacks)

It's more of a BL 1.5 or a Handsome Jack's DLC in BL2, instead of an independent game in the Borderlands franchise. The charisma of characters from BL2 ( especially Jack) are so impressive that it overshadows anyone else in this game. 
BL TPS has a much more developed and well-designed balances and level-scaling, i.e. few characters' essential gears are obtained from the mainstory; better drop rates; manageable fights with outleveled weapons. (Meaning: less grindy and more smooth game experience). Skill designs for all 6 main characters are really fun (especially Fragtrap's/Claptrap's); background story, relationships and characteristics of most characters in the game are either directly or indirectly depicted or implied in side quests. 
(Yes, Homage to the long gone 2K Aussie)

The issue most complain about is regarding its small volume: short story (of a DLC scale in BL2), little to no end game content.
It's still worth playing, not only because its story (and sidestories) fills the gap between BL1 and BL2, but It has the (personally) second to best DLC: Claptastic Voyage, right after Tiny Tina's Assault on Dragon Keep, in the Borderlands World.

This game is so knee-slapping hilarious that one of the key jokes in the plot of the story is that a door code is literally 8008. You get it? Like BOOB? Fantastic. Also some SJW nonsense going on, with characters reminding you which sexuality they like the most and feminist BS showing up in needless places. Bosses are also much worse then BL2, they are not creatively interesting and barely have any relevance to the plot. The only cool one was the final boss. Replacing slag with ice was a good idea, but the oxygen tanks need to go. You've effectively turned an open world into a giant underwater level where you have to monitor your breath. This is not Subnautica survival game, this is a shooter. Levels are also pointlessly large and amazingly empty. Side quests are generic and unfunny and seek only to waste time, and you may have to complete a few as this game has quite a few difficulty spikes. The main characters (besides the DLC bimbo) are actually well crafted and their skills and skill trees are interesting to invest in, it's a shame that they were wasted in this garbage story, which we already have a pretty decent understanding of seeing as how it's a prequel. Worst of all there are Australian accents in this game.

Long story short:
If You'r a fan of the franchise (like me) - i recommend it. You wont regret it.
If You'r new to BL universe, don't start with this game. Get BL1 first to check if You like this madhouse. 

If Yoy play'd Borderland 1 and/or 2 You know what to expect. It will be exactly that what You've faced in 2nd part + a lot more low grav conditions.
Something new are vacuum areas where You need to watch for air reserve. In exchange for Slag-element from 2nd game here we have Ice-ellement that slows down or even freezes enemies completly.
The game seems to be shorter then BL2 but longer than BL1. 
Storywise... well... Since it tells the story set between 1 & 2 we know what will happen and how it has to end. The scenarios for BL1 & BL2 where IMO great, because they had a lot of turns of action and whre generally unpredictable. Here this element is lost, but it's a prequel as the title says.
At least the gretesque and a bit black humor is still here. Several times during the playthrough i needed to pause the game to laugh lound and calm myself. The lunatic'ness is also present, as well the renowned cell-shaded graphics.

Got to a narrative element that made me feel gross, so I quit.  I understand that it is probably silly to moralize about forcing someone to do something against their will in a game where you blow people into bloody chunks, but here we are.  

This moment was clearly meant to be a story beat to develop Jack from who he was at the beginning of the game to who he is in BL2, but it isn't Jack taking the action, it is you. In order to progress, you have to choose to carry out his orders even though your own character's voice over says its a crappy thing to do.  So instead I uninstalled the game and dropped it into the "will never play" bin in my steam library.

As far as the gameplay goes, it was fun enough if you enjoy the other BL games (I've completed 1 & 2) but not super compelling.  I may have lost my tolerance for grinding as I've grown older, but it definitely seemed to weigh this game more than I remember from the earlier entries.  The weapons didn't feel as varied or as impactful as I remember, and there seems to be a lot more junk/grinder fodder.

If I hadn't run into this narrative issue, I would probably have finished the game and given it a moderate recommendation (in the realm of a 6/10 unless there was a significant improvement or decline in the latter part of the game). As it is, 4/10. Fuck you Jack.

Borderlands the Pre-Sequel is about on par with Borderlands 2, the story is ok and guns feel good to use, [strike]Running Simulator Prequel[/strike] but the gameplay is garbage just like Borderlands 2.

I said this in my Borderlands 2 review and I'll say it in this review, Borderlands the Pre-Sequel's gameplay and balancing is terrible. I know leveling up is a part of the game because it's a RPG, but I think other RPG's like Fallout 4 and Elder Scrolls Skyrim does things better when it comes to a level up system. With Fallout 4 and Elder Scrolls Skyrim you can play through the main quest without leveling up to lets say 30 just to progress in the story, but Borderlands the Pre-Sequel you have to grind your way through the main quest. And yes I know the whole point of an RPG is to grind, but I think that type of grind only works with side quests only instead of the main quest(as in side quests are optionable). 

If you want more info about the gameplay just go read my Borderlands 2 review, the gameplay is practically identical.

Borderlands 2 is one of my all time favourite games so this was a really painful experience and I don't endure to the point of pain unless I think there's something coming - a keystone that would liven up combat, better maps, GRAVITY. You have all these fun tools at your disposal, but it's like you're constantly stuck in the worst level that's just no fun to play in. Imagine if a Zelda game were 100% Water Temple or Dark Souls was just Black Knight Archers shooting you off of narrow rooftops. Disgusting.

In order to appreciate how bad the level design is you have to understand that there is a persistent low gravity mechanic, complete with a double jump. It's slow. Now, as for the level design itself, it's like a crumpled up piece of trash with nooks and crannies and bits that kind of look explorable but aren't (sometimes they are so you'd better make sure), all the while you're hopping around, taking 30 seconds between jumps, landing on pieces of arbitrary rebar and debris trying to figure out where it is you can and can not go. Why!?

2k Australia shut down just a year after this game's release. Good riddance.

No idea why people sh1t on this game, it's fantastic and whilst it doesn't live up to Borderlands 2 it's easily the 2nd best game in the franchise after Borderlands 2. I feel like most people sh1tting on this game are just mindlessly following a trend for some bizarre reason. 

Far and away better than the turd that is Borderlands 3. Yes, it's not perfect, it's relatively short, some of the characters (Pickle......GRRR!) are just plain annoying and some of the side quests are boring however overall It's far more good than bad. The laser guns are IMO excellent and the vault hunters are the best of any Borderlands game because they actually have personality. You also get more Handsome (or in this game for the most part just 'Jack') Jack in a story that whilst not amazing does a decent job of explaining who Jack is, why is is and how he got to where he is. 

Overall I highly reccomend this game along with the claptrap & doppelganger DLC. You can probably get it for like 75% off in a Steam sale and for that it's an absolute steal.

Played nearly 700 hours of BL2, got this game a while back and couldn't get nearly as invested. Decided to reinstall it recently and was surprised by how fun this game is. Overall, I would give this game a chance if you liked BL2 and want a similar experience with enough gameplay changes to warrant a new purchase.

[h1] ğŸ’» Description: [/h1]
Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a very underrated game that unfortunately got the title of the â€˜Black Sheepâ€™ in the family. Even though, the concept of space as well as the introduction of new playable characters (including  fr**cking Claptrap) was an interesting idea, that alone was not enough to satisfy the needs of the [b] hungry [/b] fanbase. According to many the game offers nothing more than the same concept and style of itâ€™s predecessor, making all the hype and wait for nothing. I beg to defer for so many reasons!

[h1] ğŸ“– Plot: [/h1]
The plot by far hands down [b] the best [/b] that the franchise has ever offered. Not only you get to know the backstory of Handsome Jack, as well as other important characters, but you also  explore the moral dilemmas and the reasons that Pandora quote: â€œAinâ€™t no place for a heroâ€. The concept of space is very appealing, there all lots of quests that make you die laughing and genuinely have an amazing time. Loot, guns, more guns, blood and original jokes, all are included and well mixed in the package, as expected from a Borderlands game.

[h1] ğŸ•¹ï¸ Gameplay: [/h1]
There are some twists here and there that make Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel unique to itâ€™s own way. A good example is the newly added gravity/O2 limitation. Even though, the art style remains the same, the introduction of the grinder, the oz kit as well as a new type of weapon and effect are the main recipes that lead to [b] fun [/b]. Like any other Borderlands  game it focuses on hard grinding and repetition, so donâ€™t be afraid to grab a friend and start the adventure.

[h1] ğŸ—ƒï¸ Side Notes: [/h1]
Borderlands the Pre-Sequel had a very bad start in the beginning. Non farmable bosses as well as many bugs made the overhyped fanbase mad, which in the end led to the gameâ€™s downfall. It  was supposed to be a completely new Borderlands experience, considering the time passed into making it, but unfortunately it could not live up to the expectations.

[h1] ğŸ“‹ Verdict: [/h1]
Overall, I really like The Pre-Sequel, the price may be little spicy, but that's not a problem for our good friend [b] steam [/b] here. I highly recommend for players not familiar with the franchise to start with [b] this [/b] game, before moving to Borderlands 2, in order to enjoy it's full potential!

Borderlands the Pre Sequel is the red headed stepchild of the Borderlands series.  The game has may innovations that set it apart from other Borderlands games.  Playing with low gravity and using oz kits provide a new level of mobility not found in any borderlands game.  The skill trees and their creative options allow for some of the most unique play styles ever found in the borderlands series.  The glitch rarity of guns can turn any weapon into an unstoppable juggernaut.  The story is probably the best of the series.  Finally the DLC Claptastic Voyage might be the best Borderlands DLC ever.  I hope you give this forgot segment of the Borderlands universe a try.

But in the end I decided no, you shouldn't. This game is no where as good as Borderlands 2 and I don't think anyone should support 2k, Gearbox, or Take-Two.
So first we have the bad map designâ€¦ Itâ€™s just not fun. Itâ€™s hard to explain why, but I can say near the start of the game it expects you to jump over death pits with a car using turbo boost. Nowâ€¦ the cars in this game suck. Their handling sucks. And multiple times I couldnâ€™t make it because right before I jumped I hit some small rock that slowed me to my death. Also the main hub area sucks because it has this top side to it that is pointless and no one uses. 
Moonstone chests are a good idea since they give the user extra buffs on their weapons, but there is no confirmation screen if you want to open them. Meaning when I first saw one I just mashed open and lost all my moonstones without knowing. 
On multiple occasions I have had sound effects and dialog break on me in story missions. One time I left a story mission and went back only to find an important door you need to open to proceed was broken because I left.
None of the bosses feel unique and you have a lot less bosses in this game than in Borderlands 2.
The whole oxygen system, and the ground pound abilities just annoying and useless. 
Lastly we have the skillsâ€¦ A lot of them donâ€™t seem that fun and none of the characters are really balancedâ€¦ Not to mention a lot of them arenâ€™t funny and lack personality when they talk during missions. A big flaw I noticed is some of the skills actually require you to be playing with another person to use. As inâ€¦ they have no buffs and are pointless to get if you play single player.

SHORT REVIEW

As a fan of Borderlands 2, it's fun. If you've never played Borderlands 2, play it first. The Pre-Sequel brings a lot of new loot, while still having the Borderlands' trademark looting style. As far as combat, the whole "space" fighting style is easy to get used to, but hard to master. Kind of like BL2. The story, however, is quite a treat for Borderlands fans, although confusing at times. Seeing Handsome Jack's past shows a completely new perspective on him, and gives his character more depth. Characters are refreshing and unique, with good overall design. They also all tie to the Borderlands world closely, which is cool. Assuming you didn't buy the Handsome Collection (you should), the character DLCs are also well designed but not 100% worth it. Other DLCs aren't the best, but with the campaign being shorter than BL2 and there being less side-quests, getting them can be quite worth it depending on how much you enjoyed the game. Buy this game when it's on sale.

Overall, 10/10 Brands on Handsome Jack's Face

I reccommend playing this before borderlands 2 just so you can understand the full grasp of the story. [h1]This is a great Borderlands game.[/h1]
But it's not going to be everyone's [i]cup of tea[/i] for a few reasons.[list]
[*] [b]Borderlands burnout[/b]â€”This game originally came out in a time when most people were [i]still[/i] playing Borderlands 2 and â€œmore of the same but slightly differentâ€ wasn't enough to grab people when they had already been saturated.
[*] [b]Triton Flats[/b]â€”This is an area right off of Concordia (the main city) that is needlessly convoluted and rife with environmental hazards that will get you insta-killed if you're not paying attention. There are also 2 very noticeable things beyond that, lack of nearby fast travel locations and a heightened sense of level scaling. Triton Flats acts as a sort of HUB area just outside of Concordia. Kind of like Fyrestone in Borderlands 1â€”so you'll be galumphing through this area repeatedly. [b]Makes the first 3-6 hours a bit of a slog.[/b]
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2198126740
[*] O2 kits are required for all air breathing characters. This isn't as bad or annoying as it seems at first. But it's something you need to manage in addition to everything else and that won't sit well with people that like exploring. However, O2 veins, canisters and any place inside an airlock you can refill your O2. It's not really an issue unless you're boosting every 2 seconds.[/list]

[h1]Pacing is all over the place.[/h1]
The game is set on Elpis, Pandora's moon. And Helios, the big space station that orbits it is bombarding the moon with a giant laser. It's heavily implied that this is destroying the moon. The intro of the game is such that Jack is no longer in control of Helios because Colonel  Zarpedon of Dahl has taken it over. So you feel some amount of urgency to stop this laser and retake Helios. But you'll find a bunch of humorous quest givers the series is known for in the meantime. Someone asking you to raise a flag while he salutes it and asks you to protect him from waves and waves of enemies for example. Making the game feel slightly disjointed. 

[h1]The story of this game is largely how Handsome Jack became a sort of 'Joker' archetype.[/h1]
The quests in this game have a loose undertone of Jack's slow decent into madness. Taking place in between the events Borderlands 1 and 2. You might have noticed Jack wears a mask and isn't the most respectable personality in BL2â€”You play as a Vault Hunter, as in any of the other games, but under Jack's employ in this.

[h1]Laser Beams, Physics and Cryostasis on Elpis.[/h1]
In Pre-Sequel, slag isn't a usable commodity yetâ€”despite being in Borderlands 2. Instead, Pre-Sequel introduces laser type weapons which can include all sorts of variables. Typically having sustained fire multiplying damage. As well as a new 'element' in being able to do cryo damage. Expectedly, you can freeze people. And they'll shatter like a Martin Finnegan art project from Bioshock. Additionally, due to being able to boost around with your O2 kit combined with the low gravity, you're able to freeze people 'mid-flight' and have them fall to the ground for extra damage. 

You can also find O2 kits with variable stat boosts dependent on whether or not you're in a vacuum. There are still class mods and shields but O2 kits behave more like relics from Borderlands 2. And [u][b]this whole game does feel like Borderlands 2 DLC.[/b][/u] I still hold Borderlands 1 higher than the rest as weapon proficiencies actually mattered in that. You'd get accuracy, damage and recoil reduction the more you used a certain gun type. Pre-Sequel borrows the BL2 model in having â€œBadassâ€ tokens earned from doing challenges. A system I don't really care for.

As mentioned, some of the game takes place on Helios itself. So you'll revisit familiar places from BL2. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2198128590

Eridium is replaced with Moonstone. The currency you use to buy the ability to hold more ammo, or backpack/bank slots. Additionally, moonstones can be used in the grinder in conjunction with weapons, shields or grenade mods.  Stuff that you'd most likely sell otherwise. Moonstones can increase the value of what comes out of the grinder. A sort of slot machine that costs items instead of money.

[i][b]THE GIST:
Pre-Sequel is understandably more polarizing than its predecessors. But I think it's more unique in what it does with the minute to minute fights. The verticality of the combat, popping helmets/air supply of enemies. It feels markedly different. And at the time of writing this, I've not played Borderlands 3 and don't know anything about it. This game feels very much like the Civilization Beyond Earth to Civilization V if you catch my drift. But it has it's own thing going on.[/b][/i]
[quote]If you've read this far, consider following my curation â€” [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/28295405/]Station Argus[/url][/quote]

There are other places in the game that are cool in theory. Nice [i]set piece[/i] moments. But in practice they very nearly become obnoxious to traverse repeatedly to complete side missions. Such as the 'Veins of Helios'.

Great game. Argueably the best borderlands game to date.

Taking place almost entirely on Pandora's moon, the Pre-Sequel adds fluctuating gravity and oxygen to the tried and true Borderlands formula. The latter works to keep players from hunkering down in one spot for fear of running out of air. The lack of atmosphere also affects fire weapons (you can't exactly catch fire without oxygen, can you?) and lasers, this game's new weapon type, adding another layer of strategic complexity to familiar situations. The low gravity part of the equation, however, was more of a miss.

Moon jumps, and the new double jump supported by spending a little precious oxygen, were never quite as satisfying as they seemed like they should be. Worse, this new mechanic encouraged adding more platforming-styled challenges to the mix which first person shooters are just not built for. Most areas are filled with bottomless holes, meaning any enemy charge could result in instant death and there will be plenty of enemy charges. Everything from bandits to torks were designed around the prevalence of low gravity, so just about every one of them wants to leap across the map and appear right behind you. It seemed like there was always someone behind me, a problem I don't remember having in the previous two games. It does make the combat more frantic and fast-paced, but at the cost of eliminating any control the player previously had over the battlefield. This is especially annoying while playing as Athena whose action skill is designed around blocking only the damage that hits the shield in front of her.

Athena is also the one that tells the game's story, a good choice as she occupies a moral middle ground in a game that isn't shy about its heroes being villains. However, using a player character's recollections to narrate the game's events means when playing as any other character the game won't quite match up with her commentary. Not that the storyline is the focus of this game or any other in the Borderlands series. And for that reason, I was surprised to find that the True Vault Hunter Mode playthrough, while not actually changing any events, did change who Athena was telling the story to, thus adding a slightly different flavor to what is usually just a retread with a more powerful character. 

Other than those handful of improvements, as double-edged as they may be, The Pre-Sequel is exactly what you've come to expect from the Borderlands series: a mad world full of zany characters, a group of Vault Hunters who are just different enough to warrant trying them all, and more guns than an American doomsday prepper has ever seen in his entire life.

Welcome to the moon, where everyone is Australian. Unoriginal jokes aside, [i]The Pre-Sequel[/i] was surprisingly good. I went in with a rather lukewarm expectation due to a lot of the hate I see for this game, but it really surpassed most of my expectations. It really is just Borderlands 2.5, but thatâ€™s not really a bad thing. The addition of low-grav jumping and ground-pounding adds verticality to the combat, which makes things even more chaotic than before. 

The story is actually pretty interesting too. I was super distracted in the beginning by the Aussie accents, but after a few hours, I grew pretty accustomed to it. After thinking on it a bit, it kind of makes sense lore-wise, since the inhabitants of the moon are on a different â€œplanetâ€ so to speak, so it would make sense for its inhabitants to speak a different language or have a different accent...or maybe it was just more cost-effective for 2K Australia to use Aussie VAs. 

I really didnâ€™t like how under-leveled our characters were without grinding through some of the side quests. Nearing the end of the game, at level 21, the next mission showed that it was [url=https://i.imgur.com/H6rSdMP.jpg]â€Impossible.â€[/url]. We did maybe 5-7 side quests and really didnâ€™t earn that much XP, so we just went ahead and did the final quest, and yeah, it was pretty fucking hard. I died countless times, but we finished it. Iâ€™m not really sure how I feel about the level design for the last mission, [url=https://borderlands.fandom.com/wiki/The_Beginning_of_the_End]â€œBeginning of the End.â€[/url] For one, it was extremely pretty, but it just felt like it kept going and going for no reason. 

This was my first playthrough of the [i]Pre-Sequel[/i], and I played as Athena. My two other friends played as the Jack Doppelganger and Claptrap. It was considerably shorter than [i]Borderlands 2[/i], but still enjoyable (except for Pickle. Fuck Pickle.) If youâ€™re okay with grinding side quests to be appropriately leveled for the main quests, and youâ€™re looking for more Borderlands 2, then this was a lot of fun to play through with friends. 

Finally, hereâ€™s my [url=https://imgur.com/a/FKZGPpU]1440p ultrawide screenshot album for Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel[/url].

[b]Disclaimer: This review was written in May 2019 and posted in August 2020.[/b]

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel (2014)

Pretty much a spin-off game, but it still got the same core gunplay mechanics like previous titles. Choose your character, team up with friends and loot and shoot your way on Elpis, Pandora's moon. Game takes place between Borderlands and Borderlands 2. Since its on a moon, you got some pretty fun gravity jump mechanics.

9/10

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a prequel to Borderlands 2 80% of the time and a sequel to Borderlands 2 20% of the time. Lillith interrogates Athena, a former Vault Hunter, after the events of Borderlands 2 as Athena relays her time as a Vault Hunter, which took place before Borderlands 2....I know it's a little complicated just pretend that the whole thing's a prequel honestly it's easier that way. Walk in the boots of four new(?) Vault Hunters, all of which are faces you've seen before: Athena the Gladiator, Wilhelm the Enforcer, Nisha the Lawbringer, and Claptrap the Fragtrap. A new vault has been discovered IN SPACE, and you've been tasked with uncovering it before the Dahl Corporation (I think?) gets there first! At the same time, you'll be working alongside some other familiar faces, including Roland, Lillith, and John, better known as Handsome Jack. Watch as John starts as a lowly Hyperion intern and ascends the corporate ladder and descends into madness, turning from friend to foe as the allure of power corrupts him.

Story-wise, it's pretty cool. It's interesting to see the origins of some famous BL2 villains, especially Handsome Jack, and the connections made between BL2 and TPS are quite interesting as you see some loose ends tied up. The involvement of aliens and the Eridian beings gets a little surreal at some points, and tbh I still don't quite understand some of their intentions and all, but it's a really cool break from all the very real, very redneck nonsense of the original BL games. 

Gameplay, it's for the most part pretty similar to BL2, but it's in SPACE. Low gravity is enabled in some environments, and in addition to a health and shield bar, you'll also have an oxygen meter. Oz kits replace relics in this game, providing unique benefits to consuming oxygen and your ground slam and jetpack moves, which you can use by consuming oxygen. Don't run out of oxygen though, or else your health will drain, unless if you're Claptrap, cause ya know, he's a robot (Claptrap also takes increased corrosive damage and reduced fire damage by default). Eridium has been replaced with Moonstone, though they function pretty much the same. Slag has not been discovered yet as a weapon element, but Cryo has been introduced, which slows and eventually freezes your enemies solid, and it's honestly my favorite element ever besides Explosive. Guns are relatively unremarkable, some neat legendaries but there's not a whole lot to comment on, it's much of the same of BL2. Laser guns however are super fucking cool and I want more of them. TPS does have significantly less raid bosses though, so if that's your thing, sorry.

The DLC for this game is pretty good in my opinion. The Claptrap story DLC is personally one of my favorite DLC's in the BL franchise, good story, good gameplay, and the new Glitch weapons are a lot of fun to use. Fair warning though, the final boss of the DLC is incredibly difficult, so get ready for them. Timothy the Doppleganger is a really fun character, and Aurelia  the Baroness seems like a really cool one as well (more about them next paragraph).

I think the characters in this game are super fun to play as. I personally have played as Claptrap, Wilhelm, and Timothy, though I've seen all of their gameplay before in videos. Claptrap is an incredibly fun spin-the-wheel type character where every fight turns into an absolute fiesta of nonsense, Wilhelm is a pretty cool take on Axton from BL2, and Timothy is a lot of fun with cool clones while also "playing" as Handsome Jack. Athena can be an elemental goddess or a melee warrior with destructive power, seems pretty fun. Nisha is a high caliber outlaw with damage levels nearing Salvador's from BL2. Aurelia is from what I understand an elemental sniper or a kinda gimmicky co-op mechanic, with another skill tree specifically dedicated to turning a co-op partner into your "bitch". All of the characters have some pretty cool skills, and I think Claptrap and Timothy have some of the coolest and most unique skill trees of the Borderlands series.

A TL;DR and some PROS/CONS-
PROS:
-Some of the same fun gameplay of BL2
-SPACE AND MOONS AND STUFF
-New cryo element is awesome
-Very fun characters to play as
-One of the better BL games to play with co-op partners
-LASER GUNS
CONS:
-Not a whole lot of "new stuff" introduced
-Story is kinda eh
-The game is often very geared towards co-op players, with dialogue addressing multiple people and entire skills and skill trees dedicated to co-op play
-Few raid bosses
-Relatively tame legendaries

TL;DR I think it's a pretty good time. It's definitely not the BL game you'll sink the most time into, but if you're looking for something just a little different to spice things up every now and then, go ahead and pick it up for $25 or less. 7.5/10

EDIT: One thing I forgot to mention, this game was produced by 2K Australia, meaning a SIGNIFICANT portion of the new voice acting is from people with heavy Australian or similar accents. This can be a CON as for some people the heavy redneck Australian accents can become very annoying after several hours of play. Nothing against Australians or anything, but the voice acting is a little grating.

It's honestly not that bad

This is such a huge disappointment after playing the first two games.

Ok, ok to be honest its not all bad. The Pre sequel is a flashback tale told by the Athena the gladiator, (not to be confused with captain americas apprentice) and the action takes place predominantly on Pandora's moon, Elpis. Here, Jack unites the vault hunters - Athena the (Marvel didnt copyright shield tossing) gladiator, Wilhelm the (im addicted to body mods, and drone spawning) enforcer, Nisha the (I have 2 pistols!) gunslinger, and Fragtrap the (Bask in the warmth of my humorous references!) Claptrap unit. The main filling of this fps rpg omfg shooter is the storyline of the Lost Legion (crazy dahl military rogues) from destroying  the moon, and witness Jack become more and more sadistic and psychotic.

As you might expect, the story is packed with humor, although most of it was weak, with Jack and claptrap once again providing the majority of the laughs, even with his more sympathetic characterization, and his gradual acceptance of a more sadistic way of doing things is amusing - and somewhat disturbing - to witness. The rest of the characters do eventually become relatable, and you start to see how the story of borderlands 2 developed, but this is lost in what was a poor attempt at adding to the borderlands universe.

The technical issues of this game were abhorrent, painful and game breaking, to the point I had to use multiple strategies to fix.
From early on in the game there are visual glitches, ridiculous amounts of clipping and pathcollision problems (both I and NPCsMobs getting stuck, etc). The framerate stuttered at times, connection problems were frequent (even on a local network), the ping was uncomfortably high most of the time and the lag was insulting. Not what I would expect from a title in an established franchise. 

Then there's the 'in your face' sexuality. The seemingly arbitrary homosexual references really pissed me off. For example, Janey Springs is a lesbian, so is Baroness Hammerlock (Sir Hammerlocks sister), and this sexual acceptance was alluded to more than once, like a lot, like they were trying too hard to make it known, like staging lgbt pride outside of Westboro Baptist Church. Sir Hammerlock is also referred to as gay. I get that 2K and gearbox are pro LGBT and I also get that the developers are Australian. But this adds nothing of comedy value to the game, unlike what was achieved within Borderlands 2. Not that I have anything against LGBT people, but I find it very insulting that the writers had to shoehorn another gay character in there and wave it in my face. I mean, Springs, which I think was one of the few more charming characters, had several dialogue sequences in which the main subject being that she was a lesbian. Great, you're a woman that likes other women. So what? I couldn't care less. If a character's defining trait is their sexual orientation, then you're a horrible writer. 

OMG the humour was dry, bland, and it felt like it was written by Australians, for Australians. Clearly 2K Australia was screaming for attention with this creation. Elpis is sparsely populated with npcs packing the Australian accent. There's all sorts of Aussie humor from O2 kits refferred to as Oz kits and billabongs to jumbucks. While I miss the usual soundbites, the changes are entertaining in their own right, and help give Elpis its own flavor, trouble is theres too much of the australian flavour. This can be seen as hypocritical, given in the in your face sexualisation of the game. That said, the coincidental fact that characters from previous games all happened to be on the moon at the exact same time - including unlikely folks such as Moxxi and Crazy Earl, it all feels a little bit like a safety net for the developers.

Ill admit that the low gravity mechanic feels like a breath of fresh air its also particularly well implemented. This makes the terrain being much more explorable, and you'll have to inspect every roof of every building to make sure you haven't missed a chest somewhere. Its combat use is very limited. You can do a ground slam but it seems a bit dated after the 50th use. Of course being on the moon means you need oxygen to breathe. The O2 kit implentation is an intriguing mechanic which does emphasis what a player does with there time, and is restrictive of where a player can go. In the time ive spent on the game its a restrictive but quirky mechanic which doesnt offer strong influence on the gameplay. 

The shift code machine in concordia is an interesting change for inputting your shift codes for the highly coveted golden keys, if it actually worked, because it doesnt always work. My advice use the main menu for the shift code entry and not the concordia machine.

The button for 'inspecting' another player is an interesting mechanic for players to show off there loadout, but its a token gesture on this game. Theres no need or requirement of it, it was clearly implented to give the impression of 'innovation' which this game is lacking.

The level design in the 'nudge-nudge wink-wink open world' maps renders the vehicles often useless. In fact, the game forces you to use the low gravityand jumping excessively in areas that could have allowed vehicles. You spend most of your time running and backtracking. Combat is not satisfying enough compared with the critical strike points of enemies in Borderlands 2 and with the world space feeling smaller and more isolated than Borderlands 2, it rapidly 
becomes incredibly repetitive.

The game just doesn't seem to be as funny or as enjoyable as Borderlands 2, and I think I understand why. 

This does not feel like a full game, it feels more like a DLC trying to be a game.

Now I understand that developers are trying to make money. However, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a blatant squeeze for money in a brazenly insipid way. Itâ€™s a paint-by-numbers effort, almost from top to bottom. And thats the sad part, because this game actually introduced new mechanics pushing towards a far greater game, but resulted in wasted potential.

Although I do recommend buying this game, I strongly recommend you buy it when its on sale for less than Â£15 (including all dlc, skins and extras).

To be honest i love this game, i have a lot of fun playing it and when it picks up/comes up i love the story. 
That being said i do have problems with the game, mainly three: 
1. The game doesn't do too much that's new, both with story and gameplay, though this seems to be problem since Borderlands 2 with the shooter games. (Also it's not like the story or gameplay are bad, just not too new)
2. The story use a bit of work, it's clear they tried to have a storyline like the 2nd game which isn't too bad it just makes some storylines and characters feel too close to just being remixs of the 2's story, that said i still love the story & characters
3. Lack of DLC, this is my biggest problem with the game mainly because this game has some of the best of the DLC in all of Borderlands, both the added hunters and story DLC are really some of the best of the best and it's sad there isn't more for the game, though i understand why story DLC would've been hard to add it still would've really nice to see more for this game.
Really great game play and immersive story line

It's a good game, but not as fun as Borderlands 2. Some of the characters can be quite annoying, and some of the areas are just too big, which can result in travel being quite boring and tedious. The sidequests also suffer from the large maps, especially since a good amount of them are fetch quests. The main characters carry the game however, especially Handsome Jack (obviously). 

Every single playable character is very unique and fun to play with. The guns are as fun and even more unique due to the inclusion of both the amazing cryo element, as well as the laser weapons.

Regarding the Claptastic Voyage, the entire DLC is fun up until the final boss and ending, due to the final boss being a MASSIVE BULLET SPONGE, where you're easily going to run out of ammo during the fight.

Play this only if you REALLY enjoy Borderlands, otherwise it's fine to skip this. The only really important part here is the story, as it provides a great origin story for Jack's descent into madness and rise to the top of the Hyperion corporation, among other things.

Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a fun game that learned well from its predecessors. The story is fairly engaging (exploring the origin of Handsome Jack was pretty cool), the guns and gameplay were solid with new additions like low gravity, and the visuals were on par with the series.

This is a game you want to play with friends, be it couch-side or online, as it adds a much more enjoyable element to the game. The dialogue and references are still witty, sarcastic, and down-right absurd in just the right places. Normally when a secondary studio (no insult to 2K Australia) takes over an IP, it doesn't do very well. However they seemed to nail just about everything with BLTPS, including an appropriately themed and well executed score.

The only problem my friend and I had with the game is that we went through most of the game without finding much loot better than our own. We traded out items and guns maybe 3 or four times at the most. That's a terribly low amount considering the game prides itself on its loot system and variety and weaponry. It was disappointing to go through the game with hardly any upgrades than from those we got back at level 11 (we ended around level 29).

Overall BLTPS was a fun and solid game with great characters, story, and gunplay, but seemingly broken loot system and bug encounters took away a good portion of the enjoyability of the game.
a pretty decent entry in the series

The gameplay is pretty solid, but the storyline is where it really is at. Quite the twist on things, and helps develop a strange appreciation for the environment of both Elpis and Pandora at the end of things.

I am not sure if I will leave a positive or negative review yet.

First, this is a typical Borderlands game. It has the unique and awesome Borderlands comic book style; the graphics are beautiful, and the skill tree is great. Nevertheless, the story is worse than the one in Borderlands 2. Well, the whole game is worse than Borderlands 2 to be honest. 

But letâ€™s take a closer look at it as a standalone title: The controls are fluid, the graphics are nice, the story is solid, and the difficulty is the typical Borderlands difficulty. Unfortunately, this made me really mad. I normally love that the enemies get harder and harder the weaker you are (in terms of level). But the end boss fights in Borderlands: The Presequel were absolutely horrible. 

Let me explain: I have been playing the whole game with a friend of mine. We finished the game in 13 hours (main story and some side quests) even though apparently most people finish the main mission in 18 hours.  The logical consequence was, that our level was way lower than recommended. And I totally get that. I knew that the bosses would be hard, but as a good gamer, I knew that I (/we) could do it. So there we were, both level 24 in front of the first big boss (I wonâ€™t explain this any further, because I donâ€™t want to spoiler you). The issue was, that my mate couldnâ€™t deal any damage. No matter what weapon he used. I donâ€™t know if he is just too bad or what the problem was, but I had to fight the end bosses alone. ALL of them. And as you may know, if you played Borderlands, the more you are in a lobby, the harder the enemies get. The boss was therefore twice as strong, but I was alone to fight him (and I was already way too low â€“ concerning my level). Just a short explanation: You will have to fight the bossâ€¦ letâ€™s say: various timesâ€¦ Many times. 

I somehow was able to finish all the bosses in my first run, but I kept dying and it took me 1 hour to beat all of them. This was just not fun. I know, you could blame me for being lvl 24 in a boss fight and for having a mate that wasnâ€™t able to help, but why the fuck do you need that many bosses? Thatâ€™s just annoying and not fun anymore.

So, this part really got on my nerves and felt like the worst decision the developers could have taken. In addition, it was very repetitive and the final boss fights were much worse than that epic Borderlands 2 boss fight, that you will never forget.

Other than that, the game was pretty awesome, like the other Borderlands games. Itâ€™s just the end that killed it for meâ€¦ But that doesnâ€™t make the whole game a bad game.

I am curious to play Borderlands 3, as many people criticise it.

If you are new to the Borderlands series, I definitely recommend you playing Borderlands 2. Itâ€™s the best one in my decent opinion.

I enjoyed that I got to play more Borderlands after playing numbers 1 and 2.  The quirky Aussie humour helped as well, and the low gravity game play added the novelty needed.  My one complaint is that there weren't as many Legendarys as I would have liked.

Short version:

Pros:
+ Handsome Jack is still great (voice acting + character arc)
+ Fun to see characters before they turn evil
+ Manages to be funny, sometimes
+ Fun with friends
+ Strong art direction (specially the gorgeous skyboxes)
(+ Mostly everything you liked about Borderlands 2 is still here)

Cons:
- Empty, boring maps
- Uninspired, repetitive quests (specially the side quests)
- Feels like DLC for Borderlands 2
- Barely any new gameplay features (the new implementations also feel gimmicky)
- Some inconsistent writing and characters
(- Most of Borderlands 2â€™s problems are still here, some even got worse)

"Long" version:
Shortly after [u]Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel[/u]â€™s release it went on a 90-something % sale on Steam. It was clearly a mistake, but I managed to secure my purchase. I got it for 4â‚¬.  That being said, I will still review it having the original price in mind.

[u]Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel[/u] is brought to us by 2K and it is a prequel to the events of [u]Borderlands 2[/u]. You can choose between 4 playable characters (6 if you have the DLC) - which were all bosses or NPCs from the previous game - and you will follow Handsome Jackâ€™s descent into madness and villainyâ€¦ IN SPACE! [spoiler]â€”Featuring glorious 3D stereophonic sound and 3D color by technicolor! â€” [/spoiler]

The story in this game is serviceable, as Handsome Jack is a compelling character with enough nuance to carry most of it; however, some of the writing is inconsistent; the story seems unfocused at times and some of the characters are poorly written and downright annoying. Having Claptrap as a side character gives you a good dose of wackiness sprinkled throughout the story but having him as a main character proved super obnoxious for me. Some of the other playable characters also lack personality and end up forgettable. I used Athena during my first playthrough and she started off as a wet blanket but got some mild character development later on, not enough to be considered redeemable though. 
While the game can have humor that works, sometimes, a lot of the jokes do not land (I would say 60% of them are just the easiest, laziest kind of jokes).
The side quests are repetitive and make you backtrack plenty of times around the empty, lifeless maps looking for items or enemies and they got boring, really fast.

[u]Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel[/u]â€™s gameplay is just like its predecessorâ€™s. It is chaotic, action-packed andâ€¦ Not very deep. While the game retains most of the good aspects of the seriesâ€™ second entry, it also features all of its flaws, some of which have been aggravated.

Each character has a special ability on a cooldown and also gets one Skill Point every time they level up and said points can be spent on three different skill trees that focus on different areas, such as survival, cooldowns or damage over time. It is just like the ones present in [u]Borderlands 2[/u].
The shooting is satisfying but the enemies feel as bullet-spongy as ever. There is no actual strategy to the combat, you spam bullets until your enemies drop, in case you get downed, you have the second-wind mechanic that allows you to get back up on your own if you score a kill before you die. Thing is, this mechanic is lame â€“ some enemies deal absurd amounts of damage and then randomly hide behind walls so there is nothing you can do. Multiplayer alleviates this somewhat, but it is still a poor excuse to mask unbalanced gameplay.
The developers introduced a new movement mechanic in [u]Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel[/u] â€“ now you can sort of boost yourself forward with your oxygen tank. This introduction feels like a gimmick. Sure, you can cover greater distances, but maps are also bigger in return; it feels good at first, as it is different from the very grounded movement of the second installment, but it gets tedious after a while. It seems as you are just slowly floating towards the objectives at a snailâ€™s pace.
That oxygen tank I mentioned before also allows you to breathe outsideâ€¦ IN SPACE! Again, a gimmick; it is super annoying when its capacity is low at first and you have to run from breathable area to breathable area and it becomes an obsolete mechanic you do not have to worry about after the first 30 minutes or so. It does allow you to do a ground-pound that sends enemies flying â€“ that was cool, but not that innovative.

Driving is a welcome inclusion to traverse longer distances, but the controls are not that great. There are two vehicle types â€“ a more durable tank-like unit and a sort of hover-bike that is overall faster but weaker.

The game looks good â€“ really good, sometimes. The moon setting allowed the developers to vary the color pallet way more â€“ however, this praise is geared mostly towards the skyboxes, that feature beautiful colors. Everything else, specially the interior areas gave me the â€œbeen there, done thatâ€ feeling. The enemy design is strong, but they are just slight variations of the creatures that you fought in Pandora.

The soundtrack is fine and voice actors are OK for the most part. Most of them are certainly charismatic. I have grown a bit tired of the constant over-the-top characters of Borderlands and having random characters shout utter non-sense in an attempt at comedy did not really work for me â€“ it might, for other, though.

I managed to get around 90 hoursâ€™ worth of content and, considering how much I paid for it, it is certainly worth playing; however, this still feels like DLC, not a full-fledged game that stands on its own. The DLC is also uninspired and feels bland and rehashed from the other two games.

Even though I do not â€œhateâ€ [u]Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel[/u] I only kept playing it because I did so with friends, but they soon grew tired of it and I ended up playing quite a large chunk of it by myself. What started out as a decent-enough experience with friends that unfortunately felt too familiar, ended up being really boring and generic by the end of my playthroughs.
Certainly recommended on a sale and if you have friends to play it with, but I am not sure how to feel about 2K releasing a game that is a downgrade from the previous installment in terms of story and innovation and charging full price for it and its DLC. Maybe that is why it leaves a bad taste in my mouth.

Final score: 6 out of 10.

If you enjoyed this review, please consider joining my [url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/goodguynickreviews]group[/url] and following my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7792954-GGN-Reviews/]curator page[/url] on Steam.

yes

Borderlands game with good ideas, executed poorly. Oz cans are a unique way to make the game have  greater mobility, but they lose their punch when you rarely ever need to worry about the oxygen itself, and they end up functioning like relics anyway. The characters on paper all sound more interesting than the ones in previous games, but in practice all characters just have a "kill-all" ability that doesn't really diversify the characters from eachother enough to motivate multiple playthroughs. The level design took the greatest hit from everything carried over from BL2. Where in BL2 you would see gorgeous vistas with varied combat arenas, TPS has two variations of the moon surface, for the entire game. The story is another massive flop. BL2 while having a flawed narrative, still told a uniquely compelling story through it's mistakes, but TPS takes the mistakes too far. The entire plot is contrived as hell, the "plot-twist" if you can even call it that, that supposedly turned Jack into who he was in BL2 was contrived to hell and back. It makes established characters seem worse than they actually were, mainly Moxxi and Wilhelm.
The DLCs aren't exactly mind-boggling either. The claptastic voyage is pretty interesting on a first playthrough and incredibly frustratingly long on any repeat ones. The Shockdrop thunderdome is just a repeat of Moxxi's thunderdome from 1 with all of the character removed, and all of the mistakes of that DLC carried over directly. there is no true "End Game" state, like with BL2's OP8 and BL3's Mayhem 10, which makes legendaries incredibly pointless too often. The new Cryo element while interesting on it's own, isn't enough to replace the now gone Slag, which made combat in 2 very unique in its own right. Also, TPS has a tiny pool of new Legendaries, mainly Cryo weapons and Oz kits, with about 80% of it's legendary pool being a repeat of 2's. Overall, very underwhelming at best, really miserable at worst. The game fails to make itself unique in the BL series, that has, for the most part, been able to have each entry stand on it's own two legs despite any flaws each had. BL1 had it's bleak atmosphere and darker tone, BL2 had it's story and incredibly deep and challenging End Game content, and BL3 has it's incredibly fun, fast-paced vertical gameplay. TPS has nothing. Play only if you're a diehard fan of the BL series, or if you are Australian.

Borderlands has one rule, be fun, but this manages to have a host of unbalanced and annoying game play issues that make it obvious why no one talks about it in terms of the series as a whole. Revisiting Boderlands: The Pre-Sequel in 2020, I found an enjoyment that I missed back at the game's release. The combat, leveling, and weapons were an improvement from the previous game. I found myself really enjoying the verticality of maps such as Pity's Fall and Veins of Helios. I also got around to playing as Aurelia and going through the Claptrap dlc, which gearbox did a great job of designing.

I was not a big fan of most of the new characters added to this game. They were not memorable, unless I think of how annoying some of them are. However, the development of some returning Borderlands characters that is told through the gap between Borderlands 1 and 2 was written well. Playing along with Handsome Jack makes the game so much better.

For anyone who hasn't picked up the games in the Handsome Collection, I highly recommend getting them. These games are original and very replayable.

I often switch between loving and hating this game due to its repetitive, yet somehow consistently original nature. It's worth the price and your time, but be prepared for plenty of pointless fetch-quests.

Very glitchy, big thrown off for me was when your character is always glitching in obstacles and you end up dying because of it. Questing aren't as fun. So for casual players or new players to the franchise i would probably stick to the mainstream ones as i mentioned earlier. Your chance of enjoying it is higher.

[Update] For the initial impressions, read below. One MAJOR flaw that makes this game far worse than the other Borderlands games is the extreme focus on killing tons and tons of really lame "trash" enemies over and over again because you have to visit the same locations multiple times. The other Borderlands games had their fair share of this, but in those cases it was fine because you could always finish your visit with killing the area's boss for a chance to get some sweet loot. NO SUCH THING in BL - TPS. Except for the last boss, no boss in the entire game respawn. Your main sources of high end gear are the Golden Loot Chest and a machine that lets you recycle gear for a chance to maybe get something better.

[Initial impressions] If you enjoyed Borderlands 2, you won't be disappointed. The game has a few tweaks compared to its predecessor. Firstly, the dialogue is more two-way than earlier and that makes the characters seem more alive and it really contributes to the story. Secondly, moonstones (similar to eridium in BL2) is always usefull, even after you've bought every inventory upgrade from Crazy "Whatyawant?" Earl.

Those are the main pros so far, but there are cons as well. The game is slightly buggy even a few months after release. I've seen quite a few enemies get stuck in terrain or worse, glitch through the floor, including a boss, which made the fight unfinishable. This, luckily, is a rare occurrence though.

Borderlands the Pre Sequal Is such an iconic masterpiece in recent video game history, and has stacked itself so well against other major fps titles. Ever since the release of the first Borderlands game, BL:PS has gotten so much better (obviously) while sticking true to its roots, which is a rarity in a game franchise lasting for so long. The replayability, the story, the animation, and the art style all makes it feel so realistically cartoonish which makes it feel truly like its own expirence. I owned this on Xbox 360 since launch day back in 2014, and the amount of love and affection 2K put into this modern masterpiece is truly astonishing. The only complaint I have about this game is that the majority of the DLC was a cash grab and nothing more. It was all recycled missions, predictable plots and overall not interesting. However, the best dlc was the Claptastic Voyage because it was all poking fun at claptrap and his phycopathic mind. It was funny and original, and if I remember correctly, it even touched on some darker topics(which may not seem dark as an adult, but playing this through my teen years really struck home with hard topics such as abandanment and such). In total, this game and the entire series was a master piece and it is 100% worth every penny.

Looking forward to B3 ^^

Iâ€™ve finished it some years ago, i did it through steam family share and i didnâ€™t have anyone to play with, so i didnâ€™t care for achievements and just completed it and the DLC once. I ended up buying it and recently i convinced my dawg to play it while we wait for the next Borderlands 3 DLC and are in the mood. So i opened it and after the merge to Shift it lost a lot of my progress. I was before the eye of Helios, instead of on the TVHM after finishing the DLC.

With all the usual Borderlands stupidity, here thereâ€™s always a grain of sincerity across the whole writing. As if the mining mission of Borderlands 2 was a template for the whole game. This is the only Borderlands story which meets the minimal requirements to be called one. The devs chose to do Jackâ€™s prequel in the edgy dindunuffin key. Basically Joker (2019).

Gameplay-wise Borderlands 2 is a direct minor upgrade on everything, and this total conversion add-on is a next step on the road to be actually playable. While the gun-play is not as terrible as in the first game, itâ€™s still not okay. Plying the third and the remaster of the first game at the same time as this one made it really clear, that shooting is still pretty bad (as if it wasnâ€™t obvious from the start). Refreshing my memory on Pre-Sequel showed me just how many mechanics from here were carried over to the next game. Also it confirmed that Pre-Sequel has the best movement system out of them all. Ledge-grabs and stupid sliding has nothing on variable gravity and jump boosters. On top of being already cool, boosters use your oxygen to work, so thereâ€™s also resource management layer to it. Ground slams in the third game are useless without the booster, and here they are pretty useful and easy to execute. The levels are filled with jump-pads. Last time i saw these it probably was Quake 3. Stingray is still the best vehicle, but at least all transport got a hover upgrade in the B3. Strafing introduced with Sandskiff has remedied the terrible vehicular controls, and in this game itâ€™s not limited to just one DLC.
Pre-sequel even has its horadric cube â€” you can grind your weapons together to up their quality, get the desired type, or even get luneshine bonuses if you spend shmeridium.
With half of the game taking place in the outer space your artefact slot is taken by an oxygen-device, and those come with an impressive range of different bonuses. They can even be similar to The Bee â€” pure increase to gun damage.
One new weapon type is lasers, and they are really cool: you have sniping railguns, shotgun splitters, automatic blasters and close-range beams. They are always elemental, and due to the low oxygen fire-type weapons became much more involved. Another thing B3 takes from here is the cold element. Itâ€™s not very effective at anything, but it slows the enemies (or you) and can even freeze your target before itâ€™s out of HP. Then you can shoot or smash it. Flyers get fall damage, and the cold beautifully synergizes with PhysX making this old game look amazing.

I donâ€™t remember how it went last time, but now on Win10 the game randomly crashes from time to time. Not as often to be really bad, but often enough to be irritating.

Pre-Sequel has a lot of above-average achievements, something beyond just grinding the levels and progressing through the story. But sometimes they are too involved. Coercing one person to help you get Claptrapâ€™s RNG achievement is one thing. But assembling four people for one side-quest is another. Itâ€™s sounds cute on paper, but with â€œone challenge in one handsâ€ rule during the co-op and missable triggers itâ€™s really unnerving. Assembling four people for a mission in the middle of the game is the biggest challenge. Even if you try hitting Steam-forums filled with other people trying to do it, chances of actually hooking up together are really slim.

Great game taking BL2 and improving on it in almost every way. The skill trees are more synergetic, the movement is really good with double jump/low gravity, there are no "broken into oblivion character", Cryo replacing Slag makes it less of an absolute need and more of a boost to weaker elements (explosive/melee), etc.

If it wasn't for the small amount of content (the studio making it got terminated) we'd have a superior game. Sadly, the main story is shorter than BL2, less engaging and there is only one DLC (but it is on the same level as Tiny Tina's from the previous game). This does expand and explains a lot about the BL2 story so if you are into that it's definitely a must play once at the very least.

Overall a great game that's almost better than it's predecessor.
If you like sci-fi fps games and Dark humour this game is the one for you.

I love Borderlands and decided to complete this game before starting Borderlands 3. Big mistake. If you are like me and are picking the game up to complete the deck, just turn back now. 

The new aspects to this game like story, mechanics, and quests bring all the worst Borderlands components and adds a few poorly implemented, bad ideas. For its sake, the story tries. Jack isn't a bad character and some of the conflicts aren't half bad, but the story isn't a highlight either which isn't a shock. 

The quests and missions are tedious. Go here, shoot this thing, go back the way you came, shoot the same thing again. Real boring. The anti grav means any contact sends you flying through the air, and contact is impossible to avoid as every single AI charges straight at you. One of the most frustrating features is the amount of shaky cam and digital vomit spewed across the screen. It's not pretty, even on high settings, and just takes away from being present and enjoying the game. 

The monotony and grind of cookie cutter, rinse and repeat quests meant I completed the game as quickly as possible just to say I did. I stopped completing side quests halfway through. Even the loot at the end wasn't that great. Old Borderlands games managed to make gameplay exciting with interesting loot and guns that behaved and felt different. Not the case here. I hope Borderlands 3 is a welcome return to the old rather than a continuance of this regrettable experience.

If your class isn't random Cla4ptrap you're a chicken shit ass bitch.

I love this game, despite how much it hates me. This game is worth playing alone for the attention to detail they provide to each character, giving you the sense that your stake in the story matters and connecting you with your character in a really solid way. The real issue comes with gameplay, specifically at the halfway point of the game. Fighting becomes tedious, with enemies becoming sponges and soaking up ludicrous levels of damage. I found myself sneaking around fights because I dreaded having to fight certain enemies. For the second-half and DLC play through with friends. 

Storywise, the game is decent, although I think Handsome Jack could have been handled better. If your familiar with borderlands """comedy""" then you'll know it is either hit, hard miss, harder miss, or painful. A lot of the humor in the game falls into those latter categories. Take that as you will.

Overall, I recommend the game. Even with all this and some truly uninspired skill trees, the attention to character and getting to jetpack around made this game worth it.

The whole Borderlands franchise is my very favorite of the loot-shooters.  As with Borderlands, the Pre-Sequel has great leveling and looting.  I love the smooth gameplay and the tongue-in-cheek humor.  And I appreciate that the developers make an effort for macOS support.  Well done.  One thing for this particular iteration -- there's a lot of emphasis on "being in space" so often the physics is a bit off for folks with 100s of hours in on other Borderlands games.  Quite a bit of "hey I can jump high" and "wow, I'm running out of oxygen".  Some folks might be put off by these changes; not me.
Borderlands is great and I recommend these games to anyone.

TIP: 
In a case where you can't connect w/ friends, try the following:
1. On Steam, click on "Friends & Chat" and set your Profile to "Offline"
2. Launch the game.
3. When you are in the Main Menu of the game, open your Steam Overlay (default key comb is Shift+Tab)
4. There click on "View all friend" and set your Profile to "Online"
5. Exit the Steam Overlay
6. Click "N" and set your profile (either "Friend Invitation Only" or "Online Public")
7. Enjoy :D

Thought the game was very good and in line with the others in the franchise. My one complaint is that it doesn't feel like they did very extensive bug testing. I had quite a few issues with invisible walls/ceilings, getting stuck and having to restart the game, interrupted dialogue, etc. Overall fun game, though.

While not as good at BL2, this games still enjoyable. Story is a bit weak, but the basic game loop is still strong. the lack of an atmosphere and lower gravity is a double edged sword. On one hand, it adds things like super high jumping, oz kit enhanced jump boosts and slamming abilities, all of which are cool and a good addition to the game imo, but also adds very slow falling, which can be annoying even with the option to quickly fall. Fire elemental is also heavily nerfed. enemies wont be lit on fire unless they're in a breathable atmosphere, which is a lot more rare in this game than the previous ones. Ice, the new element, is a bit op, dealing slight constant dmg, bonus melee dmg, and freezing them in place so they can't attack or run. The elements are a bit uneven, but other than that id say the games moderately well planned out. Not perfect, but still a fun game to play through if you don't focus too hard on the story.
Still better than Borderlands 3.

Borderlands The Pre Sequel is considered the black sheep of the franchise - so named because it takes place between Borderlands 1 and 2 for the most part, but as a story that is told in flashback by one of the playable characters in the game. 

It's a bizarre game on many levels. It never quite figures out whether it wanted to be a DLC, a true sequel, a standalone expansion pack - and its kind of sat between them all. The new Vault Hunters are for the most part, people you will have already seen (and killed in the case of two of them, ironically) in Borderlands 2.

That's odd, because it sums up its major issues. It kind of feels like its trying to fix B2's problems while not replacing it - as it takes place on Pandora's moon, there are plenty of new mechanics like limited oxygen, low gravity, lasers, new opponents... but a lot of these can get a bit old fast, and the new jumping mechanics are really cool until you realise they highlight the crappy physics B2 had.

Storyline-wise though, its fascinating. Charting Handsome Jack's rise to power, it gives an interesting backstory to B2's main villain.

Since it doesn't deviate too much from B2, and expands the universe's storyline, it should suit you if you're a fan of B2. It *isn't* as good as B2 though. Keep that in mind, and you should enjoy it.

Did you like Borderlands 2? This game is essentially the same game except with much worse playable characters. The UI is essentially the same as BL2, this is just another "story" and a pretty bad one at that.  

The main change is an O2 meter and corresponding item that allow you to breathe in space.  This isn't a terrible idea, but this forced mechanic has almost no bearing on the gameplay at all.  When you run out of oxygen you don't die you just kind of VERY slowly suffocate.

The biggest problem with this game is the level design.  Whoever designed these levels really wanted to make a platforming game where you die when you fall constantly.  Falldeaths will be FREQUENT as you play this game as it isn't always clear which parts of the level are safe.  Combine that with the abysmal tiny "map" part of the UI and you get needless frustration.

Just play Borderlands 2, it's the same game with better playable characters and a better story.

Diablo with guns; a loot based shooter ARPG. The third entry into the Borderlands series, the story takes place between the first and second games. Gameplay is similar to the other Borderlands games; I believe it originally started off as an expansion to Borderlands 2 before becoming it's own game.

There's a lot to like about the Pre-Sequel through. The game has much better mechanics than the first two games. Vault Hunters have their own personalities which makes new runs more interesting and I personally found them better balanced and interesting than earlier entries. UVHM was intended from the start and is better implemented. Slag has been replaced with cryo - this element allows you to freeze enemies and is great for dealing with badasses and the like. Addition of double jumping, low gravity and butt slams to the franchise and the new laser weapon type. Has a terrific story driven DLC.

On the negative side, there's a LOT less content than B2. There's a bit of a general lack of side quests at times compared to previous games. A few areas where difficulty jumps really quickly, TVHM scales up really fast for example. Not to mention that while the game got a great DLC in Claptastic Voyage, it's the only one it got as Holodome is just a big arena. So there's a lack of end game stuff. Getting to max level in UVHM can be really grindy. Other DLC is for new character (both Doppleganger and Aurelia are great through)

One other thing, the game was made by an Australian studio. So it contains Australian voice actors. And Australian references. And Australian humour. YMMV about this.

[h1][b]Bad Code + Rushed = A Pain In My @ss !!! [/b][/h1]

Ok lets get this out of the way first ! This is the worst one in the series . You can tell it was rushed and coded badly and Windows 10 has given it some minor issues as well as Steams API change . Main thing is the gun play ! You aim right on someone no matter the type of gun or how far or close you are from the target and the shot goes way to the left or the right. Also enemies can shoot through objects and hit you but you cant hit them....so makes fighting large groups a pain in the @ss . 

I'm a huge fan of this series but this one was a major let down for me , big time coming off of playing Borderlands 2 witch i think is the best one to date for many reasons. If any game needs a redux its this one 100% and not just a gfx HD update lol Also it seems the AI never miss as if all rounds from them find there target 100% ! I sure hope Gearbox does better with Borderlands 3 then this pile of bad code. This one just doesn't have the same feel as 1 or 2 for some reason. 

I wanted to put maybe but i voted NO being Only buy if you are a fan of the series or want the full collection ! Stick with Borderlands 1 GOTY Enhanced and Borderlands 2 GOTY ! And lets hope the best for Borderlands 3 :)

[h1][b]**Update 5/18/2020**[/b][/h1] Ok as I was stating in the review up top the game was stuttering all over. So I decided to try and google more and I came across this one saying if you open your network devices and if you have more then one ethernet adapter on your motherboard or installed in your system just select both and bridge the connections. So I tried this and it didn't work being for some reason the bridge would not connect to the internet. 

So I just selected the adapter that I was not using and right clicked it and disabled it fully. Then I went into the game and set it up gfx and rez and all that stuff and then I opened Nvidia setting and just mirrored the settings I selected for the game and saved. Now when I run it its Smooth and no Stutter or Lag at all ! I'm also running it at 1080p 144hz , Capped at 120 on Ultra and all else on and even with PhysX on Ultra the game runs smooth and no stutter now. So my review will remain till i can play it more then it might change but this game isn't as good as 1 , 2 and now 3. So we will see lol

 I think the lag or stutter is the game checking the connection for players or active connections and being one is being used and the other is not the game doesn't see that and keeps checking it causing the game to stutter. Anyway hope this helps !

[h1][b]** UPDATE Kind Of 6/14/2020 ** [/b][/h1]

Well something odd I was messing with . When Epic Games gave away the Handsome Collection I decided to install it from Epic and see if anything was different . For some Reason the Epic Version ,which I have no clue is different then the Steam version package or installer wise seems to play better. When I started to play it I could see right off the bat there was no stutter anymore at all . Also the frame rates are higher and smoother then the Steam version. Only time the games frames drop is having PhysX very high and lots of stuff going on screen at once. 

Truth even though I still think this is the worst one in the franchise I am enjoying it more with out all the stutters and low frame rates . So something to look into and check for yourself and see if you get the same results I am . Also should note the Steam version I had to Tweak INI setting and run and admin and all that crazy stuff to get it to run OK  to play . With the Epic one I just installed and played . No tweaking or editing a thing.

While Pre-Sequel has extreme downsides-- i.e. lack of dedicated drops, it's Borderlands 2 with different characters-- it's just that, BL2 with different characters. And content.

TPS is worth picking up for the story. If you enjoyed BL2's play style, Pre-Sequel is literally the same thing. Pre-Sequel also has one of the best DLCs in Borderlands history, The Claptastic Voyage. Some people prefer TCV over the Tiny Tina DLC!

I've recently played through the original trilogy as, I assume, most other people have since the huge sale they had prior to the release of BL3.

I admit that I am a casual BL player - I've been playing since launch, but have never really bothered to play past middle difficulty and while I do enjoy the BL2 engine - it is pretty dated at this point.

Of the three, I think this one actually has the best story both in terms of main-thread, but it also has some pretty well-done side quests.  That said, it has some of the most boring loot (which is saying a lot for Borderlands),   Scaling works in such a way that weapons just drop off effectiveness too quickly to actually feel important.  It's not as bad as BL2, but still pretty short lived.

There's nothing surprising in this game either good or bad - it is Borderlands, only this time your character has a voice.

fun shooter with some annoying features. weapons are mostly fun to use, except those that have horrible accuracy/recoil/bullet velocity. missions are mostly fun, except for several which are just stupid nonsense and boring "fetch" quests. characters are mostly on the insane/kooky/wacky side which I guess passes for "comedy" in Borderlands. the airless environments and the need to find air to breathe is annoying, so good thing that you can play as a robot. terrains are boring and full of bullshit death-pits where you can easily fall while driving or by foot. enemies will sometimes snipe you from across the map, fly around you and shoot you in the back, instantly moon-walk or roll into cover when you shoot them, all the while having the advantage of spawning all around you, even behind you.
despite lots of small annoyances I'd say it's a fun shooting experience, especially if you use elemental weapons and create interesting synergies with your character build and equipment.

A lot of people say this game is the worst in the franchise, but I honestly think this was one of my favorites. I like this game. There is your review. You're welcome.

The Good:
Borderlands with low gravity means a lot of badass kills that you'll be thinking about for days on.
Nice range of levels and maps
The Bad:
Minor details are not corrected (such as bugs, details in environment, etc) that suggest the game was rushed.
Inconsistent game design to the point of sometimes being annoying
Many side-missions (and some main missions) feel like errands.

Overall:
If you're already sold on the idea of Borderlands loot 'n' shoot, give this one a go because it offers a pretty good and fun borderlands experience (if you look past the details), but if this is your first BL game I would definitely recommend BL2 rather than this.

This was a highly anticipated game for me, considering Borderlands 2 is one of my favorite and most played games ever, so my expectations were sky high.  Unfortunately those expectations were not met.  The game over is a watered down and lesser version of Borderlands 2 in every way.  The game is not bad by any means and I would still recommend it, but it is a far cry from its predecessor in pretty much every aspect.  The story, characters, humor, side quests, guns and even game play feel like C+ versions of Borderlands 2.  It's hard to really pin down one thing they did wrong in this game, it is more like a lot of little things that felt lacking.  The game overall is still fun, and if you are a Borderlands fan you will likely still enjoy this game for the most part.  3/5
