Honestly, as far as general gameplay is concerned it's great. Story-wise, not so much. I feel like there were many moments that gave it true potential, story-wise, but utterly fell short.

Spoiled by BL2 this was probably the least enjoyable of the 3 before BL3. BL1 had shortcomings on the technical side but of course it was much older, this game however, feels like it took the base looter mechanics of BL2 and just smacked on some shit on top of it.

Characters.
One of the main things I loved about BL2 were the characters, specifically Handsome Jack making every character interaction worth listening to. The characters in this installment feel like a cheap attempt at reproducing the previous ones. I did not care for any of them and their dialogue got maybe 1 sharp exhale out of 10 attempts.
In terms of abilities, they are all pretty average. I remember having a hard time selecting one as none of them really grabbed my interest. Reflect damage and throw shield with captain american girl, Mcree uses Dead eye, Claptrap is just RNG nonsense that can sometimes be fun but is mostly annoying, Drone man has, well drones, Jack has drones in the shape of himself and ice girl is pretty frackin powerful.

Gameplay. 

Nothing really changed except the new O2 system which overall is ok. It's existence doesn't add any new mechanics worth writing home about but it's not a horrendous change at all. At worst its an inconvenience to manage the new resource and at best it occasionally finds a use in combat. So all things considered, the main gameplay is still great but has not been improved.

The weapons in this game are about at the same destructive level with BL2. They aren't any memorable additions I can think of off the top of my head. It's not worse than BL2 but I wouldn't call it an upgrade either. This area is fine all things considered.

The maps in this game, oh god the maps. They are all very bland and can be confusing with multi floors. I remember having to backtrack a lot as well.

So in summary, the best analogy I can make is they took the meat of BL2 and cooked it without seasoning. It feels very bland and uninspired but the gameplay portion is just like BL2 for the most part. I would not recommend this game on its own or its dlc. You will get more enjoyment out of other installments in the series but if you want more Borderlands, this will give you more borderlands.

7/10. Avoid at full price.

If you liked Borderlands 2, you'll most likely enjoy The Pre-Sequel. Its built off the same engine as Borderlands 2 but introduces a new mechanic.  The OZkit which allows you to double jump and breathe in areas with no Ozone/Oxygen.  With the addition of low gravity, the double jump mechanic is not only fun, but necessary to accomplish certain maps to progress through the story.  It's the smallest installment of the borderlands franchise but does not disappoint with story and the DLC Claptastic Voyage.  Arguably the most enjoyable DLC to date.  If you're a fan of Borderlands 1 and 2.  Then you'll enjoy this addition to the Borderlands Universe.

Game has glaring flaws and sometimes, straight-up poor game design choices. Opening a box to loot ammo/money, "cool," but there's a high chance that it will just get YEET out into the abyss or directly upwards, forcing you to scramble to pick up something as menial as ammo or money.
Melee enemies have had their annoyance cranked up to 11, constantly leaping toward you (which is more akin to teleporting as they will phase right through terrain and obstacles) and spamming a ridiculous ground slam that will knock you away.
All enemies have a melee attack as expected, but this attack has quite the knockback on it, rendering melee builds that much more tedious, and only made worse if you're in a low-gravity environment which knocks you further and with a slower fall.
The damage enemies dish out is overall quite high, especially noted with enemies that wield laser weapons, with exceedingly good aim, considerable damage considering how often they land their shots, and a penchant for hitting you even from behind cover.
Badass enemies, and even just regular enemies with rocket launchers are absurdly dangerous, travel time on rockets is borderline hit-scan at times, there is no indicator or warning, simply an explosion and, best case scenario, the single rocket (which is usually rapid-fire, by the way) has chewed through your entire shield, and about 70% of your health, and if you're lucky, it's not an elemental DoT that will surely finish you off.
Is the game fun, sure, of course, it can be, it's borderlands, after all, but is it bogged down by design choices that encompass the entire game? Absolutely.

Hard to recommend this borderlands. Maybe for those that absolutely must have more borderlands even after repeatedly, completely playing through the previous instalments and all add-ons but this one just didn't seem to measure up.

It's mostly more of the same but not as good really with low gravity making controls more 'floaty' than ever, convoluted story framing going back n forth and the comedy seems to have almost fully devolved into silly accents. 
Plus it was noticeably buggy. Crashing occasionally the worst of it but regularly I had to exit out of the game and reenter for objectives to properly spawn/activate and a silly amount of npcs and enemies, stuck in animation loops, pinned to a spot in the air.

It's a whole new dynamic which doesn't make the game boring. It's technically the same as before, but they added new twists to everything that give it an extra challenge so it doesn't feel like before, such as the gravity and freezing. But it still has that same feel which makes the game continuously fun.

!Since The Pre-Sequel is actually released after Borderlands 2, I will choose BL2 as standard. I assume that you can tell what the Borderlands is about.
[b][h1]â–º The game in a nutshell â—„[/h1][/b]
The Pre-Sequel is surprisingly better than BL2. I was expecting less tbh. The appearance is slightly better. The Story is very good. The loot and gameplay is a bit better. I played the game to the end but I did not play more than I had to to beat the boss. I did not play more than 2 characters. I don't think I will play the game again because I don't see the point why I should. It's a mediocre game with enough content.

I strongly recommend to get this game if you enjoyed BL2.

[h1]â–· Appearance â—[/h1]
The setting is all about space, spaceships, rocks, ice and a fancy space station. And the developers did their job. All levels are well designed and have alot of detail. The characters look less weird in comparison to BL2. Sadly alot of weapons are still cancer for the eye like it was in BL2. The main improvement here is the general level design. But man the weapons still suck...

[h1]â–· Story â—[/h1]
Borderlands 1 has a slightly confusing but still motivating storyline. Borderlands 2 has a clearly better story but you miss some information about the circumstances. Well The Pre-Sequel explains most of it. While the story itself is told in an excellent way, the characters improved also.

[h1]â–· Gameplay â—[/h1]
The gameplay improved somehow. I found some weapons which were really awesome and fun to play throughout the game. In BL2 you constantly switch weapons because the old ones suck really fast while advancing in your level. The skilltrees are okay I think. The action skills are more innovative compared to BL2s'. I still miss the overall usefulness of all weapon types like it was in Borderlands 1. Go with a shotgun for CQB, get a Rocket Launcher for ugly situations and get a sniper for clearing the rest. Forget Assault rifles, SMGs, Pistols, Revolvers and so on. They are crap and completely useless in comparison (god I miss BL1 gameplay). Anyway the gameplay improved "a bit".
bl2 is better but its not half bad

6 / 10. A very long drag.

Every now and then you may stumble upon an RPG which offers very unlikable characters. You can't relate to any of the offered choices, but you want to play the game regardless. Well, for me, Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel was one of those experiences. A long, dull and dragged experience.

I honestly believe that The Pre-Sequel is nowhere as good or polished as it's precursors. It's just a way to milk some more money by compiling a list of different ideas.

What bothers me the most at this particular Borderlands game is the lack of balancing and the weapons. I feel that most of the legendaries are put there for show, without much purpose. Unique, blue items are generally better, but fall-off quickly because they don't scale in level. Every 3 or 4 levels you need to redo your arsenal and that just takes too much time. Save scumming is needed to get better gear, otherwise you could just use whatever you find along the story line, but you'll generally find yourself underpowered.

The enemies are harder and more unforgiving. You have health skills to compensate, but the whole game is centered around playing co-op. Some characters even have whole sections of their skill tree dedicated to co-op and that's just weird. Sure, put some co-op skills, but don't lock a whole tree just for that...

Overall I didn't get too much kick out of this installment. I felt that the Claptastic Voyage was a hole lot better than the base game, but even that DLC, felt full of cliches and somewhat bland.

I still recommend this game to Borderlands fans. Maybe you'll like the characters and have a better experience than I had.
